abstract: The Eighth Regiment Massachusetts Volunteers, another of the regiments whose three months' term of service has expired, arrived from Baltimore at 12 o'clock Tuesday night, and there being no arrangements for their reception, owing to the uncertainty of the regimental movements, they bivouacked in the depot at Jersey City. At 7 o'clock they crossed to this City, and at the Park were met by the Seventh Regiment, five hundred strong, who had paraded...
lead_paragraph: The Eighth Regiment Massachusetts Volunteers, another of the regiments whose three months' term of service has expired, arrived from Baltimore at 12 o'clock Tuesday night, and there being no arrangements for their reception, owing to the uncertainty of the regimental movements, they bivouacked in the depot at Jersey City. At 7 o'clock they crossed to this City, and at the Park were met by the Seventh Regiment, five hundred strong, who had paraded under the Colonel's orders to receive and escort them. It will be remembered that the Seventh Regiment followed the Eighth Massachusetts to Washington, overtaking them near Annapolis, where the steamer Boston, on which they were embarked, grounded. At Annapolis, the Seventh divided with them their rations; they labored together in repairing the bridges which had been destroyed, relaying the tracks on the railroad, and putting the engines in running order, the Eighth furnishing the ready mechanics for this important and timely service. The Seventh preceeded them in their arrival at the Capital one day, and they were both quartered in the Capital. From these circumstances, a feeling of friendship sprung up between them, which will be of lasting duration. A detachment of Col. COCHRAN's Chasseurs joined the escort, and made a very creditable appearance. At the Astor House refreshments were furnished to the officers, and Mr. BAKER provided a prompt and comfortable breakfast for the men in the Park Barracks. The regiment then re-formed, the Seventh taking the right of the line. Between Chambers and Leonard streets the escort drew up at present arms while the Eighth passed by, and, further on, the Eighth halted and the escort again passed in review, the guests saluting their old friends in military style. A number of citizens of Massachusetts joined the column.

abstract: The letter of  JEFF. DAVIS to President LINCOLN, in regard to prisoners of war, raises a question of a good deal of delicacy, but of still more importance, and which will very speedily demand a decisive answer. He states that if the privateers of the Savannah, now in custody in this City,...
lead_paragraph: The letter of JEFF. DAVIS to President LINCOLN, in regard to prisoners of war, raises a question of a good deal of delicacy, but of still more importance, and which will very speedily demand a decisive answer. He states that if the privateers of the Savannah, now in custody in this City, are executed or imprisoned as pirates, he will retaliate on our prisoners who may be in his hands. If, on the other hand, they are treated as prisoners of war, he is ready to regard and exchange them as such.

abstract: This new regiment has already gone into camp at Silver Lake, Staten Island, where the men recruited are daily undergoing the routine of camp life, and a uniform system of drill and discipline. Full authority from the War Department has been received by Col. MACDONALD to put the regiment into an effective condition in regard to clothing, arms, and equipments, as fast as they are mustered into service. The uniforms are ready for the whole regiment. The officers are gentlemen of education. Most of them have seen service, and their standard of excellence and proficiency in soldierly qualities is consequently high. They are especially careful in the selection of their subalterns and non-commissioned, officers, and it would be well for competent men of the three months' volunteers, who have just returned, who desire to reenter the service, to present their claims for positions in this regiment without delay. Skill in the use of arms is a quality which the recruiting officers are looking to with much care in the acceptance of recruits; expert shots would be gladly accepted in the regiment.

abstract: This battery, under command of Maj. ASA M. COOK, arrived at Pier No. 1, North River, at about 10 o'clock last night. It numbers one hundred and twenty men, and has been stationed at Baltimore during the last six weeks. From Philadelphia the men came by the Camden and Amboy route. Owing to no accommodation being provided for them, the men will sleep on board the steamship transport. This morning they will march to the Park Barracks, and partake of breakfast, after which they will start for home.

abstract: MOVEMENTS OF PRINCE NAPOLEON. Prince NAPOLEON occupied the day yesterday in social converse with a number of our citizens, in viewing more of the sights of the Metropolis and vicinity, took dinner at the New-York Hotel, and left for Washington, under the guidance of FREDERICK SEWARD, Esq., at 6 P.M. During his stay he has visited the Central Park, the public libraries, the military camps in the vicinity,...
lead_paragraph: MOVEMENTS OF PRINCE NAPOLEON. -- Prince NAPOLEON occupied the day yesterday in social converse with a number of our citizens, in viewing more of the sights of the Metropolis and vicinity, took dinner at the New-York Hotel, and left for Washington, under the guidance of FREDERICK SEWARD, Esq., at 6 P.M. During his stay he has visited the Central Park, the public libraries, the military camps in the vicinity, the palatial dwellings of some of our millionaires, and "done the Institutions." Steadily refusing any popular ovation, and preserving his incog. with the tact of a detective, he has at the same time been the recipient of much attention from those doubtless worthy of his society. So punctilious was his avoidance of ceremony that he declined to receive even the French Consulate in uniform. He has expressed himself delighted with our bay and harbor, and during the last few sultry nights has had the good sense to take his siesta on board his yacht. During the Prince's absence the yacht will remain in the harbor and be put in thorough trim for the return. The Prince was accompanied to Washington by five or six gentlemen of his suite, and the French Consul. Though he will pay President LINCOLN a visit, he will be the guest of the French Minister during his stay in the Capital. He will return to this City via the West and the Falls, after an absence of three weeks.

abstract: The Washington correspondent of the TIMES, in his dispatches of Tuesday, indulged in some criticisms upon the courage and conduct of Lieut.-Col. MARTIN, of the Seventy-first Regiment, as evinced by his behavior in the battle of July 21. For the justice of his remarks we were directed to appeal to the rank and file of the gallant regiment itself. This appeal we have fortunately been permitted to make. The Editor of the TIMES was yesterday waited upon by members of the corps, numbering, he should judge, one-half the entire muster-roll, while from the remainder he received written communications, -- all [???] in the highest laudation of their commander, not only for his unflinching gallantry throughout the fight, but for his admirable qualities as a drill-master, and his kind, attentive supervision of the welfare of his men. This testimony is unquestionable. We can only regret that our correspondent has been led into unconscious error. He has sent us the authority on which his statements were based; but in spite of its respectability it is overborne.

abstract: "The constitutional rights on the South" is still the theme of Mr. BURNETT, in the House of Representatives. Were the "South" even professing to be in the Union this would be all very appropriate, if their rights were in danger of invasion. But the arms in their hands, in open revolt against the Government, with the avowed purpose of destroying the Constitution itself the folly of talking about their rights under it is transparent. When the Southern States shall return, or be brought back to their allegiance, their rights will be as carefully guaranteed and respected as these of the loyal States, but until then we know of no constitutional right which such men as JEFF. DAVIS and his followers can claim, save that which guarantees to them a gallows and a halter, and with their claim to these no loyal man that we know or have ever heard of proposes to interfere.

abstract: The celebrated Sixth Regiment, of Massachusetts, whose passsage through, Baltimore toward the seat of Government on the memorable 10th of April was contested by the secession mob, killing and wounding several of their number, arrived here yesterday, from Annapolis and Baltimore en route for Massachusetts, their three months' term of enlistment having expired on the 20th of July. They have been stationed most of the time at the Relay House, where their duties have been very onerous in watching and holding in check the uneasy spirits of Maryland. Notwithstanding the heavy duties which have been required of them, the admirable location of their camp and the careful sanitary management of its officer, the regiment bring home nearly the entire number that originally made up the rolls. Five or six are on the sick list with the returning regiment, and two were left in Baltimore. They were detained in the, cars at Baltimore from S.A.M. to 7 R.M. on Tuesday, on account of the accident to the train between, Baltimore and Havre de Grace. In Philadelphia the Citizens' Committee gave them a good dinner, and they arrived via the Amboy route at 4 o'clock P.M. A large deputation of citizens greeted them on arrival, and escorted them up Broadway to the park, where the regiment were provided a comfortable meal at the Barracks. They then formed, and marched to the foot of Veatry-street, N.R., where they took the steamer Connecticut, via the Norwich and Worcester route to Boston. They all appeared in excellent condition, and have evidently gained much in soldierly bearing during their active services in the field. They express a general determination to reenlist for the war. The same is true of the Eighth Regiment. The chief officers are as follows:

They have been stationed most of the time at the Relay House, where their duties have been very onerous in watching and holding in check the uneasy spirits of Maryland. Notwithstanding the heavy duties which have been required of them, the admirable location of their camp and the careful sanitary management of its officer, the regiment bring home nearly the entire number that originally made up the rolls. Five or six are on the sick list with the returning regiment, and two were left in Baltimore. They were detained in the, cars at Baltimore from S.A.M. to 7 R.M. on Tuesday, on account of the accident to the train between, Baltimore and Havre de Grace. In Philadelphia the Citizens' Committee gave them a good dinner, and they arrived via the Amboy route at 4 o'clock P.M. A large deputation of citizens greeted them on arrival, and escorted them up Broadway to the park, where the regiment were provided a comfortable meal at the Barracks. They then formed, and marched to the foot of Veatry-street, N.R., where they took the steamer Connecticut, via the Norwich and Worcester route to Boston. They all appeared in excellent condition, and have evidently gained much in soldierly bearing during their active services in the field. They express a general determination to reenlist for the war. The same is true of the Eighth Regiment. The chief officers are as follows:

abstract: This battalion, which numbers two hundred and seventy-five men, arrived in this City last night en route for home. It is commanded by Capt. SPRAGUE. On Monday morning, the battalion left Fort McHenry, and it came to this City via the Camden and Amboy Line. The men slept on board the steamer transport, and will proceed to the barracks in the Park this morning, and partake of breakfast. In the afternoon, the battalion will proceed, if transportation can be furnished, to Massachusetts. Major DEVINS, who went away in command of this battalion, has not returned with it having been elected, in Washington, Colonel of the Fifteenth Massachusetts Regiment.

abstract: THE RETURNED TROOPS. -- The Thirteenth and Twenty-eighth Regiments were to be seen about the City yesterday, receiving the congratulations of their friends, and apparently enjoying themselves to their fullest extent. They are all in good health, but are considerably sun-burnt. There was no unusual excitement, nor any disturbance in the streets, notwithstanding the large number of soldiers present. Both regiments will be mustered out of service the present week, probably on Saturday. The men very generally express a determination to return to the seat of war, and there is some talk of reorganizing the Thirteenth. If this is not done, some 200 of the men of that regiment will join the Continentals, Col. J.H. PERRY.

abstract: The Southern papers contain the Proclamations of the Governors of several seceded States, calling for additional levies of troops. In Mississippi eight regiments are called for, to be fully organized and encamped by Aug. 15. A requisition has been made upon South Carolina for two thousand more troops. Alabam is called upon for three thousand additional volunteers. Regiments are still moving Northward, among others one from Georgia and the Sumter Flying Artillery.

abstract: One of the most conclusive indications of the vigor and effectiveness with which Gen. McCLELLAN intends to perform the duties of his new De  partment will be found in the General Order, just issued by him, and which we publish this morning. He positively forbids the practice which has heretofore prevailed among both officers and  then, of frequenting the streets and hotels of Washington.
lead_paragraph: One of the most conclusive indications of the vigor and effectiveness with which Gen. MCCLELLAN intends to perform the duties of his new Department will be found in the General Order, just issued by him, and which we publish this morning. He positively forbids the practice which has heretofore prevailed among both officers and then, of frequenting the streets and hotels of Washington. He denounces this practice as eminently prejudicial to good order and military discipline -- contending very properly that the time and services of all persons belonging to the Army should be devoted to their appropriate duties with their respective commands. He therefore insists that hereafter no officer or private shall absent himself without a special permit from a commander of brigade. The good effects of this order will be very soon observed in the superior discipline of Gen. MCCLELLAN's command.

abstract: We have been listening so long to our own wailings over our disaster at Bull Run, that it may be consoling to listen to what the other side have to say about it. It is natural that the vanquished should mourn, but let us see in what style, and with how much heart, the victors exult. We are beginning to receive the comments of the Southern Press upon it,...
lead_paragraph: We have been listening so long to our own wailings over our disaster at Bull Run, that it may be consoling to listen to what the other side have to say about it. It is natural that the vanquished should mourn, -- but let us see in what style, and with how much heart, the victors exult. We are beginning to receive the comments of the Southern Press upon it, -- not their first exultations on the very eve of the victory, but their more careful and considerate rejoicings, after they had have time to measure the precise extent of their achievement.

abstract: This new regiment has already gone into camp at Silver Lake, Staten Island, where the men recruited are daily undergoing the routine of camp life, and a uniform system of drill and discipline. Full authority from the War Department has been received by Col. MACDONALD to put the regiment into an effective condition in regard to clothing, arms, and equipments, as fast as they are mustered into service.
lead_paragraph: This new regiment has already gone into camp at Silver Lake, Staten Island, where the men recruited are daily undergoing the routine of camp life, and a uniform system of drill and discipline. Full authority from the War Department has been received by Col. MACDONALD to put the regiment into an effective condition in regard to clothing, arms, and equipments, as fast as they are mustered into service. The uniforms are ready for the whole regiment. The officers are gentlemen of education. Most of them have seen service, and their standard of excellence and proficiency in soldierly qualities is consequently high. They are especially careful in the selection of their subalterns and non-commissioned officers, and it would be well for competent men of the three months' volunteers, who have just returned, who desire to reenter the service, to present their claims for positions in this regiment without delay. Skill in the use of arms is a quality which the recruiting officers are looking to with much care in the acceptance of recruits; expert shots would be gladly accepted in the regiment.

abstract: The celebrated Sixth Regiment, of Massachusetts, whose passage through Baltimore toward the sent of Government on the memorable 19th of April was contested by the secession mob, killing and wounding several of their number, arrived here yesterday, from Annapolis and Baltimore en route for Massachusetts, their three months' term of enlistment having expired on the 20th of July. They have been stationed most of the time at the Relay House, where their duties have been very onerous in watching and holding in check the uneasy spirits of Maryland. Notwithstanding the heavy duties which have been required of them, the admirable location of their camp and the careful sanitary management of its officers, the regiment brings home nearly the entire number that originally made up the rolls. Five or six are on the sick list with the returning regiment, and two were left in Baltimore. They were detained in the cars at Baltimore from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M. on Tuesday, on account of the accident to the train between Baltimore and Havre de Grace. In Philadelphia the Citizens' Committee gave them a good dinner, and they arrived via the Amboy route at 4 o'clock P.M. A large deputation of citizens greeted them on arrival, and escorted them up Broadway to the Park, where the regiment were provided a comfortable meal at the Barracks. They then formed, and marched to the foot of Vestry-street, N.R., where they took the steamer Connecticut, via the Norwich and Worcester route to Boston. They all appeared in excellent condition, and have evidently gained much in soldierly bearing during their active services in the field. They express a general determination to reenlist for the war. The same is true of the Eighth Regiment. The chief officers are as follows:

abstract: The loyal people of Missouri have taken the State Government into their own hands. They refuse any longer to have their power wielded for their destruction. They have deposed the wretched traitor who has been waging war upon them, and doing his best to ruin the State which had made him its Governor. Gov. JACKSON is now simply a rebel in arms against his own State, and the people of that State will take good care that justice is done him.

abstract: Nearly a month ago Gen. BUTLER took an advanced position beyond the village of Hampton, and threw up strong intrenchments. The post was a strong one and the force occupying it had only, in case of being severely pressed, to fall back across the river and avail itself of a very strong earthwork on the other side, built expressly to command the bridge. It seems, however, that a few nights since, an alarm was raised that the enemy was only two miles off, whereupon the intrenchments in advance were abandoned, the village was set on fire, and the whole force retreated in confusion across the bridge. The next morning no enemy was to be seen or heard of.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a month ago Gen. BUTLER took an advanced position beyond the village of Hampton, and threw up strong intrenchments. abstract: We trust that new  commanders for our armies will not be appointed solely on the recommendation of politicians, whether they be Congressmen or not. It is very well for the President to solicit their suggestions, but we hope he will not fetter himself in the slightest degree, in making his selections.
lead_paragraph: We trust that new commanders for our armies will not be appointed solely on the recommendation of politicians, whether they be Congressmen or not. It is very well for the President to solicit their suggestions, but we hope he will not fetter himself in the slightest degree, in making his selections. While we do not suppose that a Congressman would, any more readily than any other citizen, deliberately place an incompetent officer at the head of men on the battlefield, we cannot help seeing that men in such positions are exposed to influences which warp their judgments and influence their action. They will inevitably give weight to political, social and personal considerations, which should have nothing whatever to do with the designation of officers for military commands. The list recommended for Brigadier-Generals by the delegation from this State, while, as a whole, it is reasonably good, still embraces many names of men whom we should be very sorry to see placed in any such position. Let it be understood that all favoritism, -- all political, preferences, -- everything must give way before the supreme necessity of the country. We want men qualified to lead armies in the post of commanders. If they have this fitness, it matters little what else they lack. If they have it not, it matters little what else they have.

abstract: The Sanitary Commission, through its Secretary, Mr. OLMSTED, has made its first Report; and a very direct, explicit document it is, even if not vert encouraging. The Commission wastes no words on generalties or medical and philosophical theories, but go straight to the practical matters of food and drink, night soil and drainage, clothing and cleanliness, and the other very plain conditions of a soldier's health.

abstract: This battery, under command of Maj. ASA M. COOK, arrived at Pier No. 1, North River, at about 10 o'clock last night. It numbers one hundred and twenty men, and has been stationed at Baltimore during the last six weeks. From Philadelphia the men came by the Camden and Amboy route. Owing to no accommodation being provided for them, the men will sleep on board the steamship transport. This morning they will march to the Park Barracks, and partake of breakfast, after which they will start for home.

abstract: We incline decidedly to the opinion that the whole business of enlisting volunteers should be left to the General Government, and conducted upon the same rules as govern recruiting for the regular Army. But in the absence of such a better system, we must accord entire approval to the general order in which Gov. MORGAN regulates the levy of twenty-five new regiments. The provision requiring an examination of candidates for command is especially deserving of approbation. A certain degree of military preparation is to be demanded of every one who aspires to the leadership of companies and regiments; and if the same requirement be extended to the superior officers of the brigade, we shall secure an entirely novel efficiency in our armies. It is, of course, of great importance that the examiners be men of acknowledged skill and experience. It is even more important that they be above suspicion of party bias or personal partiality. These conditions observed, we see no reason to apprehend any but the happiest results from the amended policy.

abstract: We learn, authoritatively, says the Memphis Avalanche, that all the Arkansas State troops not now with BEN. MCCULLOGH, and not including the ten new regiments now in course of organization, have been turned over by the Military Board to Brig.-Gen. HARDEE. The ten new regiments, when fully organized, which will be in a week or ten days, are also to be turned over whenever wanted. Arkansas has nobly done her duty. With the ten regiments soon to be in the field, she will have nearly 25,000 men in active service.

abstract: "We have reason to believe that four more regiments will be accepted from Iowa, or that the requisition for them will soon be made. Over two hundred and fifty companies have been offered to the Adjutant-General, who has their muster-rolls -- these being exclusive of the cavalry companies. We have now seven regiments formed, taking seventy of these companies. Some of those offered are intended for Home Guards, and some are perhaps not full -- but there is, of course, more than an abundance to make up these additional regiments. There are thousands of men in Iowa eager to enter this conflict in defence of their Government under the old Stars and Stripes. They will have the opportunity. Our harvesting will soon be over, and thousands now in the fields will transfer themselves to fields of another kind."

abstract: Prince NAPOLEON occupied the day yesterday in social converse with a number of our citizens, in viewing more of the sights of the Metropolis and vicinity, took dinner at the New-York Hotel, and left for Washington, under the guidance of FREDERICK SEWARD, Esq., at 6 P.M. During his stay he has visited the Central Park, the public libraries, the military camps in the vicinity, the palatial dwellings of some our millionaires, and "done the Institutions." Steadily refusing any popular ovation, and preserving his incog. with the tact of a detective, he has at the same time been the recipient of much attention from those doubtless worthy of his society. So punctilious was his avoidance of ceremony that he declined to receive even the French Consulate in uniform. He has expressed himself delighted with our bay and harbor, and during the last few sultry nights has had the good sense to take his siesta on board his yacht. During the Prince's absence the yacht will remain the harbor and be put in thorough trim for the return. The Prince was accompanied to Washington by five or six gentlemen of his suite, and the French Consul. Though he will pay President LINCOLN a visit, he will be the guest of the French Minister during his stay in the Capital. He will return to this City via the West and the Falls, after an absence of three weeks.

abstract: The Eighth Regiment Massachusetts Volunteers,another of the regiments whose three months' termof service has expired, arrived from Baltimore at 12 o'clock Tuesday night, and there being no arrangements for their reception, owing to the uncertainty of the regimental movements, they bivouacked in the depot at Jersey City. At 7 o'clock they crossed to this City, and at the Park were met by the Seventh Regiment, five hundred strong, who had paraded under the Colonel's orders to receive and escort them. It will be remembered that the Seventh Regiment followed the Eighth Massachusetts to Washington, overtaking them near Annapolis, where the steamer Boston, on which they were embarked, grounded. At Annapolis, the Seventh divided with them their rations; they labored together in repairing the bridges which had been destroyed, relaying the tracks on the railroad, and putting the engines in running order, the Eighth furnishing the ready mechanics for this important and timely service. The Seventh preceeded them in their arrival at the Capital one day, and they were both quartered in the Capital. From these circumstances, a feeling of friendship sprung up between them, which will be of lasting duration. A detachment of Col. COCHRAN's Chasseurs joined the escort, and made a very creditable appearance. At the Astor House refreshments were furnished to the officers, and Mr. BAKER provided a prompt and comfortable breakfast for the men in the Park Barracks. The regiment then re-formed, the Seventh taking the right of the line. Between Chambers and Leonard streets the escort drew up at present arms while the Eighth passed by, and, further on, the Eighth halted and the escort again passed in review, the guests saluting their old friends in military style. A number of citizens of Massachusetts joined the column.

Between Chambers and Leonard streets the escort drew up at present arms while the Eighth passed by, and, further on, the Eighth halted and the escort again passed in review, the guests saluting their old friends in military style. A number of citizens of Massachusetts joined the column.

abstract: In the Matter of Purcell McQuillan. -- This matter, which had been adjourned till this morning from amendment of the return, was called up at the opening of the Court by Mr. Edwards, the counsel for the applicant. The officer who had attended on the return day before yesterday, handed the writ to Mr. Edward's, who at first said that no further return had been made, but on a closer examination it appeared that in the return "I beg leave to decline to obey this writ at present," had been inscribed the words "By order of Lieut.-Gen. Scott." Mr. Edwards objected that a new return should have been made as of to-day, and that the authority should have been set forth in the return, and said he should controvert the sufficiency of the return, both as to date and as to substance. The Court said that if objection was made, it would not determine upon the sufficiency of the order till the order was before it. And Mr. Edwards said he should like an order of attachment for not making a return. Mr. Woodford, who was present, inquired if he intended to deny that that indorsement was the return of the commanding officer at Fort Lafayette. Mr. Edwards said no, he had not intimated such a thing, and that he would ask that a further return be made; that the authority referred to should be produced as a part of the return, and that it should be an entirely new return, so that it might appear that up to the date of the return the officer held the prisoner in his custody, and that an attachment should be issued in consequence of the return now made.

abstract: The Richmond Enquirer, of July 24, says: "In pursuance of a call made by His Honor the Mayor, a meeting of our citizens was held, yesterday evening, at 4 o'clock, to consider the best means of providing for the soldiers wounded at the late battle of Manassas. In consequence of the storm that prevailed, the meeting was not so largely attended as it would otherwise have been; but the spirit manifested was such as we have never before witnessed on any occasion. The object of the meeting having been explained by his Honor, resolutions were unanimously adopted, appointing a Committee to proceed to Manassas, and bring down such of the wounded as can leave, and another Committee to provide suitable places for them here, either in private families or in such hospitable as may be prepared for them. The meeting that adjourned.

abstract: This battalion, which numbers two hundred and seventy-five men, arrived in this City last night en route for home. It is commanded by Capt. SPRAGUE. On Monday morning, the battalion left Fort McHenry and it came to this City via the Camden and Amboy Line. The men slept on board the steamer transport, and will proceed to the barracks in the Park this morning, and partake of breakfast. In the afternoon, the battalion will proceed, if transportation can be furnished, to Massachusetts. Major DEVINS, who went away in command of this battalion, has not returned with it, having been elected, in Washington, Colonel of the Fifteenth Massachusetts Regiment.

abstract: It seems to be settled that the Cabinet is to remain undisturbed. The President is not inclined to change any of its members, but is determined that they shall, one and all, lend their best energies to the prosecution of the war. They shall have our most zealous support in everything they may do towards this great object. We do not in the least share the apprehensions expressed in some quarters, that it would be a dangerous movement to change a Cabinet, on the heels of a disaster. It would be no more dangerous than to dismiss a Colonel for cowardice, or to supersede a General for incompetency. When an unfit man is found in place, the most dangerous thing that can be done is to leave him there. The safest thing is to put a better man in his place. The rule applies to Cabinet officers as fully and as truly as to commanders in the field.

abstract: The Twelfth Regiment N.Y.S.M., Col. BUTTERFIELD, arrived by the Camden and Amboy route at 7 o'clock last evening. This regiment was one of the first to march to the defence of the Capital, and has been one of the hardest worked and most active of the three months regiments in service. It has been stationed at Washington, Arlington Heights, Georgetown, Martinsburgh and Harper's Ferry, and they were marched into Virginia, occupying Charlestown, Bunker Hill, and other points, in conjunction with PATTERSON's Division. They have borne the toils and hardships of camp-life like true soldiers, and it was generally remarked that they were greatly improved in appearance as compared with their condition and discipline when they embarked on the Baltic three months since.

abstract: -- Everything indicates that the Government is thoroughly in earnest in its determination to give our troops tried and experienced officers. Preference will always be given in appointments to men who have seen service, and the more scars they can show the better is their chance of high command. Under this stimulus we may look for the appearance of an entirely new set of men at the head of our armies. Even our amiable old friend of the Herald has been roused into unwonted activity, and is busily engaged in raising a Plum Gut Brigade, which he proposes to command in person. If there is a short cut out of danger, he is just the man to find it, -- while the bare sight of his scars will infuse infinite ardor into the souls of those of his heroes who can get into his rear, where alone they will be visible. We understand that Brig.-Gen. BENNETT has already applied to Gen. WEBB JOHN GRAHAM, J.W. HALE and others, for certificates of wounds recived in service, and that he has a chart of Plum Gut engraved on vellum and superbly mounted. The Secretary of War will please make out his commission.

abstract: On Monday evening, JAMES BURTON, a lad residing with his mother at No. 48 Greenwich-street, was drowned while bathing at the Battery. The body was not recovered at the time, but yesterday a successful effort was made to bring it to the surface by firing cannon near the spot where it sank. An inquest will be held in the case to-day . . . . The body of another lad was also yesterday recovered in the North River, near the foot of Thirty-fourth-street. The deceased was about 7 years of age, and named JOHN H. MADDEN. He was drowned while bathing a few days since. The remains were taken to the residence of the parents, No. 269 West Thirty-fifth-street, and an inquest will be held to-day.

abstract: The Twentieth Regiment New-York State Militia, Col. G.W. PRATT, arrived in this City, en route for home, yesterday morning. Companies A, G and K came on the steamer Whitney, under command of Major HARDENBERG, bringing the prisoners of war from Baltimore. The remaining six companies arrived via the Camden and Amboy route, and the regiment united at the Park Barracks, where they dined, at 3 P.M. During the three months of their service, the Twentieth have been doing duty entirely in Maryland, guarding the Annapolis and Washington Railroad, the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, the Baltimore Custom-house, and other points of equal importance. Their services have been valuable. They have been well treated, and enjoyed excellent health, and most of the men express a willingness to reenlist under the same Colonel. The men are ruddy and healthy, and well drilled, and will prove a valuable addition to the three years' volunteers. Arrangements were made for the regiment to leave by the 6 o'clock boat for Rondout, and be mustered out of the service on the way. Extensive preparations are being made to give them a splendid reception by the citizens of Ulster County, from among whom they were recruited, after most of them had become exempt on account of seven years' militia [???].

abstract: -- JOHN SMITH, an habitual drunkard, left his lodgings, No. 9 Frankfort-street, on Wednesday evening, while suffering from an attack of mania a potu, and attempted to put an end to his existence by stabbing himself in the abdomen. The wound is a severe one, and SMITH is under treatment at the City Hospital. . . .A young man, living at No. 144 Charles-street, named PAUL SCRIVENER, retired early on Wednesday evening, but arose again at 12 o'clock, and going to the foot of West 10th-street, jumped into the river to drown himself. He was rescued in an exhausted state by a Ninth Precinct Policeman. The cause of the young man's eccentricity is not known.

abstract: -- As many slurs have been cast on the War Department for sending troops to Washington by way of Harrisburgh, it is but fair to this route to say, that it is claimed to have great advantages as a military route. Though considerably longer than the direct route through Philadelphia, yet it may be better for all that, if, as claimed, regiments can be transported, together with the heavy loads of freight essential to their efficiency, without change of any sort, and placed in Washington a very few hours behind the time in which regiments without these impediments can be taken by the other routes. The ferries over the Delaware and Susquehanna Rivers, and the break or gauge at Philadelphia, are defects in the direct route from which the other is free. Our military authorities should look at the merits of the two routes, and select the best, or give to each the business for which it is best adapted. It makes no difference in cost which way the troops go, the charges being the same.

abstract: The Chicago Journal, of July 28, says: More than forty companies have been tendered the Governor for the United States' service, since Tuesday morning last. At least thirty thousand men, besides those in the field, are now organized in this State and anxious to "go to the wars." Egypt is rising en masse. Gentlemen were in Springfield, yesterday, tendering troops, not by companies, but by whole regiments. They report that more than half the men in that region are ready to enlist, and if the other half are required they will be ready.

abstract: Official advices have been received in Washington front Gen. ROSECRANS, which fully confirm the reports previously received, that WISK and his command had precipitately fled from Gauley Bridge eastward, after destroying the bridge to prevent pursuit. One thousand muskets and several kegs of cannon powder were left behind. Gen. ROSECRANS also says that many of the inhabitants of that region who have heretofore ...
lead_paragraph: Official advices have been received in Washington front Gen. ROSECRANS, which fully confirm the reports previously received, that WISE and his command had precipitately fled from Gauley Bridge eastward, after destroying the bridge to prevent pursuit. One thousand muskets and several kegs of cannon powder were left behind. Gen. ROSECRANS also says that many of the inhabitants of that region who have heretofore been strong Secessionists, have been converted to Unionism through the excesses of the rebel troops, who are now entirely cleared out of the Kanawha Valley. And if the latest dispatches which reach us are true -- and we see no good reason to doubt them -- WISE and his whole command are likely to fall into the hands of our forces. This would indeed be a triumph which would go far to efface the memory of Bull Run. He is stated to have retreated from one point to another, pursued continually by our troops, until he is at last in a position where it will be impossible for him to escape.

abstract: It is amazing how much "spoils" the rebels bagged after the fight at Manassas. The Richmond Whig says that "among the items not previously mentioned are 600 tents and 7,000 axes." As all the tents were left behind in camp, and as there were not probably 500 axes in the whole Army, the Whig's story seems slightly improbable.

lead_paragraph: The rebel accounts of the battle of the 21st continue to be exceedingly interesting, -- and we accordingly continue our extracts from them. Some of the Munchausenisms which they embody are excessively ludicrous. One of these rebel raconteurs reports that a certain Pennsylvania regiment was mowed down "by acres" by their artillery. Another writer describes the onset of MCDOWELL's column "54,000 strong," -- and a third speaks in thrilling terms of the narrow escape they had from being outflanked when "PATTERSON's division of 20,000 swept in to the aid of the General in command." As PATTERSON's division came no nearer the field than Harper's Ferry, the deliverance of the rebels was not nearly so miraculous as it seemed.

abstract: It is curious to observe the different light in which the old question out of which of the national pockets the money is to come presents itself to different nations. The English theory is that, apart from class interests, the method of indirect taxation is most convenient for ordinary purposes, and that an Income-tax is peculiarly available, if it should not be absolutely reserved, for such emergencies as war.

abstract: No important movements have yet taken place. An additional force has been sent to guard the ford  at Harper's Ferry. On Tuesday night it was reported that considerable bodies of rebel foragers were within six miles of the Ferry, which gives rise to the suspicion that a much larger body is nearer us than Leesburgh. Some think that Gen. JOHNSTON'S army is on the move northward.
lead_paragraph: SANDY HOOK, Md., Thursday, Aug. 1.

abstract: Gov. GAMBLE and Lieut.-Gov. W.P. HALL were sworn and inaugurated in the Convention in the af  ternoon session to-day. Each made a strong Union and patriotic speech amid loud applause. After the presentation of an address to the people of the State by the Convention, it adjourned to the third Monday in December, unless sooner called together by the new Government, or is demanded by the public safety.

abstract: -- On Wednesday night CORNELIUS A. AMBROSE, a native of this City, 22 years of age, jumped into the water at Pier No. 38 East River, and was drowned. Deceased had been living for some time at No. 1 Bayard-street, but none of his acquaintances knew him intimately, and the motive which prompted him to commit suicide is not known. The body has not been recovered.
lead_paragraph: -- On Wednesday night CORNELIUS A. AMBROSE, a native of this City, 22 years of age, jumped into the water at Pier No. 38 East River, and was drowned. The body has not been recovered.

abstract: From the date of this letter you will perceive that the Brigade of Gen. Cox is steadily advancing up the Valley of the Kanawha. After a delay of eight or ten days at Camp Pocatallico, which seemed inexplicable to those not in the confidence of the General, an order was issued Tuesday evening to prepare two days' rations, and be ready to march at 4 o'clock the following morning.
lead_paragraph: Special Correspondence of the New-York Times.

abstract: A correspondent of the Boston Journal, who has been traveling through Pennsylvania, writes: "A neighbor of Mr. Buchanan was in the cars. He represents that the Ex-President has been long dangerously sick from sheer exhaustion. He has little sympathy from his fellow-townsmen, who upbraid, him as being the author of all our National troubles. He is obliged to hear much that must wound him, and letters by the basket full are sent to him full of abuse and calumny, and so much so that while he was so sick his friends would not allow, him to see any letters unless they knew where they were from. Miss Lane is represented as making herself agreeable to all who call, and keeping open house to all who come to Wheatland, with that same grace that made her so popular at the White House.
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the Boston Journal, who has been traveling through Pennsylvania, writes: "A neighbor of Mr. Buchanan was in the cars. abstract: This Regiment, Col. N.J. JACKSON, which has been stationed at Meridan Hill, near Washington, arrived in this City last evening. On its way through Baltimore it was cheered most lustily, and every ostentation of favor was exhibited. Upon arriving at the foot of Cortlandt-street, the men were marched to the Park Barracks and partook of supper. This morning the Regiment will leave on one of the Fall River boats for home. All of the men seem in the most excellent spirits, and the majority of them expressed their intention of reenlisting for the war. Before the men left Washington the arms, which were Minie rifles and accoutrements were handed over to the Sixth Maine Regiment, which was only armed with the old flint-lock musket, altered to percussion cap.
lead_paragraph: This Regiment, Col. N.J. JACKSON, which has been stationed at Meridan Hill, near Washington, arrived in this City last evening. abstract: -- Early yesterday morning a countryman from Jersey found a new traveling bag on the front steps of No. 86 Barclay-street, which seemed, to be well-filled with clothing. Rejoicing at his good fortune, the Jerseyman trudged on until he reached a secluded place, when he stopped to examine his treasure. His honor may be imagined at the discovery, after the removal of many swathins, of a dead male infant, which probably had been murdered and disposed of thus by its guilty parents. The Coroner will investigate the case.

abstract: Col. EMORY, of the Third (new) Regiment of United States Cavalry, has taken ground to form a camp for his men, adjoining Pittsburgh, Pa., where his head-quarters have been located by the War Department. Five recruiting offices are open for the organization of the regiment, but it proceeds very slowly. The officers are all on hand, of course. A letter from the Colonel to the authorities, asking power to buy horses and begin drill at once, is under consideration. The camp of the Third is in "Linden Grove," near Oakland, and a little outside of Pittsburgh.

abstract: The secession organs in the City tell us of numerous meetings held in various quarters in support of a peace policy. Where they are held, or by whom they are attended, these journals do not inform us. So far as we know anything of them they are secret, -- and are attended only by a very small number of political wire-pullers, who are anxious to make some issue by which their old party organizations can be revived. What degree of success is likely to follow their efforts, they will soon be in a position to ascertain.

abstract: But the most remarkable case of panic is of such recent occurrence that it must be familiar with most intelligent people. At the battle of Solferino, a French corps of fifteen thousand picked troops ran some fifteen miles back to Bresola, because five straggling Austrian huzzars suddenly appeared on the road, their object being to surrender themselves as prisoners to the French. A graphic description of this most disgraceful affair was published at the time, from the pen of H.J. RAYMOND, of the TIMES, who saw the panic.
lead_paragraph: But the most remarkable case of panic is of such recent occurrence that it must be familiar with most intelligent people. abstract: The last number of the Journal des Economiste contains a report of a conversation in the Paris Society of Political Economy on the "Economical Effects of Secession in the United States." Mr. JOHN STUART MILL, one of the most distinguished thinkers and ablest writers of the age, happened to be in Paris and took part in the conversation, which was shared by M. LABOULAYE, author of an excellent book on the United States, ...
lead_paragraph: The last number of the Journal des Economiste contains a report of a conversation in the Paris Society of Political Economy on the "Economical Effects of Secession in the United States." Mr. JOHN STUART MILL, one of the most distinguished thinkers and ablest writers of the age, happened to be in Paris and took part in the conversation, which was shared by M. LABOULAYE, author of an excellent book on the United States, (Historie Politique des Etats Unis,) which is not as well known as it should be; M. GARNIER, M. WOLOWSKI, and other distinguished Economists and Publicists. We translate the conversation, from which the American reader will see both the limitations of the thoughts of even the best foreign observer, on the American question, and at the same time how warmly they sympathize with the cause of the Republic:
headline: {'main': 'FRENCH VIEWS ON SECESSION.; Interesting Discussion in the Paris Society of Political Economy, on the Nature and Prospects of the Secession Movement Views of Mr. John Mill, M. abstract: Companies G, Capt. MOUNT, "Monmouth Guard," of Freehold, and F, "Ocean Guard," of Long Branch, arrived at Freehold by railway at 10 o'clock A.M. on Thursday, and were enthusiastically received at the depot by a large number of citizens and several military companies, among which were the Monmouth Guard and the Union Zouaves, headed by Brig.-Gen. HAIGHT and Colonels PARKER, PATTERSON and BENNET. They were accompanied by the Trenton Cornet Band, and marched from the depot to the business part of the town, where the people were out in force to bid them welcome. Flags were hung across the street from the Court-house and American Hotel, bearing the mottoes "Welcome, noble Sons of Monmouth," and "Welcome, Defenders of the Flag." The companies were marched and countermarched through Main-street, and drawn up in line in the Court-House ward, where they were welcomed by a patriotic speech from AMOS RICHARDSON, Esq., Principal of the Academy, which was responded to by the Band playing "Hail Columbia." Prayer was then offered by Rev. Mr. ROSS, of the Methodist Church. Three cheers were given at the mention of the name of Dr. EDWARD F. TAYLOR, of Middletown, who, though not connected with any of the regiments in the recent fight, went to the field and was taken prisoner, while voluntarily attending to the wounded. After the prayer the companies partook of a bountiful collation spread by the ladles in the Court-house yard. A well-executed drill, according to HARDEE, was then gone through with by the Freehold Company, the Long Branch boys having left their guns at Trenton. The Third Regiment were in Gen. MCDOWELL's Division, and at the time of the battle were advancing as couvoy to the baggage in the reserve.

abstract: This fine corps, which has just returned from the seat of war, under the command of its gallant commandant, Col. HENRY M. BAKER, will be muster out of the service to-day, at the Hudson House in Jersey City, when the men will be paid off. Now that the three months' service has expired, the Second will be again newly organized, to proceed to the scene of action, and the great body of the corps will join the three-years volunteers of the present great Army now assembled at Washington, Virginia, &c. The regiment will be 1,000 strong, and the men are a fine set of able-bodied, athletic young soldiers.

abstract: Recent trials, by order of the Government, of WIARD's steel rifled cannon, served with HOTCHKISS' shot and shell, have resulted in demonstrating the great superiority of both the gun and projectiles. So satisfactory, indeed, were these trials that orders have been given for seven thousand of the shot and shell for the State of Ohio, while Mr. WIARD has received orders for a large number of his rifled cannon -- six to fifty-pounders for the Navy, and six and twelve-pounders for the field service -- also several batteries for the State of Illinois.

abstract: COMMISSIONERS OF CHARITIES AND CORRECTION. -- From the report of the Committee of the Whole, made up for the two weeks ending Aug. 1, it appears that 536 persons have been transferred from the City Prisons to the Workhouse on Blackwell's Island, of which number 178 were males, and 358 females. A leave of absence of one week has been granted to each keeper, with the understanding that but one keeper shall be absent at the same time. Several employes, who joined military companies, have returned to the City, and resumed their positions. In the case of inmates who are in receipt of aid from the fund for families of volunteers, the Warden has been instructed to obtain the amount, and transmit it to the Commissioners to await their decision as to the ultimate disposition of it. The enlargement of the building for lunatics is progressing under the direction of the Warden of the Penitentiary and by the inmates of that institution. At Ward's Island, sixty-eight acres of land are under cultivation. Drs. COAN and SMITH have been appointed Assistant Physicians on Randall's Island during the absence of Drs. CHALMERS and MARSHALL. The receipts for the two weeks amount to $423 33. The weekly statement shows that the number of inmates in the various institutions. July 27, was 8,250; during the week 2,211 were admitted, 50 died, 1,697 were discharged, and 395 were sent to Blackwell's Island.

abstract: -We are con  stantly in the receipt of able and wellwritten articles on the illegality and unconsti tutionality of secession. We must decline publishing them, simply because all
lead_paragraph: -- We are constantly in the receipt of able and well-written articles on the illegality and unconstitutionality of secession. We must decline publishing them, simply because all further argument on that subject is a waste of time and words. The people have made up their minds upon it, and neither need nor wish any additional argument. They see a large and formidable portion of the people waging war on the Government -- bringing every possible energy they can command to bear for its destruction. It needs no reasoning to prove that this is a crime, and must be treated as such. If the rebels had appealed to reason in support of their claims, they would have been met on the same ground. But they have discarded argument and appealed to force, and all that remains is to meet them on their own ground, and with their own weapons.

abstract: DISPOSAL OF THE FAMOUS DIGHTON  Rock At a late meeting of the Royal Society of Northern Antiquaries, of Copenhagen, over which King FREDERICK Ill, of Denmark, presides, a warranty deed from Mr. NIELS AR NZEN, of Fall River..
lead_paragraph: -- At a late meeting of the Royal Society of Northern Antiquaries, of Copenhagen, over which King FREDERICK III, of Denmark, presides, a warranty deed from Mr. NIELS ARINZEN, of Fall River Mass., (apparently a Scandinavian, originally,) was read, by which, "in consideration of his esteem for Prof. C.C. RAFU, editor of the Antiquitates Americana, and for the Royal Society of Antiquaries in Denmark, he does give, grant, and convey unto the said Professor and Royal Society, the rock known as the Writing or 'Dighton' Rock, and the lot or parcel of land surrounding it, situated in Berkley, in said County of Bristol," its limits being stated in detail in the deed.

abstract: Very high expectations are entertained by the people from the accession of Maj-Gen. McCLELLAN to the command of the forces at Washington. He brings energy, experience, a resolute character, and above all, the prestige of brilliant success, to the enlarged field..
lead_paragraph: Very high expectations are entertained by the people from the accession of Maj-Gen. MCCLELLAN to the command of the forces at Washington. He brings energy, experience, a resolute character, and above all, the prestige of brilliant success, to the enlarged field on which he is to act hereafter, -- and these are the qualities which command and deserve the confidence of the public. We share these hopes to the fullest extent, -- and trust that every possible facility which the Government, as well as the people, can afford, will be given him in the discharge of his duties.

abstract: -- A gentleman named BENJAMIN HALLOCK, who has been engaged in buying cattle for the past five years, from the West for New-York City was robbed of $3,500 in the sleeping-car of the Great Western Railway, on Tuesday night. He got on board the train at Suspension Bridge, and immediately procured a berth and turned in. He left the car three or four times during the triip, in order to obtain refreshments, and he is most positive that the money was taken while in the car, for upon leaving London station, and when lying in his berth awake, he had his hand upon his wallet, which he carried in his pantaloons pocket. As the train neared Chatham station he awoke, and, to his alarm, found that his money was gone. Seach was at once instituted, but it proved fruitless. Upon the train's arrival at Windsor yesterday morning the railroad officials were immediately placed in possession of the particulars, but they have not yet succeeded in getting on the track of the guilty parties -- Detroit Free Press. Aus. I.

abstract: The first of August, 1861, will be a memorable day in the fiscal history of the United States. It records the passage through both Houses of Congress, within a few hours, of
lead_paragraph: The first of August, 1861, will be a memorable day in the fiscal history of the United States. It records the passage through both Houses of Congress, within a few hours, of four measures of fundamental importance, each of them well entitled to the most careful and deliberate examination. Such is the hothaste under which they have been passed through Congress, and so imperfect the telegraphic communications, that it is next to impossible to state their provisions with any reasonable approach to accuracy. We learn enough, however, to know that each of them is of vital concern to the country. It has not been thought necessary to afford our moneyed classes, or property-holders, or the public Press of this City, any opportunity whatever of examining any of these measures before their passage. And even now it is difficult to ascertain precisely the contents of the laws actually passed. From the best lights we can obtain, we suppose the general results to be as follows:

abstract: Europe  THE WAR ELEMENT OF THE WORLD Europe has to-day under arms four millions of soldiers! And although the programme that was to have made this a battle Summer has been entirely changed, even in peace it seems..
lead_paragraph: Europe has to-day under arms four millions of soldiers! And although the programme that was to have made this a battle Summer has been entirely changed, even in peace it seems as though the major portion of the social forces were destined to be absorbed in purely destructive purposes. Europe is covered with citadels and armed to the teeth. Every day new engines of destruction are invented. Fleets are multiplied; ships are covered with armor; floating citadels and batteries are built to move on the water. England, for the first time in her history, has girt herself round with fortresses. Germany, the philosophic Germany, Switzerland, the neutral and pacific, are perpetually drilling their citizens in the exercise of arms. As for France, she has, within the last ten years, doubled her war taxes, as England has, during the same period, doubled hers. France borrows untold millions for war; and England does the same. Austria borrows, Russia borrows, Piedmont borrows -- all borrow for war -- even the Turk wants to borrow. Amid all this, suppressed mutterings of pent-up thunder rumble round the horizons of the European nations.

abstract: Since the culminating of the great rebellion in actual war, the Northern mind has been constantly exercised, and the Northern nerves tried by the peculiar mode of warfare adopted by the Southern rebels, and by its unexpected success
lead_paragraph: Since the culminating of the great rebellion in actual war, the Northern mind has been constantly exercised, and the Northern nerves tried by the peculiar mode of warfare adopted by the Southern rebels, and by its unexpected success thus far. Indeed, the very mention of a "masked battery" bids fair to become a bugbear to Northern ears, and the name BEAUREGARD a goblin to frighten children with. But enough has been already revealed in the campaign to show that their success has resulted, paradoxical as it may seem, from the extreme simplicity -- even juvenility -- of their tactics -- as a mere tyro in chess will sometimes, by the very absence of intelligent plot or scientific design, for several moves utterly disconcert a skillful and practical player. His game is simply not "according to HOYLE."

abstract: The Northern part of the State at present presents no serious difficulties. Gen. POPE, by prompt and judicious measures, has insured the protection of the North Missouri and Hannibal and St. Joseph Railroads. There will be constant troubles in many of the
lead_paragraph: The Northern part of the State at present presents no serious difficulties. Gen. POPE, by prompt and judicious measures, has insured the protection of the North Missouri and Hannibal and St. Joseph Railroads. There will be constant troubles in many of the Northern counties, but it is not apprehended that they will amount to anything so serious as to require the operations of any considerable number of troops. The bridges and tracks of the railroads have been placed in the keeping of the leading and property-holding Secessionists, Gen. POPE giving them to understand that he would hold them strictly responsible for their protection, their property and even their lives paying the forfeit if the destruction of hindrance of these important thoroughfares should occur. The wisdom of this proceeding is apparent to every one. Gen. POPE also wisely says it is out of the question to fight those guerrilla parties of rebels with the regular soldiers. The Home Guards and Union men, who are largely in the majority in the country, must protect themselves against them. Whenever the rebels collect in numbers sufficient to justify operations against them by a large body of troops, an expedition will be promptly undertaken. It is the duty of Union men everywhere in the State to organize and fight the rebel scoundrels after their own fashion, and not be overawed in any instance by their blustering or their devilish atrocities.

abstract: The Journal of Commerce seizes upon the present opportunity to propose a settlement of the dispute between the Union and its foes. It demands an armistice of three months, and a Convention of delegates from all the
lead_paragraph: The Journal of Commerce seizes upon the present opportunity to propose a settlement of the dispute between the Union and its foes. It demands an armistice of three months, and a Convention of delegates from all the States, to agree upon some basis, either of preserving the Union or of separating. For the sake of its preservation, it recommends additional guarantees, such as may satisfy the South, that their rights will not be assailed.

abstract: CORONER'S INQUEST IN THE CASE OF MRS. SELLERS. The Coroner's Jury, in the case of Mrs. SELLERS, who was killed on Thursday night by a fireengine, rendered their verdict yesterday afternoon, in accordance with the facts heretofore stated. The jury censure the firemen for their carelessness in this case, and recommend some salutary punishment as an example for the future. Mrs. SELLERS was a highly respected lady and mother of a large family.
lead_paragraph: CORONER's INQUEST IN THE CASE OF MRS. abstract: -- The Baltimore Sun states that MICHAEL ROCHE, builder and contractor of that city, has contracted with a company in Havana to construct no less than eight hundred frame houses, of three classes, varying in size and embellishments to suit the three classes of society found in Havana -- the poor, the middle and the rich. All the houses will be one story in height, with the apartments succeeding each other on the ground floor, and running back to a great depth. The object of the company is to place a dwelling within the reach of every man's means. Parties become subscribers by paying a certain amount monthly, and come into possession of the house and lot in eight years, when payment ceases. The frames are to be fitted together in this country and then shipped to Havana. The value of the contract will be several millions of dollars, and will prove a great blessing to the mechanics of Baltimore.

abstract: We have thus far traced the history of our National Union from the era of its first germination down to the time for the call for the Federal Convention of May, 1787.
lead_paragraph: We have thus far traced the history of our National Union from the era of its first germination down to the time for the call for the Federal Convention of May, 1787. We have seen that during all the intervening years there never was a time when any one of the colonies, or States, if you please, was vested with any independence which did not accrue to it solely in virtue of its being a member of the Union, or which it could have enjoyed without the protection of the General Government. We have seen that the chief aim of the Confederation of 1781, was to perpetuate a Union formed and consolidated before the existence of any distinct State organizations or State Constitutions: and that that Confederation was ratified and confirmed by all of the Colonies or States, before our National Independence was actually achieved, or conceded by Great Britain. And we have thus shown how impossible it was that any one State, in severalty, could be regarded at that time, as possessing any element of sovereignty or independence outside, or independently, of the National capacity of the Union. Yet it must, nevertheless, be conceded, that the Confederation did associate with each State, in severalty, the idea of a sovereignty and independence not otherwise belonging to it, and utterly incompatible with the supreme authority of the General Government. Even so, it must also be conceded that a Convention is fully empowered to reconstruct, revise, alter or amend that Confederation as the original Conventions were to ratify it, was fully competent to revoke any grant or reservation of sovereignty to each State, so far as necessary, and to restore it (at least with the consent of the people of those States) to the General Government. At any rate the members of the Federal Convention so construed their powers, and the result, as we will show, was sanctioned by the people and States of the whole Union. Hence it will appear that whatever of sovereignty, or separate independence, each State may have claimed under the Articles of Confederation, the same was surrendered to the people, and by them vested in the General Government, by the consolidation of the Union under the provisions of the present Constitution.

abstract: The Augusta (Ga.) Chronicte expects very soon to see two parties arrayed in the new Confederacy, struggling for the Presidency next Fall, and the division, it thinks, will be upon the point of admitting other States, "one favoring the admission of other States, which may choose to accept our Constitution, the other clinging to the delusion of a pure slaveocracy." The present Provisional President and Vice-President both "favor the idea of ultimate reorganization," while HOWELL COBB, it is implied, and the ultra Southern Party, are forever opposed to the admission of Free States. Here, then, says the Chronicle, is the programme, as we think. HOWELL COBB for President, upon the basis of no admission of any Free State, and no admission of such Slave-States as willfive the power in the Confederacy to admit Free States by a two-thirds vote. In this wise, as we take it, is a party to be organized in opposition to the preent Administration.

abstract: Bark Golden Era, of Rockland, Capt. THORNEDIKE, from Ichaboe, June 6, and St. Helena, June 19, reports that on July 27, lat. 31° 40', lon. 74° 45', she saw a small schooner run down to a large two topmast schooner, which hove to. She supposed the small schooner to be a privateer, as she was alongside until lost sight of. July 31, Cape Hatteras bearing west by south thirty-five miles she was boarded by an officer from the United States steamer Union, who informed the Captain of the existing blockade, and also that they fell in with, on the 28th, the brig B.F. Martin, of Boston, with a prize crew on board, and chased her on shore, twenty miles north of Cape Hatteras, and burned her.

abstract: RECOLLECTING A COMRADE IN DISTRESS. -- While the Second Regiment, of Hudson County, were quartered at Trenton previous to their departure for the seat of war, HUGHEY MCNICHOL, a member of Company G, Hudson Guards, was accidentally shot through the lung by one of his comrades, and has been an invalid ever since. After receiving their pay on Friday evening, the company took up a contribution, amounting to $103, to be presented to MCNICHOL.
lead_paragraph: RECOLLECTING A COMRADE IN DISTRESS. -- While the Second Regiment, of Hudson County, were quartered at Trenton previous to their departure for the seat of war, HUGHEY MCNICHOL, a member of Company G, Hudson Guards, was accidentally shot through the lung by one of his comrades, and has been an invalid ever since. After receiving their pay on Friday evening, the company took up a contribution, amounting to $103, to be presented to MCNICHOL.

abstract: We are informed on good authority that HUGH MARTIN, Jr., now acting as United States Consul at the port of Matanzas, Cuba, is a strong Secessionist, and that he is using his official position in aid of the Confederate cause. A single fact only need be cited discharge from the service any commissioned volun-in proof. When the steamer Matanzas left the port of that name a few days after the pirate Sumter had taken in her prizes to Cienfuegos. Mr. MARTIN gave to her a letter to the Commander of the Sumter, asking him to allow the Matanzas to proceed on her voyage unmolested, in case he should fall in with her. Mr. MARTIN assured Capt. LEMMES that he was a true Southerner, having been appointed from Baltimore by President BUCHANAN; that he should take great pleasure in affording his vessel any facilities in his power for the successful prosecution of her voyage, and that if he would call off Matanzas Point whenever the Sumter's supply of coal should become short, he would send him two or three lighters. This letter was freely exhibited to those proposing to take passage on the Matanzas by MARTIN, and our informant read it over twice himself.

abstract: Having failed to get within ear-shot of any official personages in his own official capacity, Mr. KING has just assailed the French Minister of Finance in a formidable pamphlet of twenty-six pages, but accompanied by appendixes, and schemes for direct steam communication between Europe and the South, and cotton statistics, and copies of Georgia State laws, and the ordinance of Georgia ratifying the United States Constitution, and the secession ordinance repealing the same, and Gov. BROWN's commission to Mr. KING, and Gov. BROWN's instructions to Mr. KING -- altogether running up the pamphlet to near one hundred pages. It is a luminous and voluminous book, well adapted to cheer and refresh the French Minister of Commerce, in the sultry Summer months, when he naturally seeks light and romantic reading.

abstract: The resignation by Hon. ROBERT TOOMBS of his position as Secretary of State of the so-called Confederate Government has been announced by telegraph, but the reason for this step was not stated. We find in a special dispatch for the Memphis Argus, dated Richmond, July 26, that Mr. TOOMBS has been appointed a Brigadier-General in the Provisional Army of the Confederate States, and that he has given up his place in the Cabinet for active service in the field.

abstract: Among the Confederate prisoners at the Old Capitol guard-house, says the Washington Star, is a young man, named BUCK, a native of Massachusetts, who was engaged in teaching school in Virginia, and who was impressed at the point of the bayonet, and taken from his school-room to join the Confederate Army. His aged father, (some seventy years old,) seeing his son's name in the list of prisoners in the papers, hurried to this city, and on meeting his boy, was so much overcome at seeing him thus situated, that he fell to the floor insensible.
lead_paragraph: Among the Confederate prisoners at the Old Capitol guard-house, says the Washington Star, is a young man, named BUCK, a native of Massachusetts, who was engaged in teaching school in Virginia, and who was impressed at the point of the bayonet, and taken from his school-room to join the Confederate Army. abstract: A new system of stage lightning has just been adopted at the Grand Opera, doing away with the old float or rampe, which had been found so injurious to the eves as well as to the voices of the performers. In the present arrangement the float is placed 30 centimetres (2 1/2 feet) below the boards of the stage, and the emanations from the burners are carried off through two pipes reaching to the top of the roof. The luminous rays collected by a double reflector in the shape of a seashell, are transmitted to the stage through a sloping aperture, covered with a plate of dull glass, which subdues the glare of the gas. By this contrivance all danger of the actresses' dresses catching fire is obviated, and a source of hurtful emanations and disagreeable heat, as inconvenient to the spectators as it is to the actors, is removed. The air, being no longer disturbed by the vibrations caused by the heat, the propagation of the sonorous rays is much more regular, and even the light cast on the stage is stronger and better distributed. M. LISSAJOUX, Professor of Natural Philosophy at the Lycee St. Louis, is the inventor of this system.
lead_paragraph: A new system of stage lightning has just been adopted at the Grand Opera, doing away with the old float or rampe, which had been found so injurious to the eves as well as to the voices of the performers. By this contrivance all danger of the actresses' dresses catching fire is obviated, and a source of hurtful emanations and disagreeable heat, as inconvenient to the spectators as it is to the actors, is removed. The air, being no longer disturbed by the vibrations caused by the heat, the propagation of the sonorous rays is much more regular, and even the light cast on the stage is stronger and better distributed. M. LISSAJOUX, Professor of Natural Philosophy at the Lycee St. Louis, is the inventor of this system.

abstract: Our cotemporary, the Tribune, having long and vehemently urged the forward movement of our troops, and having, with equal vehemence, after their defeat, called for the dismissal of such members of the Cabinet as favored such advance, in a fit of sudden repentance...
lead_paragraph: Our cotemporary, the Tribune, having long and vehemently urged the forward movement of our troops, and having, with equal vehemence, after their defeat, called for the dismissal of such members of the Cabinet as favored such advance, in a fit of sudden repentance, or chagrin, or desire to recover lost favor with the public, takes the black veil, enters the cloister, and forever foreswears all expression of opinion or criticism upon the conduct of our rulers, dooms itself to perpetual silence upon matters with which the public are most concerned, except, perhaps, a covert sneer, and adopts a style which will undoubtedly recover again the good opinion of the Emperor of the French. "All is vanity and vexation of spirit," repeats the newly-seated editor. Henceforth the acts of public men are no longer to be spoken of except with approval, and all that a journalist has to do, is, in Oriental fashion, to regard in silence or obsequiously applaud.

abstract: On the 8th of July, Mrs. EMMA AMELIA SCOTT, the wife of a rich merchant in New-York City, eloped with a Mr. NEWTON ST. JOHN, one of the fast young men that abound in that metropolis. The husband and parents of the lady were almost frantic at her disappearance, and New-York detectives were dispatched in pursuit of the couple. A few days ago one of the officers arrived in this city and called on the Chief of Police. He stated that he had been over almost all of the West where it was probable the parties would go, but finding no traces, should return home. He left, however, the miniatures of the lovers with Chief MCDONOUGH, so that he might recognize and arrest them should they come to this city. Saturday the Chief received information that led him to suspect that the couple were among the passengers on the steamer Hawkeye State, just arrived from St. Paul, and Detectives WELSH and EAGAN were dispatched with the miniatures to find out.

abstract: A gentleman named HENRY KNEELAND, residing at Fairfield, Conn., committed suicide, on Friday afternoon, at his brother's law office, No. 49 William-street, by shooting with a pistol. The body was, yesterday, removed to St. Mark's Church, Second-avenue, where, prior to the funeral services, Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest. Mr. HENRY K. BOGERT, of the firm of BOGERT & KNEELAND, residing at No. 14 East Twenty-fifth-street, testified that the deceased came into his office about 3 o'clock in the afternoon, and closed the door. Mr. BOGERT asked him why he closed the door, but he made no reply. He then seated himself, and, after making a remark, in which the word "dishonorable" was made use of, he drew a pistol from his side-pocket, and, placing the muzzle to his ear, discharged it. Mr. BOGERT immediately sent for a physician, who came in a few minutes, but too late to render effectual assistance, as death resulted in a few moments after his arrival. When Mr. KNEELAND came into the office he seemed to be perfectly tranquil, and he was never heard to threaten suicide, nor was ever anything seen to indicate that he contemplated such a deed. He had been pecuniarily embarrassed for some time, and it is supposed that this fact predisposed him to the commission of the deed. Deceased was a native of this State, and has left a large family, who reside in Fairfield, Conn.

abstract: "The right of free discussion, freedom of opinion and of speech, as guaranteed by the Constitution, few men of the North would be willing to interfere with.
lead_paragraph: The right of free discussion, freedom of opinion and of speech, as guaranteed by the Constitution, few men of the North would be willing to interfere with. They are among the fundamental principles of our American institutions, and are absolutely necessary to the preservation of Republican liberty. In no part of the world are they so much respected, so secure, as in the Free States of this Union. We listen to opinions and sentiments in sympathy with and verging upon treason in the social circle, in the forum, even in the halls of legislation, with no thoughts of violence; and though the blood may boil, and the heart swell with indignation, yet we remember that the Constitution is a shield to the utterer, and we let him alone. We may execrate the treason and denounce the traitor, we may refute and rebuke, but the right of free speech, even to the justification of revolt, we at once admit and respect.
