abstract: The vicinity of Essex Market, in Grand-street, presented a lively scene, yesterday, on the occasion of the mustering out of the United States service of the Sixty-ninth Regiment N.Y.S.M.
lead_paragraph: The vicinity of Essex Market, in Grand-street, presented a lively scene, yesterday, on the occasion of the mustering out of the United States service of the Sixty-ninth Regiment N.Y.S.M. The men were notified to assemble at 10 o'clock, but it was fully an hour later before the mustering officer, Maj. SHEPHARD, arrived. The scene in the armory was most picturesque. The men appeared in the most ununiform of uniforms. They had coats of red, white and blue, of gray, black and green; and of no particular color at all, besides some who had no coats at all. The same charming variety was visible in the pants, while the dishabille in the style of accoutrements kept pace with the rest. The floor looked like a deserted battle-field. There were fragments of knapsacks, cartridge-boxes, bayonets, bent muskets, and all the minute paraphernalia of war. In the midst of all this, eight hundred men were engaged in earnest conversation, producing a chaos from which it seemed almost impossible to extract military discipline. Gradually, however, stacks of muskets are overhauled, equipments are adjusted -- the shrill voice of Capt. THOMAS FRANCIS MEAGHER calls out "shoulder arms," and his company files out in comparatively good order. Soon other companies are disentangled from the mass, and after much confusion at the stairs -- which are built on the tenement-house principle of the least possible accommodation, and the greatest imaginable danger in case of fire -- most of the companies were at length out, when a rush of outsiders took place to get in, and for a time a dead lock on the stairs occurred. The men with the muskets going down had the right of way, but the men coming up had the energy and the muscle, and fairly kept the armed men at bay while they passed under threats of "charge bayonets."

abstract: Mr. Aaron Clark, an old and honored resident of this City, died in Brooklyn, on Friday evening last. Commencing public life as Private Secretary of Gov. D.D. Tompkins, he subsequently became Clerk of the State Senate and House of Assembly, member of the Common Council of this City, and then Mayor for two terms. In the intervals of this highly honorable public career, he became cashier of one, of the banks of this City, which position he left to fill the more lucrative post of agent under the lottery grants of Messrs. Yates & McIntyre, the duties of which he discharged until the expiration of the term of the grants from this State, retiring from the business when the sanction of the law was withdrawn. A work of his on the subject of making the water frontage of the Hudson more commodious and safer for commercial purposes by a system of dockage along the whole line of the City, attracted much attention at the time of its publication, but was considered somewhat in advance of the requirements and resources of the times, though there are those who believe that such a system will be ultimately adopted.

abstract: The events of the last few weeks force us to the conclusion that our spy system is by no means equal to that of the enemy. On the advance of our Army towards Fairfax Courthouse, a dispatch of BEAUREGARD'S was found, from Richmond, warning BONHAM of our intended advance, on Wednesday morning, and bidding him have his pickets on the alert.
lead_paragraph: The events of the last few weeks force us to the conclusion that our spy system is by no means equal to that of the enemy. On the advance of our Army towards Fairfax Courthouse, a dispatch of BEAUREGARD's was found, from Richmond, warning BONHAM of our intended advance, on Wednesday morning, and bidding him have his pickets on the alert. It is not improbable that every succeeding movement was known to the enemy soon after the information of it passed our Commander's lips. Certain it is, that the flank movement, on the morning of the great battle -- the intended surprise -- found preparations all made to receive it, and even intrenchments thrown up.

abstract: A noted Secessionist named GARRETT, a man of wealth and standing, residing near Knoxville, was arrested on Thursday, but discharged for want of evidence against him. Yesterday, however, by an escaped "contraband," it was learned that through him or his agency, information was frequently transmitted to the Rebel Army regarding the strength and position of our forces. He was rearrested last night on the strength of this information.
lead_paragraph: SANDY HOOK, Md., Saturday, Aug. 3.

abstract: There were no military movements out of he ordinary routine at Washington yesterday. A number of the new military appointments are  understood to have been confirmed by the Senate among them those of Major-Gens. FREMONT,
lead_paragraph: There were no military movements out of he ordinary routine at Washington yesterday. A number of the new military appointments are understood to have been confirmed by the Senate -- among them those of Major-Gens. FREMONT, MCCLELLAN, DIX and BANKS, and Brigadier-Gens. HOOKER, CURTIS, MCCALL, SHERMAN, LANDER, KELLEY, KEARNEY, POPE, HEINTZELMAN, PORTER, STONE, REYNOLDS, HUNTER, FRANKLIN, ROSECEANS, BUELL, MANSFIELD, MCDOWELL and MEIGS. It is expected that the Senate will to-morrow act upon the appointments for the eleven new regular regiments authorized by the present Congress. The rebels are still heard from occasionally, through the medium of the scouts. They yesterday bravely captured three ladies within a mile of Cloud's Mills.

abstract: It always seemed to me that History was a little hard on Nero for his fiddling while Rome was burning. If he was not in the habit of running with...
lead_paragraph: It always seemed to me that History was a little hard on Nero for his fiddling while Rome was burning. If he was not in the habit of running with the machine, what good could he have done at the fire? and as his spirits would naturally sag as he looked out on the conflagration that he couldn't quench, what more natural or innocent than to lift down the old Cremona? Holding this faith, and as we are situated much as the Imperialists held that Nero was, why shouldn't we keep on with our fiddling, though over the mountains our country burns?

abstract: On Friday afternoon, United States Marsha MURRAY arrested on board the steamship Northern Light, as she was coming into port, Mr. AUSTIN E. SMITH, late Navy Agent of San Francisco, a rabid Secessionist, and brother of the notorious Extra BILLY SMITH, of Virginia.
lead_paragraph: On Friday afternoon, United States Marsha MURRAY arrested on board the steamship Northern Light, as she was coming into port, Mr. AUSTIN E. SMITH, late Navy Agent of San Francisco, a rabid Secessionist, and brother of the notorious Extra BILLY SMITH, of Virginia. It seems that SMITH, on hearing that Old Virginia had seceded, made up his mind that the United States Government was entirely blotted out; and although he held a lucrative office under it -- the gift of BUCHANAN -- he threw up his commission in disgust, vamosed his office, and hurried off as speedily as possible to plant himself on the "sacred soil." There was only one thing that this distinguished Virginia office-holder regretted on vacating his office, and that was that he had not more Government money in his possession to take along with him. It will be recollected from our San Francisco correspondence that he boasted to his friends, on the eve of his departure, of his ardent desire to rob the United States Government of a good round sum, but as he only had $10,000 in his possession, he said he was ashamed to steal so small an amount, and should therefore leave it behind. One F.F.V. considers himself as good as another, and it is not to be wondered at that SMITH should hesitate to present himself, with the proceeds of a petty larceny of $10,000 in his pocket, before such a magnificent thief as JOHN R. FLOYD. It is not certain, however, that he did not take that amount, small as it is -- in fact he is charged with so doing by the Government -- but we forbear to repeat the charge, lest he should consider it libelous. SMITH has been expected here, for some time past, and the Marshal has been on the lookout for him. As the Northern Light was coming up the bay he boarded her, and finding SMITH among the passengers, took him into custody. When the steamer arrived at the dock, the prisoner was taken to the New-York Hotel, where he passed Friday night, under guard of two Deputy Marshals. Yesterday the Marshal telegraphed to Washington to know what disposition should be made of the prisoner, and received instructions from Secretary SEWARD to hand him over to the military authorities. He was therefore transferred from his hotel to Fort Lafayette, where he spent last night, and will probably spend many nights to come with his secession confreres from Baltimore. The Marshal retains possession of all his baggage, including letters and correspondence, which will doubtless throw more lustre on his already brilliant reputation.

abstract: Dull times and warm weather play the deuce with our places of amusement, even when the public mind is more susceptible of recreation than it is at present. August at best is a terrible month for managers. This year it promises to be more calamitous...
lead_paragraph: Dull times and warm weather play the deuce with our places of amusement, even when the public mind is more susceptible of recreation than it is at present. August at best is a terrible month for managers. This year it promises to be more calamitous than usual. The two or three places that remain open are so sparsely attended that we doubt if the small running expenses are obtained. The FLORENCES, at the Winter Garden, seem to bear the brunt of this neglect. They appear nightly to audiences curiously small, the numbers composing it being scattered in so many directions that it looks more like a lodge than a theatre. It is hard, too, for the FLORENCES possess not only talent, but industry, and never seem in the slightest degree discouraged. We trust that when they have returned to their regular repertoire, they will attract more attention. It seems to us that almost any of their old pieces would be better than such vapid trash as "America's Dream." We hear, by the way, that the FLORENCES will give a grand performance on Wednesday next for the benefit of the widows and orphans of the Sixty-ninth Regiment.

abstract: -- WM. G. Life was extinct before he was taken up. Deceased was a native of Ireland, 30 years of age. WM. SEARS, another fireman was very seriously injured at the same time by falling from another engine.

abstract: Mr. CRITTENDEN is a patriot of the most noble type that we all know. He has descended to us from the former and better age of the republic, and we love to hear his warm and all-embracing prayers for the justice, integrity and honor of the Government, and his tender appeals for kindness and forbearance toward erring citizens of the rebel States.
lead_paragraph: Mr. CRITTENDEN is a patriot of the most noble type -- that we all know. He has descended to us from the former and better age of the republic, and we love to hear his warm and all-embracing prayers for the justice, integrity and honor of the Government, and his tender appeals for kindness and forbearance toward erring citizens of the rebel States. His words are always pleasant to be listened to, for they remind us of the times when WEBSTER, CLAY, BENTON and CRITTENDEN were in the Senate, and the owls and bats of treason did not vex the dusky air of an approaching political night.

abstract: CORNELIUS B. AMBROSE, on Wednesday night last, jumped into the water at Pier No. 37, East River, and was drowned. His body was recovered yesterday. It appears that deceased had been ill for a long time, and his friends believe he had become partially insane.

abstract: Prince NAPOLEON, accompanied by the French Minister, Count MERCIER, Capt. BONFILS, Lieut.-Col. RAGOU, Lieut.-Col. PISANI, and Mr. MAURICE SANDS, visited the White House at 12 o'clock to-day. The party were met at the President's by the Secretary of State, who presented the Prince and his suite to President LINCOLN. The utmost cordiality was manifested, and the presentation and reception seemed to be mutually satisfactory.

abstract: There is good as well as evil about the repulse at Bull Run. If it was bad for the Army that fought there, bad for the country, bad for the prestige, which, as well as valor wins battles, it was a God-send for the croakers.
lead_paragraph: There is good as well as evil about the repulse at Bull Run. If it was bad for the Army that fought there, bad for the country, bad for the prestige, which, as well as valor wins battles, it was a God-send for the croakers. If it saddened patriotism, it made their hearts glad -- brought them into the foreground. It is wonderful the number of prophets, those who foretell events after they have happened, there are in the land; how many who can tell you exactly how any great calamity might have been avoided, and a great good achieved. It is wonderful too, how many great Generals we have whose existence has been revealed by the disaster at Bull Run; hoary veterans from the banker's desk, the merchant's counting-house, the lawyer's office, the editor's sanctum, and all the way down to the cobbler's stall, who, had they been consulted, could have reversed that calamity, and given us the fortifications, guns, the whole Army of rebels, and carried us safely through the intrenched camps at Manassas, on a triumphant march upon Richmond. "Don't you see," says one as he seizes you by the button -- "how easily the thing might have been done? The wind on the day of the battle was in the southwest, and all you had to do was to throw a blazing brand into the woods on that side of the enemy. The fire would have kindled and gone roaring and surging, crackling and swirling down upon him, smoking out his soldiers, firing off his cannon, exploding his magazines, driving him from his ambush and concealed batteries into the open fields, where our soldiers could have speared his disordered columns with their bayonets like so many suckers?" "Why did Gen. SCOTT" -- says another -- "permit MCDOWELL to march upon Bull Run at all until he had a hundred thousand men to hurl upon the enemy? Why didn't he wait till PATTERSON'S division had swept down from Harper's Ferry on the enemy's flank, and MCCLELLAN'S forces had crossed the mountains and attacked him in the rear? Don't you see the trap BEAUREGARD would have been in, with a hundred thousand men in front, twenty thousand on his flank, and a victorious enemy thundering in his rear? We should have had him safe enough then, Sir -- safe enough." "If MCDOWELL" -- says a third -- "had only moved cautiously, cutting away the woods and planting batteries as he went -- if he had dug riffle pits and thrown up intrenchments, made regular approaches, as was done at Mantua or Sebastapol, in less than six months he would have driven the rebels from the Gap. But he was too hasty; he was rash, Sir, and hence the repulse." And thus it is with these military croakers, the light of whose martial genius has, unfortunately for the country, been so long under a bushel.
headline: {'main': 'A Carnival for Croakers.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Carnival for Croakers.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Coroner GAMBLE yesterday held an inquest at the City Hospital, upon the body of PETER FLYNN, a native of Ireland, 60 years of age, whose death resulted from injuries accidentally received on the 9th of June last. The deceased, who was a public porter, had taken a load of nails to the upper floor of one of the warehouses in the lower part of the City, and in descending the stairs missed his footing and fell to the bottom. His leg was fractured, and he died from exhaustion consequent upon the injury.
lead_paragraph: Coroner GAMBLE yesterday held an inquest at the City Hospital, upon the body of PETER FLYNN, a native of Ireland, 60 years of age, whose death resulted from injuries accidentally received on the 9th of June last. abstract: The Richmond Dispatch, of July 28, says: "Mr. MEMMINGER stated yesterday to the Bankers' Convention that the Treasury Department had, for the first time, on that day, received proof impressions of the Confederate State Bonds, which will soon be issued in sums of $5, $10, $20 and $50. As these bonds will be received as bank notes by all the Southern banks, they will form a very convenient currency, and we are glad to find the measure has been adopted, and have no doubt the people will readily aid in their circulation."
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Dispatch, of July 28, says: "Mr. MEMMINGER stated yesterday to the Bankers' Convention that the Treasury Department had, for the first time, on that day, received proof impressions of the Confederate State Bonds, which will soon be issued in sums of $5, $10, $20 and $50. As these bonds will be received as bank notes by all the Southern banks, they will form a very convenient currency, and we are glad to find the measure has been adopted, and have no doubt the people will readily aid in their circulation."

abstract: Officer HAWKINS of the Eleventh Precinct Police, yesterday arrested JOHN B. KNAPP and CHARLES GRUNDLESS, both soldiers, just returned from the war, for assaulting and stabbing AUGUSTUS KRISTMAN, living in Second-avenue near Forty-first-street. The parties got into a quarrel, and during the progress of it, KRISTMAN was very seriously stabbed several times in the side and back, by the two prisoners. Justice BROWNELL held them for trial.

abstract: The Court of Inquiry in the case of Col. SMITH, of this regiment, has been dissolved by order of Gen. DIX, for the supposed reason that there was no just ground for the charges against him and which led to his arrest.
lead_paragraph: The Court of Inquiry in the case of Col. SMITH, of this regiment, has been dissolved by order of Gen. DIX, for the supposed reason that there was no just ground for the charges against him and which led to his arrest. Under date of Friday, an order was issued by the State Adjutant-General, CAMPBELL, directing Col. SMITH to resume the command of his regiment, to the end that it might be mustered out of the service of the United States as soon as practicable, and suspending the arrest until further orders. abstract: MICHAEL MCGOFF, a longshoreman, was drowned on Thursday at the foot of Robinson-street, N.R. He occasionally drank to excess, and is supposed to have fallen from the pier while intoxicated. Deceased was a native of Ireland, 30 years of age....ROBERT HUNTER, employed as porter by SPRAGUE & COOPER, Nos. 26 and 28 Parkplace, who has been missing since Wednesday evening, was found drowned yesterday near Christopher-street ferry. The circumstances under which he came to his death are not known. He was a native of Scotland, 40 years of age.

The cheering was acom  panied by a shower of stones that fell among the ranks of the volunteers. The soldiers immediately
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore Clipper of Thursday states that as the Fifth New-York Regiment passed that city on Wednesday, a party of Irish Secessionists began cheering for JEFF. DAVIS. The cheering was acom panied by a shower of stones that fell among the ranks of the volunteers. The soldiers immediately fixed their bayonets and charged upon the men who lined the sidewalks. Several shots were also fired, but we could hear of no one being injured.

abstract: The Washington Star, under the head of "a very narrow escape," says that on Monday last BEAUREGARD was reconnoitering in person, within three or four miles of the Chain Bridge, and had left a party of ten or fifteen of his troops scouting there, but ten minutes before the latter were all made prisoners by Capt. MOTTE, of New-York, and a Union company that went out (from the Chain Bridge) for the purpose of capturing them.

abstract: Few ships now going to sea, particularly on East India or California voyages, consider their outfit perfect without one or more guns of long range to defend themselves against the possible pirates who may lay in their track. The clipper-ship Prima Donna, now loading at Pier No. 10, East River, in SUTTON & Co.'s California line, has a fine rifled cannon on board for this purpose, and Capt. HARRIMAN, her commander, will, no doubt, make good use of it if any pirate of the Jeff. Davis stripe should interfere with him. WIARD's steel rifled guns are in quite general demand for these purposes.

abstract: The Confed  erate States are evidently very suspicious of each other, and jealous of the league they are supposed to have formed. When the secession movement was fairly inaugurated, each State that seceded signalized its departure
lead_paragraph: -- The Confederate States are evidently very suspicious of each other, and jealous of the league they are supposed to have formed. When the secession movement was fairly inaugurated, each State that seceded signalized its departure from the Union by stealing all of the United States' property within its territory. Some of the States made huge grabs -- in printers' phrase, they got "fat takes." Louisiana seized about $600,000 in coin, besides valuable arms in the Baton Rouge Arsenal. Texas got over a million dollars' worth of Government property through TWIGGS. North Carolina secured a splendid prize in 42,000 stand of superb arms, taken with the Fayetteville Arsenal. South Carolina, Florida, Georgia, Alabama, Mississippi and Arkansas got very little plunder, because the United States had not much of value within their borders for them to seize.

abstract: In reply to the slurs and imprecations so industriously thrown upon the Secretary of the Navy through many presses, it is but necessary to remind the public, that on assuming control of his Department, on the 4th of March, Mr. WELLES found that his predecessor had left but three ships at his disposal for the work of aiding with the Navy to maintain the integrity of the Union; all the rest fit or ready for sea service being at points from which he could not make them available in the instant emergency that was upon the country. Since then, he has actually managed to get a hundred and sixty-three vessels actively employed in some way or other in connection with the work of closing the ports of the revolted States, and suppressing piracy under the pretence of privateering. So effective a naval force was never before improvised under any Government with so small means at hand for commencing and pushing through the work.
lead_paragraph: In reply to the slurs and imprecations so industriously thrown upon the Secretary of the Navy through many presses, it is but necessary to remind the public, that on assuming control of his Department, on the 4th of March, Mr. WELLES found that his predecessor had left but three ships at his disposal for the work of aiding with the Navy to maintain the integrity of the Union; all the rest fit or ready for sea service being at points from which he could not make them available in the instant emergency that was upon the country. Since then, he has actually managed to get a hundred and sixty-three vessels actively employed in some way or other in connection with the work of closing the ports of the revolted States, and suppressing piracy under the pretence of privateering. So effective a naval force was never before improvised under any Government with so small means at hand for commencing and pushing through the work.

abstract: Almost universal gratification was expressed yesterday at the result of the labors of the State  Convention, in the election of Judge HAMILTON R. GAMBLE for Provisional Governor; WILLARD P.HALL, of Buchanan, for Lieutenant Governor,
lead_paragraph: Almost universal gratification was expressed yesterday at the result of the labors of the State Convention, in the election of Judge HAMILTON R. GAMBLE for Provisional Governor; WILLARD P.HALL, of Buchanan, for Lieutenant Governor, and MORDECAI OLIVER, of Green County, for Secretary of State. Every man who has a direct personal interest in the State, who is solicitous that peace should be restored to us, and that a wise and conservative Government should be re-established, felt relieved when told that Judge GAMBLE had been placed at the head of public affairs in this trying emergency. As it is well known, he is no politician, he has no political ambition, and if he was drawn from retirement to take part in the deliberations of the Convention months ago, it was because he believed that he had a duty to perform, from which he would not shrink. He took a leading part in the action of that Convention. Nothing but a conviction of duty, we are satisfied, could have induced him to accept the office of Governor, even for a temporary period, and we estimate, therefore, the more highly the sacrifice of personal comfort which it implies. His election will do more to restore peace to the State than anything that has transpired for a long while, and we congratulate the people upon it.

Regiments have been constantly arriving; the city has bean fairly thronged with troops; eight steamboats have been preparing for their transportation down the river, and on last evening there were strong indications that "the great fleet" was about to move.
lead_paragraph: Unusual interest has been created by the unwonted military activity which has followed the arrival of Maj. Gen. FREMONT in St. Louis. Regiments have been constantly arriving; the city has bean fairly thronged with troops; eight steamboats have been preparing for their transportation down the river, and on last evening there were strong indications that "the great fleet" was about to move. The commanding General of this Department has not seen proper to inform the public accurately beforehand with respect to the precise objects of his enterprise, plans of his campaign, or date of the departure of his expedition. Upon these points time will undoubtedly enlighten the community.

abstract: No news of special importance reaches us from Washington. The most interesting occurrence which took place there yesterday was a visit of Prince NAPOLEON to the camps and fortifications in the vicinity, accompanied by Secretary SEWARD, AND escorted by a company of dragoons.
lead_paragraph: No news of special importance reaches us from Washington. The most interesting occurrence which took place there yesterday was a visit of Prince NAPOLEON to the camps and fortifications in the vicinity, accompanied by Secretary SEWARD, AND escorted by a company of dragoons. The deputation which recently visited the rebel lines with a flag of truce, having a communication from Secretary CAMERON relative to the recovery of the body of Col. CAMERON, of the Seventy-ninth, returned on Saturday, having been unsuccessful in their mission on account of some pretended informality in the address of the letter conveyed by them. They were not suffered to approach Fairfax Court-house. The two ladies who went to carry hospital supplies and money to our wounded in the hands of the rebels, also returned yesterday, not having been permitted to enter the rebel lines. They left their supplies, however, with the officers in command at Fairfax Court-house, who gave them a receipt, with the assurance that they should be distributed in the manner intended, under the direction of our own surgeons, who are also prisoners. The report of the third session of the Sanitary Commission, which has been prepared, will shortly be published.

abstract: A correspondent of the Georgia Citizen, writing from Richmond, says there are over 900 men employed in the Tredegar Iron Works, where they turn out over ten cannon per day, from five to one hundred and thirty-four pounders -- columbiads, howitzers, field-pieces, rifled cannon, shell-shot and balls enough to supply an Army of 500,000 men. The musket-stock is made in a peculiar way. The piece of wood is put into a machine, and it comes out a perfect stock; five hundred are turned out in a day. Cartridges are made by women and girls. Between three and four hundred are employed; about 800,000 are turned out per day. There are 1,200 mules employed in conveying the war munitions, stores, etc.
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the Georgia Citizen, writing from Richmond, says there are over 900 men employed in the Tredegar Iron Works, where they turn out over ten cannon per day, from five to one hundred and thirty-four pounders -- columbiads, howitzers, field-pieces, rifled cannon, shell-shot and balls enough to supply an Army of 500,000 men. The musket-stock is made in a peculiar way. The piece of wood is put into a machine, and it comes out a perfect stock; five hundred are turned out in a day. Cartridges are made by women and girls. Between three and four hundred are employed; about 800,000 are turned out per day. There are 1,200 mules employed in conveying the war munitions, stores, etc.

abstract: The prisoners taken by the rebels at Bull Run are being distributed for safe keeping throughout the Southern States, some of them being sent as far South as Montgomery. A large number have been sent to Raleigh. If well treated, they will still be subject to all the diseases incident to a Southern climate, to which many will undoubtedly fall victims. The Fire Zouaves are caged up in a factory at Richmond, and are gazed at through the bars by the populace as if they were wild beasts. We know of no other mode in which these prisoners can be returned to us except by exchange; but, unfortunately, we have no rebel prisoners of the rank and file, our practice being to discharge all such on their taking the oath of allegiance. Gen. MCCLELLAN's command took a thousand, at least. Had these been retained, we could by this time have secured the return of every prisoner lost by us at Bull Run. Would it not be well to change our practice in this respect, and retain all the prisoners actually taken in arms, to meet the contingency of a reverse on our part similar to the one we have just sustained?
lead_paragraph: The prisoners taken by the rebels at Bull Run are being distributed for safe keeping throughout the Southern States, some of them being sent as far South as Montgomery. abstract: "For some time past, the regulations ordered by Gen. BANKS (then in command of this District), concerning the regiments in and around the city, have been almost entirely disregarded, and particularly in regard to their having the freedom of the city, and the carrying of arms whilst therein. Certainly the men were scarcely to be blamed in this matter, when their superior officers set them such a bad example, in disregarding the published orders. The evils complained of prevailed to such an extent that many ladies were really afraid to venture far from home. Large numbers of intoxicated soldiers were allowed by the police to roam through the streets, and the results of such conduct was attested on Wednesday evening, when one was severely stabbed, and the other so seriously injured that his life is despaired of. This state having been made known through the Press to Gen. DIX, he has promptly determined to enforce Gen. BANKS' regulations, with an added improvement to them of his own dictation; and it is highly gratifying to state that his orders have been published to the several regiments now quartered here, and they will be enforced. In no instance will more than three soldiers of each company be allowed to leave their respective camps, and these must ba provided with written passes from the commanding officer of each regiment; nor will any commissioned officer be allowed to leave without such a passport. Further, it is made the duty of the military police of the city to require any soldier (in case he deems it necessary) to produce his Colonel's certificate. These new regulations went into effect yesterday, and they had the most salutary effect, as but few of the men could be seen upon the streets, and none of these, as far as could be learned, were intoxicated. Yesterday morning two of the regiments had out scouting parties, who went through the city armed, for the purpose of arresting all stragglers who had not come into camp on the previous night. They succeeded in taking into the camps a large number, and many of these were at once placed in the guard-house. If Major-Gen. DIX will maintain the regulations he will receive the thanks of great numbers of our citizens.
lead_paragraph: "For some time past, the regulations ordered by Gen. BANKS (then in command of this District), concerning the regiments in and around the city, have been almost entirely disregarded, and particularly in regard to their having the freedom of the city, and the carrying of arms whilst therein. Certainly the men were scarcely to be blamed in this matter, when their superior officers set them such a bad example, in disregarding the published orders. The evils complained of prevailed to such an extent that many ladies were really afraid to venture far from home. Large numbers of intoxicated soldiers were allowed by the police to roam through the streets, and the results of such conduct was attested on Wednesday evening, when one was severely stabbed, and the other so seriously injured that his life is despaired of. This state having been made known through the Press to Gen. DIX, he has promptly determined to enforce Gen. BANKS' regulations, with an added improvement to them of his own dictation; and it is highly gratifying to state that his orders have been published to the several regiments now quartered here, and they will be enforced. In no instance will more than three soldiers of each company be allowed to leave their respective camps, and these must ba provided with written passes from the commanding officer of each regiment; nor will any commissioned officer be allowed to leave without such a passport. Further, it is made the duty of the military police of the city to require any soldier (in case he deems it necessary) to produce his Colonel's certificate. These new regulations went into effect yesterday, and they had the most salutary effect, as but few of the men could be seen upon the streets, and none of these, as far as could be learned, were intoxicated. Yesterday morning two of the regiments had out scouting parties, who went through the city armed, for the purpose of arresting all stragglers who had not come into camp on the previous night. They succeeded in taking into the camps a large number, and many of these were at once placed in the guard-house. If Major-Gen. DIX will maintain the regulations he will receive the thanks of great numbers of our citizens.

abstract: The Herald is assailing the Administration for not having shown a proper appreciation of the Republican newspapers--especially the TIMES and Tribune. These papers, it says, are the "parents of the Republican Party;"
lead_paragraph: The Herald is assailing the Administration for not having shown a proper appreciation of the Republican newspapers -- especially the TIMES and Tribune. These papers, it says, are the "parents of the Republican Party;" to them is due the "credit of the construction and success of the party;" "whatever of success it has achieved, it owes originally and chiefly to them;" "they have given it brains, inoculated it with ideas, educated it to victory;" and in spite of all this, the Administration, the moment it came into power, not only utterly ignored and neglected these papers, but actually "attempted to breakdown the very journals which gave it existence and success, because they freely discussed and criticised its course, by starting a servile organ here, and sustaining it and its editors by all sorts of fat advertising jobs, naval jobs, Army jobs and contract jobs,"

abstract: The Hamilton, C.W., Spectator of July 29 says: "Early on Sunday morning, about 5 o'clock, a beautiful flag, bearing as many stars upon it as the States out of the American Union, might have been descried floating proudly from the dome of the Anglo-American Hotel. As the building has long been vacant, it is evident that some persons well acquainted with the place were instrumental in the flag-hoisting. Policeman GRAHAM was the first to observe the obnoxious emblem, and removed it as speedily as he could, or it is probable that mischief might have been caused by its exhibition. We imagine it to be a small business for any one to take the trouble of displaying the secession flag, especially as this was rather a costly one. It is lying at the Police-office, where the owner or owners, we presume, can have it on application."

abstract: The News learns from a well-informed citizen of Southwest Missouri, who possesses peculiar facilities for acquiring knowledge of the plan of the Secessionists in that region, that their real object is not to attack Cairo or Bird's Point, but to make a desperate attempt to secure possession of St. Louis. There is a strong force under Gen. PILLOW at New-Madrid, Mo.; another at Pocahontas, Ark., believed to be now under the command of BEN. MCCULLOCH, and another in Mississippi County, under JEFF. THOMPSON. The plan is to keep up a constant threat to attack Cairo and Bird's Point, so as to keep the National troops there employed, menace Gen. LYON in Southwest Missouri by threats of attack from Generals PRICE and RAINS, while the forces at New-Madrid and Pocahontas effect a junction at Pilot Knob, and from there march on St. Louis, take it, reinstate Gov. JACKSON, and with this city as a basis of operations wrest Missouri from the National Government.

abstract: The extra session of the National Congress, which ceases to-morrow, is one that will be memorable in the history of the country. Its members were called together by the necessities of a great crisis, in which the very existence of the Union was involved. They
lead_paragraph: The extra session of the National Congress, which ceases to-morrow, is one that will be memorable in the history of the country. Its members were called together by the necessities of a great crisis, in which the very existence of the Union was involved. They found a gigantic rebellion organized, with a hundred thousand men in arms, in open defiance of the authority of the Government, and advancing for its overthrow. They found the National Treasury empty, the country without an army, saw undisciplined militia and volunteers hastily gathered for the emergency: -- they found it comparatively without arms, and almost destitute of the warlike munitions so absolutely essential to its defence. They were required, in order to meet the exigencies of the occasion, to reorganize the National systern of finance, -- to resuscitate the National credit, damaged to an almost infinite extent by the late traitorous and corrupt Cabinet, and an imbecile and equally corrupt Executive, -- to organize and provide for the equiping and maintaining of a vast Army, -- to enlarge and render efficient the Navy -- in brief, to provide for a conflict, mightier a thousand fold than any that the country had ever been engaged in, and to carry which forward to a successful issue required a degree of patriotism and wisdom, an energy and courage such as were never before demanded of the representatives of the American people.

abstract: The people of Providence extended a cordial welcome to the Rhode Island First on Thursday last. The members of the First Battery, numbering 135 men, had a breakfast given them at 7 A.M., and complimentary speeches were made by Hon. T.A. JENCKES and Col. BURNSIDE. At noon the whole regiment paraded, and at 4 o'clock, after another parade, a farewell address from Col. BURNSIDE was read. Before the regiment was dismissed, an elegant flag was presented to Company H, Mechanic Rifles, Capt. DAY.

abstract: One of the most interesting incidents of the battle, says a Southern journal, is presented in the case Of WYLIE P. MANGUM, Jr., son of ex-Senator MANGUM, of North Carolina. This young man was attached to Col. FISHER'S regiment. I believe, and owes the preservation of his life to a copy of the Bible presented
lead_paragraph: One of the most interesting incidents of the battle, says a Southern journal, is presented in the case Of WYLIE P. MANGUM, Jr., son of ex-Senator MANGUM, of North Carolina. This young man was attached to Col. FISHER's regiment. I believe, and owes the preservation of his life to a copy of the Bible presented him by his sister. He had the good book "in his left coat pocket. It was struck by a ball near the edge but the book changed the direction of the bullet, and it glanced off, inflicting a severe, but not dangerous flesh wound. The book was saturated with blood but the advice written on a fly-leaf by the sister who gave it was perfectly legible.

abstract: PILLOW has made his proclamation. He is marching into Missouri to deliver the people from the intolerable thraldom of the General Government. He promises not to stay long in the State, -- and we presume that in this particular he will keep his word. He repeats the infamous lie started by BEAUREGARD, that the Union troops make "Beauty and booty" their watchword and declares that "no quarter will be shown to men marching under such a banner." It is quite possible that PILLOW is fool enough to believe his own statements on this subject, but the probability is that he resorts to these falsehoods as the only means of inciting his men to fight.

abstract: Recruiting for the Army, for the past week, flows a slight improvement. Twenty-five men for the old Army were obtained at Chatham, Cedar and liudson streets. The latter office is established exclusively for cavalry, and of the men enlisted there,
lead_paragraph: Recruiting for the Army, for the past week, shows a slight improvement. Twenty-five men for the old Army were obtained at Chatham, Cedar and liudson streets. The latter office is established exclusively for cavalry, and of the men enlisted there, three-fourths are old soldiers. A detachment was sent to Carlisle, on Wednesday. For the new Twelfth Regiment, the offices in Broadway, Yorkville, and Fort Hamilton contribute each, on an average, four men per day. Five regular officers, sending in returns from the country, all complain of the "competition in recruiting," even in the rural districts The regulars, left idle in the city by volunteer drummers, went to the provinces, and were doing well, when the latter followed them. One batch of United States gentlemen had quietly rented three rooms on the first floor of a country hotel, the two adjoining which were renied next day by some "Thirty-fourth fellows," as an indignant Captain writes. Fort Trumbull, Conn., Fort Independence, Boston, Newport, Ky., and Fort Hamilton, will soon, however, look like regimental head-quarters, as bands and banners for the "depots" located there are being procured.

abstract: The Washington correspondent of the Philadelphia Press telegraphs: "One of the most deplorable issues of the defeat of our Army, is the expulsion of citizens from Fairfax County. Expulsion is too mild a term to employ in explanation of their condition. They are obliged to fly with their families, or be impressed into the army and carried down South. Two of these men were in my office to-day. They gave me a statement of their condition: A notice was served on them, at their own houses, to appear on a specified day at the quarters of Gen. BEAUREGARD, bringing with them the best arms they had. They are Northern men, as a very large proportion of the farmers of Fairfax County are; they could not dare to appear before BEAUREGARD, and be compelled to take up arms against the Union. Their only alternative was to escape with their families. This they have done, flying, in many cases, at midnight, and by a circuitous journey, through forests, to reach Washington. I am requested by those of them with whom I have conversed, to suppress their names, as any proof that they had been giving information would prove disastrous to their prospects of ever recovering the property they have hastily abandoned.

lead_paragraph: This crack corps promises to be one of the most respectable and efficient yet raised in the City. It is composed of a superior class of young men, all enthusiastic for the cause and full of [???] ardor. The Colonel, J. AUGUSTUS PAGE, is a well known artist and gentleman of elegant leisure. He has exhibited the most exquisite taste in the invention of a uniform, producing a costume which, for utility and elegance, far surpasses anything to be seen outside the French Army. Several popular, literary men and artists accept positions under him as officers; amongst others, Mr. FITZJAMES O'BRIEN is one of his captains, and Mr. FRANK WOOD a lieutenant.

abstract: The following is a list of officers of the regular Army, graduates of West Point, many of whom saw service in Mexico, and who, for that and other controlling considerations of fitness, are supposed to be better calculated
lead_paragraph: The following is a list of officers of the regular Army, graduates of West Point, many of whom saw service in Mexico, and who, for that and other controlling considerations of fitness, are supposed to be better calculated for high command -- for the positions of Major and Brigadier-General -- and, of course, for any subordinate position, than any individual, whatever distinction he may have achieved, taken from civil life. This list has been made, at our request, by a gentleman, formerly, but not now, of the Army, and whose name, were we at liberty to give it, would commend the classification to the candid consideration of every person connected with the Army, who, like himself, is familiar with the positive and relative fitness of the persons named. As the classification of an individual, it is, of course, liable to the criticism to which the fallibility of individual, judgment, as to the character of men and their fitness for particular positions, is necessarily subject, even on the part of those best capable of an enlightened and impartial opinion.

abstract: DEATHS FROM COUP DE SOLEIL.--The heat on Saturday prostrated a large number of persons, and four deaths from its effects have been reported ot the Coroners. JOHN BRENAN, a laborer employed in the stave-yard at the foot of Seventh-street, East River, was prostrated, and died before a physician could be
lead_paragraph: DEATHS FROM COUP DE SOLEIL. -- The heat on Saturday prostrated a large number of persons, and four deaths from its effects have been reported ot the Coroners. JOHN BRENAN, a laborer employed in the stave-yard at the foot of Seventh-street, East River, was prostrated, and died before a physician could be sent for. He lived at No. 305 Monroe-street.... THOMAS JOURDON, a hod-carrier, was overcome while working on Stewart's building, corner of Broadway and Tenth-street. He was taken to his home, No. 133 West Thirty-second-street, where he soon died. He was a native of Ireland, 55 years of age....PATRICK SHERIDAN was overpowered while laboring at the foot of Fourth-street. North River, and died in a very short time. He was a married man, 30 years of age, residing at No. 175 East Sixteenth-street..... LAWRENCE KILLIAN, a laborer on board a coal barge at the foot of Twenty-first-street, East River, died at Bellevue Hospital in consequence of the heat, which prostrated him while he was at work. He lived at No. 173 West Twenty-seventh-street, where he has left a wife and child. Coroner JACKMAN yesterday held an inquest in each case.

abstract: Gen. PILLOW has actually moved into Southeast Missouri with a heavy column of rebel troops, and has issued a proclamation announcing his intention to drive out the National forces and reinstate CLAIB. JACKSON at Jefferson City. A division of the rebel Army, (probably Missourians,) under the notorious JEFF. THOMPSON, are within twenty miles of Bird's Point. Whatever the ultimate intention of this expedition may be, they must attack and overpower our men at Bird's Point, and leave a sufficient force to fend off a counter-attack from Cairo, before proceeding Northward to Jefferson City or St. Louis -- otherwise they will be exposed to an assault in their rear and a breaking of their line of communication. It is hardly probable that a battle in that quarter can be delayed many days.

abstract: Our people are so unused to wars on a colossal scale, and their consequent financial burdens, that it may help them to estimate their ability to carry on the one in which they are at present engaged, by comparing its
lead_paragraph: Our people are so unused to wars on a colossal scale, and their consequent financial burdens, that it may help them to estimate their ability to carry on the one in which they are at present engaged, by comparing its probable burdens with those sustained by England in her great contests growing out of the French Revolution. These commenced in 1793, and continued, with little interruption, till 1815. At the period first named, the population of England, Scotland, and Wales, did not exceed 9,500,000. That of Ireland was some 3,500,000, or 4,000,000 more; but as that country was in a state of chronic rebellion, it was a source of weakness rather than strength, leaving the whole brunt of the contest to fall upon the other portions of the Kingdom, which furnished all the money, and nearly all the soldiers for the contest.

abstract: The various financial measures for the prosecution of the war, the Loan bill, the income, direct and excise taxes, and the amendment of the tariff, have all become laws, and will undoubtedly produce ample means for the...
lead_paragraph: The various financial measures for the prosecution of the war, the Loan bill, the income, direct and excise taxes, and the amendment of the tariff, have all become laws, and will undoubtedly produce ample means for the immediate wants of Government, at any rate, till the next session of Congress. They have all been passed in great haste, and, with the exception of the Loan bill, will undoubtedly be subject to important modifications, should the measures inaugurated become permanent features of our system. The haste characteristic of the action of Congress is most strikingly illustrated in the Tariff bill, which adds very largely to the already existing high rates of duties, on many articles, and virtually abolishes the warehouse system, by providing that upon all merchandise (not afloat) imported after the passage of the act, duties shall be paid within three months after entry. The increased rates are chiefly upon luxuries, with the exception of tea, coffee and sugar.
headline: {'main': 'The New Financial Measures The Tariff.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The New Financial Measures The Tariff.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: HOPE CHAPEL. -- Mr. DE CORDOVA's new entertainment at this establishment will close this evening and we recommend our friends to take the final opportunity of listening to an extremely vivid poem, and gazing upon a series of life-like pictures of the war. Mr. DE CORDOVA's health is such that his physicians have peremptorily forbidden his going on with his arduous duties in this warm season. He is, therefore, compelled to forego his present lucrative engagement; but we hear, with pleasure, that the entertainment will be brought before the public during the coming Autumn. It is certainly one of the few things that can interest the public in these war times.
lead_paragraph: HOPE CHAPEL. -- Mr. DE CORDOVA's new entertainment at this establishment will close this evening and we recommend our friends to take the final opportunity of listening to an extremely vivid poem, and gazing upon a series of life-like pictures of the war. Mr. DE CORDOVA's health is such that his physicians have peremptorily forbidden his going on with his arduous duties in this warm season. He is, therefore, compelled to forego his present lucrative engagement; but we hear, with pleasure, that the entertainment will be brought before the public during the coming Autumn. It is certainly one of the few things that can interest the public in these war times.

abstract: With reference to military movements at Washington, our readers need expect but little enlightenment at present. Gen. McCLELLAN recently called a consultation of all the representatives of the Press there, and an agreement was entered into, that no information of a character like-...
lead_paragraph: With reference to military movements at Washington, our readers need expect but little enlightenment at present. Gen. MCCLELLAN recently called a consultation of all the representatives of the Press there, and an agreement was entered into, that no information of a character likely to enlighten the enemy relative to his plans and intentions should be published. The Government on its part, in return for this forbearance of the Press, has been requested, and will no doubt do so, to furnish all needful facilities for obtaining and immediately transmitting all information suitable for publication, particularly after the occurrence of engagements with the enemy.

abstract: The multitude of contractors who would supply the troops of the new levy with all that they require, are somewhat puzzled with the explicitness of the proposal that is required by Gen. ARTHUR. It is evident from the published document that the State is resolved the men shall be well fed, and that is not what these cormorants desire. The majority, too, are disgusted with the clause in the advertisement which say that as the expenditures under the contract will be upon account of the United States, the payments will be made "when the funds are furnished and provided by the General Government." The object of this is, of course, to secure responsible men as contractors, and to exclude the horde of hand-to-mouth speculators who put in for the contracts with the hope of dividing their luck with a large retinue of bankers. It is abundantly apparent that if the contract falls into good hands the men of the new levy will be most liberally provided for. Wednesday will decide the fate of a legion of Army followers. The public interest demedds that the contract be given to the man who is known to be capable of fulfilling its conditions with honesty and liberality.

abstract: The Regiment left the Navy-yard Tuesday, July 16, at 10 o'clock, and marched up the Avenue over  the Long Bridge, to their camping grounds, within five miles of Fairfax, where, at 9 P.M., they stacked and bivouacked for the night in the open field, to-...
lead_paragraph: The Regiment left the Navy-yard Tuesday, July 16, at 10 o'clock, and marched up the Avenue over the Long Bridge, to their camping grounds, within five miles of Fairfax, where, at 9 P.M., they stacked and bivouacked for the night in the open field, together with Col. BURNSIDE's Brigade, consisting of the First and Second Rhode Island Infantry, Second Rhode Island Battery, and Second New-Hampshire Volunteers. At 5 A.M., July 17, (Wednesday,) the brigade formed a line of march, and proceeded to Fairfax Court-house, where they arrived at 10 A.M., and found the breastworks of the enemy deserted, as well as the town, of all secession troops. Halted in the town before the Court-house; the flag was hoisted upon the Court-house by the Rhode Island Regiments, the band saluting it with the National airs.

abstract: We have at last received the Charleston reports of the battle at Manassas, and as might have teen expected, they carry off the palm completely from their Virginia cotemporaries in the brilliancy and variety of the falsehoods...
lead_paragraph: We have at last received the Charleston reports of the battle at Manassas, -- and as might have teen expected, they carry off the palm completely from their Virginia cotemporaries in the brilliancy and variety of the falsehoods with which they are garnished, LEONIDAS W. SPRATT, it seems, was on the field, and gives the Mercury the benefit of his observations. He gives full details of the manner in which Senator FOSTER, of Connecticut, was killed, although the Senator was in his seat next day as if nothing whatever had happened. He repeats the falsehood that some of our men displayed the secession flag, -- when there was not such a flag in the Army except one taken at Fairfax. Mr. SPRATT also asserts, from the most indisputable documentary evidence, captured in the battle, that Gen. MCDOWELL's force was 130,000!

abstract: THE SLAVER FALMOUTH. The preliminary examination of Capt. CHAS. H. KIMBALL and crew of the brig Falmouth, seized as a slaver off the coast of Africa, June 14, by the United States steamship Sumter, and brought to this port, commenced before Uni-...
lead_paragraph: THE SLAVER FALMOUTH. -- The preliminary examination of Capt. CHAS. H. KIMBALL and crew of the brig Falmouth, seized as a slaver off the coast of Africa, June 14, by the United States steamship Sumter, and brought to this port, commenced before United States Commissioner OSBORN yesterday afternoon. Ex-Judge BERBE appeared for the prisoners, and Mr. G.P. ANDREWS for the Government. Lieut. GEORGE W. YOUNG, of the Sumter, testified to the circumstances attending the seizure of the Falmouth, and the evidences of her character found on board the vessel, which were such as to prove conclusively that she was a slaver. Indeed, Capt. KIMBALL admitted this to be the character of his vessel at the time she was seized, but said that he had abandoned his original design of capturing a cargo of slaves before seizure, and was about leaving the coast. At the close of Lieut. YOUNG's examination, the case was adjourned till to-day.

abstract: -- Wide as has been the demoralizing influence of secession among the officers of the National Government, in all the departments, who happened to have been born on whose residence was in the Southern States, and dishonorable as has been the desertion of the National flag by vast numbers of them, it is a pleasant thing to know that there are those who are true to the Union, who remain faithful among the faithless, though natives and residents of the rebel States. Of such, Judge WAYNE, of the Supreme Court of the United States, is a worthy example. His fidelity to the Constitution, the firmness of his adherence to its sanctions, the genuineness of his patriotism, though surrounded on all sides by traitors, are worthy of all commendation. Though a native and a citizen of Georgia, he has escaped the mania of secession, so sweeping and almost universal in that State, never wavering in his allegiance to the Government, nor yielding for a moment to the terrorism which prevails there. Among the Southern Judges of the National Courts we believe that he alone has not drifted away from honor and official duty into the treason of secession. He is in Washington, prepared for the discharge of his judicial trusts, regarding himself as a citizen of the United States, and ready to defend and uphold the authority of the National Government, though his State is among the foremost in the rebellion that would overthrow it.
lead_paragraph: -- Wide as has been the demoralizing influence of secession among the officers of the National Government, in all the departments, who happened to have been born on whose residence was in the Southern States, and dishonorable as has been the desertion of the National flag by vast numbers of them, it is a pleasant thing to know that there are those who are true to the Union, who remain faithful among the faithless, though natives and residents of the rebel States. abstract: -- The orders recently issued by most of the commanding officers of our military posts and great Military camps, prohibiting the sale of intoxicating drinks to the men, cannot but be most salutary. The great enemy to subordination and discipline, and one great source of demoralization in the Army, is intemperance. It is the great peril of the soldier, if left to the free indulgence, of his appetite in this respect. His situation, in camp especially, exposes him to peculiar temptation. The absence of regular employment, the idleness, save while engaged in the drill and exercises of the day, the ennui of his position, all impel him to the use of intoxicating drinks as the readiest resort for that excitement which he feels is almost a necessity with him. The placing of temptation, therefore, beyond his reach, is not only a necessity in preserving discipline, but a real blessing to the soldier himself. It preserves his health, his strength, his self-respect, and the spirit that makes him enduring under fatigue, and courageous in time of danger. These orders are worth more, if rigidly enforced, in reference to the sanitary condition of the soldiers, than a car-load of medicines.
lead_paragraph: -- The orders recently issued by most of the commanding officers of our military posts and great Military camps, prohibiting the sale of intoxicating drinks to the men, cannot but be most salutary. The great enemy to subordination and discipline, and one great source of demoralization in the Army, is intemperance. It is the great peril of the soldier, if left to the free indulgence, of his appetite in this respect. His situation, in camp especially, exposes him to peculiar temptation. The absence of regular employment, the idleness, save while engaged in the drill and exercises of the day, the ennui of his position, all impel him to the use of intoxicating drinks as the readiest resort for that excitement which he feels is almost a necessity with him. The placing of temptation, therefore, beyond his reach, is not only a necessity in preserving discipline, but a real blessing to the soldier himself. It preserves his health, his strength, his self-respect, and the spirit that makes him enduring under fatigue, and courageous in time of danger. These orders are worth more, if rigidly enforced, in reference to the sanitary condition of the soldiers, than a car-load of medicines.

lead_paragraph: The Thirteenth Regiment paraded yesterday afternoon for the last time before being mustered out of service, on Fort Greene,and was reviewed by the Mayor and Common Council. There were about 809 man in line. After the review, the regiment executed some battalion movements in a creditable manner, and then marched through some of the principal thoroughfares to the Armory and were dismissed. Col. AREL SMITH was in command, having been restored to duty by the Assistant Adjutant-General. The Thirteenth, it is expected, will be mustered out of the service and paid off to-day.

abstract: On the evening of July 29 a large meeting was held at the 'Merchants' Exchange, in New-Orleans, to make arrangements for the relief of the soldiers wounded at Manassas. Gen. W.A. ELMORE presided, and Rev. Dr. PALMER spoke.
lead_paragraph: On the evening of July 29 a large meeting was held at the Merchants' Exchange, in New-Orleans, to make arrangements for the relief of the soldiers wounded at Manassas. Gen. W.A. ELMORE presided, and Rev. Dr. PALMER spoke. Among other things he said that he did not believe this would be a protracted war. Protracted wars did not prevail among the great civilized nations of the earth, but only among barbarians. Such a war would bankrupt any nation in one year. Even England, in the war of the Crimea, found herself pressed and worried to the extreme in furnishing her Army with supplies. For what duration of time could the North hope to sustain 400,000 men? As to the issue, the enemy might as well throw their millions into the rivers as to expect to subjugate us. Our cotton gave us immense power. The millions of Europe depended on it for their bread. As for the blockade, we laughed it to scorn. This war must soon terminate, or the civilized nations of Europe must become engaged in it; and he predicted our independence would be acknowledged before the first day of next year. But we would carry on this war until that end was accomplished.

abstract: Yesterday morning our reporter paid a visit to the City Almshouse, where a number of the wounded captured at Manassas are now quartered. The Almshouse is a large four-story building, recently erected and completed, with the exception of the plastering.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning our reporter paid a visit to the City Almshouse, where a number of the wounded captured at Manassas are now quartered. The Almshouse is a large four-story building, recently erected and completed, with the exception of the plastering. It is situated on a commanding elevation, in the northeastern portion of the city, and affords from its windows and spacious porches a magnificent view of the surrounding country. It is most admirably adapted for a hospital, the use to which it is now put, as well on account of its interior arrangements as its salubrious situation.

abstract: The Head-quarters of the United States Army has been practically transferred from Eleventh-street, in this City, to the National Capital. Gen. SCOTT'S office in town having been for months divested of the Commander-in-Chief, orders and regulations for the...
lead_paragraph: The Head-quarters of the United States Army has been practically transferred from Eleventh-street, in this City, to the National Capital. Gen. SCOTT's office in town having been for months divested of the Commander-in-Chief, orders and regulations for the Army are now dated "Washington," instead of New-York. Officers reporting for duty, however, frequently do so at the Eleventh-street establishment and as no general order forbidding them to do so has been published, one of the chief functions of a military head-quarters is still performed in New-York.

abstract: -- We have at last Mr. HARVEY's statement in reply the outburst of indignation which, upon its first disclosure, greeted the fact that he had been in telegraphic correspondence with Judge MAGRATH, of Charleston, during the deliberations of the Cabinet concerning Fort Sumter. We publish it in another column; and simple justice compels us, to say, that it completely relieves Mr. HARVEY from the aspersions so industriously and maliciously thrown upon his loyalty. It was almost universally assumed by the Press, and especially by the Tribune, with which he had been connected, that he had acted as a spy for the rebels at the Capital of the country, and in the very Council Chamber of the Government.

abstract: Of the character and policy of LOUIS NAPOLEON, CAVOUR was accustomed to speak with much freedom. No one had better opportunities than CAVOUR of sounding their depths. He was the only living man who had ventured to grapple with him face to face, and who had used him for his purpose.
lead_paragraph: Of the character and policy of LOUIS NAPOLEON, CAVOUR was accustomed to speak with much freedom. No one had better opportunities than CAVOUR of sounding their depths. He was the only living man who had ventured to grapple with him face to face, and who had used him for his purpose. The estimate he had formed of his capacity was not a high one, but he fully admitted his fertility of resource, his physical and moral courage, and his knowledge of the people he governs. "He has no definite policy," he remarked to an English friend. "He has a number of political ideas floating in his mind, none of them matured. They would seem to be convictions, founded on instinct. He will not steadily pursue any single idea if a serious obstacle presents itself, but will give way, and take up another. This is the mot de el'nigme to his policy. It is by steadily keeping this in view that I have succeeded in thwarting his designs, or in inducing him to adopt a measure. The only principle -- of principle it can be called -- which connects together these various ideas, is the establishment of his dynasty, and the conviction that the best way to secure it is by feeding the national vanity of the French people. He found France, after the fall of the Orleanist and Republican Governments, holding but a second place amongst the great Powers; he has raised her to the very first. Look at his wars, look at his foreign policy; he has never gone one step beyond what was absolutely necessary to attain this one object. The principle ostentatiously put forward in the first instance has been forgotten or discarded as soon as his immediate end has been accomplished. It was so in the war with Russia; it has been so in the war with Austria. In the Crimea he was satisfied with the success of his army in the capture of Sebastopol, which took from the English troops the glory they had earned by their devotion and courage, and to which they would have added had the war continued. In the struggle with Austria he was astounded by the greatness of the victories of Magenta and Solferino. The military glory of France had been satiated, and he thought no more of the liberty of Italy, of the free and united nation which he was to have called into existence from the Alps to the Adriatic. It is this uncertain policy, guided by dynastic and selfish considerations, which makes him so dangerous to you, and which renders it necessary that you should ever be on your guard. Not that he is hostile to England, or that he has any definite design against her. On the contrary, he has much affection for your country. He is a man of generous impulses, and has strong feelings of gratitude towards those who have served and befriended him. At the bottom of his heart he is greatly attached to Italy. His earliest recollections are bound up with her. He is to this day a 'carbonaro' in his desire for Italian freedom and hatred of Austria. He has not forgotten the kindness and hospitality shown to him when an exile in England. He admires your institutions, and the character of the English people. But all this is as nothing when compared with the maintenance of his dynasty, the establishment of which he looks upon almost in the light of a religious obligation. If the moment came when he thought a sacrifice necessary to sustain it, however great that sacrifice might be, however painful or repugnant to his feelings, he would make it. No one has had better opportunities of knowing him than I have. He has talked to me with the greatest openness of his future plans. But he has invariably assured me at the same time, that his first object was to maintain peace and good understanding with England. I believe," he solemnly added, "that from policy as well as from affection, such are his views; and that only in a moment of the utmost emergency, when he was convinced that his influence in France depended upon it, would he depart from them. But that moment may come, and you would be madmen if you were not prepared for it." As regards the Peace of Villafranca, CAVOUR attributed it to no distinct policy, but rather to a variety of motives. "There is no profound secret or mystery about it," he said; "it was rather an impulse than the result of any well-considered design. Two splendid victories had added sufficiently to the glory of the French arms. The horrible scenes he had witnessed on the field of battle had made a deep impression upon him. He felt much disgust at the quarrels among his Generals, who were sacrificing the honor of their country to personal jealousies. Then there were the heat, the dust, and the labor, for he did not spare himself; indeed, he did everything. His exertions and the fatigue he went through were amazing. His health was beginning to give way. He had had enough of campaigning and its hardships, and was anxious to get back to Paris. To add to all this, he could not resist the temptation of dealing in person with a legitimate Emperor, as his uncle had done before him, of imposing, without consulting any one, the conditions of peace, and of earning at the same time, by his generosity and moderation, the gratitude, and perhaps eventual support, of a still powerful though vanquished enemy. These various motives and considerations together led him to abandon the great cause in which he had embarked, and to forget the proclamations, the promises, and the hopes of the day before." CAVOUR was convinced that the difficulties of an attack upon the Quadrilateral had been exaggerated. He believed that the fortresses would have soon fallen. The result of subsequent inquiries made by the Austrian Government itself into the state of Mantua and Verona fully confirmed his opinion. After the fatal day of Solferino a panic had seized the Austrian army. The result of the battle was first known in Verona by a vast number of soldiers and camp followers blockading up the gates leading to the city. The greatest disorder prevailed even in the forts, which were without the necessary guns and ammunition, and in some of which the troops had been gained over. At the same time the inhabitants of the city were ready to rise. It is believed that LOUIS NAPOLEON was not unacquainted with these facts, and that he urged them upon the Emperor of Austria at Villafranca to obtain his acceptance of the conditions of peace.

abstract: RECORDER'S REPORT.--Recorder MARTINDALE, of Jersey City, reports that for the three months ending July 31, 459 persons were brought before him on the following charges Drunkenness, vangrancy and disorderly conduct, 273; assault and battery, 63; violating City Ordnances, 10; passing counterfeit ...
lead_paragraph: RECORDER's REPORT. -- Recorder MARTINDALE, of Jersey City, reports that for the three months ending July 31, 459 persons were brought before him on the following charges: Drunkenness, vangrancy and disorderly conduct, 273; assault and battery, 63; violating City Ordnances, 10; passing counterfeit money, 4; gambling, 3; insanity, 6; fighting in the streets, 16; stealing by petty thieves, 50; receiving stolen goods, 1; picking pockets, 3; burglary, 4; deseriers, 5; larceny, 7; threatening life, 6; attempt at rape, 1; keeping a disorderly house, 1; surrendered by ball, 2; bigamy, 1; fugitives from justice, 1; stabbing with a knife, 1; incendiary, 1. They were disposed of as follows: Discharged, 278; committed to jail and work-house, 50; sent to jail for trial, 25; held to bail, 52; committed to the City prison, 20; sent, to the alms-house, 14; committed to Bergen for safe-keeping, 3; escaped from officer, 1; delivered to authorities of Newark, 1; fined, 14.

abstract: We felt much cheerd, a few days ago, in announcing that the Missouri State Convention had deposed the traitor Governor, JACKSON, and the seditious General Assembly of that State. The offence of the Legislature was that it had passed an unconstitutional ...
lead_paragraph: We felt much cheerd, a few days ago, in announcing that the Missouri State Convention had deposed the traitor Governor, JACKSON, and the seditious General Assembly of that State. The offence of the Legislature was that it had passed an unconstitutional military bill, putting the militia of the State in the hands of a traitor Governor, and compelling them to swear fealty to that Governor, instead of to the Constitution of the United States. The offence of the Governor was that he had openly conspired with armed enemies of the United States, and was using the militia and the treasure of the State in trying to withdraw Missouri from the Union. And further, that in the violent effort to accomplish this revolution, he had been driven from the State, and compelled to abandon his office.

abstract: The importance of establishing camps of instruction for out volunteers, similar to those used for the education of new levies in the French army, is now universally admitted by those who have given military affairs any serious attention.
lead_paragraph: The importance of establishing camps of instruction for our volunteers, similar to those used for the education of new levies in the French army, is now universally admitted by those who have given military affairs any serious attention. Nevertheless, this essential feature in the conduct of the war for the Union is threatened with serious embarrassment and injury from the natural eagerness of the several States to have a camp or camps of instruction established within their respective borders, -- quite overlooking the fact that all military experience is in favor of making those camps as large as possible, in order to accustom both officers and men to the harmonious movements of such vast bodies of troops as must be called into play in a campaign or battle; and that it has also been found desirable to bring together in these immense military schools all the elements that are expected to cooperate, subsequently on the march and in the field. Men from all the departments and colonies of France are thus brought together, and imbued as much as possible with common feelings and discipline -- taught to know and value each other as members of the same army, and furnished with that stimulus of rivalry which so rapidly promotes the acquisition of knowledge.
