abstract: THE MURDER IN WEST-STREET.--Coroner JACKMAN yesterday investigated the circumstances attending the murder of WILLIAM LEE, a private in the First Regiment Scott Life Guard, who was shot on Monday morning, at a drinking-saloon, corner of Morris and West streets, by ...
lead_paragraph: THE MURDER IN WEST-STREET. -- Coroner JACKMAN yesterday investigated the circumstances attending the murder of WILLIAM LEE, a private in the First Regiment Scott Life Guard, who was shot on Monday morning, at a drinking-saloon, corner of Morris and West streets, by ALBERT UHL, the bar-keeper. There were several witnesses of the affray, and their testimony before the Coroner corresponded in all essential particulars. The evidence of MICHAEL VALLERY, a fireman on the steamer Harriet Lane, tells the whole story of the affair. He deposed that LEE was absent from his regiment on furlough, and was going back to his camp on the day of the occurrence. Having met several of his friends in West-street, of whom the witness was one, the party stood chatting on the corner, until finally the witness invited all to take a drink. They went into the saloon at the corner of Morris and West streets, and after having taken refreshments, the witness and bar-keeper had some words about the payment. Witness stated that he had no money, but would return in the evening and settle for the liquor. The barkeeper replied with an oath, that he would not be "burned" out of his property in that way. Witness then started for the door, and had got three or four feet from the bar, when the prisoner followed and hit him on the head with a club, which staggered him somewhat. As quickly as he recovered, he turned upon the barkeeper, but was restrained from striking him by a man named KELLY, The deceased then walked toward the bar and asked the prisoner why he struck the witness, at the same moment lifting a water-pitcher as if to throw it. The prisoner instantly produced his revolver and shy deceased, who fell to the floor insensible. He was removed to the Hospital. None of the party were threatening the prisoner at the time he fired at the deceased. Witness never had a disturbance at the place before, and did not know whether the prisoner knew him or not. Officer DAVIN, of the Twenty-seventh Precinct, testified that he arrested the prisoner, and Dr. HALL, of the Hospital, was examined as to the nature of the wound which caused the man's death. The jury declared that the deceased had died "from a pistol-shot wound inflicted by the prisoner, ALBERT UHL," who was committed by the Coroner pending action of the Grand Jury. The prisoner is a native of Germany, 23 years of age. He admitted having fired the pistol, but said that it was done in self-defence.

abstract: At a meeting of the Kings County Board of Supervisors held yesterday, Supervisor KIRBY, chairman of the Commission appointed to distribute the $50,000 voted two months ago by the Board for the benefit of the families of the volunteers, reported that all except about $4,000 of the $50,000 had been used and asking for further instructions. As the Thirteenth, Twenty-eighth, Seventy-first, Twelfth, Sixty-ninth and other regiments containing men whose families have been aided by this Committee, had returned, it was thought not advisable now to appropriate a large sum for the families of those remaining in the service and of those who may go, until a more systematic plan could be adopted to raise the money by bonds instead of directly from taxes. As this seemed to be the general feeling of the members, and as $10,000 was deemed sufficient to enable the Committee to meet their engagements until next meeting, that sum was therefore voted. There was no disposition manifested to shrink from voting a sufficient sum of money, but it was thought that an arrangement could be made to raise money on bonds so as to throw the burden of payment, in part upon the tax-payers in future years.

abstract: Much has been said of the vast increase of taxation which the war will occasion, and the direct tax of $20,000,000 required by the re  cent law of Congress, is referred to by ...
lead_paragraph: Much has been said of the vast increase of taxation which the war will occasion, and the direct tax of $20,000,000 required by the re cent law of Congress, is referred to by a numerous class of croakers, as an evidence of the onerous burthens which the people will be compelled to bear to order to prosecute it vigorously and to a successful issue. A very little figuring will show the extent of this burthen and how light it will in fact be. The portion of the $20,000,000 tax assigned to the State of New-York is $2,003,918. From this will be deducted 15 per cent. fur collection by the State, amounting to $390,787, leaving the amount to be paid $2,214,081. To meet this, a tax of only one mill find a-half on the dollar will be required.

abstract: "The secret sessions of Congress," says the Examiner, "are occupied with the maturing of a plan of financial policy for the Government, which will be permanent during the war. It is understood that the debate on this subject presents a single alternative, on which the sentiment of Congress is much divided, it is, whether the Government should extend the produce-loan, or whether it should take the control of the crops of cotton, sugar and tobacco, as purchaser. Each plan has its respective advantages. The latter, however, is considered more direct, more available, and comprehending a larger mutuality of advantages, and is recommended by views, contained in memorials to Congress, of some of the largest planters and most important capitalists of the South.

abstract: A gentleman recently from Jacksonville, gives us some interesting statements touching the present position of the various ports of Florida, and how easy the rebels of that State, and also of Georgia and South Carolina, supply themselves and keep up communication with the outside world. So far as is known, there is no blockade of any of the harbors and inlets from Brunswick, Georgia, to Indian River.

abstract: THE END IS NOT YET. -- Let not our people deceive themselves with the notion that either the first or second battle of Bull Run is decisive, or likely to terminate the campaign on the Potomac. Facts do not justify such hopes, nor our position warrant the expectation. The forces of SCOTT must, of necessity, be demoralized by the brilliant action that has crowned the Southern arms with victory over great odds. But the invading army is neither destroyed nor captured. Our forces are comparatively quite small. Washington is not taken. It is strongly intrenched, and SCOTT has available many more troops than ourselves. The forces that have just been, routed will be rallied, reinforced, and brought back into the field with every precaution and advantage that generalship and military resources can furnish. The prestige and position of the Abolition Government, no less than SCOTT's reputation, urge them to prompt and peculiar efforts to retrieve the late severe check they have met with. MCCLELLAN has already been sent for. Circumstances all point to a speedy renewal of battle on the Potomac. The next struggle will be one of life or death to the invaders -- of great importance to us in regard to the time of the war. It is to be hoped that our own brave forces will be properly strengthened, and our able and indefatigable Generals put in condition not only to defeat and discomfit, but to annihilate the enemy, and drive his remnant from the polluted soil of Maryland, and soon end the war.

abstract: An election was held in Kentucky, on the 3d inst., for State Treasurer and for Members of the General Assmebly. The returns indicate an overwhelming triumph of the Union men. Three times now has Kentucky solemnly proclaimed to the world her determina  tion to stand by the Union.
lead_paragraph: An election was held in Kentucky, on the 3d inst., for State Treasurer and for Members of the General Assmebly. The returns indicate an overwhelming triumph of the Union men. Three times now has Kentucky solemnly proclaimed to the world her determina tion to stand by the Union. First, in the election in February for members of the Peace Conference, when a majority of 80,000 votes was cast for the Union candidates. But in that case the relative strength of parties was not accurately expressed, for the Secessionists, foreseeing their inevitable defeat and wishing to escape the consequent loss of prestige, withdrew their candidate before election day, leaving only the Union men to vote. Secondly, in the election of members to the present Congress on the 20th day of June; when every district was contested, and Vice-President BRECKINRIDGE took the stump in behalf of the Secessionists. A decisive and crushing victory of the unionists was the result. Nine districts out of ten wore carried, and the aggregate majority in the State against the Secessionists was near 60,000 votes.
headline: {'main': 'Kentucky Still for the Union.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Kentucky Still for the Union.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: It may yet
lead_paragraph: It may yet prove fortunate for the National forces that the rebels do not profit by our experience, and refuse to give politicians military positions. Mr. ROBERT TOOMBS, Secretary of State, has, we are informed, left that position to take the field as Brigadier-General, and HOWELL COBB has laid down the Speaker's mallet, which he has so long wielded in the "Provisional" Congress, to lead a regiment of Georgians. Although the Confederates do now and then make an un-Wise appointment, as recent events in Western Virginia demonstrate, it must, at least, be admitted that they have preserved the harmonies in these more recent promotions; for, mournful as the fact may be, they were sadly in need of General TOOMBS after the battle in front of Manassas, and in view of the approaching scarcity of provisions among them, what could be more appropriate than to put a Colonel on their COBB.

abstract: The action taken by the Republican State Committee, which met at Albany yesterday, is of the highest importance. Seventeen out of the twenty-four members were present. They were in session but two hours, and adjourned subject to the call of the officers, after adopting ...
lead_paragraph: The action taken by the Republican State Committee, which met at Albany yesterday, is of the highest importance. Seventeen out of the twenty-four members were present. They were in session but two hours, and adjourned subject to the call of the officers, after adopting a resolution providing for the appointment of a Committee of Five, to wait upon the Democratic State Committee which meets in Albany to-morrow, to invite them to call their Convention for the same time and place as that of the Republicans, for the purpose of uniting in the nomination of a Union ticket, pledged to a vigorous prosecution of the war, and the restoration of the authority of the Constitution in all sections of the country. This Committee of Five, which consists of Messrs. Opdyke, Draper, Strong, Dart and Allen, is also empowered to act for the State Committee in fixing the time and place for holding the Convention.

abstract: -- JOHN WRIGHT, lately deceased, of the firm of WRIGHT, BROTHER & CO., made the following liberal bequests. The total amount bequeathed is $100,000, and it is to be divided as follows: One moiety, or equal half part thereof, to be divided between the Pennsylvania institution for the Blind, Pennsylvania Institution for the Deaf and Dumb, the Pennsylvania Hospital for the Insane, the Willis' Hospital and House of Refuge. The other moiety, or equal half part, to be divided between the Society of the Sons of St. George, the Union School and Children's Home, the Northern Home for Friendless Children, the Rosine Association, the Philadelphia Lying-in Charity, the Union Benevolent Society of Philadelphia, the Pennsylvania Training School for Idiotic and Feeble-Minded Children, and the Widows and and Single Women's Society. To the Industrial and Beneficial Institute of Frankford, $1,000. -- Philadelphia Ledger, Aug. 6.

abstract: There is a hopeful sign that reason is not entirely extinguished in Dixie. So far from it, we are happy to say, that a livelier and more ingenious puzzle now occupies the public attention of the secession States than for a long time has been before their astute statesmen.
lead_paragraph: There is a hopeful sign that reason is not entirely extinguished in Dixie. So far from it, we are happy to say, that a livelier and more ingenious puzzle now occupies the public attention of the secession States than for a long time has been before their astute statesmen. The question is this: Does the blockade in reality benefit or hurt the people of the South? If the colleges were not all closed, and the "boys" gone to the war, we should expect to hear every debating society in the eloquent region south of Mason and Dixon's line canvassing this question. It would quite put aside those other two perennial questions in polemics: Is there more happiness in the pursuit of an object, or in its possession? --Was England right in her treatment of BONAPARTE? The New-Orleans papers' vow that their citizens never lived so cheaply or so well as since the blockade was established at the mouth of the Mississippi. Flour has fallen to a lower price than has been known for years, because none can be shipped away. Meat is so cheap that the poorest can eat it three times a day. Sugar sells at minimum prices, and thus makes up for the slight advance that has taken place on coffee. And lastly and chiefly, the blockade has kept foreign vessels and yellow fever away, and men, instead of going off with "Yellow Jack" and the black vomit, are spared to die gloriously for their country.

abstract: Whatever may be the result of the war to the rebellious States, the North can reap from it nothing but good. How, even should the South prove strong enough to maintain its independence, that independence should prove anything but a curse it is impossible to see; but the task is not difficult to show the immense gain accruing to the loyal States from this contest for principle and for the Union.

abstract: POLICEMAN MURDERED BY A BURGLAR--ARREST OF THE MURDERER.--At about 12  o'clock Monday night, Mr. ATTISON, residing at No. 128 Adamsstreet, heard a burglar at work at the house adjoining, No. 130 occupied by Mr. SANXAY. Mr. ATTISON at once proceeded to the street, and called for the Police, when the burglar ran down Pearl to Prospectstreet, in the direction of Fulton Ferry, hotly pursued by several citizens.
lead_paragraph: POLICEMAN MURDERED BY A BURGLAR -- ARREST OF THE MURDERER. -- At about 12 1/2 o'clock Monday night, Mr. ATTISON, residing at No. 128 Adams-street, heard a burglar at work at the house adjoining, No. 130, occupied by Mr. SANXAY. Mr. ATTISON at once proceeded to the street, and called for the Police, when the burglar ran down Pearl to Prospect-street, in the direction of Fulton Ferry, hotly pursued by several citizens. At the corner of Prospect and Washington streets, the burglar was overtaken and seized by Officer DAVID MARTIN, of the Second Precinct. The officer had scarcely taken hold of him when the burglar stabbed him twice on the left side of the neck, severing the jugular vein, and causing death in less than 15 minutes. As the burglar made the second plunge with the knife, Officer MARTIN dealt him a blow on the head with his club, which knocked him senseless to the sidewalk, where he remained a few seconds, and then attempted to make his escape. Fortunately Officer BUCK, of the Second, and Officer HARROLD, of the First Precincts, heard the disturbance, and came up in time to capture the assassin. He was taken to the Station-house and locked up, but refused to give any account of himself, except that he was a native of Ohio, and that his name was JOHN WILLETTS, neither of which assertions are believed to be true. On his person was found 32 skeleton keys, a full set of burglar's tools, false whiskers and hair. The deceased leaves a widow and three children, who reside at No. 32 Stanton-street. When stabbed MARTIN was taken to the office of Dr. GILFILLAN, but he was beyond the reach of medical skill. Dr. BAUER, assisted by Drs. COOPER and WILLETTS, made a post mortem examination of the body yesterday afternoon, when they rendered a verdict "that the deceased came to his death by hemorrhage from the left subclavian vein, near its junction with the common jugular vein, having been incised by a dirk-knife which was planned into the chest from above the left collar-bone." Coroner HORTON will commence an investigation of the case at 2 o'clock this afternoon.

abstract: Gen. LYON has signalized his campaign in Missouri by another brilliant feat of arms. BEN. MCCULLOCH has had an opportunity to measure strength with him, and has been decidedly worsted. Gen. LYON received information on Thursday last that the enemy was approaching St. Louis in three columns, numbering 20,000 men, and immediately started out to meet him, with five complete regiments of volunteers, two or three companies of regular infantry, and two or three companies of regular cavalry. He met MCCULLOCH the next day, at a place called Dug Springs, about 19 miles southwest of Springfield, when a fight took place between 4 and 6 o'clock in the afternoon. The principal feature of the battle was a charge of Gen. LYON's cavalry, numbering two hundred and seventy, against a body of rebel infantry, estimated at from two to four thousand. They came upon this force suddenly, and being in a position where it was inconvenient to retreat, cut their way through it with the loss of only five men, including the Lieutenant commanding. The enemy then made their appearance in large numbers, but was speedily dispersed by Gen. LYON with his artillery -- the infantry not being brought into action at all. The rebels then retreated southward, and subsequently took up another position on the Fayettsville road, at a place known as McCulloch's store. At last accounts, Gen. LYON had strongly intrenched himself in the vicinity of the enemy, who were expected to attack him soon. Considerable excitement was occasioned on Tuesday at St. Louis by a report that a body of five thousand rebels, taking advantage of Gen. LYON's absence, was approaching the City to take possession of it, and vigorous measures were taken to repel them. They did not, however, make their appearance.
lead_paragraph: Gen. LYON has signalized his campaign in Missouri by another brilliant feat of arms. BEN. They came upon this force suddenly, and being in a position where it was inconvenient to retreat, cut their way through it with the loss of only five men, including the Lieutenant commanding. The enemy then made their appearance in large numbers, but was speedily dispersed by Gen. LYON with his artillery -- the infantry not being brought into action at all. The rebels then retreated southward, and subsequently took up another position on the Fayettsville road, at a place known as McCulloch's store. At last accounts, Gen. LYON had strongly intrenched himself in the vicinity of the enemy, who were expected to attack him soon. Considerable excitement was occasioned on Tuesday at St. Louis by a report that a body of five thousand rebels, taking advantage of Gen. LYON's absence, was approaching the City to take possession of it, and vigorous measures were taken to repel them. They did not, however, make their appearance.

abstract: From a gentleman recently arrived from Naasau, N.P., we learn that the inhabitants are largely in favor of the secession cause, and every report of disasters to the Union troops is hailed with delight. They express their belief that the result of the contest can be only in the recognition of the Southern Confederacy. They derive their information of our affairs mostly from Southern papers, although their trade is almost entirely with the North.

abstract: The Chamber of Commerce held a special meeting yesterday, for the purpose of welcoming home Hon. J.A. WRIGHT, late United States Minister to Prussia. There was a fair attendance of the members. Mr. PELATIAM PERRIT, the President, introduced Mr. WRIGHT in appropriate terms, when he arose and addressed the Chamber in a speech of some length, upon the state of our National affairs. He referred to the patriotic course pursued by the merchants in their prompt and munificent response to the wants of the Government in furnishing the means for carrying on the war, and also to their liberal subscriptions for the same purpose. He had arrived here after an absence of four years, to contemplate with sorrow, though not with despair, the condition of his beloved country. He rejoiced to see that the time for the exhibition of party feelings had gone by, and that the effort of every true citizen was put forth to sustain the Government in its hour of trial. He belonged to a school of politicians who acknowledged only the sovereignty of the General Government, and which did not divide their allegiance with any State; that stood up for the Constitution founded by WASHINGTON, JEFFERSON, and FRANKLIN. That Government had sheltered him at home, and protected him abroad, and to it he owed all allegiance. The first duty of the citizen was to defend his country. The German people, as a whole, were heartily in favor of the American Union, and were ready to assist by their lives in defending it. He received the warmest personal assurances from the King himself that he prayed for the perpetuity and prosperity of our whole Government, and he said, on the occasion of his taking final leave of him, "God grant you may succeed in sustaining. the integrity of the old Union." [Applause.] If they desired the support of European Governments, they must depend upon themselves. He referred to the vacillating course of the public Press of Europe, and particularly to the tone of the London Times. That paper had declared that the South was a unit, and that the North was divided. The Press had been subsidized in the interests of the South, and foreign gold was being employed here to undermine and destroy the country and our institutions. We should, he said, not depend on outside support and sympathy until every effort of our own had been exhausted to sustain the Constitution. The European masses loved liberty. His house had been besieged by persons who wished to enlist in the armies of the Union, and he was at last compelled to put up a notice that his was not a recruiting office. The German troops were slow to move, but they always moved right; their impulses were strong for freedom. Wherever a good cause needs assistance, they were prompt to lend a helping hand, and no nation responded more heartily when appealed to in behalf of public liberty. [Cheers.] He had received hundreds of letters of sympathy from all parts of Germany. He saw an affecting instance of devotion to home and country while abroad. An American lady who had been stricken down by disease, when dying, asked that she might first embrace her little child, and then that she might be wrapt in the American flag and expire in its folds, as a testimony of her love for her country. The people of the South would say to him as ABRAHAM said to LOT, "Let there be no strife between us, turn thee to the right or to the left as it pleaseth thee." But ABRAHAM would not have said this had LOT overturned all the sacred arrangements of his household, and conspired to overthrow the patriarchal government and all that ABRAHAM held sacred. When the South should cease to pull down the pillars of the Constitution, and give over their efforts to subvert the fabric of government, then he would listen to them. Until rebellious hands were no longer raised in this suicidal work, let millions of money and thousands of lives, if need be, be laid upon the altar of patriotism, to maintain the supremacy of the Constitution. [Applause.] He was ready to hail with joy the day which should restore peace to the country, but he devoutly prayed that we might have no peace that was not founded in principle.

abstract: MARY MCPHERSON, a stalwart dame, of Caledonian extraction, was arrested yesterday on a charge of having attempted to shoot a man named JAMES POWERS, whose residence is at No. 33 Division-street. Some time since the parties lived together in the married relation, but a separation occurred in consequence of incompatibility of temperament, and since that time the women has cherished enmity towards the complainant. Meeting him on Tuesday evening, she produced a pistol and fired at his bead. The bail, however, missed the mark, and POWERS took measures to have her perished. Justice OSREEN committed the accused for trial.

abstract: The crew for the United States sailing-frigate Potomac, 50, was mustered on board the receiving ship North Carolina yesterday, at the Brooklyn Navyyard. They will number about 500 all told.
lead_paragraph: The crew for the United States sailing-frigate Potomac, 50, was mustered on board the receiving ship North Carolina yesterday, at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. They will number about 500 all told. The Potomac was reported ready for sea yesterday, and orders to put her in commission are expected to-day. Her officers are to be present at the Lyceum this morning.

abstract: The Southern journals which we receive through Adams' Express, have partially recovered, from the spirit of wild exultation into which they were thrown by the first news of the rebel victory at Manassas, and look at matters more reasonably. Thus the Memphis Appeal, which was more extravagant in its first outbursts than any of its contemporaries, has come to comprehend that the "haughty spirit of the supercilious Yankee" has not been conquered, and that, "slung with the shame of their defeat, they are making new and vigorous efforts to crown their next advance upon us with at least a reasonable hope of success." It announces that Gen. MCCLELLAN, "the most experienced strategist, and in fact the ablest officer in the National Army, except the Commander-in-Chief,"has been called to Washington, and that now great care is to be taken in recruiting, &c. Hence it comes to this conclusion: "It is well for us, we repeat to open our eyes to a proper appreciation of these stubborn facts, and act in such a manner as to fearlessly confront the consequences flowing from them. There can be no doubt of the fact that we have already broken the backbone of this war upon the South, and, by one or two more strokes as signal and telling as the one at Manassas, can handsomely finish our work. The difficulty is, that the North will never acknowledge its inability to conquer us, until the fact is demonstrated by experience."

abstract: Virginia, more than any other State in or at present out of the Union, is responsible for the heresies which underlie the present rebellion, and it is but a just retribution that the chief weight of its chastisement should fall upon her. The tendency of the extreme doctrines of Virginia on the subject of State rights has been everywhere, and especially at the South, instrumental in weakening the sentiment of loyalty to the National Government and paving the way to revolt against its authority. The idea of superior allegiance to the State has for many years been a peculiar feature of Virginia radicalism. JEFFERSON, MADISON, MONROE -- all her early statesmen denounced it as a fatal heresy, destructive to the harmony and prosperity of the Union. But on the demise of these patriotic men. Democracy ran wild in Virginia, and under the influence of her new political leaders it became a fundamental article of democratic faith, that the allegiance of every citizen was due first to his State, and that the residuum of fealty only belonged to the Union.

lead_paragraph: The authorities of the Central Park will provide, occasionally, musical concerts during the season. The first will occur on the Mall, on Saturday, the 10th inst., at 4 1/3 P.M., if the weather is fine. The selection will be of popular music, for which purpose Dodworth's Band has been engaged.

abstract: Some of the officers of the Thirteenth Regiment, not having had sufficient fighting in the service of their country, wound up yesterday by a set-to in Gen. COOK's office, where they accidentally met. Col. ABEL SMITH, Lieut.-Col. CLARK, and Quartermaster MUMBY, were the belligerent parties. Having met at the office of the General, their difficulties at Baltimore were renewed, when it is alleged that Col. SMITH made some belligerent demonstrations, and was pitched into a la Hyer by Lieut.-Col. CLARK and Quartermaster MUMBY. The parties were separated before any serious damage had been done, when Col. SMITH preferred a complaint before a Justice of the Peace, against CLARK and MUMBY, for assault and battery. The case will be investigated on Friday afternoon.

abstract: The schooner Abbie Forrest, from Eletheura, reports that on the 4th inst., in lat. 36° 45', long. 75° 24', she was boarded by an office from the United States ship Vincennes, bound south on a cruise. The officer reported having seen a suspicious steamer the day previous, but there being no wind, he could not give chase to her. On the 4th, passed a large quantity of cask shooks. On the 5th, passed near the lower mast of a square-rigged vessel having the rigging and top attached; had not been long in that situation and appeared to have been cut away. It was reported at Eletheura, but not generally credited, that a topsail schooner privateer was in Crooked Island Passage.

abstract: In the House of Commons on the 25th, Sir C. WOOD made some financial explanations relative to India, and asked for discretionary power to burrow 25,000,000 for railway purposes. He said the Govern  ment had evinced great anxiety to develop the resources of India as a cotton-producing country. He believed the result would be that ultimately England...
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons on the 25th, Sir C. WOOD made some financial explanations relative to India, and asked for discretionary power to borrow 5,000,000 for railway purposes. He believed at the end of the present year the Indian expenditure and income would be balanced. He said the Government had evinced great anxiety to develop the resources of India as a cotton-producing country. He believed the result would be that ultimately England would be rendered independent of America for cotton. This year the supply of Cotton from India would be about 300,000 bales more than ever before.

abstract: PETER CONNER, a laborer, employed at LAMONT's sugar refinery, in One Hundred and fifty-eighth-street, near the North River, died on Tuesday evening, from the effects of the heat. A unknown man was found on Tuesday afternoon, in a dying condition, upon the sidewalk in First-avenue, near Fifty-eighth-street. He was removed to the Nineteenth Precinct Station-House, where he shortly afterwards expired, seemingly from exhaustion consequent upon the extreme heat. Coroner JACKMAN hold an inquest in each case.

abstract: The steamship Columbia, on her outward passage to Havana, on Thursday, July 25, at 7 P.M., lat. 32° 44', lon. 78° 19', passed a small fore-and-aft schooner, pilot-boat build, with her mainsail reefed and jib furled; had no name on her stern; had something amidships, covered with canvas -- undoubtedly a gun. She is, without doubt, the same vessel described in the papers of July 23, about 60 feel long, and painted a deep lead color. On our approach she hoisted the American ensign, which saved her from being handled rather rough. As soon as we passed her she made all sail. As to her being one of the piratical vessels which infest our coast there is but little doubt. The Columbia left at Key West, July 28, (outward trip,) the United States steamer Macedonian, and steamers Crusader, Water Witch and Salvor. The steam-frigate Niagara sailed same day on a cruise.

abstract: Hard as the war we are now engaged in may bear upon individual interests, and calamitous as it doubtless is, for the time, to the commerce and trade of the country, yet it has its elements of good as well as of evil. The American people, in their fierce pursuit of those vast material enterprises, of the success of which we boast so much, were in danger of forgetting the necessity of providing for the possible contingencies of the future. More than three-quarters of a century of internal repose, and, with the exception of three or four years, of peace with all the world, afforded an opportunity of developing the natural resources of the country, of changing continental forests to farms and fields, of building up cities and towns; of creating for ourselves a world-wide commerce, and of advancement in a career of progress that carried us to a high position in the scale of nations. But this long period of peace made us negligent of preparing for the accident of war.In our prosperity we overlooked the teachings of history. The fallacy that the future would be as the past, that the Union would never be disturbed by internal revolt, because it never had been, that the people and the States would always be loyal to the Constitution, because they had never been otherwise, came to be with us an article of political faith, upon the assumed truth of which the policy of our Government was based. We kept no standing Army, because we had no martial neighbors whose enmity we feared, or whose power we had occasion to dread. Even the militia of the States came to be contemned as a useless pageant, and was fast falling into disrepute under the ridicule it attracted by its broad caricature of war. Thus, while all our energies were directed towards the accomplishment of physical enterprises, the martial spirit, so essential to the maintenance of the power and strength of a great nation, was fast dying out. We were warned of possible insurrection -- of collision between the State and National Governments. We laughed at the folly of the admonition. We refused to listen to the roar of the cataract, even when its sound was in our ears, until in sight of the rapids down which the inevitable drift lay. We started at last from our dream of security, to see treason organized into open revolt, without a preparation in advance to meet it. We had no Army, no arms, no munitions of war; and for the time, the Government was at the mercy of a rebellion whose conspiracies had been ripening for years. Up to this time we had scarcely thought of country or of home. We had given no consideration to the idea that we might one day be required to preserve the power inherent in a united people by compelling national unity. Our prosperity was our boast and our idol, and in our folly we did not admit, even to ourselves, the possibility of its interruption. We had come to measure everything, even the Union itself, by the standard of commercial value.

abstract: With light receipts and a good inquiry, holders of State and Western Flour have been enabled to sell their supplies more advantageously to-day, the market being decidedly firmer, with an upward tendency. The reported sales reach 18,258 bbls., including Superfine State of $4 20@$4 25; poor to choice Extra State at $4 40@$4 80, mainly at $4 45@$4 50, afloat and delivered; Superfine Western at $4 15@$4 25; extra Iowa, Wisconsin and Illinois, at $4 40@$5 50; extra Indiana and Michigan at $4 45@$5 60; inferior extra Ohio at $4 85@$4 90; round-hoop extra Ohio, Shipping brands, at $4 95@$5 65 bbl.

abstract: The Journal of Commerce, is in tribulation. The invitation of the Republican State Committee to the Democrats, to unite upon a State ticket this Fall, shocks its nerves. It makes no secret of its alarm, -- though it finds very great difficulty in assigning any plausible reason for opposing the union. "The proposition of the Republicans," says the Journal, "in plain English is, to invite the Democrats to surrender their political principles and associations." To this the Journal cannot consent. It protests against any such surrender, even for the sake of uniting the people of the State still more thoroughly in defending the Government against destruction.

abstract: Col. BURNSIDE had a splendid reception at Newport, the other day, and made a speech of acknowledgment, in which he gave some interesting statements concerning the battle at Bull Run. The Providence Journal says that upon the propriety of attacking the enemy at the time it was made, Col. BURNSIDE expressed himself unreservedly. He said: "I called upon Gen. MCDOWELL and expressed my dissent to the policy of fighting the enemy at that time. Senator WILSON was present, and looked at me when I made the remark as though I was a coward. Gen. MCDOWELL said, if I do not fight them to-morrow I cannot do it in six months. Better, said I, wait that time than hazard a battle now. Gen. MCDOWELL invited a meeting of officers at his head-quarters on the night before the battle, but he (MCDOWELL) was not present until 10 o'clock, and then nothing was to be heard but the reception of orders for the following day. On the return of our troops to Washington, I felt so much anxiety about the fate of that city, that I tendered them for its defence to Gen. SCOTT, not doubting they would stay a few days after the expiration of the term of service. He replied, 'There is no danger.' Two days afterwards, in company with Gov. SPRAGUE, I called upon Gen. SCOTT, and repeated my apprehensions, and renewed the offer of assistance. Gen. SCOTT gave me in detail his reasons for not apprehending an attack on Washington, and told what the rebels would do, and, added Col. BURNSIDE, with emphasis, everything that the old General predicted then has been confirmed."

abstract: Capt. W. SALTUS RICHARDSON, of the brig Naiad, one of the vessels which fell into the hands of the privateer Sumter, and which was afterwards released, has just arrived here in company with the brigs Ben Dunning and Machias, and gives the following statement of his experience with the pirates.

abstract: FUNERAL OF OFFICER MARTIN. -- The funeral of Officer MARTIN, of the Second Precinct, who was killed by a burglar at the corner of Prospect and Washington-streets, Monday night, took place yesterday afternoon from his late residence, No. 32 Stanton-street. The services at the house were conducted by Rev. W.H. MILBURN, after which a procession was formed and the body escorted to its final resting-place in Greenwood Cemetery. The procession was composed of 225 Policemen from New-York, about 100 of the Brooklyn force, and some 25 carriages. The Police of the Second Precinct acted as a body-guard, and Deputy-Inspectors DICKS and FOLK rode at the head of the line. Accompanied by a band of music, the procession passed through Fulton and Court-streets to the place of burial. The murderer of Officer MARTIN has been identified as a notorious burglar named CURTIS, well known to the Police of New-York. The Police of the Second Precinct on Tuesday raised a purse of $300 for the family of Officer MARTIN, and arrangements are now on foot to place the family above ward.

abstract: The Richmond Dispatch is delighted to hear that T.F. MEAGHER was among the killed at Bull Run. It thinks he deserves his fate, for fighting against Virginia, after that State voted against the Know-Nothings three or four years ago. This is perfectly characteristic of the Secessionists. They cannot understand how it is that the Democrats of the North can resist their breaking up the Union, after they have voted together so long. They seem to think that their political services ought to be requited by aiding them to destroy the Government.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Columbia, Capt. ADAMS, we have advices from Havana to the 3d inst. There is no extraordinary news. The Captain-General of Cuba is absent at St. Domingo taking formal possession of the Dominican territory for the Spanish crown. No foreign vessels-of-war in Havana. The people are quiet, although depredations upon the community by robbers of the highways and streets seem to be on the increase. The markets have been active. Sugars for Nos. 11 and 12 at 7 1/3 to 8 reals per arroba, but the qualities not fine, of the small stock remaining 120,000 boxes in this City against 250,000 boxes in 1859 at same date. Molasses -- slight movement; Clayed at 2 reals per keg and Muscovado at 3 reals per keg. In freight there is no business offering for American vessels. Other flags, Falmouth and orders, varies L2 1s. 8d. to L2 7s. 8d. per ton, not Spanish invoice weight. Exchanges in regular demand, moving at London 60 days' sight at 13 7/8 to 16 prcm., New-York 5 [???] 6 do., United States gold coins at 6 to -- premium, Mexican Dollars 4 1/2 to 5 do. Money plenty for speculation or trade.

abstract: We republish another of Mr. RUSSELL'S letters to the London Times. Mr. RUSSELL insists that he was right in saying that the people of New-York, at the time of his first arrival, evinced none of that intense hostility to secession which they have...
lead_paragraph: We republish another of Mr. RUSSELL's letters to the London Times. It was written from Washington just after his return from the Southern States, and is mainly a descrip tion of the changed condition of Northern sentiment concerning the secession movement. Mr. RUSSELL insists that he was right in saying that the people of New-York, at the time of his first arrival, evinced none of that intense hostility to secession which they have since displayed. Indeed, he thinks the Secessionists have reason to complain of something very like duplicity on their part, and to charge them with deserting them after having given them very substantial encouragement, in word and act, to enter upon the work of destroying the Union.

abstract: MICHAEL WELSH, a lad eleven years of age, whose parents live at No. 31 Oak-street, was drowned on Tuesday evening, while bathing off Pier No. 31 East River. His body was not recovered. FRANCIS MCCABE, a youth of fourteen years, was drowned on Tuesday evening while bathing at the foot of Thirteenth-street, East River. Yesterday his body was recovered and taken to his late home. No. 391 Third-avenue, where Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest upon it.

abstract: It was to be expected that the war would deal a severe blow to commercial and business affairs. The dullness from this cause is heightened by the season of the year, when, in the best of times, little is doing. But we think we are now justified in taking for the future a more cheerful view, and in predicting, as soon as the cool weather sets in, a decided revival of business, and a reasonable activity in all the leading branches of our industry.
lead_paragraph: It was to be expected that the war would deal a severe blow to commercial and business affairs. abstract: ALLEGED MURDER AT ENGLISH NEIGHBORHOOD. -- On Tuesday night an affray occurred between a man named CARR, residing at English Neighborhood, and TAYLOR, toll-gate-keeper on the Hackensack Turnpike, resulting in the death of CARR. It is stated that CARR passed through the gate, when a dispute arose in reference to the toll, and upon his return the quarrel was renewed, and TAYLOR drew a carving-knife and stabbed CARR through one of his lungs, causing instant death. He then made his escape. An investigation will take place to-day.
lead_paragraph: ALLEGED MURDER AT ENGLISH NEIGHBORHOOD. -- On Tuesday night an affray occurred between a man named CARR, residing at English Neighborhood, and TAYLOR, toll-gate-keeper on the Hackensack Turnpike, resulting in the death of CARR. It is stated that CARR passed through the gate, when a dispute arose in reference to the toll, and upon his return the quarrel was renewed, and TAYLOR drew a carving-knife and stabbed CARR through one of his lungs, causing instant death. He then made his escape. An investigation will take place to-day.

abstract: Yesterday, says the Philadelphia Ledger of Aug. 6, Mr. CHEW, of Germantown, applied to Judge LUDLOW for an injunction to prevent Senator MASON from taking money out of the estate in which he is interested, located in this county. In asking for the order, Mr. CHEW said: "I apply to your honor for an order to prevent JAMES M. MASON from taking out of the jurisdiction of the Court funds which the Trustees have invested under the order of the Orphan's Court. Already a very large sum has been taken out of the State by that very remarkable traitor, and I have no prospect of ever getting retribution if the balance of the funds is taken away." Judge LUDLOW suggested that a citation might be issued, and notice could be made by publication. Senator MASON has ten days in which to appear and answer.

abstract: On Tuesday we published a telegraphic report of the Proclamation of Gov. GAMBLE, the Provisional Governor of Missouri, to the people of that state, which contained, as we construed the document, most grave and unjust reflection on the troops of the United States.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday we published a telegraphic report of the Proclamation of Gov. GAMBLE, the Provisional Governor of Missouri, to the people of that state, which contained, as we construed the document, most grave and unjust reflection on the troops of the United States. We considered the employment of such language inconsistent with a heartfelt loyalty and respect for the National Government, and calculated even to sow the seeds of sedition in the hearts of the people of Missouri. And we so expressed ourselves in most decided terms.

abstract: A letter to ELLWOOD WALTER, Esq., Secretary of the Board of Underwriters, dated Santa Cruz, Tenereiffe, June 7, says: "On the 1st of June, at S.A.M., a boat with Capt. EVANS and six men, belonging to the American brig J. Nickerson, of Boston, came into this port. Capt. EVANS reports that he sailed from Lisbon, May 22, with a cargo of wine and salt, bound to Rio Grande, Brazil; that on the 28th, in the evening, a heavy sea struck her on the port bow, causing several planks to start, and opening a leak, which increased until the 31st. At night, he and his crew abandoned the vessel, which sunk almost immediately after, about 12 miles northeast of Point Arraga, on this Island." The J. Nickerson was built at Fall River in 1847, was 198 tons, rated A 2, and was owned by the Captain, (EVANS.)

abstract: A gentleman who has resided for thirty years in Mississippi, and is well acquainted in the State, has just arrived in this City, and makes some interesting statements regarding the condition of the South. He represents that the utmost terrorism is exercised, and the whole South is subject to a military desporism. The most venerable citizens, long residents of standing in the community, are at the mercy of the mob, and unless they ??? in with the secession cry, must risk the loss of property and life. Business is stagnant; specie has all down to the region of the battle-fields; cotton is so ??? per pound. There is not leather enough to make shoes for the troops, and no safe whatever for real estate or slaves. The planters have been ??? to keep the cotton away from the seaboard, but the utmost faith is felt in their ability to whip the Yankees, and retrieve all their losses in a twelvemonth. He thinks the Southern troops number about 300,000, but admits that this is little else but guess-work, as the utmost care is taken to keep the people in ignorance on that point. None of the troops that he saw were well clad or equipped, and so great is the scarcity of arms that some regiments have been disbanded, and all the old rifles and muskets are being collected for the purpose of alteration.

abstract: Our advices from Gen. LYON'S Army are to Sunday. The Cavalry charge heretofore reported, was made by a scouting party sent out to ascertain if the enemy were approaching. abstract: Two full-sized specimens of the species of whale called by ichthyologists the Beluga Catodon, but commonly known as the white whale of the Arctic Seas, are now on exhibition at Barnum's Museum These interesting and curious fish were captured in the river St. Lawrence, near the Isle aux Coutres, on Friday last, and were brought to this City yesterday by Mr. H.D. BUTLER, to whom so many are indebted for the pleasure they experience in the possession of parlor aquaria. Mr. BUTLER's attention was drawn to these whales about two years ago by Mr. DETU, a Canadian gentleman, who forwarded two dead specimens to this City, with a variety of beautifully-finished leather, which had been manufacturing of their skins. Being impressed with the idea that living specimens might be obtained, Mr. BUTLER conceived the purpose of making an expedition to the St. Lawrence to procure them. A schooner was chattered at Quebec, fitted with all the appliances necessary for the capture of the fish, with a crew well skilled in the art of taking them. The point selected was near la Riviere Orelle, below the Saginaw, where the St. Lawrence is about 16 miles wide. A trap several acres in extent was constructed of poles, into which the fish were decoyed and captured. The rise and fall of the tide which is some 20 fact at this point of the river, greatly aided the enterprise, leaving the fish nearly dry at low water. Large tanks had been prepared, into which they were placed, and transported by the Grand Trunk Railroad to Portland, and thence to this City. The fish are as large as any of their species being 20 feet in length, and weighing 2,000 pounds each. They are perfectly white, and appear to be in good health. An immense reservoir, purposely constructed for their accommodation in the basement of the Museum, affords them ample room in which to swim. It is found necessary to keep the water in the reservoir at a low temperature by supplying it daily with tons of ice.

abstract: There is one advantage that the nation will derive from the system of direct taxation soon to be inaugurated, that should go far to recencile all good citizens to its inconveniences  and its burdens. That is, the economy it will in the end, insure in the expenditures, and the honesty in the disbursements of the Government.
lead_paragraph: There is one advantage that the nation will derive from the system of direct taxation soon to be inaugurated, that should go far to recencile all good citizens to its inconveniences and its burdens. That is, the economy it will in the end, insure in the expenditures, and the honesty in the disbursements of the Government.

abstract: "A good deal has been said," remarks the New-Haven Palladium, "about the shooting of 'an Alabama Colonel' by Capt. GORE, of the Hartford Company in the Second Regiment. We learn that the Colonel that was killed on the occasion referred to was from South Carolina--as was judged from papers found on his person. As the regiment was passing within a few rods of a wood he rode out and advanced toward them. Capt. GORE and Lieut. SCOTT, of Company H, of Hartford, immediately ran toward him with drawn swords, demanding his surrender; seeing his mistake he drew his pistol, when Lieut. SCOTT, of Company H, 'Billy' GOODYEAR, of the New-Haven Grays, and 'Jonny' PETERS, of the Palladium office, (also of the Grays,) fired at him, when he fell. As he fell, a dozen balls were put into him by both companies. Capt. GORE and Lieut. SCOTT secured his sword, pistols and sash, and Mr. PETERS brought home his wallet, containing $83 in South Carolina money and a number of papers."

lead_paragraph: The Charleston pirates remained on the Flag all night -- that vessel being anchored near the Navy-yard. Arriving at the Navy-yard gate at 10 1/2 o'clock, we found a large crowd of anxious inquirers, including many important persons, who could have bought an ordinary sized institution, but they could not come in. abstract: If it were possible to be surprised at anything that pusillanimity and treason can suggest, we might well wonder that in any portion of the loyal States there are men urging a cessation of hostilities, and a submission to the final disruption of the Government. The loyal North was recently united to a man.
lead_paragraph: If it were possible to be surprised at anything that pusillanimity and treason can suggest, we might well wonder that in any portion of the loyal States there are men urging a cessation of hostilities, and a submission to the final disruption of the Government. The loyal North was recently united to a man. After the humiliation of the National flag at Fort Sumter, there was a universal demand that the indignity should be atoned for in apology and obedience to the laws, or in blood. So spontaneous, so energetic, and so universal a cry for war was never uttered by any people. It was felt that the long catalogue of wrongs and robberies that rebellion had perpetrated had received its crowning aggravation in the insult to the flag, which is the emblem and shield of the Nation's honor. If there was any division of public sentiment when the Government was impelled to take up arms in vindication of the integrity and honor of the Republic, it was not on the necessity of the war, but on the policy of such long forbearance towards the conspirators as the Government had observed.

abstract: An Army officer has just made a must interesting estimate of the materials required by an army. He says that 50,000 men consume daily 312 tons, 10 cwt. of provisions alone, thus requiring 300 horses to carrry food enough to support them for the first four days assuming that they themselves could carry the first three days' food and 300 horses to carry the food
lead_paragraph: An Army officer has just made a must interesting estimate of the materials required by an army. He says that 50,000 men consume daily 312 tons, 10 cwt. of provisions alone, thus requiring 300 horses to carrry food enough to support them for the first four days -- assuming that they themselves could carry the first three days' food -- and 300 horses to carry the food needed every day afterwards. Thus 1,800 tons of provisions should be sent with an army commencing a week's march. Then baggage and ammunition would require at least as much more carrying material, and Cavalry ten times as much, so that an army of 50,000 properly supplied, and having a small proportion of horse soldiers, would need the services of over one thousand horses drawing a ton each, for a single day's necessaries. The march from Alexandria to Bull Run should have had nearly 3,000 carrying horses, premising that they would require food marching both ways.

abstract: War has its aesthetics as well as its ugliness; and we are free to express the opinion, that the recent combat between the U. S. frigate St.Lawrence and the C. S. privateer Petrel is the neatest thing, of the season. The story was published yesterday, and it is not a long one, because the fight itself was not long.
lead_paragraph: War has its aesthetics as well as its ugliness; and we are free to express the opinion, that the recent combat between the U.S. frigate St. Lawrence and the C.S. privateer Petrel is the neatest thing, of the season. The story was published yesterday, and it is not a long one, because the fight itself was not long. It is told in this wise: On Monday, the 29th of July, the St. Lawrence, doing duty on theblockade off Charleston harbor, whilst standing in towards Charleston, discovered a schooner displaying the rebel flag. The St. Lawrence gave chase, and, on nearing the Petrel, she hove about and stood for the St. Lawrence, and soon fired three shots at the latter -- once with grape and twice with solid shot. The frigate was struck, but no damage done. The St. Lawrence then fired twelve guns, including one shell. The shell struck the galley, knocking it to splinters, and entered the hold of the Petrel, where it exploded, causing the privateer to sink immediately.

abstract: The Washington Star says: "There are now sixty-five prisoners confined in the old brick Capitol building, corner of A North and First-street East, under a guard of soldiers who patrol the sidewalk around the building. The lower windows have been closed with boards nearly to the top, leaving only sufficient space for light and ventilation, and several smaller buildings in the rear are surrounded by a tight board fence twelve feet high, inclosing quite a space of ground for a yard. In this and the outer buildings Potomac water has been introduced, and everything rendered as comfortable and pleasant as the circumstances will permit. The prisoners are cheerful and quiet, though some are extremely bitter in their denunciations of the 'Yankee Government.' Occasionally, passing soldiers who happen to be intoxicated, address them in rather uncomplimentary terms, and with expressions which render their seclusion, for the time being, remarkably agreeable to themselves. Sometimes soldiers go still further, and when the back of the sentry is towards them, toss a brick at the first head which appears at the window. Not long since a Fire Zouave, who had several times invited them out to 'get licked,' in passing by the dining-room, tossed a brick over into the room, with the intention of 'spiting' some of them while at dinner; but they had luckily just left the table, and no damage was done. Many have been furnished with civilian's dress by friends in the city, together with many of the little luxuries of home. Their quarters are quite spacious and can accommodate a large number."
lead_paragraph: The Washington Star says: "There are now sixty-five prisoners confined in the old brick Capitol building, corner of A North and First-street East, under a guard of soldiers who patrol the sidewalk around the building. Many have been furnished with civilian's dress by friends in the city, together with many of the little luxuries of home. Their quarters are quite spacious and can accommodate a large number."

abstract: We wish to invite the attention of our manufacturing engineers to this subject, because we do not believe that Government officers who insist on low steam, heavy machinery, and boilersabove water, will have the monopoly of the designing, when the reform begun by the Bull Run disaster has ramified in the various departments.
lead_paragraph: We wish to invite the attention of our manufacturing engineers to this subject, because we do not believe that Government officers who insist on low steam, heavy machinery, and boilersabove water, will have the monopoly of the designing, when the reform begun by the Bull Run disaster has ramified in the various departments. The reason why a few extraordinarily fast war-vessels would be of the greatest value is patent to anyone who will contemplate the necessities of coast defence, cruising for pirates, and naval warfare. Half-a-dozen ships, capable of 20 knots in smooth water, would, in the first place, distance any Government or private sea-steamers in existence, either in the chase or in the retreat. They would carry the earliest intelligence, forces and supplies from squadron to squadron, and, in many cases, from fort to fort; they would run down any pirate; they would manoeuvre more rapidly than any other vessel, and they would perform, both as transports and fighting ships, all those invaluable functions which speed alone can insure. They would, in all cases, have the choice of position in an encounter, which is oftentimes worth more than impenetrable sides. Their advantages will not be questioned, although they cannot all be appreciated till actually experienced. The question is, can such ships be made at a reasonable cost?

abstract: The Democratic State Central Committee met at Albany yesterday, with a full attendance of delegates, and a large number of prominent Democrats from all parts of the State being present. The Sub-Committee of the Republican State Committee sent in a communication asking cooperation in the effort to unite the parties on a Union ticket,...
lead_paragraph: The Democratic State Central Committee met at Albany yesterday, with a full attendance of delegates, and a large number of prominent Democrats from all parts of the State being present. The Sub-Committee of the Republican State Committee sent in a communication asking cooperation in the effort to unite the parties on a Union ticket, to which the Democratic leaders returned a lengthy and labored reply, declining to enter into the proposed arrangement. It was then resolved to hold the Democratic State Convention at Syracuse on Wednesday, the 4th day of September next, and the Committee adjourned. On ascertaining the action of the Democrats, the Republican Sub-Committee, in accordance with the powers delegated to them, issued a call for the Republican State Convention to meet at Syracuse on the 11th day of September -- one week after that of the Democrats.

abstract: The Richmond Examiner is congratulating itself on the extreme simplicity of the bran-new Republicanism inaugurated by the Pro-Slavery aristocracy of the South. It is "indeed astonishing," it says, "to what a degree this simplicity has been carried." The "moral grandeur" of a Congress assembled at Richmond, without the slightest pomp or circumstance, -- no frescoed roofs or panels, no doorkeepers, no pages even, -- overcomes the Examiner with emotions too deep for utterance. "Our Congress," it says, "Our Congress has but few officers, -- a Secretary and Doorkeepers, -- with only assistants as are necessary. There are no perquisites and no sinecures: Office-beggars and lobby cormorants do not distract its legislation. The substance of the country is cared for; plainness and economy are apparently studied in the smallest matters; and the traditions of Washington corruption and extravagance are lost and forgotten to the spectator in what he sees at Richmond."
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Examiner is congratulating itself on the extreme simplicity of the bran-new Republicanism inaugurated by the Pro-Slavery aristocracy of the South. There are no perquisites and no sinecures: Office-beggars and lobby cormorants do not distract its legislation. The substance of the country is cared for; plainness and economy are apparently studied in the smallest matters; and the traditions of Washington corruption and extravagance are lost and forgotten to the spectator in what he sees at Richmond."

abstract: The first naval engagement between the Confederate and the National Governments, according to the Petersburgh Express, took place on Sunday, the 21st of July, near the fortification at Oregon inlet, on the North Carolina coast, between the steamer Beaufort, commanded by Lieut. DUVAL, and a National steamer, name unknown. The particulars are given in an extra of the Raleigh Standard. The result is highly creditable to the gallant Lieut. DUVAL, who commanded, and his men. Though he fought against immense odds, he achieved a great triumph, which is the more brilliant from the disproportions between the vessels and their forces. The National steamer was a large three-masted propeller, carrying six heavy guns, and a rifled cannon forward and aft, and having on board at least 175 men. The Beaufort is a small steamer, carrying only one smooth-bored gun, and a crew of twenty-six. The engagement commenced at 10:15 A.M., and terminated at 11 A.M. The enemy fired fifteen shots, five or six of which were from the rifled cannon. The Beaufort, eight shots, three of which struck the enemy. The National vessel finally retreated, and sought safety behind a projecting bluff.

abstract: "We regret to learn," says the Troy Times of Monday evening, "that our distinguished fellow-citizen, Gen. Wool, has not received orders to repair to Fortress Monroe, and take command of the troops stationed there. The [???] that prevailed yesterday, indicating that such orders had reached him was unfounded. The General is not aware that any orders have been issued respecting him as yet; but is in hopes that the positive assertions of the New-York papers that he is to be ordered away, may prove to be true. He is anxious to enter the field at once."

abstract: The New-Orleans Bee attempts to show how unanimous the people are in the determination to meet the blockade with an embargo which will be more damaging to foreign nations than a blockade has been to them. It says: "If England and France want our cotton, they must send their vessels up the Mississippi by forcing the blockade, or they will not get it. We are fully prepared to dispense with the two hundred millions of dollars, which is about the value of the crop, unless we can dispose of it in our own way. Nay, more: if such a misfortune could possibly occur as the successful invasion of Louisiana by the soldiers of the National Government, every pound of cotton in our State would be consigned to the flames, sooner than that it should pass through Northern hands. This, too, is the unchangeable resolve of the people of the South. The European nations who will need the great Southern staple know, therefore, what they have to expect, and may govern themselves accordingly. And we may ask, in conclusion, whether there can exist the smallest chance of conquering a people who are ready at any time to immolate their most valued possessions, if the sacrifice can benefit the South, or injure the North?" The Bulletin makes the suggestion that there should be a military organization in our common schools.

abstract: Ever since the departure of the "De Kalb" Regiment from New-York City attacks have appeared in several American and German newspapers, against the officers, and particularly against the commander of the regiment, Col. VON GILSA. So far,
lead_paragraph: Ever since the departure of the "De Kalb" Regiment from New-York City attacks have appeared in several American and German newspapers, against the officers, and particularly against the commander of the regiment, Col. VON GILSA. So far, we have considered it below our dignity to take notice of these attacks, or to answer them; in the first place, because the writers of the same did not give their names; and in the second place, because all these articles bore on their face the stamp of untruth and unwarranted exaggeration.

abstract: The correspondent of a Georgia paper, referring to the rapid manufacture of cannon and small arms at Richmond, Va., describes a musket-stock machine of a peculiar kind. The piece of wood is put into a machine, and it comes out a perfect stock, five hundred of them a day. The writer forgot to mention, for the edification of his readers, that this is the gun-stock turning machine which has been the admiration of visitors to Harper's Ferry the last forty years, and which the Virginia troops "captured" from the Armory about the last week in April. A creditable fact may be mentioned, in connection with this seizure; that of three hundred and fifty workmen and laborers at the Harper's Ferry Armory, the Confederates were able to seduce or drive no more than fifty into their service. Though starvation to their families, and danger to themselves stared them in the face, the greater part of them stood firm in their faith to the Union.

lead_paragraph: During the present week the University of Vermont, at Burlington, held its regular Commencement exercises. The Literary Societies celebrated their anniversary on Tuesday. Rev. J.M. After its conclusion a joint meeting of the Societies was held for the purpose of electing the Orator and Poet for 1862.

abstract: In the House of Commons, on the 25th ult., as we learn by the latest news from Europe, Sir C. WOOD made the statement, in the course of some remarks on India, that this year the cotton supply from India would be 300,000 bales greater than it had ever been before.
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons, on the 25th ult., as we learn by the latest news from Europe, Sir C. WOOD made the statement, in the course of some remarks on India, that this year the cotton supply from India would be 300,000 bales greater than it had ever been before. He added that the Government was making every exertion to develop the resources of India as a cotton-producing country, and he doubted not that England would ultimately be rendered independent of America for cotton.

abstract: A week ago a propeller, loaded with coal, ran upon a reef between the Jersey and Staten Island shore, opposite New-Brighton, and a libel having been filed against her in this City, Deputy-Marshal PETER MILLER was sent down to execute the process. To the astonishment of the Deputy, the parties engaged in raising the propeller indignantly resisted the service of the process, and with the aid of two Jersey constables, arrested the Officer and took him before a local magistrate of the State of New-Jersey, who fined him $100. These facts coming to the knowledge of the United States Marshal for this District, he issued a warrant for the arrest of the Jersey constables, and such other parties as should resist the execution of the process. The service of this warrant, however, was found to be as difficult as thefirst process, and the Deputies returned with the information that they were met at the propeller by an armed body of men, determined to resist their authority even to the death. Under these circumstances the Marshal called upon the Surveyor of the Port for a revenue cutter to execute the warrant, which was granted. The cutter left for the scene of the rebellion on Tuesday, and returned yesterday, having seized the propeller and transferred her to the Staten Island shore. She also brought to the City two prisoners, one of whom is a Jersey Constable who arrested Officer MILLER, and the other a farmer who satupon the jury which found him guilty of trespass,when he was taken before the Magistrate. The ground on which resistance was made to the execution of the process was that the propeller lay out of the jurisdiction of the Government officers of this District.

The service of this warrant, however, was found to be as difficult as thefirst process, and the Deputies returned with the information that they were met at the propeller by an armed body of men, determined to resist their authority even to the death. Under these circumstances the Marshal called upon the Surveyor of the Port for a revenue cutter to execute the warrant, which was granted. The cutter left for the scene of the rebellion on Tuesday, and returned yesterday, having seized the propeller and transferred her to the Staten Island shore. She also brought to the City two prisoners, one of whom is a Jersey Constable who arrested Officer MILLER, and the other a farmer who satupon the jury which found him guilty of trespass,when he was taken before the Magistrate. abstract: A CHILD POISONED BY ITS GRANDMOTHER SHOCKING CASE. Coroner GAMBLE yesterday investigated the circumstances in connection with the death of MARY C. HORNER, a child 3 years of age, who was poisoned with alcoholic liquor, administered by ANN McDERMOTT, her grandmother. The principal witness before the Coroner was JOHN REDDEN, a boy 14 years of age, who lives at No. 312 East Nineteenth-street, where the deceased and her grandmother also resided.
lead_paragraph: A CHILD POISONED BY ITS GRANDMOTHER -- SHOCKING CASE. -- Coroner GAMBLE yesterday investigated the circumstances in connection with the death of MARY C. HORNER, a child 3 years of age, who was poisoned with alcoholic liquor, administered by ANN MCDERMOTT, her grandmother. The principal witness before the Coroner was JOHN REDDEN, a boy 14 years of age, who lives at No. 312 East Nineteenth-street, where the deceased and her grandmother also resided. The boy testified that the child's mother went to service in the country about a month ago, leaving her in the care of the woman MODERMOTT, who was in the habit of drinking to excess. He had often seen her drunk, and sometimes she gave liquor to the child. On Saturday last, just after 6 o'clock, he saw Mrs. MODERMOTT fill a large teacup three-quarters full with sweetened liquor, and make the little girl drink it. Soon afterwards the child was staggering about the sidewalk, making fun for the children of the neighborhood. The grandmother was drunk at this time. The witness saw her again, on Monday afternoon, give the child about the same quantity of liquor as she made her drink on Saturday. That night about 12 o'clock he heard the little one moaning loudly, and, going to the room, he found her lying insensible on the bed, with blood streaming from her nose and mouth, and the grandmother in a drunken stupor on the floor. He called in Policeman VAN ORDEN, of the Eighteenth Precinct, who took the child to Bellevue Hospital, and arrested the brutal grandmother. The little sufferer was placed under the care of Dr. VEDDER,the House Surgeon, but she never recovered consciousness, and death resulted on Wednesday evening. The Jury rendered a verdict inculpating the grandmother, who was committed to prison by the Coroner. The accused is about 50 years of age, and was born in Ireland. She states that she was very sorry for what she had done, but denied that she intended to kill the child.

abstract: An educated Italian gentleman, a refugee, has been engaged in this City in teaching his poor fellow countrymen, under the supervision of a benevolent society. To eke out a rather scanty income, he had given lessons in Italian ...
lead_paragraph: An educated Italian gentleman, a refugee, has been engaged in this City in teaching his poor fellow countrymen, under the supervision of a benevolent society. To eke out a rather scanty income, he had given lessons in Italian to a Southern lady, a daughter of a wealthy house. After his year's labor, on sending in his account, he found that his pupil had suddenly departed. Soon, however, he received a letter from her in her Southern home, saying that she had the means at hand to settle his bill, but she should reserve them and not send the money till the war was over, for fear of giving aid to the enemy!

abstract: The London Times is neither logical nor ingenuous on American Loans. If the article which we copied a day or two since from the City (or Money) columns of that journal, was designed simply as a plea for British neutrality, financial as well as political, between the North and South, we can well understand the ...
lead_paragraph: The London Times is neither logical nor ingenuous on American Loans. If the article which we copied a day or two since from the City (or Money) columns of that journal, was designed simply as a plea for British neutrality, financial as well as political, between the North and South, we can well understand the motive, without appreciating the extraordinary line of argument adopted by the writer. His text is repudiation; not National, but State repudiation, in which category, in order to make "the balance of disgrace nearly equal," he is pleased to include Pennsylvania and Indiana, on the North, with Mississippi and Florida on the south of the line. The text, we may mention by the way, is one of the writer's own selection. The point was not made on this side, at the initiation or in the early progress of the present rebellion. JEFFERSON DAVIS and the State of Florida were first singled out and denounced in the columns of the London Times as gross and unblushing repudiators, and therefore unworthy of all confidence in their open rebellion against the National Government. It is charged by this writer that DAVIS was never denounced in the halls of Congress as a repudiator, until he turned traitor, and that he is now "frequently assailed by speakers at Washington for the minor as well as the major sin." We are not aware of the fact, but if it be so, the authority and strongest ground of denunciation were derived from the London Times, before that great journal assumed its position of lofty neutrality between the right and wrong of the American Civil War.

abstract: We publish the testimony taken on the last day of the inquest upon the body of Mr. ROBERTS, whose death, in his own room, at the hands of Major MURRAY, had been regarded as one of the most mysterious events of the day.
lead_paragraph: We publish the testimony taken on the last day of the inquest upon the body of Mr. ROBERTS, whose death, in his own room, at the hands of Major MURRAY, had been regarded as one of the most mysterious events of the day. The report includes the statement of Major MURRAY himself, which was to the effect that ROBERTS attempted to shoot him, -- and that he killed him in order to save his own life. He said that he had never seen the man before, and could not imagine any motive or provocation for the attempted murder. The evidence of a lady who had been living with MURRAY for some years, as his wife, however, supplies the motive. She testifies that she had made the acquaintance of ROBERTS by borrowing money from him, -- that he became violently enamored of her, and that this was the secret of his desire to get rid of Major MURRAY. The explanations were regarded as satisfactory by the jury, and the prisoner was released. It is certainly a very extraordinary story, and shows that romantic passion does not find its only home in Paris.

abstract: The Fourteenth Massachusetts Volunteers, Col. GREEN, which left Boston at a very early hour on Thursday morning, arrived here via Groton, shortly after midnight, and repaired directly to the Park Barracks, where a good meal had been in waiting for ...
lead_paragraph: The Fourteenth Massachusetts Volunteers, Col. GREEN, which left Boston at a very early hour on Thursday morning, arrived here via Groton, shortly after midnight, and repaired directly to the Park Barracks, where a good meal had been in waiting for them for some ten hours, their movements not being fully known by the Sutler. Their horses and army equipage had preceded them several hours, and were landed at Jersey City in charge of Lieut. MAY. They have been principally recruited in Essex County, a portion coming from Suffolk and the City of Boston. They number 1,042 men, including Field and Line Officers. They wear the regulation uniform, -- light blue overcoats and pantaloons, and dark blue coats and caps Their arms are the old Spridgfield musket, which is to be exchanged for the Enfield rifle. Thev have a complete outfit including many comforts not always included in the regular Army supplies. They went into camp at Fort Warren on the 24th of June. They have 120 horses, including those belonging to the field and staff, twenty-four baggage and two hospital wagons, and four ambulances. After partaking of dinner, the regiment formed and marched, crossing the Cortlandt-street Ferry. They took a special train shortly after 4 o'clock P.M., and will report directly to Maj.-Gen. BANKS, at Harper's Ferry. The list of officers was published yesterday.
