abstract: The most important intelligence this morning is from Fortress Monroe. A dispatch from there, dated Thursday, announces that on the night previous a body of rebel troops, headed by MAGRUDER, entered Hampton and entirely destroyed it by fire.
lead_paragraph: The most important intelligence this morning is from Fortress Monroe. A dispatch from there, dated Thursday, announces that on the night previous a body of rebel troops, headed by MAGRUDER, entered Hampton and entirely destroyed it by fire. On Wednesday scouts and fugitives informed Gen. BUTLER that a large body of rebel troops was approaching Hampton, and this intelligence was confirmed by a deserter, formerly a resident of Maine, who gave the particulars relative to the strength and appointments of the expedition. It consisted of seven thousand men, including two hundred cavalry, with eight pieces of artillery -- the object being to draw out Gen. BUTLER's forces and attack Hampton or Newport's News, if practicable, or at least to burn Hampton, to prevent its being used for Winter quarters by the National troops. Gen. BUTLER, acting on this information, at once repaired with a considerable force to Hampton Bridge, and took the necessary measures to prevent a crossing by the rebels. Gen. MAGRUDER, with about five hundred men of his expedition, made his appearance about midnight, and immediately set fire to the town. He also attempted to force a passage of the bridge, but was repulsed with the loss of three killed and six wounded. The destruction of Hampton was a most wanton and unjustifiable act, which, it is understood, the rebels intend to charge upon Gen. BUTLER.

abstract: VERY ROMANTIC, VERY. A fine-looking, brighteyed girl of 16 was yesterday placed under the protection of Miss FOSTER, the matron of the City Prison, whose case presents features of a more than ordinarily interesting character. Her name is BRIDGET ...
lead_paragraph: VERY ROMANTIC, VERY. -- A fine-looking, bright-eyed girl of 16 was yesterday placed under the protection of Miss FOSTER, the matron of the City Prison, whose case presents features of a more than ordinarily interesting character. Her name is BRIDGET DOKAY, and her parents still live in the City of Dublin, which is her native place. The particulars of her romantic career were given by herself, with such an air of modest truthfulness that no one would wish to question her veracity. She stated that when thirteen years of age she became acquainted with a worthy young man named KELLY, a carpenter, who wished to marry her. Her parents, who were well-to-do, prudent people, objected to the match, because of her youth, and prevailed upon the young man to leave the neighborhood, giving him a fit-out of $100. His departure grieved her, and she determined to follow him. After the lapse of a few months she learned that he had procured employment on board a vessel as ship's carpenter, and that he sailed out of Liverpool. Thither she repaired as quickly as she obtained the means, but only to learn that KELLY's vessel had a few days previously sailed for New-York. The damsel was disappointed, but her desire to see her truant lover was not conquered. She immediately procured a suit of Sailor-boy's clothing, for which she discarded her own girlish attire, and then shipped, under the name of EDWARD JOHNSON, as cabin-boy for a trip to New-York, whither she arrived, but still failed to accomplish the purpose she had undertaken. Friendless and without means, after she had been here a week or two, it became necessary that she should obtain employment, and, noitwithstanding the hardships to which she had been subjected on her first voyage, there was a certain fascination about a sailor's life which induced her to follow it. So, for three years, she has been voyaging from port to port, two of which were passed in the capacity of cabin-boy, and the third as an able seaman, her robust constitution enabling her to take her "trick at the wheel" and perform the varied duties of her lot as well as the best man on board. During all this time, notwithstanding an evident refinement of manner not characteristic of an ordinary sailor, and delicatcy of appearance, which ought to have betrayed her sex, her secret was never discovered. She performed her duties so well that her three last voyages have been made in one vessel -- the ship Resolute, of the Black Ball line -- the Captain having pressed her to remain with him, and complimenting her as a "promising young man." But, amid all the hardships of her condition she lost no opportunity of searching for the young carpenter, of whom, however, she has lately lost every trace. On Thursday night, cherishing a hope that she might encounter him in some of the low saloons in Water-street, which seafaring men frequent, she determined to explore them. Mixing freely with the unruly characters there, she found it necessary to treat them to liquor. An attempt, however, was made to impose upon her liberality, which she resisted, and one of the ruffians made an assault upon her. The discovery of her sex was then made, and created such excitement that the police were attracted by the disorder which the crowd occasioned. The young sailor-girl was taken to the Station-house, where she made a partial statement to the Police Captain, who was favorably impressed with her ingenuous manner, and provided her with good accommodation for the night. Yesterday morning she was arraigned before Justice OSBORN, who lectured her upon the impropriety of her conduct, and informed her that she had been guilty of a misdemeanor, at which she seemed greatly surprised. Miss FOSTER, the matron, made her change her male attire for one more appropriate to her youth and sex, and she is now metamorphosed into a very pretty girl, rather sun-burned, it is true, and having her hair cropped too closely, but withal interesting and womanly. She acknowledges to feeling great restraint in her new garments, but declares she will never discard them again. Her great hope now is to obtain some respectable employment, and doubtless it will soon be found for her.

abstract: We respectfully suggest to the Hon. JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE that he transfer his services and his presence to the Southern Confederacy as soon as possible. Every day's experience shows that he is neither ornamental nor useful in any loyal locality. His reception the other ...
lead_paragraph: We respectfully suggest to the Hon. JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE that he transfer his services and his presence to the Southern Confederacy as soon as possible. Every day's experience shows that he is neither ornamental nor useful in any loyal locality. His reception the other day at Baltimore, whither he had gone to stir up the ashes of treason, and egg on the people of that city to further conflict with the National Government, should admonish him that he is becoming thoroughly understood and heartily despised everywhere. His own State has spurned his counsels, and will be heartily rejoiced if he will enable them to fill his seat in the Senate with an honorable and a loyal man.

abstract: If any enthusiastic admirer of the country of districts highly cultivated without being remorselessly utilized to the last inch of forest of acres broad and richly covered, without being ruled and smoothed into angular flats of mountain and stream without eternal rocks and sterility of valley and vista ...
lead_paragraph: If any enthusiastic admirer of the country -- of districts highly cultivated without being remorselessly utilized to the last inch of forest -- of acres broad and richly covered, without being ruled and smoothed into angular flats -- of mountain and stream without eternal rocks and sterility -- of valley and vista without inaccessible Alpine gorges -- of wide-spreading plains variegated with patches of forest on the neighboring hill-tops, and rolling tracts of yellow stubble, and the green and the ripe crops, and the red clover blending in the hazy air as they stretch away under the brightest of skies to the base of the purple mountains -- if the lover of this quality of country would revel in its beauties, these sultry August days, let him go to the Valley of Lebanon. Such were the sentiments that mitigated our martial ardor as we nodded in a half reverie and a New-Jersey Central car over the military route to Washington. Well, it will be no less agreeable to our soldiers for its beauty. Their last look at the free land for which they fight could not fall upon more lovely valleys, nor could a more tempting landscape welcome them home.

abstract: The public has a lively interest in the capacity, dispatch and economy of the various means of transporting troops and materiel between such important depots as New-York and Washington; but since the interested ...
lead_paragraph: The public has a lively interest in the capacity, dispatch and economy of the various means of transporting troops and materiel between such important depots as New-York and Washington; but since the interested disputes, public and private, which have grown out of the opening of a new military line, are perfectly unsatisfactory, we propose to state, in the fewest words, the facts in the case. The old route, via Philadelphia, is about seventy miles shorter than the route via Easton and Harrisburgh; it has facilities for a large regular traffic, but any extraordinary amount of irregular traffic, such as several regiments of troops and their baggage, must, so to speak, dam it up to a greater or less extent at its narrowest paints -- the ferryboats on the Delaware and the Susquehannah.

abstract: The action of Congress in authorizing the confiscation of the property of persons waging war upon the Government, puts into its hands the most effective weapon yet provided for crushing the rebellion.
lead_paragraph: The action of Congress in authorizing the confiscation of the property of persons waging war upon the Government, puts into its hands the most effective weapon yet provided for crushing the rebellion. It is tenfold more effective than the severest penalties directed against persons. The resentment provoked by excessive corporal punishments incites, often, to the perpetration of crime, instead of operating as a warning against it. But when property is endangered, men are left in a condition in which they can reason. If the rebels in Virginia, for instance, felt assured that as fast as our arms progressed, the property of each traitor would be seized and sold, it would strike more terror into their hearts than all the apprehension for personal safety under a most disastrous defeat. Men do not enjoy the idea of being stripped of everything that can support life, or render it agreeable or tolerable. Secession has not yet taken such firm hold of the Southern mind as to be more valuable than their horses, farms, merchandise and negroes. The object of secession was to increase the number and value of these. Let the rebels see that it involves the destruction of them all, and they will not be long in grounding their arms. It is the sure remedy for the pacification of such States as Maryland and Missouri, and will strike more terror than any display of our military strength.

abstract: The proceedings of the State Committees of the Republican and of the Democratic Parties of the State of New-York, in regard to the election of State officers, are before the people. We are not afraid of the judgment ...
lead_paragraph: The proceedings of the State Committees of the Republican and of the Democratic Parties of the State of New-York, in regard to the election of State officers, are before the people. We are not afraid of the judgment that will be passed upon them by all patriotic and fair men. The Republican Party is the dominant party of the State -- declared so at the ballot-box, when all the machinery of the Federal Government in New-York City was in the hands of the Democratic Party, by the sweeping majority of 50,000 votes. The right of the Republican Party to its fairly won victory has been honorably conceded by the masses of the Democracy; and their devotion to the principle of republican institutions by which the majority rules and represents the Government, has been emphatically manifested in their eager and enthusiastic rally to the support of the Constitution while in the keeping of a Republican Administration.

abstract: Attracted by the rumor that Hon. JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE, who reached this city on Wednesday evening, would be serenaded and probably publicly address his friends, an assemblage of about 2,000 person gathered last night in front of the Eutaw louse, at which the Kentucky statesman was stopping, and anticipating by an hour or more the time at which if was reported the musical compliment was to be paid him, vociferously demanded the presence of "JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE."

abstract: The city is full of trophies sent by our gallant boys from the field of Manassas to their friends in this city. We cannot describe all these various mementoes of the great fight, but one which we observed at the Empire House, in the Fourth District, corner of Jackson and Tchoupitoulas streets. It was sent to Dr. FISHER by a relative, who is in HAYS' Regiment, and consists of a Major's uniform, the name of the owner, Major S.F. NICKERSON, being written on the lining of the coat. The wearer of this uniform was singled out by one of our boys, who put a bullet through his forehead, and taking possession of his body appropriated the uniform and a belt which the officer wore, that contained a variety of useful little things for a soldier. But of all the trophies, noneappear to have afforded our boys more comfort and gratification than that box of dressing-gowns. Our dusty and tired boys must have presented as gorgeous an appearance, dressed off in the luxurious robes supplied by the ladies of New-York, as the Seminole warriors who, having captured the wardrobe of a traveling theatrical company, arrayed themselves in the garbs of Rolla, William Tell, Hamlet and Macbeth, and had a grand old time of it.

abstract: The Manchester Examiner, of the 20th July, contains the most philosophical and appreciative article on the American insurrection and the lesson it teaches that we have seen lately in any English paper. The Examiner has a healthy and hearty sympathy with...
lead_paragraph: The Manchester Examiner, of the 20th July, contains the most philosophical and appreciative article on the American insurrection and the lesson it teaches that we have seen lately in any English paper. The Examiner has a healthy and hearty sympathy with the United States Government, and pays a handsome compliment to the energetic and sweeping policy of President LINCOLN, as enunciated in his message to Congress, for suppressing the revolt against the National Government. The Examiner does not at all concur in the shallow deduction of the London Times and the tory politicians whose sentiments it reflects, that republicanism is proved to be a failure by the events now occurring in the United States. Republicanism truly is undergoing a severe trial at the present moment -- but not republicanism primarily. It is republicanism with a dangerous adulteration that is passing through the crucible.

abstract: the Louisville, Ky., papers, that JOSEPH HOLT, of Kentucky, the eloquent and devoted champion of the Union, has left that city to spend a brief season at Niagara Falls. We suggest that inasmuch as Mr. HOLT is so near to New-York City the Union men in the Metropolis of the country should testify in some appropriate way their appreciation of the brave and gallant man. Mr. HOLT is a Democrat. His first shining worth as a patriot became evident in the latter days of Mr. BUCHANAN's Administration as his Secretary of War. Cannot all men, of all parties, in New-York, unite in inviting Mr. HOLT hither, and giving him such an ovation as he deserves?

abstract: The Leavenworth papers of Aug. 3, notice the presence of Col. MONTGOMERY in that city. His men were in the vicinity of the fort, waiting for their arms and equipments. On the evening of the L2d, Col. MONTGOMERY addressed the people to Leavenworth declaring against allowing, the volunteers to return fugitive slaves, and predicting that by the next Spring the war would be ended either favorably or adversely to the rebels. He disowned all connection with JENNISON.

abstract: CHARLES WILSON, of Washington, was in Richmond several weeks ago, and was arrested as a Union man, and confined a week and discharged. With a friend he started at midnight for Ohio. When about seven miles from Charleston, Kanawha County, he was arrested by young WISE, and imprisoned five weeks. In prison, he with other Union prisoners made a small American flag, and put it out of the window when the battle at Pokey was fought, and in consequence they were fired on by the guards, but not injured. When WISE began to retreat WILSON and 57 others were sent with the Army by various conveyances, and during a difficulty which occurred by some of the rebels firing into one of their own boats, he escaped in the confusion and got to the National troops. He went to Cincinnati with Col. NORTON, whence he arrived in Washington on Saturday night. Mr. WILSON says that WISE has 600 to 800 Union men forced in his ranks. Some 200 deserted during the retreat. WISE's party is in miserable condition. He forced men to cut their own wheat and deliver it to him without pay or promise to pay.
lead_paragraph: CHARLES WILSON, of Washington, was in Richmond several weeks ago, and was arrested as a Union man, and confined a week and discharged. With a friend he started at midnight for Ohio. When about seven miles from Charleston, Kanawha County, he was arrested by young WISE, and imprisoned five weeks. In prison, he with other Union prisoners made a small American flag, and put it out of the window when the battle at Pokey was fought, and in consequence they were fired on by the guards, but not injured. When WISE began to retreat WILSON and 57 others were sent with the Army by various conveyances, and during a difficulty which occurred by some of the rebels firing into one of their own boats, he escaped in the confusion and got to the National troops. He went to Cincinnati with Col. NORTON, whence he arrived in Washington on Saturday night. Mr. WILSON says that WISE has 600 to 800 Union men forced in his ranks. abstract: We have taken occasion, more than once, to caution the public against the romantic tales of their own bravery, told by members of the ELLSWORTH Zouaves, especially those of them who reached Washington earliest on the day after the battle.
lead_paragraph: We have taken occasion, more than once, to caution the public against the romantic tales of their own bravery, told by members of the ELLSWORTH Zouaves, especially those of them who reached Washington earliest on the day after the battle. Besides the intrinsic evidence furnished by the stories themselves we had pretty good reason, to doubt whether they had actually monopolized all the valor of our Army at that time.

abstract: Every page of the morning edition of the New-York TIMES is stereotyped, and worked in duplicate. We have resorted to this expedient as the only means of delivering our very large and constantly increasing edition to our subscribers at a reasonably early hour in the morning. We trust that any defects in the typography and general appearance of the paper will be pardoned until they can be remedied, -- which shall be at the earliest possible moment.

abstract: DEAR WIFE: I wrote a letter to Capt. KIRKER a few days since acquainting him of my being in close confinement here, also Capt. MeIvor and Lieut. abstract: The battalion of soldiers' wives, numbering nearly 300, besieged His Honor's office, yesterday, in inquire when the City Council was going to make the appropriation for their relief, some of them stating that they were entirely destitute, and others that they had been turned out of their houses by heartless  landlords, because they could not pay their rent.

abstract: As the probable result of the present year's harvest in the United Kingdom cannot fail to have some influence upon the value of money, and upon the extent of our commercial operations both at home and abroad, a few comments, based upon practical  sources of information, bearing upon the crops genreally, cannot fail to be interest aat this period.
lead_paragraph: As the probable result of the present year's harvest in the United Kingdom cannot fail to have some influence upon the value of money, and upon the extent of our commercial operations both at home and abroad, a few comments, based upon practical sources of information, bearing upon the crops genreally, cannot fail to be interest aat this period. We learn from our correspondents that wheat-cutting has been commenced in Essex, Kent and Devonshire, and that the crop exhibits what may be termed an irregular growth. Nevertheless, the yield, taken as a whole, will, it is thought, come up to the average of most previous years. Upon some of the heavy lands there is less corn to the acre than in 1859, but upon the light soils the produce is fully equal to that period. Of course some of the growers complain of a deficiency; but that portion of the crop now cut will, it is said, come up to quite five quarters to the acre. On some of the Highly cultivated soils between Colchester and Barking Creek, the produce will, it is thought, exceed six quarters, exclusive of the "tail" wheats. Throughout Yorkshire the crop is fairly represented even by the farmers themselves, since they admit that "there is nothing to complain of." In Cambridgeshire and Suffolk there is quite one-third more wheat than last season; and in Norfolk, especially upon the most sandy soils, the yield is likely to prove very large. The appearance of the crop in Surrey and Berkshire, as well as in most other parts of England, is said to be satisfactory, although it does not promise so heavy a yield as in 1859. For the most part the plants are strong and reedy, and a very small portion of the crop has been beaten down by high winds of heavy rains. So far, therefore, there are fair prospects before us; but we now require fine, dry weather to bring the produce to maturity. Anything short of that would, of course; place the crops in great peril. Hence the anxiety which prevails in all quarters, as to ultimate results, especially as so much damage was sustained last year from the long continuance, of unsually wet weather. As regards barley, the crops, it appears, are everywhere looking remarkably fine; indeed, judging from our reports, in no previous corresponding period was ever witnessed a finer or more healthy crop. In some of the best barley counties, the yield, it is said, will exceed five -- perhaps six -- quarters to the acre, and the entire crop is fully a fortnight earlier than in the ordinary run of years. The same remarks may be applied to oats, which upon many of the most inferior lands appear to promise one of the largest growths ever known. Considering, however, that the quantities annually grown in this country are very limited compared with the consumption, even an increased production can have very little influence upon the extent of our importations from, abroad. With some few exceptions, both beans and peas withstanding that they have grown rapidly, will [???] out heavy crops even in moderately farmed districts.

abstract: It being understood that Hon. GALUSHA A. GROW, of Pennsylvania, Speaker of the House of Representatives was in the City, the Republican Central Committee determined, to give him a serenade last evening, at the St. Nicholas Hotel.
lead_paragraph: It being understood that Hon. GALUSHA A. GROW, of Pennsylvania, Speaker of the House of Representatives was in the City, the Republican Central Committee determined, to give him a serenade last evening, at the St. Nicholas Hotel. A fine band of music was in attendance, and nearly a thousand enthusiastic citizens, many of the most prominent of whom were personally presented to the distinguised guest. Amid loud calls for Mr. GROW, the band succeeded in playing several patriotic airs.

abstract: The arrival yesterday of the venerable and distinguished JOHN J. CRITTENDEN having been announced, a large concourse of citizens waited on him at his hotel; and at their urgent request he kindly consented to address them in the evening. Accordingly, directly after sunset a large assemblage convened at the State House, and Mr. CRITTENDEN was introduced.
lead_paragraph: The arrival yesterday of the venerable and distinguished JOHN J. CRITTENDEN having been announced, a large concourse of citizens waited on him at his hotel; and at their urgent request he kindly consented to address them in the evening. Accordingly, directly after sunset a large assemblage convened at the State House, and Mr. CRITTENDEN was introduced. He was looking care-worn and fatigued by travel, and at first his remarks were not very audible. He spoke of the great contest before us; the suddenness with which it was precipitated upon us. But a few short months ago, said Mr. CRITTENDEN, such a calamity as is now shrouding our country in gloom was unthought of among the people. But now that we are involved in it, we must meet it like men. It is not a war that is to be prosecuted for the sake of warfare, and ought to be conducted with none of the common barbarities of war. It must nevertheless be prosecuted by no half-way measures. My friends, we must gather the utmost strength of the country, and gird up the energies of our minds to this most momentous contest. And let it be prosecuted only for the purpose that it ought to be carried on and concluded for the restoration of our Government and the Union. In any event, it is a war that cannot last long. It will prove itself too oppressive upon all classes of our people to permit of its being long continued.

abstract: The Philadelphia Press publishes a letter dated on board the Niagara,, off Cape St. Antoine. July 18, whence that vessel had gone in pursuit of the Sumter. A vigilant lookout had been stationed all over the Niagara, and $12 reward had been offered to the one who should first sight the pirate, but the only vessels hailed after leaving Key West were a Spanish coaster and war steamer, the English bark Nugget and H.B.M.'s steamer, the Barracouta. At the date of the letter the Niagara was waiting to speak the California steamer, en route for this port. Quite an excitement was created on the 17th by the breaking out of a fire near the magazine. In consequence of the ignition of some liquor in the spirit room. It was extinguished without difficulty.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Press publishes a letter dated on board the Niagara,, off Cape St. Antoine. July 18, whence that vessel had gone in pursuit of the Sumter. abstract: Not a little error and confusion has been created by writers in the newspapers, especially since the recent battle before Manassas Junction, by confounding the names of two meritorious officers in the Army. There are two Col. SHERMANS in the Army: Col. WILLIAM T. SHERMAN, of Ohio, and Co. THOMAS W. SHERMAN, of Rhode Island. The former is the only one of the two who was engaged in the battle at Bull Run.
lead_paragraph: Not a little error and confusion has been created by writers in the newspapers, especially since the recent battle before Manassas Junction, by confounding the names of two meritorious officers in the Army. There are two Col. SHERMANS in the Army: Col. WILLIAM T. SHERMAN, of Ohio, and Col. THOMAS W. SHERMAN, of Rhode Island. The former is the only one of the two who was engaged in the battle at Bull Run. He is a brother of JOHN SHERMAN, Senator from Ohio. He is not the Capt. SHERMAN who first organized the famous SHERMAN's Battery.

abstract: While promeuading on Fourth-street yesterday forenoon, Col. J.V. GUTHRIE, of the First Kentucky, saw a gentleman whom he thought he recognized as Col. TYLER, late of the United States Army, but now an Adjutant-General in the rebel Army. So strongly was he impressed with this idea, that he turned and followed.
lead_paragraph: While promenading on Fourth-street yesterday forenoon, Col. J.V. GUTHRIE, of the First Kentucky, saw a gentleman whom he thought he recognized as Col. TYLER, late of the United States Army, but now an Adjutant-General in the rebel Army. So strongly was he impressed with this idea, that he turned and followed. Presently he met Capt. DICKERSON, and upon consultation they were both satisfied that Col. GUTHRIE was right in his surmise. Thereupon Col. GUTHRIE approached Col. TYLER, and claimed him as a prisoner of war. TYLER appeared somewhat amazed, but confessed his name and rank in BEAUREGARD'S Army, and said that "traveling as a citizen, and without arms, he did not anticipate an arrest."

abstract: In the chagrin over the Bull Run affair, we seem to be almost unconscious of the peaceful victories which our cause has recently achieved. In the seceded States there are only about five millions of whites. In the Slave States, including Western Virginia,...
lead_paragraph: In the chagrin over the Bull Run affair, we seem to be almost unconscious of the peaceful victories which our cause has recently achieved. In the seceded States there are only about five millions of whites. In the Slave States, including Western Virginia, loyal to Government, there are fully three millions. The South has thus nearly divided itself, numerically as well as geographically, on this very subject of secession. This fact is really conclusive of the contest, whether considered in the light of the moral or material influence it carries. With Kentucky, Missouri, Western Virginia, Maryland and Delaware as a part of the Confederate Government, we should find ourselves in a very different position from that we now occupy. Had Kentucky seceded, she would have added immense strength to the rebellion, by her great wealth, by the abundance of her productions adapted to the subsistence of an Army, and by her geographical position. As it is, united with Western Virginia, of which our forces now hold undisputed possession, the high road to East Tennessee, which is also loyal, is fully opened. East Tennessee is the key of the military operations of the rebels. With this in our possession, the forces now collected at Manasses would break up without a soldier being directed against them. Kentucky against us would be an almost impassible barrier to our arms, extending from the crest of the Alleghanies to the Mississippi. Hence the earnest and constant efforts of MAGOFFIN and his crew, to place the State, when he found he could not carry it out of the Union, in a position of "armed neutrality," to be crossed by neither party. The recent election has put an end to all such wretched subterfuge. Kentucky will now not only offer a free passage across her soil, but will contribute, and liberally, a most gallant soldiery to our Armies.

abstract: A large number of the returned volunteers of the different regiments have joined the Continental Guard, under Col. PERRY. The tents and camp equipage have been furnished by order of the Secretary of War, and the regiment is in quarters at Camp Wyman, near Fort Hamilton. Capt. FOSTER, Company K, is filling up his company roll at the room for receiving volunteers, No. 7 Montague Hall, opposite the City Hall, Brooklyn. Members of the company on leave of absence or on furlough, are requested to report at head-quarters of the company on Tuesday, at 10 o'clock A.M. regiment will be mustered in on Wednesday, the 14th inst.

abstract: The Prince NAPOLEON left Washington this afternoon. He was accompanied by the French Minister, and will go only as far as Philadelphia to-night. On Monday he will resume his journey and go old New-York and Albany to Niagara Falls. Owing to the intense heat, the Prince will not go further west than the Falls.
lead_paragraph: The Prince NAPOLEON left Washington this afternoon. He was accompanied by the French Minister, and will go only as far as Philadelphia to-night. abstract: The first formal proceedings in the suit promoted against Dr. ROWLAND WILLIAMS, by the Bishop of Salisbury, were taken in the Court of Arches yesterday. The suit is instituted against the reverend gentleman as the writer of the article in the Essays and Reviews, entitled "Bunsen's Biblical Researches," and it is alleged in the citation with which he has been served, and the articles which will be filed, that he has thrown contempt upon the prophetical books of the Old Testament, and otherwise depraved the Scriptures. Mr. TOLLER exhibited a proxy, under the hand and seal of the Bishop of Salisbury, constituting him his proctor in the case and Mr. DEBOIS was duly constituted proxy for Dr. WILLIAMS. It was announced that the articles had been laid before counsel, and that a day would in due course be appointed for their hearing. It is generally understood that the defence of Dr. WILLIAMS will be, that in the article complained of he has merely set forth in detail the leading views of Baron BUNSEN, as expressed in his leading theologocal writings, especially in his Egypt's Place in Universal History, and his Gott in der Geschichte; and that in his own commentaries upon these he has not laid himself open to any charge which will subject him to ecclesiastical punishment.

abstract: -- Right-Rev. Samuel Bowman, D.D., Assistant Bishop of the Episcopal Church in the Diocese of Pennsylvania, died suddenly on Saturday last, while on his way from Pittsburgh to Buffalo, whither he was going to discharge official duties. Bishop Bowman was a native of Wilkesbarre, and was born in 1800. He was educated for the Bar, but soon after admission turned his attention to the study of Divinity, and was ordained a Deacon, by Bishop White, in the year 1823. In the following year he was ordained a Priest. Immediately after he was ordained a Deacon, he took charge of St. John's Church, Piqua, Lancaster County. In October, 1825, he became Rector of Trinity Church, Easton, devoting also a portion of his time to an infant congregation at Allentown. In 1828 he was called to St. James' Church, Lancaster, and continued there for thirty years, only giving it up when he was elected Assistant Bishop of Pennsylvania, in 1858. In 1848, Dr. BOWMAN was elected Bishop of the Diocese of Indiana, but he declined it, preferring to remain with his congregation. The failing health of Bishop POTTER preventing him from attending to all the arduous labors of his Diocese, the Convention of the Church, in May, 1858, determined to elect an Assistant Bishop. On the 28th of the month, on the sixteenth ballot, Dr. BOWMAN was elected, his principal competitor having been Rev. A.H. VINTON, D.D. Although Dr. BOWMAN was voted for by the High Church Party, he has never been regarded as an ultra man. He was consecrated Aug. 25, 1858, so that he filled his sacred office less than three years. As Bishop POTTER's health has much improved lately, it is probable that no action upon electing another Assistant Bishop will be taken before the annual meeting of the Convention of the Diocese, next May.

abstract: The joys of the "Wanderleben" have been the theme of German poetry since Germany began to write verses; and it must be confessed that in this country pedestrian excursions can be most pleasantly carried out.
lead_paragraph: The joys of the "Wanderleben" have been the theme of German poetry since Germany began to write verses; and it must be confessed that in this country pedestrian excursions can be most pleasantly carried out. The excellent roads, the variety of scenery, the comfortable stopping places and the hospitality of the people, render a foot journey in Germany more delightful than in any other part of Europe. With my knapsack on my back. I have already, traversed, more than a thousand miles of the country, penetrating into remote valleys or forests, and studying the character of the people where it is yet unaltered by intercourse with the world.

abstract: The Dispatch contained yesterday an account of the shooting of Capt. CHARLES H. AXSON, of Company M, First Regiment Sonth Carolina Volunteers, on Tuesday evening, near Wilson, N.C., on the Wilmington and Weldon Railroad, by ARTHUR B. DAVIS, of the Second Georgia Regiment, then en route for this city. The circumstances attending the death of Capt. AXSON.
lead_paragraph: The Dispatch contained yesterday an account of the shooting of Capt. CHARLES H. AXSON, of Company M, First Regiment Sonth Carolina Volunteers, on Tuesday evening, near Wilson, N.C., on the Wilmington and Weldon Railroad, by ARTHUR B. DAVIS, of the Second Georgia Regiment, then en route for this city. The circumstances attending the death of Capt. AXSON excited a feeling of bitter indignation against DAVIS, though no attempt at retaliation was indulged in prior to the arrival of the Petersburgh cars on Wednesday evening. When they reached the depot in this city, four South Carolina volunteers approached the car in which the prisoner was confined under guard, and expressed an intention of shooting him. Finding them determined, the Superintendent of the road (THOS. H. WYNN, Esq.) ordered the car containing the prisoner and guard (two men armed with muskets) to be backed to the Manchester side of the river. This done, and the four who had made the demonstration, being told that DAVIS would be carried across the river to the camp near the reservoir, left in the latter direction.

abstract: OPENING CONCERT AT CENTRAL PARK. The Commissioners of the Central Park, ignoring the turmoil and discord of "grim-visaged war," have revived the pleasant concerts which, in the "weak piping times of peace," a year ago, so captivated the popular heart. The first experiment was made yesterday, and received such an orerwhelming indorsement...
lead_paragraph: OPENING CONCERT AT CENTRAL PARK. -- The Commissioners of the Central Park, ignoring the turmoil and discord of "grim-visaged war," have revived the pleasant concerts which, in the "weak piping times of peace," a year ago, so captivated the popular heart. The first experiment was made yesterday, and received such an orerwhelming indorsement from the popular voice as may well encourage a repteition. Never did the Park have so gay an appearance; the grand promenade was crowded with the votaries of Apollo, who listened delightfully to DODWORTH's fine band. To protect the people from the fierce rays of the sun an awning had been erected, wherein the multitude could sit and listen at their ease. At no time, either, were there such a number of carriages present, from the sulky of the fast man to the more aristocratic landau carrying Jeemes with folded arms upon the box. "Music." saith the divine WILLIAM. "hath charms," and really judging from the immense throng at Central Park yesterday he must be pretty nearly right, and there is no doubt that these concerts will prove as successful this year as they were last.

abstract: All through the North and West the first Volunteers for the war are now receiving their pay, and it comes not in money for the $11 a month would never have tempted the majority to such hard service but in the warm welcome and ovation of the people.
lead_paragraph: All through the North and West the first Volunteers for the war are now receiving their pay, and it comes not in money -- for the $11 a month would never have tempted the majority to such hard service -- but in the warm welcome and ovation of the people. In distant villages on the prairie, in lumber-towns by the Penobscot, in the coal-settlements of the Alleghanies, in our great cities, whether on the Ohio or the Atlantic, the weather-beaten companies of those who first sprang to arms, are marching proudly in these days through the cheering crowds. If in a smaller town, there is the gay assembly of the whole population, the ladies sprinkling the bayonets with flowers, the sober welcome and prayer of the pastor, the inevitable oration on the green, and a welcome from bright eyes all around, which makes the poor volunteer quite oblivious of the eloquent periods poured out on him.

abstract: Far the severest sufferers from the general collapse of business consequent upon the war, are tho women of New-York and other cities who have a heretofore earned their livelihood in the various industrial occupations.
lead_paragraph: Far the severest sufferers from the general collapse of business consequent upon the war, are tho women of New-York and other cities who have a heretofore earned their livelihood in the various industrial occupations. Some of these industries are now almost entirely destroyed; while in many of the establishments the working force is reduced to a half or a quarter what it has been in former years. Folders and stitchers, sewing girls, women employed on all kinds of fancy work, and in all the lighter operations of the arts and manufactures, have thus been thrown out of employment in great numbers; and even domestic servants, in large number, have been discharged from their situations and set adrift in the City, -- owing to the failure of their employers, or from a desire to economize in view of present and prospective hard times. Besides these, too, there are thousands of women -- such as laundresses, sewing women, boarding-house keepers, &c., -- who were sustained or helped forward in various ways by the great army of young men whom the Metropolis has sent to Virginia, whose little means of earning a livelihood is now entirely cut off, and many of whom are reduced to extremes of want, with but little hope or prospect for the future. Probably not less than twenty-five thousand of the working women of New-York have thus been thrown out of employment during the past few months.

abstract: The Auburn Advertiser gives the following as Rev. Dr. THOMHSON's account of the interview between himself and Gen. MCCLELLAN, a few months ago. Dr. T. related the incident last last week in that village, where he was visiting: "Gen. MCCLELLAN had attended Dr. THOMPSON's church for six months or more, and had become greatly interested in the subject of religion. Just previous to his departure for the seat of war, he called upon Dr. THOMPSON for religious conversation and instruction. During the interview, by request of Dr. THOMPSON, they kneeled together in prayer. Dr. THOMPSON prayed, and at the conclusion he noticed that the General still remained kneeling. 'Pray for yourself,' said the Pastor, placing his hand on the General's shoulder. Gen. MCCLELLAN then in an earnest and simple manner prayed for his country, for the success of the soldiers who were about to go forth to pour out their blood for its salvation, and for wisdom from on high to lead his men to the victory, that the cause of good government might prevail.

abstract: Liverpool 49 days, with merchandise to order, arrived this morning. The first week out, she experienced a heavy gale from N. W., during which she stove in boats and water-casks, and had her decks filled with water. After the gale, she passed through considerable wreck-stuff, consisting of vessels' topmasts, lower masts, watch-houses, &c. On the 7th inst., at 4 P. M., fifty miles south of Nantucket Shoals, made a vessel to the southward, keeping ahead, and apparently waiting for her to come up; but as it was getting dark, and Capt. R. was somewhat suspicious of the vessel, he kept away four points out of his course. In the morning, nothing was to be seen of her. Capt. R. has no doubt but that she was a privateer.

abstract: ENGINEERS IN THE NAVY ADJOURNMENT OF THE BOARD OF EXAMINERS. The Board of Examining Engineers, consisting of Chief Engineers, Wm. H. SHGSK, T. ZELLER, and J. WHIPPLE. United States Navy, who have been in session since last May, at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, adjourned on Friday, the 9th, to meet at the Boston Navy-yard, on the 13th.
lead_paragraph: ENGINEERS IN THE NAVY -- ADJOURNMENT OF THE BOARD OF EXAMINERS. -- The Board of Examining Engineers, consisting of Chief Engineers, WM.H. SHOOK, T. ZELLER, and J. WHIPPLE, United States Navy, who have been in session since last May, at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, adjourned on Friday, the 9th, to meet at the Boston Navy-yard, on the 13th. This course has been adopted by the Honorable Secretary of the Navy in order to accommodate the many young men living in that vicinity, who are desirous of presenting themselves for an examination, but in consequence of the time and expense attending a trip at a distance from their homes are debarred an opportunity. It is expected that when the Board shall have completed its labors at Boston, it will adjourn to Philadelphia and other large cities, before returning to New-York. The following candidates for promotion and admission have passed satisfactory examinations, and will be appointed as follows, viz. First Assistant Engineer W.H. Rutherford, to be a Chief Engineer; Edward Marsland to be a First Assistant engineer, and Thaddeus Smith, J. Mercer, G.C. Huntley, H.H. Burritt, T. Lynch, J. Van Hovenburg, G.C. Cooper, R.N. Ellis, A.E.T. Mullin, and John Lowe, to be Third Assistants.

abstract: Capt. TRUMAN SEYMOUR, of Fort Sumter faine, one of the prominent candidates of the New-York Delegation for a Brigadier Generalship, commenced his public career when about sixteen years of age, as one of the corps who, under the direction and authority of the Legislature, made...
lead_paragraph: Capt. TRUMAN SEYMOUR, of Fort Sumter fame, one of the prominent candidates of the New-York Delegation for a Brigadier Generalship, commenced his public career when about sixteen years of age, as one of the corps who, under the direction and authority of the Legislature, made the geological survey of this State, the results of which are now exhibited in our State Geological Hall at Albany. Young SEYMOUR was very efficient in this service, and made a fine individual collection, which, if we mistake not, he presented to the Albany Medical College, receiving therefor the thanks of the Trustees and Faculty of that Institution. Upon the completion of this work, and mainly through his own indomitable will and perseverance, he was appointed to the West Point Military Academy, from which he graduated in 1846. He soon after entered the Mexican campaign, and on the 19th of April, 1847, was brevetted First Lieutenant for his gallant conduct at the battle of Cerro Gordo, and on the 26th of August of the same year, he received the brevet of captain for like conduct at Contreras and Cherubusco. After the close of the Mexican War he was for some years an instructor at West Point. He served through the last campaign against BILLY BOWLEGS in Florida, visited Europe in 1859 and 1860, and was among the few in the latter year who ascended to the top of Mont Blanc -- his brilliant and thrilling description of which will be remembered by many of our readers. Capt. SEYMOUR, while in Mexico, also made the perilous ascent of Popocatapetl, a mountain whose summit is as rarely reached as that of Mont Blanc. On his return from Europe he repaired, we believe, directly to Fort Moultrie, where, and subsequently at Fort Sumter, his long-suffering and heroism in common with Major ANDERSON's entire command, are as "household words" throughout the country. On his release from Sumter, Capt. SEYMOUR's health was considerably impaired, but we believe it has much improved since he has taken the field. It seems that he did not accompany our army in its recent movement, but remained with the reserve in Washington.

abstract: "An intelligent mechanic called on us this morning, and gave a statement of his escape from North Carolina, and of his observations on the route. He had been employed in the shops of the North Carolina Railroad, between Weldon and Charlotte, for some time, but grew uneasy in consequence of having been hauled up before Vigilance Committees three time on suspicion of being a Union man.
lead_paragraph: "An intelligent mechanic called on us this morning, and gave a statement of his escape from North Carolina, and of his observations on the route. He had been employed in the shops of the North Carolina Railroad, between Weldon and Charlotte, for some time, but grew uneasy in consequence of having been hauled up before Vigilance Committees three times on suspicion of being a Union man. He states that there are but a few Union men in North Carolina, and they live with a halter round their necks. The Southerners where he resided knew all about how the Manassas battle would come off five days before it really took place, and the North Carolina Central Railroad passed 8,000 Georgia, Alabama and South Carolina troops north just before it took place. Our informant escaped just while they were rejoining most loudly over the result of the Manassas affair, and when they thought themselves invincible.

abstract: DEAR SIR: In reply to yours of Aug. 2, I hasten to say that the information (which you say is from Chicago) "that Illinois had no more volunteers, and that we would have to initiate incasures for drafting," is without the least foundation. I'am amazed that any citizen of Illinois should give currency to any such statement.
lead_paragraph: SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 6, 1861.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon the pirates of the sckooner Petrel, captured by the St. Lawrence, were brought from Moyamensing Prison to the United States District Court, for the purpose of having a hearing. The prisoners were handcuffed in pairs, and drove up from the prison in two omnibuses. There were thirty five in all, one being left in a sick bed in prison.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon the pirates of the schooner Petrel, captured by the St. Lawrence, were brought from Moyamensing Prison to the United States District Court, for the purpose of having a hearing. The prisoners were handcuffed in pairs, and drove up from the prison in two omnibuses. There were thirty five in all, one being left in a sick bed in prison. Long before the arrival of the prisoners a large-crowd congregated around the Court, and as soon as the prisoners were brought in, the room was rapidly filled. The men presented a very shabby appearance, some of them being meanly clad and bare-footed. As soon as they were seated the irons were taken from their hands, and the men were guarded by the Deputy Marshals an a posse of police.

abstract: The first direct communication from Hon. ALFRED ELY, since his capture on the 21st ult. -- nearly three weeks ago -- has been received. A letter, written by his own hand, and addressed to his wife, was received by her this morning by mail. We are permitted to extract from it so much as may be of interest to the public. The letter is very brief. It will be seen that he alludes to previous letters sent. They have not been received:

abstract: The United States Marshal made an important arrest yesterday, after two days' hunting about town. Some days ago, a well-dresed stranger arrived in this city, and stopped at the Parker House. He registered his name and habitation as "C. JORDAN, Pittsburgh, Penn."
lead_paragraph: The United States Marshal made an important arrest yesterday, after two days' hunting about town. Some days ago, a well-dresed stranger arrived in this city, and stopped at the Parker House. He registered his name and habitation as "C. JORDAN, Pittsburgh, Penn." It came to the knowledge of the United States District Marshal that a person of some note from Secessia was in town, who really hailed from Norfolk. The officers got hold of one end of the thread of evidence, and pulled it out of a tangled web until they traced the stranger from Norfolk to the stranger at the Parker House, hailing from Pittsburgh. An erroneous description of the traveler, and the fact that he had shaved his moustache, delayed the search for a whole day, but the officers found him yesterday, at the office of the Southern Steamship Company. He was taken in custody, and carried to the United States Court-house, to await further developments.

abstract: We notice with sincere pleasure the appointment of Lieut.-Col. ROBERT NUGENT, of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., to a Captaincy in the regular service of the United States. No more deserving volunteer officer could have been selected by the War Department, nor one more likely to reflect credit on the organization of our State militia. The Lieutenant-Colonel, or rather Captain, as we must henceforth call him, was born in the north of Ireland -- his brother, JOHN M. NUGENT, being at present the Mayor of Dundalk. Capt. NUGENT came to this country immediately after the abortive insurrection of 1848; and having strong military tastes, soon enrolled his name in the Fourth Company of the National Guards, and served two years under Capt. RIBLETT, thus graduating as a high private from the Seventh. On the organization of the Sixty-ninth, in 1852, Capt. NUGENT, we learn, became one of its earliest officers, and has served faithfully in its ranks as Lieutenant, Captain, Major and Lieutenant-Colonel, down to the present day. A clear-headed; warm-hearted, fearless, earnest and thoroughly-educated gentleman, we commend Capt. NUGENT, of the Thirteenth Infantry United States Army, to the most friendly notice of his new associates, -- assuring them that while his old companions in arms do not grudge any sacrifice that is for the benefit of the Union, they deeply regret both on account of their invariably pleasant official and social relations, the loss of their Lieutenant Colonel. -- New-York Leader.

abstract: A man calling himself CHARLES KING, hailing from North Carolina, was last night arrested by Officer STEVENS, of the Southern District, by order of Major-Gen. DIX, on the charge of being concerned in the raising of a number of men, whose purpose it was to organize themselves into a crew, and take passage on some boat, intending to capture it in the same manner as the St. Nicholas, and then turn her into a pirate. By some means the purpose of KING got out, and coming to the ears of Major-Gen. DIX, he gave the order for his arrest. Quite a number of young men had joined the fortunes of KING, and as their names are known, it is not likely that they will escape. KING was this morning conveyed to Fort McHenry, where he will be continued until the facts are investigated.

abstract: ARREST OF A NOTORIOUS FORGER AND COUNTERFEITER. JEERY COWDEN, alias JOHN COLBURN, alias A. P. MILLER, a notorious forger and counterfeiter, was arrested late last (Friday) night, near the Hoboken Ferry, by Sergeant D. JACOBS and Officer MURPHY, of the Fifth Precinet.
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF A NOTORIOUS FORGER AND COUNTERFEITER. -- JERRY COWDEN, alias JOHN COLBURN, alias A.P. MILLER, a notorious forger and counterfeiter, was arrested late last (Friday) night, near the Hoboken Ferry, by Sergeant D. JACOBS and Officer MURPHY, of the Fifth Precinct, Brooklyn, and detective-officer CHARLES NOYES, of St. Louis. The charge against him is forgery on the banks of Chicago, St. Louis, Pittsburgh, Columbus and Detroit, to the extent of between $20,000 and $30,000. He is also charged with having, under the guise of a drover, passed a large amount of the Brighton counterfeits upon Western Bankers. Immediately upon the arrest of COWDEN, the officers hurried him to Jersey City, and guarded their prisoner during the night at a private house, and in the morning took an early train for St. Louis, via Philadelphia and Pittsburgh.

abstract: It may be considered almost certain that ere this a battle has been fought at Springfield, between the National force, under Gen. LYON, and the rebels, under BEN. McCULLOCH and other leaders. Our latest dispatches represent that subsequent to the affairs at Dug Springs and Curran,...
lead_paragraph: It may be considered almost certain that ere this a battle has been fought at Springfield, between the National force, under Gen. LYON, and the rebels, under BEN. MCCULLOCH and other leaders. Our latest dispatches represent that subsequent to the affairs at Dug Springs and Curran, Gen. LYON retired to Springfield, considering it imprudent to remain away from that important point-while there was a chance that the enemy, with superior numbers, might outflank him, and gain possession of it. He reached there on Monday morning, and prepared for a vigorous defence against the rebels, who were reported to be advancing against him by four different roads, their advance guards being only fifteen miles distant. In anticipation of an immediate attack, Gen. LYON had called in the Home Guards from the country around, and was perfectly confident of victory, although he had no intrenchment, and the number of his Army was inferior. He retired, however, when his splendid artillery, which, served by such men as Gen. SIEGEL, would no doubt prove too much for the enemy in a field fight such as was expected. The condition of the enemy's Commissariat was represented to be very bad, and this fact, it was believed, would hasten the battle. We shall probably soon have news of a decisive character.

abstract: On opening the window on the west side of my room this morning, I beheld the town of Hampton in flames. It was not long after reveille. The smoke was rising in dense columns of black on the right, while the lighter columns told where the fire had been raging longer. It first broke out about midnight.
lead_paragraph: FORTRESS MONROE, VA., Thursday, Aug. 8, 1861.

abstract: Let us hope that one benefit that will come out of the state of solution into which all the elements of society are now thrown, will be to direct the public mind towards a more rational style of living.
lead_paragraph: Let us hope that one benefit that will come out of the state of solution into which all the elements of society are now thrown, will be to direct the public mind towards a more rational style of living. It is certainly difficult to conceive anything more irrational than our American style. New-York leads off, followed by our other cities, and the country not much behind -- in the career of show and sham, waste and riot. We scarcely know what such a thing as social independence is. People try to conceal the essential poverty of their lives under gaud and glitter. All our habits and usages -- our housing, menage, eating, dress -- are pitched in the highest key of extravagance. What wonder that the huge hollow sham collapses at every commercial reverse, and comes tumbling about our heads?
headline: {'main': 'Economy and the Art of Living.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Economy and the Art of Living.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: HENRY KING, a wealthy resident of Allentown, Penn., died a few weeks since, leaving an estate valued at $300,000. He died childless. He was a brother of T. BUTLER KING, one of the Commissioners of the Confederate States, now in Europe. Mr. KING had made a will, leaving half of his property to his wife and the other half to his brother, but a few weeks before his death, exasperated at the secession sentiments of his brother, he made a new will, leaving most of his property to his wife, and the remainder to charitable purposes.
lead_paragraph: HENRY KING, a wealthy resident of Allentown, Penn., died a few weeks since, leaving an estate valued at $300,000. He died childless. He was a brother of T. abstract: -- The census of Ireland for the year 1861, which has just been published by the British Government, reveals the startling fact that there has been during the past ten years a decrease of Irish population of 789,842 -- the population of Ireland in 1861 being 5,764,543, as compared with 6,552,385 in 1851. This is a diminution of 12.02 per cent., while during the previous decennial period there was a decrease of 19.85 per cent.

abstract: Every page of the morning edition of the New-York TIMES is stereotyped, and worked in duplicate. abstract: It is easy to see that the Democratic leaders in this State have made up their minds to bring forward fresh compromises as a means of saving the Union. This is the real motive of their declining to join the Republicans in sustaining the war. They expect to create a Peace Party, that is a party which will commission the South to dictate its own concessions and return to the Union upon its own terms.

abstract: That the Confederate leaders are preparing for an attack on Washington in front, and in the rear through insurgent Maryland, we think there are many reasons for believing. While BEAUREGARD pushes upon Alexandria and Arlington, and Gen. JOHNSON attempts a...
lead_paragraph: That the Confederate leaders are preparing for an attack on Washington in front, and in the rear through insurgent Maryland, we think there are many reasons for believing. While BEAUREGARD pushes upon Alexandria and Arlington, and Gen. JOHNSON attempts a crossing of the Potomac above, Gen. MAGRUDER will probably leave his camp at Yorktown, and try to put himself, with a good part of his Army for a nucleus, at the head of the rebels in Maryland, crossing at or near Aquia Creek.

abstract: The letter of Gen. BUTLER to the Secretary of War, making inquiries as to the disposal of the numerous fugitive slaves now at Fortress Monroe and daily arriving there, has been responded to by Mr. CAMERON, and his reply was yesterday dispatched to Gen. BUTLER.
lead_paragraph: The letter of Gen. BUTLER to the Secretary of War, making inquiries as to the disposal of the numerous fugitive slaves now at Fortress Monroe and daily arriving there, has been responded to by Mr. CAMERON, and his reply was yesterday dispatched to Gen. BUTLER. The question with regard to negroes owing service to persons in rebellion against the authority of the Government of the United States, and used by them in hostility to the Government, is sufficiently met by the law recently passed by Congress, declaring their confiscation when captured. Of course, when such negroes are fugitives, no claim for their return can be recognized. With regard to negroes escaping from the service of loyal masters, a more difficult question is presented. This difficulty will be overcome, the Secretary thinks, by also receiving such fugitives into the service of the United States, and by keeping a record showing the name and description of the fugitive, and the name and character of the master, as a guide to the proper disposal of such cases at the close of the war. Gen. BUTLER is also instructed to prevent any interference with the slaves of peaceful citizens, and to permit the voluntary return of a fugitive, except in cases where the public good may require their detention.

abstract: The western part of Michigan, especially the region about Niles, was visited Wednesday night by a severe storm of rain, accompanied by terrific thunder and lightning.
lead_paragraph: The western part of Michigan, especially the region about Niles, was visited Wednesday night by a severe storm of rain, accompanied by terrific thunder and lightning. Trees were uprooted, buildings destroyed, cattle and horses killed, and in some instances human life lost.

abstract: Prince NAPOLEON'S experience at Manassas was not such as to create in his mind a very favorable opinion of the rebels or their cause. Only himself was accommodated with a bed. His companions were compelled to sleep in their carriages, and the rebel soldiers slept any and everywhere under hedges and trees, they being without tents. The troops are miserably fed, and the Prince said he had but one good meal while he was there.

abstract: Traitors at home and sympathizers with traitors abroad persist in discussing the question of the insurrection against the American Government as if it were simply a question of interpretation of written Constitutions.
lead_paragraph: Traitors at home and sympathizers with traitors abroad persist in discussing the question of the insurrection against the American Government as if it were simply a question of interpretation of written Constitutions. Is secession a reserved right of a state or not? Is State sovereignty, independent of and superior to the sovereignty of the Union? Does not the Republican principle entitle a people to change their Government at pleasure? And if a State wishes to withdraw from a Union that it no longer loves, why should it be restrained? What part of the Constitution forbids it? So the debate goes on, as if the issue involved was one of merely abstract consideration and interpretation, in which the sharpest polemic is apt to have the victory and the accord of right.

abstract: DESPERATE FIGHT AND STABBING AFFRAY.  Early yesterday morning several young men, who had been drinking freely on Saturday night, paid a visit to the house of HENRY BUTHMAN, No. 220 Centrestreet, which has a notoriously bad reputation, and there engaged in a bloody fight. How the affray originated is not known, but it was generally participated in, and knives, decanters and clubs were used.
lead_paragraph: DESPERATE FIGHT AND STABBING AFFRAY. -- Early yesterday morning several young men, who had been drinking freely on Saturday night, paid a visit to the house of HENRY BUTHMAN, No. 220 Centre-street, which has a notoriously bad reputation, and there engaged in a bloody fight. How the affray originated is not known, but it was generally participated in, and knives, decanters and clubs were used. Several persons were injured badly, and three men named PETER MORRISON, TIMOTHY O'BRIEN and THOMAS MULLIGAN were stabbed in the side and body by a ruffian known as "Frenchy." Their wounds, however, are not very severe. The Fourteenth Precinct police hurried to the scene of the disturbance, but "Frenchy" had fled before they arrived. BUTHMAN, the proprietor of the place, was arrested.

abstract: Fowls of all kinds, when laying, like a secret place, where their fellows cannot see them. Therefore, they do not like to squat down in the hennery, surrounded by a greedy flock, that are ready to pounce into the nest, as soon as an egg is layed, and devour it.
lead_paragraph: -- Fowls of all kinds, when laying, like a secret place, where their fellows cannot see them. Therefore, they do not like to squat down in the hennery, surrounded by a greedy flock, that are ready to pounce into the nest, as soon as an egg is layed, and devour it. Therefore, to gratify the hen's secretiveness, and at the same time save the eggs from being devoured by one of the flock my practice has been, for a number of years, to make their nests in nail kegs -- not those that are very small, nor the largest ones -- but of those that will hold about one hundred pounds of nails. In years past, I have been accustomed to fill a keg about half full of straw for a nest; but, the past Winter, I have sawed all the kegs in two equal pats -- knocking out the heads, and then nail a piece of cloth over the large end of each half keg, for a bottom. Any kind of old or new cloth may be tacked on with small trimming tacks. During the Winter, these half kegs are nailed up against the side of the hennery, about four feet from the floor. Hens that lay will soon learn that when they get into these nests, their fellows cannot see them, as they are completely secluded in their cosy little nests; and if they themselves are disposed to eat eggs, they find that, if they attempt it while standing on the edge of the keg, they cannot reach them conveniently; and if they hop down into the nest, and attempt to pick the eggs, they will roll down against their feet, and they soon learn that they are not able to pick hard enough in such a position to break the shell. I find that a cloth bottom is superior to a wooden bottom, covered with a nest of straw. As the weather becomes warmer, so that the hens seek nests in the yard, we make nests in secluded nooks, or the kegs might be removed from the hennery and nailed against the side of the fence, and a little roof made over them.

abstract: We learn the following from "Camp Federal Hill," Baltimore, Md., Col. ABRAM DURYEE'S Regiment of Zouaves, (Fifth Regiment N.Y. Volunteers.) This fine regiment moved from Camp Hamilton, near Fortress Monroe, on the 25th ult., and reached Baltimore on the 16th, as was then supposed, en route for Washington. D.C.
lead_paragraph: We learn the following from "Camp Federal Hill," Baltimore, Md., Col. ABRAM DURYEE's Regiment of Zouaves, (Fifth Regiment N.Y. Volunteers.) This fine regiment moved from Camp Hamilton, near Fortress Monroe, on the 25th ult., and reached Baltimore on the 16th, as was then supposed, en route for Washington. D.C. It is is now thought that this regiment will be detained there some time, perhaps months, in erecting fortifications at that point, which is an important one, and, in connection with Fort McHenry, holds the city of Baltimore under perfect control. We hear also that the Bull Run affair produces an intensity of feeling in the regiment, absolutely startling in its depth, and in the deliberate resolves, if they ever have a chance to avenge those who fell there. Several of the soldiers of that regiment were firemen at home, and the first reported heavy losses of the Fire Zouaves were deeply felt, and its cause as deeply execrated. The regiment is far from being satisfied with their prospective shelvement, and would much prefer to be actively engaged with Gen. MCCLELLAN or Gen. BANKS, for the Union cause.

abstract: We received a visit, to-day, from a very intelligent, moderate Union man, named CHARLES SUTTON, who has escaped, with his wife and eight children, from near Fairfax Court-house, with the loss of nearly all his property. His quietly-told story gave one a strong impression of the miseries induced by the rebellion, and gave one a deeper feeling of hatred towards the ambitious conspirators who have plunged the South into such distress and agony. Mr. SUTTON came from the North into Virginia about twenty years since, and all his children are natives of the Old Dominion. His farm was located near Fairfax, and at the election, some ten weeks ago, he voted "Union." Before the National advance to Fairfax, Mr. SUTTON deemed it prudent to leave his farm for Washington. When the rebels appeared in that region, they seized about $600 worth of Mr. S.'s property, some of which they promised to pay for, while the rest they took without pay. When the Bull Run affair took place, his family joined in the National retreat, his wife and children driving to Georgetown in an ox wagon. When they left the house they left it open, with all the furniture, provisions, &c., there. They broke down the few fences, so that what live stock the rebels had left might wander off and get food and water. Among other abandoned property was 800 bushels of wheat, quantities of hay, butter, &c. Arriving safely in Washington. Mr. S. brought his family North to a more congenial locality.
lead_paragraph: We received a visit, to-day, from a very intelligent, moderate Union man, named CHARLES SUTTON, who has escaped, with his wife and eight children, from near Fairfax Court-house, with the loss of nearly all his property. His quietly-told story gave one a strong impression of the miseries induced by the rebellion, and gave one a deeper feeling of hatred towards the ambitious conspirators who have plunged the South into such distress and agony. Mr. SUTTON came from the North into Virginia about twenty years since, and all his children are natives of the Old Dominion. His farm was located near Fairfax, and at the election, some ten weeks ago, he voted "Union." Before the National advance to Fairfax, Mr. SUTTON deemed it prudent to leave his farm for Washington. When the rebels appeared in that region, they seized about $600 worth of Mr. S.'s property, some of which they promised to pay for, while the rest they took without pay. When the Bull Run affair took place, his family joined in the National retreat, his wife and children driving to Georgetown in an ox wagon. When they left the house they left it open, with all the furniture, provisions, &c., there. They broke down the few fences, so that what live stock the rebels had left might wander off and get food and water. Among other abandoned property was 800 bushels of wheat, quantities of hay, butter, &c. Arriving safely in Washington. Mr. S. brought his family North to a more congenial locality.

abstract: Is it permitted to believe that the South will yield, and that the Union will be main  tained? Though to-morrow's telegraph may meek to-day's prediction, we do not hesitate to answer in the affirmative. What authorises us to speak thus is precisely the famous battle which is always going to but never does take place.
lead_paragraph: * * * Is it permitted to believe that the South will yield, and that the Union will be main tained? Though to-morrow's telegraph may meek to-day's prediction, we do not hesitate to answer in the affirmative. What authorises us to speak thus is precisely the famous battle which is always going to but never does take place. We Europeans who enjoy the enviable happiness of having two million professional soldiers, are inclined to despise the American Volunteers, because they do not immediately fly at each other's throats. But if they do not fight, do not imagine it is because they fear death. A Western pioneer exposes his life, perhaps, as many times in the course of the year as the bravest European soldier. * * * But in proportion as the situation develops, the clearer becomes one fact of which the South had not dreamed, namely: That the war is useless; and another fact, still more singular, which the North will be obliged to confess before long, viz.: That war is all but impossible. They do not fight, in fact, because they do not know how to begin the conflict. Neither Army is organized for a long campaign; the spaces necessary to be occupied on each side are immense; and hardly could the most ingenious tacticians of Europe, having at their disposal old troops, be prepared to concentrate in masses, as wanted, or to spread themselves over the face of a country in a multitude of platoons -- hardly could they solve the problem of occupying so vast a field of operations. If the Anti-President of the South, (we must say, under the circumstances, Anti-President, as they used to say Anti-Pope in the Middle Ages,) if the Anti-President of the South, JEFF. DAVIS, had been able to carry out his first plan -- to inundate Virginia with troops, take possession of Washington by a rapid march, there proclaim himself sole legitimate President of the whole Confederation, drag into Congress the hesitating and the neutral, frighten the timid, and thus impose on the North, by quasi-legal means, the principle of the unlimited extension of Slavery -- a short campaign of that sort might have been of some service to the South. Now that the plan has failed, what can be the result of the war? If the slaveholding South succeeds in breaking up the Union, it will have created by its side a separate State which will be an open asylum for all fugitive slaves. If the North collects an Army sufficiently formidable to invade the South, and conquer it, the Union, at least in its present form, becomes dissolved by the very fact of victory; the most subtle imagination fails to conceive of a National system in which one-half of the federated States belongs, against its will, to a league, and at the same time remains free.

abstract: We observe, on the French side of the Bee of yesterday, two letters from Gov. T.O. MOORE, to Maj. BENJAMIN BUISSON, which suggest some curious reflections. The first is dated New-Orleans, July 11, 1861, and authorizes Maj. BUISSON to construct fortifications for the protection of the city outside of its limits, and for this purpose to take possession of such positions, houses, and other property as might be necessary to effect the object, it being understood, of course, that the owners should be paid a fair price for whatever might be taken. On the 21st of the same month, this authority was revoked, the Governor stating that he will not hereafter grant any authority for works of defence without the approbation of the Confederate commander of this department. It is ardently to be desired that there may be no clash or disagreement between our Confederate, State, or municipal authorities in reference to our common defence. Nor should there be any confused counsels, and, above all, no blunders. Furthermore, there is no time to be spent in any wrangling. The interests at stake will not admit of it. Let our authorities take no step without mature deliberation and consultation with regular military engineers or other officers thoroughly competent to decide upon what is necessary to be done, and then let them take no steps backward. The enemy will know everything that transpires, and it there is any weak place in our defences, or confusion in our counsels, he will be certain to profit by it. Forewarned, forearmed.

abstract: "On Saturday afternoon a train of twenty-seven cars, laden with artillery, powder, and shot and shell, passed through this place, destined for Cairo, to be used by Gen. FREEMONT. The train was in charge of the Adams Express Company. Gen. FREMONT telegraphed to Pittsburgh to have this supply of artillery and munitions sent through by express. It was telegraphed back that the attendant expense would be heavy. The reply was characteristic of the man, that expense was not the matter in question. He wanted the material, and it must go through in the quickest possible time. There must be hot work close at hand on the Mississippi. Gen. FREMONT takes hold just as if he knew what to do and how to do it most effectually. If he does not wipe out the Bull Run stain ere long, the country is much mistaken in its man. There were several big guns -- 32 and 42 pounders -- on the train."

abstract: Earl RUSSELL has bade farewell to his old constituents of the City of London, and the benches of that body, in which the best part of his forty-seven years of public life have been passed. The doors of that arena are now closed to him, and the name of Lord JOHN is a matter of history, beyond the chance of future accident. The Earl has the reputation of being somewhat hard in temperament.
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Saturrday, July 27, 1861.

abstract: Nations unaccustomed to the weight of heavy taxation, are as restive and intractable as a broken horse, which resents as an insult the imposition  of burthens calculated to impede his elasticity of motion. But as the fiery steed gradually tones down under the gentle persuasives of the master, and at length learns to submit with grace, if not with humiliation, to the pressure of the saddle,...

July 25, in latitude 28째 08 longitude 68째13' she was boarded and taken possession of by the privateer schooner Dixie, a prize crew placed on board, and ordered into Charleston or Wilmington. Capt.
