abstract: The Richmond Enquirer publishes what purports to be a letter from JOHN L. HODSEN, Adjutant-General of the State of Maine, addressed to Col. DUNNELL, of one of the Maine Regiments, concerning one Capt. BRADY, whom the Government had decided not to commission.
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Enquirer publishes what purports to be a letter from JOHN L. HODSEN, Adjutant-General of the State of Maine, addressed to Col. DUNNELL, of one of the Maine Regiments, concerning one Capt. BRADY, whom the Government had decided not to commission. The letter instructs the Colonel how to suppress any difficulty that might result from an apprehended resistance of BRADY'S men; -- and at the close the writer remarks: "You will require several dozen handcuffs for prisoners taken in battle, if not for your own folks, and you had better procure them now."

abstract: A new impetus was given to the organization of this regiment by the arrival of Count WRATISLAW, who last week was unanimously elected Colonel, and who, until now, was attached to the division of Gen. BUTLER, at Fortress Monroe. Being a descendant of the well-known military family of that name, he has been trained from his earliest youth to the life of a soldier, rising in the Austrian Army, step by step, to the grade of a captain. In the year 1818 he joined the Army of Hungary, of which he is a native, where in consequence of his personal bravery and strategical talent, he was promoted to the rank of Lieutenant Colonel and Chief of the Staff of Gen. KLAPKA's Army corps. His deeds, his wounds, and the unanimous voice of his countrymen, are guarantees that his services will be a valuable acquisition to our National Army. Indeed, he has already proved his military qualities in this country by the superior discipline which he imparted to his command at Newport's News.

abstract: As I write this morning, the sound of bugle and drum and fife, and even the measured voice of the drill-officers strike upon my ear, instead of the accustomed hum of industry. This alone tells of the great change which has come over our country within a few months. Heretofore, an actual soldier was a rare object to most of us.

LEE was concentrating a large force of rebels somewhere in Hardy county, with the intention of marching in this direction and driving everything before him. abstract: Quite an excitement was raised in the city yesterday by the arrest of a Confederate officer, who made his appearance in our streets in the morning attired in the garb of a civilian. It happened as follows: Col. GUTHRIE was walking along Third-street accompanied by a military friend, and near the corner of Walnut-street a gentleman passed him, whom he immediately recognized as Lieut.-Col. TYLER, of the Confederate Army, formerly a captain in the Second Dragoons. On being assured that he was not mistaken in the matter, Col. G. approached the secession officer, and in "appropriate terms" told him he was a prisoner of war. TYLER, after recovering the little shock which his nervous system sustained on the reception of this news, said that as he was not dressed in military uniform, and visited the city as a civilian, he had no idea of being arrested. He was compelled, however, to reconcile himself to the belief, and in a few moments, accompanied by Col. GUTHRIE, he went to the Burnet House. On his way thither, he explained the object of his visit to be to convey his wife, who is a daughter of J.J.B. WRIGHT, of this city, and at present residing at Sedamsville, to Richmond, Va.

abstract: "We have from time to time exposed the conduct of various persons in this city who have been, and are yet, engaged in the criminal practice of smuggling contraband goods through to the Southern Confederacy over the Louisville and Nashville Railroad and otherwise. It is the custom of the smugglers, in many instances, to send the forbidden articles by wagon to Elizabethtown and other stations on the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, the road taking them up at those points and carrying them forward to Nashville. We have good authority for stating that a number of hacks are nightly engaged in this illegal traffic, and that Brooks' station, a short distance from the city, has been an important depot for contraband goods. It is known that an extensive grocer on Market-street dispatched a quantity of contraband articles on Sunday night last, employing a hack as the vehicle of conveyance. Between 10 and 11 o'clock on Sunday night, the grocer alluded to visited his store in a back, took a number of articles from the back door of the store, and placed them in the back, which was evidently heavily laden, starting in the direction of Brooks' Station."

abstract: The Richmond (Va.) Dispatch discusses with much cleverness the dilemma that it supposes the United States Government is in, in regard to holding Washington. In a few days, says that print, "the Confederate flag will be floating from the heights opposite Washington
lead_paragraph: The Richmond (Va.) Dispatch discusses with much cleverness the dilemma that it supposes the United States Government is in, in regard to holding Washington. In a few days, says that print, "the Confederate flag will be floating from the heights opposite Washington City," and the administration "having already taken the precaution to box up the archives of the Government and send them to some securer spot near the North Pole, the Dispatch wonders whether the President, Cabinet, Congress, and all will not "scamper ingloriously away to distant places of security." To impress the Government and Congress properly with a sense of their dangerous position, the Dispatch suggests "cannon balls whizzing over their city, and shells bursting under their feet," as something they will find particularly disagreeable, and to some extent personally unsafe. The Dispatch is rather moved by the picture it has drawn of the strait that the "Lincoln Government" is in, and encourages its members to fight manfully where they are, and so "retrieve their honor," rather than run away and abandon Washington, which will be a virtual "abandonment of the war."

abstract: FATAL FRACAS IN A BAR-ROOM. Coroner JACKMAN was called upon yesterday, to take the antemortem deposition of a sailor named JOHN WILLIAMS, who is lying at the point of death in the New-York Hospital. The injured man, with a number of seamen, was drinking on Sunday night, at a porter-...
lead_paragraph: FATAL FRACAS IN A BAR-ROOM. -- Coroner JACKMAN was called upon yesterday, to take the antemortem deposition of a sailor named JOHN WILLIAMS, who is lying at the point of death in the New-York Hospital. The injured man, with a number of seamen, was drinking on Sunday night, at a porter-house kept by JAMES SMITH, at No. 346 Water-street. Finally, most of them became drunk, and a fight resulted, during which knives were drawn. One of the sailors, a man named AUGUSTIN BARCO, engaged WILLIAMS and wounded him in the side and abdomen with a sheath knife, cutting him so severely, that his liver was injured and his intestines came out. The ruffian next attempted to stab some of the others, but he only managed to cut one GEORGE JOHNSON slightly in the breast, after which he fled from the premises. He was not long at liberty, however, as Officer CRAIG of the Fourth Ward found him. He admitted that he had injured the sufferers, and yesterday Justice OSBORN committed him to prison. The man JOHNSON is also detained as a witness in the case.

abstract: No marine structure but the Great Eastern, has so largely excited the curiosity of Ihe American public as the Stevens Battery, not so much by reason of its supposed vastness, or its impregnable or destructive or any specially defined features, but from the mystery that has ever hung over its origin, character, size, appearance, destination, and perhaps its very existence. Imagination has indeed pictured it as an exaggerated sword-fish, a multangular floating fortress, a steam-propelled carving knife, and all things marine, by turns; but what it is, the Government has wisely retrained from making known. Now that the responsibility of finishing or abandoning it is thrown upon the public, to a certain extent, the veil of secresy is removed -- we would almost say unwisely, for the grand work still embodies features far in advance of any that have been developed by our transatlantic neighbors, and yet it is impossible to keep such matters secret from an enterprising rival.
lead_paragraph: No marine structure but the Great Eastern, has so largely excited the curiosity of Ihe American public as the Stevens Battery, not so much by reason of its supposed vastness, or its impregnable or destructive or any specially defined features, but from the mystery that has ever hung over its origin, character, size, appearance, destination, and perhaps its very existence. abstract: The late American Minister in Paris, Hon. C.J. FAULKNER, of Virginia, was yesterday arrested in Washington by a detachment of the Provost Guard, under orders from the military authorities, and is not at present allowed to hold communica-...
lead_paragraph: The late American Minister in Paris, Hon. C.J. FAULKNER, of Virginia, was yesterday arrested in Washington by a detachment of the Provost Guard, under orders from the military authorities, and is not at present allowed to hold communication with his friends. He expected to close up his business with the State Department, in connection with his late Mission, last evening, and would doubtless have left immediately for Virginia The specific charges upon which the arrest was made are not yet made public, but they will doubtless be promulgated on his examination, which is to take place soon. It will be recollected that Mr. FAULKNER's name has been mentioned in connection with a commission as Brigadier General in the Rebel Army, and this fact may have had something to do with his arrest. He remarked, however, on being arrested, that he was not aware of having done anything to justify such a proceeding. A skirmish took place on Thursday at Lorettsville, between a detachment of the New-York Nineteenth, attached to Gen. BANKS' command, and a company of rebel cavalry, in which the latter were completely routed, with the loss of a lieutenant killed and several men wounded.

abstract: The  Nashville (Tenn.,) Union and American, a secession sheet, announces that the Hon. T. A.R. NELSON, of East Tennessee, has been arrested in Lee County, Virginia, and that he will probably be tried for "treason." Mr.
lead_paragraph: The Nashville (Tenn.,) Union and American, a secession sheet, announces that the Hon. T. A.R. NELSON, of East Tennessee, has been arrested in Lee County, Virginia, and that he will probably be tried for "treason." Mr. NELSON was a member of the late Congress of the United States. He was a firm Union man, and will be remembered for a noble and annihilating reply to some of the bullying and treasonable flourishes made by that pestilent fire-eater, ROGER A. PRYOR, early in that eventful session.

abstract: The schooner Mary and Adeline L. Jenkins, which arrived at this port yesterday morning, reports having been spoken by a privateer. Capt. JENKINS says that while lying at anchor under Tangier Island, in the Chesapeake Bay, waiting for wood, a pungy-...
lead_paragraph: The schooner Mary and Adeline L. Jenkins, which arrived at this port yesterday morning, reports having been spoken by a privateer. Capt. JENKINS says that while lying at anchor under Tangier Island, in the Chesapeake Bay, waiting for wood, a pungy-rigged craft came across from the direction of Ingram Bay. She came up under his quarter and hailed him, asking where he loaded, and where he was bound. Capt. JENKINS informed the pirate that he had loaded his cargo (wood) up Tangier Sound, and was bound to New-York. The pirate did not make any reply, but kept off and run under the stern of the schooner for the purpose of reading her name.

lead_paragraph: The case of the Ex-Police Commissioners of Baltimore, now held in Fort Lafayette, by order of the Government, as State prisioners, was against before the County court, Judge GARRISON, yesterday noon. abstract: A special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday afternoon in the rooms of the Chamber, for the purpose of welcoming Hon. SALMON P.CHASE, Secretary of the treasury, and Hon. CALEB B. SMITH, Secretary of the Interior.
lead_paragraph: A special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday afternoon in the rooms of the Chamber, for the purpose of welcoming Hon. SALMON P. CHASE, Secretary of the treasury, and Hon. CALEB B. SMITH, Secretary of the Interior. About a hundred of the most prominent merchants of the City were present, including PETER COOPER, Esq., MOSES H. GRINNELL, and other gentlemen of equal note. The honorable guests were introduced to the Chamber by JOHN J. CISCO, Esq., Assistant United States Treasurer in this City, and Collector HIRAM BARNEY.

abstract: Intelligence was received here this morning, which explains the apparent inactivity of the rebels, since the battle of Bull Run. According to these accounts, no sooner was it known at Richmond that Gen. McCLELLAN had been withdrawn form Western Virginia, than it was determined to take advantage of that circumstance, to recover all that had been lost through the wonderful celerity and military genius of that remarkable man.

abstract: One Dr. BLAISDELL, for many years a resident of Georgia, owner of a plantation and negroes and other property, all of which has been confiscated, was driven from Macon not long since, on twentyfour hours' notice, simply because of Northern...
lead_paragraph: One Dr. BLAISDELL, for many years a resident of Georgia, owner of a plantation and negroes and other property, all of which has been confiscated, was driven from Macon not long since, on twenty-four hours' notice, simply because of Northern birth, and therefore suspected of having a lingering sympathy for that section, and is now in Cincinnati, as we learn from the Gazette. He has been at Richmond and Manassas. He says JEFF. DAVIS did not command in person at the battle of Stone Bridge, and that the story of undermining the ground at Manassas is pure fiction. The rebels have too many disaffected in their ranks, to place such a fine opportunity in their way of perpetrating such a grand blow up.

On the 3d of August she was captured while attempting to go into Wilmington.

On the 3d of August she was captured while attempting to go into Wilmington.

abstract: The Paris correspondent of the Times says it was currently believed that a solution of the Roman question was near at hand. Nortwithstanding the weak denial of the statement that the Papal Government had supplied arms to the insurrectionists at...
lead_paragraph: The Paris correspondent of the Times says it was currently believed that a solution of the Roman question was near at hand. Nortwithstanding the weak denial of the statement that the Papal Government had supplied arms to the insurrectionists at Naples, it is affirmed that such was really the case, and this fact has determined the Emperor to postpone the solution no longer. The solution expected is the evacuation of the Roman territory by the French, and its occupation by the Italian troops.

abstract: -The late de  tection and arrest of GEO. F. HOTCHKISS, clerk in the Post-office at New-Haven, Conn., explains a series of important mail depredations covering a term of...
lead_paragraph: The late detection and arrest of GEO. F. HOTCHKISS, clerk in the Post-office at New-Haven, Conn., explains a series of important mail depredations covering a term of several months. The number of letters abstracted and destroyed by this wholesale operator will probably never be known, as complaints are for the most part confined to those containing valuable remittances. The number of such has been large, though the aggregate amount of cash inclosures does not reach more than a few hundred dollars. Several thousands in notes, drafts, coupons, etc., have been destroyed.

abstract: A special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday afternoon in the rooms of the Chamber, for the purpose of welcoming Hon. SALMON P.CHASE, Secretary of the Treasury, and Hon. CALEB...
lead_paragraph: A special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday afternoon in the rooms of the Chamber, for the purpose of welcoming Hon. SALMON P.CHASE, Secretary of the Treasury, and Hon. CALEB B. SMITH, Secretary of the Interior. About a hundred of the most prominent merchants of the City were present, including PETER COOPER, Esq., MOSES H. GRINNELL, and other gentlemen of equal note. The honorable guests were introduced to the Chamber by JOHN J. CISCO, Esq., Assistant United States Treasurer in this City, and Collector HIRAM BARNEY.

abstract: The Richmond Enquirer says: "Capt. ROBERT B. GARLAND, U.S. Infantry, and Capt. ADDISON GARLAND, U.S. Marines, both of Amherst County, Va., have resigned their positions to serve their native State in the present war. Lieut. WESTWOOD MCCREERY, of this city, who resigned his post in the United States Army, has reached here from Fort Pickens a few days ago, and has already taken service in the Confederate Army."

abstract: Yesterday morning, pursuant to order, the first four companies of the National Guard, Col. MARSHAL, LEFFERTS, assembled at their armory over Tompkins Market, in order to receive the pay due them for their service to the United States. Major PATTEN paid the men. To-day the remuining four companies will he paid. The amount received by a Private is $23 21, a Corporal receives $26 34, a Sergeant $32 01, an Orderly Sergeant $67 31, all of which includes $5 98 for clothing computed at the rate of $3 83 per month. Second Lieutenants received $163 03, including servants and rations; First Lieutenants $171 47, Captains $202 80. The Adjutant received $199 07, the Surgeon $200, the Major $275 93, and Col. LEFFERTS $345 90. The sum required to pay off this regiment amounts to about $35,000.

abstract: Some  time ago, a report went abroad through the country that the Secretary of War had issued an order disallowing enlistments of any soldiers in the United States service, who could not speak the English language.
lead_paragraph: Some time ago, a report went abroad through the country that the Secretary of War had issued an order disallowing enlistments of any soldiers in the United States service, who could not speak the English language. This report caused great dissatisfaction among all adopted citizens, as we might have expected; for they are not only as a general thing devotedly patriotic, but already, in the present war, have shown praiseworthy alacrity in responding to the call of the Government for troops, and distinguished prowess on every battle-field. SIEGEL and ROSECRANS have won laurels as fadeless in the cause of the Union, as any soldiers who have a better acquaintance with English as their mother tongue; and their countrymen, and indeed all adopted citizens, regarded the Government order as a gratuitous and most mischievous insult upon their brilliant generalship and invaluable services.Explanations were immediately sent out by the Secretary of War, that the order had been wholly misunderstood - that it was not to disallow the enlistment of the foreign-born who could not speak English, - but only to decline their enlistment in companies that had officers speaking the English language only. The reason was given that they could not understand orders given them in English by their officers, and so could not be perfected in drill, nor understand orders given in presence of an enemy. It was not intended to discontinue the acceptance of companies composed wholly of adopted citizens, provided they had adopted citizens for officers, whose commands would be intelligible.

abstract: ARREST OF AN ESCAPED FELON. -- A desperate character, named MIKE REYNOLDS, was arrested a few days since on a warrant issued by Justice POPE, of Hoboken, and committed to the County Jail, on the charge of committing an outrageous assault, and battery on Mrs. STANTON and family, at Washington Village. It has since transpired that the accused is the same person arrested about fire years since, on a charge of having committed a rape upon a colored servant girl living in Mr. GREGORY's family at Weehawken Hill. Before the day of trial, REYNOLDS succeeded in making his escape from jail, disguised in female attire, and has been absent from this part of the country until within a few days past. Mr. GREGORY has taken steps for his trial on that charge, at the Fall Term of Court.
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF AN ESCAPED FELON. -- A desperate character, named MIKE REYNOLDS, was arrested a few days since on a warrant issued by Justice POPE, of Hoboken, and committed to the County Jail, on the charge of committing an outrageous assault, and battery on Mrs. STANTON and family, at Washington Village. abstract: The Daily News and the Tribune are seriously exercised by our lack of admiration for the Fire Zouaves. The grief of the News is natural enough, since its proprietor paid the traveling expenses of those among them who...
lead_paragraph: The Daily News and the Tribune are seriously exercised by our lack of admiration for the Fire Zouaves. The grief of the News is natural enough, since its proprietor paid the traveling expenses of those among them who wished to desert. As a matter of course he is sensitive in regard to their reputation. The Tribune's zeal on their behalf is probably due to its natural sympathy with those who are loud-mouthed and vociferous in advance of danger, and who run howling with fear the moment they come upon it.

abstract: The Journal of Commerce copies a very silly paragraph from a Washington letter in the Express, about Gov. SEWARD's jealousy of Gen. Dix as a candidate for the Presidency, and adds: "This is but a sample of the daily gossip on these topics which we find in the papers." What special privileges in the way of reading the newspapers the Journal may enjoy we do not know, but this paragraph which the Journal quotes is the only allusion to the question of Presidential nominations we have happened to meet. The Journal has either invented its facts or is very unfortunate in its exchanges.

abstract: The letter of Mr. CAMERON, Secretary of War, to Gen. BUTLER, at Fortress Monroe, indicates the policy of the Government in regard to the treatment of slaves who shall escape from citizens of rebel States and seek protection in the armies of the United States. The ground taken seems to be eminently prudent and sound, and cannot fail, we think, to give satisfaction to the country.

abstract: ARREST OF AN ESCAPED FELON, A desperate character, named MIKE REYNOLDS, was arrested a few days since on a warrant issued by Justice POPE, of Hoboken, and committed to the County Jail, on the charge of committing an outrageous assault and bat-...
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF AN ESCAPED FELON. -- A desperate character, named MIKE REYNOLDS, was arrested a few days since on a warrant issued by Justice POPE, of Hoboken, and committed to the County Jail, on the charge of committing an outrageous assault and battery on Mrs. STANTON and family, at Washington Village. It has since transpired that the accused is the same person arrested about five years since, on a charge of having committed a rape upon a colored servant girl living in Mr. GREGORY's family at Weehawken Hill. Before the day of trial, REYNOLDS succeeded in making his escape from jail, disguised in female attire, and has been absent from this part of the country until within a few days past. Mr. GREGORY has taken steps for his trial on that charge, at the Fall Term of Court.

abstract: Intelligence was received here this morning, which explains the apparent inactivity of the rebels since the battle of Bull Run. abstract: The Confederate Congress at Richmond is holding secret sessions, but enough has transpired to disclose the fact that the great subject is the ways and means for the prosecution of the war the alternative being whether the Government should assume the...
lead_paragraph: The Confederate Congress at Richmond is holding secret sessions, but enough has transpired to disclose the fact that the great subject is the ways and means for the prosecution of the war -- the alternative being whether the Government should assume the entire crops of the South -- cotton, sugar and tobacco, or such portions of them as the planters may subscribe towards its loan. These crops, yet to be harvested, are its only resource, by the confession of Mr. STEPHENS, its Vice-President, who is now stumping his own State in behalf of the loan. There is no specie at the South, except in the vaults of the banks at New-Orleans, and the managers of these very prudently refuse to be represented in a Convention of Southern Banks to consider the wants of the rebel Government. There is no money, except the depreciated bills of non-specie-paying banks.

abstract: Whereas, by the act of the General Assembly, passed May 6, 1861, it is made the duty of the Governor " to raise, organize and equip a provisional force of fifty-five thousand volunteers,twenty-five thousand of whom, or any less number which the wants of the service may demand, shall be fitted ...
lead_paragraph: Whereas, by the act of the General Assembly, passed May 6, 1861, it is made the duty of the Governor "to raise, organize and equip a provisional force of fifty-five thousand volunteers,twenty-five thousand of whom, or any less number which the wants of the service may demand, shall be fitted for the field at the earliest practicable moment, and the remainder of which shall be held in reserve, ready to march at short notice;" and whereas the provisional force which has been organized, armed, equipped, and fitted for the field has been transferred to the service of the Confederate States; and whereas the President and Congress of the United States have been deaf to the promptings of justice, and notwithstanding their troops have been ingloriously defeated in their plans of subjugation by the intrepid valor of the South, have appropriated immense amounts of money and are bringing into the field large additional armaments to effect their purpose of overriding and trampling upon the rights and liberties of our people:

abstract: The pressure of the times will, hardly interfere with the health and pleasure of City folk, by driving them from the narrow quarters, late hours and elaborate dinners of the fashionable resorts, to the country inns and farm-houses, the hunting and fishing, and the riding and clambering of the fresh mountain districts, so easily accessible on the west and the north.
lead_paragraph: The pressure of the times will hardly interfere with the health and pleasure of City folk, by driving them from the narrow quarters, late hours and elaborate dinners of the fashionable resorts, to the country inns and farm-houses, the hunting and fishing, and the riding and clambering of the fresh mountain districts, so easily accessible on the west and the north. While a few fastidious letter-writers make fun enough of homely fare and tasteless surroundings, as if they any more defined all country life than the Five Points characterize all city I life, the great mass of wiser and quieter City people are much given, of late, to ferreting out the fruitful valleys, the commanding hill-sides, and the good living of Southern New-York and New-England, and Northern Jersey and Pennsylvania, and of bringing to town in October a company of hard-fisted boys, and rosy wives and daughters -- the sight of which brings professional sorrow to the countenance of the family physician. We advise people who can't afford fourth-story rooms of the Newport persuasion, and don't know where to go for the fresh air they sorely need, to make a reconnoisance up the Harlem railroad, for instance, to the mountain and lake districts of Croton Falls, Salisbury, and the upper Housatonic. A hundred miles to the northward, lies perhaps the most agreeable country for summer-reasoning purposes -- scenery, health, and facilities for good living considered -- that has yet been discovered by New-Yorkers. In addition to the highly cultivated valleys, and the lakes and forests of a hilly section, the Toccounuc mountains break up into spurs and peaks innumerable (the highest being 2,800 feet above the sea,) and affording views into four States, besides the gorges and waterfalls, which are the delight, of picincists and trout fishermen. The quiet towns on either side the Hudson, and the hill and valley counties of Northern Jersey, are all accessible by rail, and the reason why more of our citizens do not find such delightful, yet economical summer resorts, is because they do not try.

abstract: There is considerable bad feeling, it is said, in the First Regiment of Long Island Volunteers, now stationed at Fort Schayler, growing out of the fact that the families of the men who enlisted in NewYork have not as yet received any relief, and will not do so, under present arrangements, until the regiment is actually at the seat of war.
lead_paragraph: There is considerable bad feeling, it is said, in the First Regiment of Long Island Volunteers, now stationed at Fort Schuyler, growing out of the fact that the families of the men who enlisted in New-York have not as yet received any relief, and will not do so, under present arrangements, until the regiment is actually at the seat of war. On the other hand, the families of the men who enlisted in Brooklyn have received relief from the time the regiment entered the service-several weeks ago. This state of things very naturally creates considerable ill feeling. This regiment had more difficulties to contend with probably than any other that has been raised. It was not recognized by either of the War Committees in New-York or Brooklyn, and the only assistance received was from private sources; and in this way aid came in slowly, for there was a vague suspicion that the attempt to raise a regiment would not be successful. The fact that the Colonel, JULIES ALLEN, has sumounted all these difficulties, and has a full command, fully armed and equipped, would indicate that he is the right man in the right place. This regiment will leave for the seat of war, it is now expected, on Friday or Saturday next.

abstract: Capt. BOREHAM, of the brig Sea Foam, arrived yes-to-day, informs us that the Sumter arrived off Curacoa on the night of the 17th of July, and fired a gun for the fort, but the people of the fort not knowing her national flag, would not allow her to come in until the Governor had been consulted. The Sumter then sent an officer with an armed crew ashore to talk with that official as to coming into port, to coal up and refit, which the Governor allowed, against the protest of the United States Consul. She lay at Curacoa for eight days. During the time, the crew had their liberty ashore, and, as Capt. B. says, "raised the devil generally." The Captain of the Sumter said he was very sorry he had not arrived three days sooner, as he wanted ice badly -- which article Capt. B. had a cargo of, and he had only arrived the day previous. Capt. B. was detained four days waiting the departure of the Sumter, which took place on the 24th. He saw no privateers or suspicious vessels on the passage home.
lead_paragraph: Capt. BOREHAM, of the brig Sea Foam, arrived yes-to-day, informs us that the Sumter arrived off Curacoa on the night of the 17th of July, and fired a gun for the fort, but the people of the fort not knowing her national flag, would not allow her to come in until the Governor had been consulted. The Sumter then sent an officer with an armed crew ashore to talk with that official as to coming into port, to coal up and refit, which the Governor allowed, against the protest of the United States Consul. She lay at Curacoa for eight days. During the time, the crew had their liberty ashore, and, as Capt. B. says, "raised the devil generally." The Captain of the Sumter said he was very sorry he had not arrived three days sooner, as he wanted ice badly -- which article Capt. B. had a cargo of, and he had only arrived the day previous. Capt. B. was detained four days waiting the departure of the Sumter, which took place on the 24th. He saw no privateers or suspicious vessels on the passage home.

abstract: It is now well ascertained that the whole plan of the advance of our forces upon Manassas Junction, the deviations of the different columns, the movements designed as feints as well as for attack, were as thoroughly known to the rebel Generals as to our own.
lead_paragraph: It is now well ascertained that the whole plan of the advance of our forces upon Manassas Junction, the deviations of the different columns, the movements designed as feints as well as for attack, were as thoroughly known to the rebel Generals as to our own. Hence they were fully prepared to receive it with an overwhelming force, and defeat was almost inevitable, as it is in nine times out of ten, in such cases. It is the object of strategy to mislead the enemy, and to assail him in his weakest point. But up to this time we have had no strategy in the campaign in the East, because the rebels, through spies, with which Washington is swarming, are kept constantly informed of all our plans and the condition and strength of our forces, and can always adapt the strength and mode of their resistance to our plan of attack. Hence the disasters, or perhaps we should say, the uniform want of success in Eastern Virginia, the campaign in which is directed from Washington, while in other parts of the country our arms have made steady progress.

abstract: At last rumor has sated the truth about Gen. WOOL. His things are being packed up, and in a few days the office, which for years has been the headquarters of the Department of the East, will be vacant.
lead_paragraph: At last rumor has sated the truth about Gen. WOOL. His things are being packed up, and in a few days the office, which for years has been the headquarters of the Department of the East, will be vacant. Whether Troy will henceforward contain any such officer as Gen. WOOL, seems a mystery now; but as war has made Fortress Monroe the chiefest point recorded in the old geographical arrangement of this Department, and New-York the most central and convenient locate for such a post as Troy was, there is a strong probability that no "General in the Army" will be stationed in the later town again. Of the posts put down in the last register, soldiers are still stationed in the following:

abstract: This splendid corps is rapidly organizing, under the command of Col. EUGENE LE GAL. late of the Fifty-fifth Regiment N.Y.S.M. The reputation of Col. LE GAL as an experienced officer and thorough ...
lead_paragraph: This splendid corps is rapidly organizing, under the command of Col. EUGENE LE GAL. late of the Fifty-fifth Regiment N.Y.S.M. The reputation of Col. LE GAL as an experienced officer and thorough soldier is well established, and his many friends and admirers will be happy to learn that he is about to lead to battle, in defence of our Union, a regiment of our volunteer soldiery. The Lieutenant-Colonelcy of the McClellan Ritles is reserved far an officer of the United States Army. On the list of staff and line officers, most of whom have seen active service, either with returned City Regiments or in Europe, we notice the names of Capt. FITZJAMDO O'BRIEN, of the New-York Seventh Regiment N.G.; and Capt. DE LA PATOURELLE, of the Chasseurs de Vencennes and Chevalier of the Legion of Honor. Capt. 0'BRIEN is well known as a distinguished and elegant writer and is a near connection of the celebrated Irish patriot, WM. SMITH O'BRIEN. He will doubtless receive numerous offers of enlistment from his countrymen in this City emulous of serving under one bearing so distinguished a name. The regiment has gone into camp at Fort Hill, Staten Island, a most healthy and picturesque locality. The head- quarters in this City are at No. 84 Nassau-street.

abstract: Prof. J.G. HOWELL, Principal of the Model School in Chicago, is organizing a Students' Regiment. The day after the disaster at Bull Run the regiment was accepted; orders were given to organize at once and rendezvous in St. Louis on the 23d of this month. One company, the National Rifles, is composed wholly of students and graduates of the Normal University. Two other companies selected from like material through the State at large, will rendezvous at Bloomington on the 20th. The educational institutions at Jacksonville contribute a company. Bureau, DuPage, Madison and McLean Counties furnish each a company, and two companies are now being carefully selected at Chicago. The company elections are held only when each company is fully organized, and after them the regiment election. Gen. FREMONT, whose suggestions and advice had been obtained, is to furnish two of the field officers of the regiment. The post of Adjutant to the regiment, it is expected, will be filled by T.CRANDALM. CRANDAL, of West Point, and for upwards of ten years Professor of Tactics in the Military Academy, near Baltimore. Some of the companies have connected with them officers of rank in the Mexican war, and many of ELLSWORTH's original Zouaves, of reliable habits, are among the volunteers. The regiment will be attached to Gen. FREMONT's Division.

lead_paragraph: At last rumor has stated the truth about Gen. WOOL. His things are being packed up, and in a few days the office, which for years has been the headquarters of the Department of the East, will be vacant. Whether Troy will henceforward contain any such officer as Gen. WOOL, seems a mystery now; but as war has made Fortress Monroe the chlefest point recorded in the old geographical arrangement of this Department, and New-York the most central and convenient locale for such a post as Troy was, there is a strong probability that no General in the Army" will be stationed in the latter town again. On the posts put down in the last register, soldiers are still stationed in the following:

abstract: There is considerable bad feeling, it is said, in the First Regiment of Long Island Volunteers, now stationed at Fort Schuyler, growing out of the fact that the families of the men who enlisted in NewYork have not as yet received any relief, and will not do so, under present arrangements, until the regiment is actually at the seat of war.
lead_paragraph: There is considerable bad feeling, it is said, in the First Regiment of Long Island Volunteers, now stationed at Fort Schuyler, growing out of the fact that the families of the men who enlisted in New-York have not as yet received any relief, and will not do so, under present arrangements, until the regiment is actually at the seat of war. On the other hand, the families of the men who enlisted in Brooklyn have received relief from the time the regiment entered the service -- several weeks ago. This state of things very naturally creates considerable ill feeling. This regiment had more difficulties to contend with probably than any other that has been raised. It was not recognized by either of the War Committees in New-York or Brooklyn, and the only assistance received was from private sources; and in this way aid came in slowly, for there was a vague suspicion that the attempt to raise a regiment would not be successful. The fact that the Colonel, JULIUS ALLEN, has surmounted all these difficulties, and has a full command, fully armed and equipped, would indicate that, he is the right man in the right plane. This regiment will leave for the seat of war, it is now expected, on Friday or Saturday next.

abstract: The long and severe drouth which has so parched the earth for weeks, and given rise to serious fears for the safety of the crops, was broken on Monday by a slight fall of rain, with symptoms of a more plentiful shower.
lead_paragraph: The long and severe drouth which has so parched the earth for weeks, and given rise to serious fears for the safety of the crops, was broken on Monday by a slight fall of rain, with symptoms of a more plentiful shower. The wind, which had finally settled in the eastern quarter, continued to increase in violence until it blew a heavy gale from the Northeast, accompanied during the night with copious showers, which thoroughly watered the thirsty earth, and rejoiced the hearts of thousands whose cistern had run dry. During the day the gale increased in violence, and the rain descended in continuous floods. There was some damage done to fruit and ornamental trees, and the fields of corn on Long Island and elsewhere were considerably prostrated by the force of the gale. The encampments near the City suffered more or less from the descending floods, and on Hiker's island, which was exposed to the full force of the northeast gale, the soldiers were pretty thoroughly drenched. It required great exertion to prevent the tents from being blown away. The tide rose to high that the outbuildings ranged around the shore were submerged, and wholly beyond reach for two or three hours. On the South Brother, where there is a small encampment, the tide covered about half the island, and also put their small buildings twenty or thirty yards out of reach in the water. The Continental Guard at Camp Wyman, near Fort Hamilton, had their grounds inundated with the rain, but by industrious ditching, and the superior character of their tents, the men were kept comparatively dry.

abstract: Recent events have made these two qualities much talked of, but it may be questioned whether they are justly appreciated by the mass of those who attribute one or the other of them so freely to men who are, or a few days ago were, in the service of their country.
lead_paragraph: Recent events have made these two qualities much talked of, but it may be questioned whether they are justly appreciated by the mass of those who attribute one or the other of them so freely to men who are, or a few days ago were, in the service of their country. The lexicographers tell us that courage is that quality of mind which enables men to encounter danger and difficulties with firmness, without fear, of depression of spirits, and that cowardice is the want of courage to face danger. But do these definitions convey either a clear or a just notion of the qualities which they are intended to express? If the Chevalier BAYARD had lacked courage to face the danger which MGNS. BLONDIN gaily braved every time he walked upon that rope that trembled, with, the roar of Niagara; if RICHARD the Lion-hearted had shrunk from the midnight work which the resurrection-man performs with as much indifference as if he were digging ditches in broad daylight; if the woman who will go through fire and water for her child, swoons upon a giddy height, or shrieks at the sight of vermin; if the sailor who in black darkness furls the sail upon the slippery yard, that now dips in the ocean and now sweeps up to heaven, is palsied with terror on the back of a restive horse, do we call them cowards? We certainly do not; and yet they as certainly do lack courage to face certain kinds of danger, real or imagined; and, as far as they are concerned, it matters not all all whether the cause of their fear has or has not a real existence.
headline: {'main': 'Courage and Cowardice.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Courage and Cowardice.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: HOMICIDE IN WATER-STREET.--An inquest was held yesterday, at the New-York Hospital, by Coroner JACKMAN, on the body of GEORGE WILLIAMS, who was so fearfully stabbed on Sunday night last at No. 346 Water-street by AUGUSTINE BARCO. From the evidence of eye-witnesses to the fatal affray, it appeals that the deceased, the prisoner, and several of their companions, all of whom were sailors, met at a sailors' boarding-house, kept by a man named JAMES SMITH.
lead_paragraph: HOMICIDE IN WATER-STREET. -- An inquest was held yesterday, at the New-York Hospital, by Coroner JACKMAN, on the body of GEORGE WILLIAMS, who was so fearfully stabbed on Sunday night last at No. 346 Water-street by AUGUSTINE BARCO. From the evidence of eye-witnesses to the fatal affray, it appeals that the deceased, the prisoner, and several of their companions, all of whom were sailors, met at a sailors' boarding-house, kept by a man named JAMES SMITH. They had all been drinking, deceaced was very much intoxicated, and the prisoner somewhat so, but not to that extent to incapacitate him for talking intelligibly, or prevent him from knowing what he was about. Deceased at length becoming offended at some remark, began calling his companions by foul and abusive names. The prisoner at once stepped up to deceased and inquired if thesefoul epithets were applied to him personally. The deceased replied in the affirmative, and at the same time expressed a desire to fight with BARCO, placing himself on the instant in an attitude of defence. At this point the proprietor of the house interfered, and told them to leave his house if they were going to fight. The whole party thereupon left the house and proceeded to the sidewalk, immediately upon reaching which the deceased struck the prisoner upon the neck a powerful blow with his fist, which brought him to the pavement. BARCO soon regained his feet, at once drew a dirk-knife, rushed frantically forward, and despite the efforts of two or three bystanders to prevent it, he plunged the dirt to the hilt into the abdomen of deceased, inflicting a ghastly and mortal wound, through which the intestines of the unfortunate man prodruded to the extent of thirty-six inches, as testified to by Dr. JAMES L. LITTLE, who made the post-mortem examination. BARCO immediately fled, pursued by GEORGE CHAMBERLAIN, one of the witnesses, but was unable to effect his arrest unaided, owing to the fact that the prisoner made an attempt to stab him, and threatened to kill him if he followed further. CHAMBERLAIN therefore abandoned the pursuit, and gave the Fourth Ward Police a description of him, which enabled Officer CRAIG after to take him into custody. The injured man was taken to the Hospital, where he died the next day. The jury rendered a verdict in accordance with the above facts, and the prisoner was thereupon committed to the Tombs to await the action of the Grand Jury. He says he is a native of Spain, thirty-four years old, and denies having perpetrated the deed. The deceased was a native of Greece, and twenty-four years of age. The principal witnesses were sent to the House of Detention.

abstract: A dispatch from St. Louis, published in the evening papers yesterday, announced the defeat of the National Army at Springfield, Missouri, and the death of Gen. LYON.
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from St. Louis, published in the evening papers yesterday, announced the defeat of the National Army at Springfield, Missouri, and the death of Gen. LYON. The information was first received in St. Louis by the Secessionists, on Monday evening, through a special courier from the vicinity of the battle, who rode several horses to death in his haste to be before the Government courier with the news. Gen. FREMONT, however, is stated to have received his dispatches about midnight. The rebel reports announced the total rout of the National Army; but the dispatches of Gen. FREMONT simply announced an engagement, with severe loss on both sides, the death of Gen. LYON, and the retirement of the National forces towards Rolla in good order, under the command of Gen. SIEGEL. Still later dispatches, however, turn the National defeat into a most glorious victory, although the report of the death of Gen. LYON is confirmed. The engagement took place on the 10th inst. The National forces, in three columns, under the command respectively of Generals LYON, SIEGEL and STURGES, made the attack at 6 o'clock in the morning, at a place nine miles southeast of Springfield. The enemy, according to the muster rolls captured on the field, numbered twenty-three thousand, including regiments from Louisiana and Tennessee, with Texas Bangers and Cherokee half-breeds, while our forces were but eight thousand strong, including some two thousand Home Guards. Gen. LYON fired the first gun, when the engagement immediately became general. After two or three hours' severe cannonading, the execution done by Capt. TOTTEN's Artillery proved too much for the enemy, and they commenced to fall back, when the National cavalry, posted on the enemy's left, and Gen. SIEGEL's artillery on the right, commenced a terrific onslaught, which spread slaughter and dismay in the rebel ranks. They were pursued to their camps, and shells from TOTTEN's artillery set fire to their tents and baggage, and completely destroyed them. The rebel Gens. McCULLOCH and PRICK were both killed. Gen. LYON was killed while leading a charge at the head of his column, after having one horse shot under him. The command then devolved upon Gen. SIEGEL, who deemed it prudent to retire to Springfield, and subsequently to Rolla, as before stated, carrying with him a large amount of specie taken from the Springfield Bank, to prevent its falling into the hands of the enemy.

abstract: Several of the letters received at the North. from soldiers and others held as prisoners at Richmond, express the hope of a speedy release through an exchange of prisoners between the two Governments.
lead_paragraph: Several of the letters received at the North, from soldiers and others held as prisoners at Richmond, express the hope of a speedy release through an exchange of prisoners between the two Governments. We see no indications that their wishes are likely to be gratified. The Government has thus far adhered rigidly to the position taken by the President in his proclamations, that this is not a war but an insurrection, -- that the Government of the United States is engaged in an attempt to enforce its laws against individuals and combinations which refuse obedience to them. While hostilities are conducted on this basis, the Government must of necessity ignore very many of the rules and usages of recognized warfare.

abstract: Capt. BORNHAM, of the brig Sea Foam, arrived yes-to-day, informs us that the Sumter arrived off Curacoa on the night of the 17th of July and fired a gun for the fort, but the people of the fort not knowing her national flag, would not allow her to come in until the Governor had been consulted. The Sumter then sent an officer with an armed crew ashore to talk with that official as to coining into port, to coal up and refit, which the Governor allowed, against the protest of the United States Consul. She lay at Curacoa for eight days. During the time, the crew had their liberty ashore, and, as Capt. B. says, "raised the devil generally." The Captain of the Sumter said he was very sorry he had not arrived three days sooner, as he wanted ice badly -- which article Capt. B. had a cargo of, and he had only arrived the day previous. Capt. B. was detained four days waiting the departure of the Sumter, which took place on the 24th. He saw no privateers or suspicious vessels on the passage home.
lead_paragraph: Capt. BORNHAM, of the brig Sea Foam, arrived yes-to-day, informs us that the Sumter arrived off Curacoa on the night of the 17th of July and fired a gun for the fort, but the people of the fort not knowing her national flag, would not allow her to come in until the Governor had been consulted. The Sumter then sent an officer with an armed crew ashore to talk with that official as to coining into port, to coal up and refit, which the Governor allowed, against the protest of the United States Consul. She lay at Curacoa for eight days. During the time, the crew had their liberty ashore, and, as Capt. B. says, "raised the devil generally." The Captain of the Sumter said he was very sorry he had not arrived three days sooner, as he wanted ice badly -- which article Capt. B. had a cargo of, and he had only arrived the day previous. Capt. B. was detained four days waiting the departure of the Sumter, which took place on the 24th. He saw no privateers or suspicious vessels on the passage home.

abstract: STABBING AFFRAY. -- Yesterday afternoon a man named EDWARD NOCTON was arrested by Officer CARROL, of the Jersey City Police, charged with stabbing a lad named EDWARD POST in the back of the neck. The wound inflicted was within half an inch of the spine, but is not of a serious nature. It was stated that a party of boys were amusing themselves by throwing stones at NOCTON, who became enraged and used his knife as above stated. He was committed for examination.

abstract: SECTION 1. THE Congress of the Confederate States of America do enact, That, whenever there shall be declared war between the Confederate States and any foreign nation or Government, or any invasion or predatory incursion shall be perpetrated, attempted or threatened against the territory of the Confederate States by any foreign nation or Government, and the President of the Confederete States shall make public proclamation of the event, or the same shall be proclaimed by act of Congress, all native, citizens, denizens or subjects of the hostile nation or Government, being males of fourteen years of age and upwards, who shall be within the Confederate States, and not citizens thereof, shall be liable to be apprehended, restrained, or secured and removed as alien enemies; Provided, that, during the existing war, citizens of the United States residing within the [???] States, with intent to become citizens thereof, and who shall make a declaration of such intention, in due form, and acknowledging the authority of the Government of the same, shall not become liable, as aforesaid, nor shall the act extend to citizens of the States of Delaware, Maryland, Kentucky, Missouri, and the District of Columbia, and the Territories of Arizona and New-Mexico, and the Indian Territory south of Kansas, who shall not be chargeable with actual hostility, or ether crime against the public safety, and who shall acknowledge the authority of the Government of the Confederate States.

abstract: A letter from our Army at Sandy Hook, Md., (Gen. BANKS' column,) shows us how difficult it must be for a Union soldier to play the agreeable in the midst of a rebel population.
lead_paragraph: A letter from our Army at Sandy Hook, Md., (Gen. BANKS' column,) shows us how difficult it must be for a Union soldier to play the agreeable in the midst of a rebel population. [???] says that Martinsburgh and Charlestown, Va., after having been a short time in the possession of the Union Army, had been abandoned, and are now reoccupied by the rebels. In Martinsburgh, it is said, the Union troops found a few Union men; but in Charlestown, none at all -- not a living soul that avowed any love for the old flag, or any desire for the restoration of the Union. The ladies, even, forgot the proprieties of life and the decencies of the sex, in insulting officers, who treated them, however, always with marked consideration and politeness. The women would walk far around the flag-staff on which the Stars and Stripes were raised, in order, as they said, not to be dishonored by its shadow. They refused, in most cases, to sell to the troops the commonest necessaries of life; and poisoned two soldiers and attempted it on others. When they sold at all, they asked extortionate prices -- "twenty-five and fifty cents a loaf for bread;" and such price for other edibles as to put them "virtually beyond the reach of all but officers;" and this too at a time when the soldiers were "absolutely suffering from hunger." The writer concludes as follows:

abstract: London Times warns English capitalists against the "danger" of lending money to the Government of the United States.
lead_paragraph: London Times warns English capitalists against the "danger" of lending money to the Government of the United States. It would have been in a little better taste to have withheld this advice until they were asked to lend it. For the present, according to appearances, the United States will be able to get along without making such an application. Probably, by and by it will be made; -- and then the warnings of the Times will be timely.

abstract: of the war, so far, has put on record some very discreditable acts on the part of volunteer regiments, in leaving the service in presence of a threatening battle.
lead_paragraph: of the war, so far, has put on record some very discreditable acts on the part of volunteer regiments, in leaving the service in presence of a threatening battle. Pennsylvania has furnished more than her share of these retiring soldiers. Gen. PATTERSON was disabled by the refusal of his regiments to stay with him a few days over their time. And by this means the battle of Bull Run was lost. The Fourth Pennsylvania Regiment actually marched from the field at Bull Run as the roar of artillery in front announced that the nation was in struggle with its enemies, because their three months' enlistment had expired.

abstract: From a reliable source we receive information to the effect that the steamer Cuyler, blockading this port, has landed thirty or forty men, with three eighteen-pounders, on Egmont Key, who have erected a battery on the east side of that island.
lead_paragraph: From a reliable source we receive information to the effect that the steamer Cuyler, blockading this port, has landed thirty or forty men, with three eighteen-pounders, on Egmont Key, who have erected a battery on the east side of that island. Our readers will not be at a loss to account for the causes which induced this movement on the part of the enemy when we inform them that the portion of the smack Wilbur's crew, who were permitted to leave here on Friday of last week, instead of going directly to the latter place, ran alongside the Cayler, immediately after which the cannon above mentioned were sent ashore. This crew would have avoided the blockading steamer by taking the inland passage, but (as was feared by those of our citizens who doubled the propriety of allowing them to go back to Key West at that particular time) they preferred giving their friends a call before going home. We say friends because our informant states that this same crew were on the island with the troops -- whether as volunteers in the Lincoln service, or as prisoners, the reader can judge from the facts before him. We hope that this affair will serve to make our commander more cautious in future in allowing persons whom he does not know to be "sound on the goose" to go in the direction of Key West, or in the neighborhood of the blockading steamers.

abstract: We learn that the negotiations between the Secretary of the Treasury and the Banks may be regarded as mainly concluded. The arrangement is substantially that set forth in the TIMES of yesterday.
lead_paragraph: We learn that the negotiations between the Secretary of the Treasury and the Banks may be regarded as mainly concluded. The arrangement is substantially that set forth in the TIMES of yesterday. The Banks of New-York, Boston, and Phildelphia take at once, $50,000,000 of the 7 3-10 Government Bonds, with the privilege of taking an equal sum on the 15th of October; and a further equal sum on the 15th of December; no other Government Stocks or Bonds, excepting those payable on demand, to be negotiated or paid out until February 1, 1862, should the Banks conclude to take the whole amount named, the Government reserving the right to avail itself of a National loan or a loan in Europe. The details are not fully perfected, but these will not interfere with the consummation of the great event, which is by far the most important that has taken place since the outbreak. In effect, it pledges the entire capital of the country to the support of its military strength, and must, in the mind of every impartial person, be regarded as determining the result of the contest. It will everywhere carry conviction of success. There may be some hard fighting yet; but 5,000,000 people without means, without commerce, and without mechanical skill, cannot long resist 22,000,000, possessing abundant resources, the command of the sea, with the ability to supply themselves with the most approved weapons of warfare, and an abundant commissariat. Indifferent observers cannot resist the conclusion that, in the end, victory will remain on the side of the most numerous battalions, no matter what the reverses we sustain in the outset. The South, for years, have been preparing for the contest; the North only as many months. This gives them a temporary advantage, which in a few weeks more will be completely neutralized. Man for man, the North have shown themselves fully equal, to the South. As we can put five soldiers into the field to one on their part, our people hereafter will entertain no anxiety as to the final result. The action of the Banks will accomplish a vast good in a moral point of view, both at home and in Europe. It will be regarded as full proof of the loyally of our people. It will revive the sentiment of nationality, somewhat confused and shaken by recent events. It will strengthen the feeling that we still belong to one great family. It will place us on a height the Confederates can never reach. It shows that we are able to carry on the war with solid capital, and not compelled to resort to notes of insolvent Banks, or to the Quixotic scheme of Government taking to itself the entire crops and products of the people, to find a market for them if it can, and, if it cannot, to be without available means altogether. There is no doubt that the condition of the South is already well nigh desperate, and that fear and frenzy alone keeps up their organization. We profess to be contending for a principle; but if, with our vast superiority of numbers, we were in the position of the South with respect to means -- if our Banks were without specie -- if we were cut off from the sea, and if our Secretary of the Treasury, on visiting New-York for money, had been compelled to return penniless -- we should give over the contest as hopeless, however much it might mortify our pride or destroy the hopes we had entertained of our future career. The South are really in worse condition in respect to their finances than we can picture to ourselves. Time will soon begin to tell with fearful effect upon their organization. An Army must be regularly paid and fed, or it will not long remain an Army. It will one day tumble to pieces like a rope of sand. We shall then begin to wonder that such an inevitable event was not more clearly foreseen. The conduct of Mr. STEPHENS, Vice-President of the Confederation, in wandering about from county to county, soliciting contributions to the rebellion in whatever the planters and farmers raise, is enough to show that it is on its last legs. That such contributions are solicited proves that the rebels have no money. If they should be made to any considerable extent, they would not help their case, as they could not be turned into money till we were driven from the command of sea.

abstract: On the evening of August 1, Mr. JOHN BRIGHT spoke in Rochdale on behalf of Mr. CHEETHAM, the Liberal candidate for Parliament. His speech is reported in the Manchester Guardian. In the course of it he said: Without complimenting Mr. CHEETHAM, I can tell you that he is a most active -- I believe the most active -- member of an association formed in this district for the purpose of promoting a better supply of cotton, not from India alone, but from all parts of the world where cotton can be grown, and although perhaps it would be too much to say that that association had been able to produce any great results, because so short a time has elapsed since its operations began, yet it has now sown the seed as it were of a production of cotton in very many parts of the world, where that production probably would never have been heard of, or thought of, if it had not been for the labors of that association. With regard to the supply from India, I may tell you this, that there is no man from Lancashire of late who has been more assiduous in his attendance in London whenever anything was to be done with the Minister from India, or with the House of Commons, with the view to promote the opening of the industry of that vast country, so as to increase the production and export of cotton to this country. I think that, just now, if you can find a man who on questions of great State policy agrees with us, at the same time having a deep personal interest in this great cotton question, and having paid so much attention to it as Mr. CHEETHAM has, I think there is double resson why he should receive the votes and have the confidence of this division of the county. [Cheers.] Now, is this cotton question a great question, or not? I met a spinner to-day, -- he does not live in Rochdale, though I met him here, -- and I asked him what he thought about it; and he said, "Well, I think cotton will come somehow." [Laughter.] And, I find that there is that kind of answer to be had from three out of four of all the spinners you ask. They know that in past times, when cotton has risen 50 or 80 per cent., or some extravagant rise, something has come -- the rate of interest was raised, or there has been a commercial panic from some cause or other, and down the price has gone, and when everybody said "There would be no cotton at Christmas," there proved a very considerable stock at Christmas. And so they say now. I don't in the least deny that it will be so; all I assert is, that this particular case is new; that we have never had a war in the United States between different sections of that country, affecting the production of cotton before; and it is not fair nor wise, but rather childish than otherwise, to argue from past events, which were not a bit like this, of the event which is now passing before our eyes. They say, "It is quite true there is a civil war in America, but it will blow over: there will be a compromise, or the English Government will break the blockade." Now, recollect what breaking the blockade means. It means a war with the United States; and I don't think, myself, that it would be cheap to break the blockade, at the cost of a war with the United States. I think that the cost of a war with the United States would give, probably, half wages, for a very considerable time, to those persons in Lancashire who would be out of work if there was no cotton, to say nothing at all of the manifest injustice and wrong against all international law, that a legal and effective blockade should be interfered with by another country. It is not exactly the business of this meeting, but my opinion is, that the safety of the products on which this country depends rests far more on the success of the Washington Government than upon its failure; and I believe nothing could be more monstrous than for us, who are not very averse to war ourselves, to set up for critics -- carping, cavilling critics -- of what the Washington Government is doing. I saw a letter the other day from an Englishman, resident for twenty-five years in Philadelphia, a merchant there, and a very prosperous merchant. He said, "I prefer the institutions of this country (the United States) very much to yours in England;" but he says also, "If it be once admitted that here we have no country and no government, but that any portion of these United States can break off from the central Government whenever it pleases, then it is time for me to pack up what I have, and to go somewhere where there is a country and a government." Well, that is the pith of this question. Do you suppose that if Lancashire and Yorkshire thought that they would break off from the United Kingdom that those newspapers who are now preaching every kind of moderation to the Government of Washington would advise the Government in London to allow these two counties to set up a special Government for themselves? When the people of Ireland asked that they should secede, was it proposed in London that they should be allowed to secede peaceably? Nothing of the kind. I am not going to defend what is taking place in a country that is well able to defend itself. But I advise you, and I advise the people of England, to abstain from applying to the United States doctrines and principles which we never apply to our own case. At any rate, they have never fought for "the balance of power" in Europe. They have never fought to keep up a decaying Empire. They have never squandered the money of their people in such phantom expeditions as we have been engaged in. And now at this moment, when you are told that they are going to be ruined by their vast expenditure, why the sum that they are going to raise in the great emergency of this grievous war is no greater than what we raise every year during a time of peace. [Loud cheers.] They say that they are not going to liberate slaves. No; the object of the Washington Government is to maintain their own Constitution, and to act legally, as it permits and requires. No man is more in favor of peace than I am; no man has denounced war more than I have, probably, in this country; few men, in their public life, have suffered more obloquy -- I had almost said, more indignity -- in consequence of it. But I cannot, for the life of me see, upon any of those principles upon which States are governed now -- I say nothing of the literal word of the New Testament -- I cannot see how the state of affairs in America, with regard to the United States Government, could have been different from what it is this moment. We had a heptarchy in this country, and it was thought to be a good thing to get rid of it, and to have a united nation. If the 33 or 34 States of the American Union can break off whenever they like, can see nothing but disaster and confusion throughout the whole of that continent. I say that the war, be it successful or not, be it Christian or not, be it wise or not, is a war to sustain the Government and to sustain the authority of a great nation; and that the people of England, if they are true to their own sympathies, to their own history, and to their own great Act of 1834, to which reference has already been made, will have no sympathy for those who wish to build up a great Empire on the perpetual bondage of millions of their fellow men. [Loud cheers.]
lead_paragraph: On the evening of August 1, Mr. JOHN BRIGHT spoke in Rochdale on behalf of Mr. CHEETHAM, the Liberal candidate for Parliament. His speech is reported in the Manchester Guardian. In the course of it he said: Without complimenting Mr. CHEETHAM, I can tell you that he is a most active -- I believe the most active -- member of an association formed in this district for the purpose of promoting a better supply of cotton, not from India alone, but from all parts of the world where cotton can be grown, and although perhaps it would be too much to say that that association had been able to produce any great results, because so short a time has elapsed since its operations began, yet it has now sown the seed as it were of a production of cotton in very many parts of the world, where that production probably would never have been heard of, or thought of, if it had not been for the labors of that association. With regard to the supply from India, I may tell you this, that there is no man from Lancashire of late who has been more assiduous in his attendance in London whenever anything was to be done with the Minister from India, or with the House of Commons, with the view to promote the opening of the industry of that vast country, so as to increase the production and export of cotton to this country. I think that, just now, if you can find a man who on questions of great State policy agrees with us, at the same time having a deep personal interest in this great cotton question, and having paid so much attention to it as Mr. CHEETHAM has, I think there is double resson why he should receive the votes and have the confidence of this division of the county. [Cheers.] Now, is this cotton question a great question, or not? I met a spinner to-day, -- he does not live in Rochdale, though I met him here, -- and I asked him what he thought about it; and he said, "Well, I think cotton will come somehow." [Laughter.] And, I find that there is that kind of answer to be had from three out of four of all the spinners you ask. They know that in past times, when cotton has risen 50 or 80 per cent., or some extravagant rise, something has come -- the rate of interest was raised, or there has been a commercial panic from some cause or other, and down the price has gone, and when everybody said "There would be no cotton at Christmas," there proved a very considerable stock at Christmas. And so they say now. I don't in the least deny that it will be so; all I assert is, that this particular case is new; that we have never had a war in the United States between different sections of that country, affecting the production of cotton before; and it is not fair nor wise, but rather childish than otherwise, to argue from past events, which were not a bit like this, of the event which is now passing before our eyes. They say, "It is quite true there is a civil war in America, but it will blow over: there will be a compromise, or the English Government will break the blockade." Now, recollect what breaking the blockade means. It means a war with the United States; and I don't think, myself, that it would be cheap to break the blockade, at the cost of a war with the United States. I think that the cost of a war with the United States would give, probably, half wages, for a very considerable time, to those persons in Lancashire who would be out of work if there was no cotton, to say nothing at all of the manifest injustice and wrong against all international law, that a legal and effective blockade should be interfered with by another country. It is not exactly the business of this meeting, but my opinion is, that the safety of the products on which this country depends rests far more on the success of the Washington Government than upon its failure; and I believe nothing could be more monstrous than for us, who are not very averse to war ourselves, to set up for critics -- carping, cavilling critics -- of what the Washington Government is doing. I saw a letter the other day from an Englishman, resident for twenty-five years in Philadelphia, a merchant there, and a very prosperous merchant. He said, "I prefer the institutions of this country (the United States) very much to yours in England;" but he says also, "If it be once admitted that here we have no country and no government, but that any portion of these United States can break off from the central Government whenever it pleases, then it is time for me to pack up what I have, and to go somewhere where there is a country and a government." Well, that is the pith of this question. Do you suppose that if Lancashire and Yorkshire thought that they would break off from the United Kingdom that those newspapers who are now preaching every kind of moderation to the Government of Washington would advise the Government in London to allow these two counties to set up a special Government for themselves? When the people of Ireland asked that they should secede, was it proposed in London that they should be allowed to secede peaceably? Nothing of the kind. I am not going to defend what is taking place in a country that is well able to defend itself. But I advise you, and I advise the people of England, to abstain from applying to the United States doctrines and principles which we never apply to our own case. At any rate, they have never fought for "the balance of power" in Europe. They have never fought to keep up a decaying Empire. They have never squandered the money of their people in such phantom expeditions as we have been engaged in. And now at this moment, when you are told that they are going to be ruined by their vast expenditure, why the sum that they are going to raise in the great emergency of this grievous war is no greater than what we raise every year during a time of peace. [Loud cheers.] They say that they are not going to liberate slaves. No; the object of the Washington Government is to maintain their own Constitution, and to act legally, as it permits and requires. No man is more in favor of peace than I am; no man has denounced war more than I have, probably, in this country; few men, in their public life, have suffered more obloquy -- I had almost said, more indignity -- in consequence of it. But I cannot, for the life of me see, upon any of those principles upon which States are governed now -- I say nothing of the literal word of the New Testament -- I cannot see how the state of affairs in America, with regard to the United States Government, could have been different from what it is this moment. We had a heptarchy in this country, and it was thought to be a good thing to get rid of it, and to have a united nation. If the 33 or 34 States of the American Union can break off whenever they like, can see nothing but disaster and confusion throughout the whole of that continent. I say that the war, be it successful or not, be it Christian or not, be it wise or not, is a war to sustain the Government and to sustain the authority of a great nation; and that the people of England, if they are true to their own sympathies, to their own history, and to their own great Act of 1834, to which reference has already been made, will have no sympathy for those who wish to build up a great Empire on the perpetual bondage of millions of their fellow men. [Loud cheers.]

abstract: The Government is compelled to put forth all its strength in grappling with treason in Missouri. Gen. FREMONT has been obliged to proclaim martial law in the City and County of St. Louis, and to put under arrest JOHN A. BROWNLEE ...
lead_paragraph: The Government is compelled to put forth all its strength in grappling with treason in Missouri. Gen. FREMONT has been obliged to proclaim martial law in the City and County of St. Louis, and to put under arrest JOHN A. BROWNLEE, the President of the Board of Police Commissioners. Gen. FREMONT is throwing up defences on the west and south of the city, and planting heavy guns to command all the approaches to the city. There are now ten thousand troops in St. Louis, and in another week the number will be doubled. In a few weeks a permanent camp of 30,000 men will be established on the site of the memorable "Camp Jackson," and this being done, rebellion in Missouri will only be an exasperating disease, never a fatal malady.
