abstract: COMMITTEE. This Committee held a meeting at the Capitol on Tuesday evening. In the absence of the President and Vice-President, TUNIS G. BERGEN, Esq., was called to the Chair. The Committee of Six, on Resolutions, appointed at a previous meeting, ...
lead_paragraph: COMMITTEE. -- This Committee held a meeting at the Capitol on Tuesday evening. In the absence of the President and Vice-President, TUNIS G. BERGEN, Esq., was called to the Chair. The Committee of Six, on Resolutions, appointed at a previous meeting, was called on for a report, when two reports were presented. The first, signed by JOHN WHITE, TUNIS G. BERGEN and JOSEPH WILSON, embraced the declaration that the Republican Party caused the war, and favored the calling of a National Convention, to arrange terms of peace between the rebels and the Government. The other report, presented by Mr. H. C. PAGE, was in favor of prosecuting the war with the utmost vigor, as the only means of securing a permanent peace, and pledging the Democracy of Kings County to an unqualified support of the Government in all constitutional acts. Both reports were laid onthe table. The Committee decided upon holding the primary meetings on Wednesday, the 29th inst., at 3 P.M., and then adjourned.

abstract: Tne Albany Atlas and Argus attempts to define the position which the Democracy of this State will take, on National politics, in the coming election.
lead_paragraph: The Albany Atlas and Argus attempts to define the position which the Democracy of this State will take, on National politics, in the coming election. It says the Democrats will resist any separation of the Union, and of course any recognition of the Southern Confederacy, "to the extent of the ability of the Government, and until further resistance is mere madness." In so doing, it will simply support the Government and cooperate with the Republican Party. It says that the Democrats will oppose to the bitter end any attempt to "hoist the banner of negro emancipation." In this, too, they will be simply following the policy distinctly marked out by the Administration and repeatedly proclaimed, in the most unmistakable language, by President LINCOLN in all his messages and public papers.

abstract: The report of the battle fought by Gen. LYON near Springfield, Mo., conveys the assurance of victory, but leaves a painful impression on the public mind. It is stated that our gallant Army, numbering about eight ...
lead_paragraph: The report of the battle fought by Gen. LYON near Springfield, Mo., conveys the assurance of victory, but leaves a painful impression on the public mind. It is stated that our gallant Army, numbering about eight thousand, (we quote the report of Gen. LYON's aid to Gen. FREMONT,) engaged the enemy, numbering about twenty-three thousand, at six o'clock on Saturday morning, fought them victoriously all day, and drove them from the field and back upon their encampment and baggage wagons, which latter were burnt by the well-directed shells from our batteries. The pursuit of the enemy, it is said, was continued until nightfall, when our Army "rested for the night in the encampment of the enemy."

lead_paragraph: In obedience to the order of Judge GARRISON, of the King's County Court, Mr. Sheriff CAMPBELL, accompanied by Deputy-Sheriffs HIGGINS and DALLON, yesterday morning, at 9 o'clock, started for Fort Hamilton, to arrest Col. BURKE, commanding officer at that place, for disobeying the writ of habeas corpus, requiring him to bring into Court the Baltimore Police Commissioners, placed in his custody by Lieut.-Gen. SCOTT, and also to bring before the said Court the Commissioners aforesaid.

abstract: a source entitled to credit that since the battle of Bull Run no less than one hundred and thirty-seven commissioned officers of volunteers have resigned.
lead_paragraph: a source entitled to credit that since the battle of Bull Run no less than one hundred and thirty-seven commissioned officers of volunteers have resigned. This is exclusive of those whose terms of three months' enlistment had expired, and is entirely among those who had enlisted for three years, or for the war. What the motives of these resignations were is of course only matter of conjecture. Very many of the officers had undoubtedly made the discovery that their position was not the sinecure they had imagined -- that it involved labor, care, responsibility and danger -- and that the rewards connected with the service were not commensurate with the sacrifices required. And many of them, without doubt, made the discovery at the battle of Bull Run that they were not equal to the duties they had rashly assumed.

abstract: The following proclamation has just been issued: HEAD-QUARTERS, WESTERN DEPARTMENT, ST. LOUIS, Aug. 14, 1861. I hereby declare and establish martial law in the City and County of St. Louis. Major J. McKINSTRY, United States Army, is appointed Provost-Marshal. All orders and regulations issued by him will be respected and obeyed accordingly.

abstract: Work, and not display, is now the order of things in the United States. The real business of war has begun, and men have already forgotten the phase of speech-making and flag-waving, of calls for universal sympathy, and anger at not obtaining it.
lead_paragraph: Work, and not display, is now the order of things in the United States. The real business of war has begun, and men have already forgotten the phase of speech-making and flag-waving, of calls for universal sympathy, and anger at not obtaining it. It is a relief to find that the captious- ness and irritability with regard to this country which marked the first weeks of the war have almost passed away. The course taken by the British Government is now recognized as most just and fitting, and even the comments of British society are taken in good part. The Northerners seem at last to understand that when two adverse communities are in arms, sympathy with the one involves antipathy to the other. When an Army enters a hostile territory to conquer its defenders and coerce its inhabitants, it is impossible to desire the success of the invaders without desiring the defeat of the invaded. Now, we, having no quarrel with the people of the Confederate States, did not think it our duty to cheer on their enemies. In any misfortune caused by famine, or pestilence, or fire, or even barbarous foes like the Indians of the frontier, any American community would have the sympathy of Englishmen; but, as the North now tacitly acknowledges, any display of partnership on our part against the South would have been most ungenerous and offensive. The change in feeling, however, which has evidently taken place is due less to reflection on the matter itself than to the absorption of men's thoughts by more earnest business. In the first days of the war, as in the first days of all wars, there was nothing but excitement and speculation, enthusiasm and apprehension. It was a time of vague passion, which had not yet been concentrated into energy. All public uprisings, too, have in them something of vanity and display. When the young fashionables or the sober lawyers and merchants volunteer to march off anywhere for the defence of their country there is a consciousness of doing something fine, which, if not rewarded by immediate admiration, is apt to grow irritable. The mind's eye of Fifth-avenue turned to England while cleaning its rifles and buying its red shirts for the war. But this amateur spirit has been soon exhausted. A stronger purpose and a stricter organization have succeeded as the war has advanced. It is the usual, the necessary course -- from popular enthusiasm to military discipline, from the more refined to the coarser material of armies, from gentlemen who serve gratuitously to well-paid farm laborers, mechanics and navvies; from volunteers for three months to soldiers for five years -- in short, from a militia almost purely American, to a standing army in which Irishmen and Germans are counted by thousands.

abstract: SIMON CAMERON, Secretary of War of the United States, has been singularly exercised about the body of his deceased brother, Col. CAMERON, of the New-York Volunteers, killed at Manassas. Actuated by a silly pride about addressing Gen. JOHNSTON ...
lead_paragraph: SIMON CAMERON, Secretary of War of the United States, has been singularly exercised about the body of his deceased brother, Col. CAMERON, of the New-York Volunteers, killed at Manassas. Actuated by a silly pride about addressing Gen. JOHNSTON on the subject in the latter's proper official capacity, just as the British authorities were towards our WASHINGTON, he has resorted to every device to secure this object. Some are already known to the public. A day or two ago a flag of truce came to our pickets and sent in the following to Col. J.E.B. STUART, of the Cavalry, commanding at Fairfax Courthouse: WAR DEPARTMENT, JULY 30, 1861.

abstract: The battle which took place near Springfield, Mo., on Saturday, appears to have been even more hotly contested than that of Bull Run. Viewed in a military light, it may be considered a drawn battle; but taking into consideration the great ...
lead_paragraph: The battle which took place near Springfield, Mo., on Saturday, appears to have been even more hotly contested than that of Bull Run. Viewed in a military light, it may be considered a drawn battle; but taking into consideration the great disparity of forces, it may well be considered a great victory for the National arms. Gen. LYON, it seems, was led to take the initiative by apparently authentic reports that heavy reinforcements under Gen. HARDEE were on their way to join the rebel forces under MCCULLOCH. Our Army marched out of Springfield on Friday evening, only fifty-five hundred strong -- the Home Guards remaining behind -- and rested on the prairie during a portion of the night. About sunrise on Saturday morning the enemy's outposts were driven in, and soon after the action became general. The main attack was made in two columns, led by Gens. LYON and STURGES, while Gen. SIEGEL had a flanking force of about a thousand men, with four pieces of artillery, on the south of the the enemy's camp. During the battle, which raged from sunrise until past one o'clock in the afternoon, three distinct charges were made by the rebels upon Capt. POTTER's Battery, but each time they were repulsed with terrible slaughter. Gen. LYON, it appears, fell early in the day, at the head of a Kansas regiment which he was leading on a charge - its Colonel having been disabled. The enemy at last was thrown into disorder, and commenced retreating, but our forces were so badly cut up that it was not deemed prudent to pursue. Gen. SIRGEL lost three of his guns, but spiked them and destroyed the carriages before he left them. Our loss is variously estimated at from one hundred and fifty to three hundred killed, and several hundred wounded; while that of the enemy is placed at least two thousand killed and wounded. They also lost, as before stated, all their tents and camp equipage, and about one hundred horses. Gen. PRICE was not killed, as stated in the first dispatches, and there appears to be some doubt about the death of MCCULLOCH. The rebels made no attempt to follow our forces on their retirement from Springfield, and it was considered probable that Gen. SIEGEL would not fall back further than Lebanon, where he would await reinforcements.

abstract: Yesterday morning, shortly after 11 o'clock, the fire-bells in the City sounded twenty strokes, that being the signal agreed upon to let those firemen know who wished to join in the escort to the Fire Zouaves, that that regiment was nearing the City.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, shortly after 11 o'clock, the fire-bells in the City sounded twenty strokes, that being the signal agreed upon to let those firemen know who wished to join in the escort to the Fire Zouaves, that that regiment was nearing the City. Shortly afterward, a number of companies proceeded to the foot of Cortlandt-street, and awaited their arrival. At about 2 o'clock, the Zouaves arrived in Jersey City, where they were welcomed by a number of friends, who were awaiting their arrival. Immediately upon landing from the cars, the regiment was marched to the boat, and conveyed to this City. No quarters being assigned the returned Zouaves by the Government, and Col. TOMPKINS, United States Quartermaster, not having been officially notified of their return, they had no place to go to. By the kindness, however, of Major EATON, a dinner was provided for the men in the Park, whither they marched. After stacking arms, the friends of the returned soldiers crowded around them, congratulating them on their arrival once more in New-York, and listening to some wondrous tale of the war.

abstract: BARNUM's MUSEUM. -- Mr. BARNUM has got a hippopotamus, and a Nubian keeper who speaks English with an Oriental accent. About the hippopotamus there is no sort of doubt, and we would be the last to cast a shadow of a suspicion upon the child of the Sun who looks after so distinguished a visitor for us. When the first, hippopotamus was taken to England the fashionable world there was moved to its centre. He was regarded as a rival of the Duke of Buckingham, and by the aflability of his manners and his readiness to dine with every one who asked him, did in point of fact supersede that lamented nobleman. The Duke had to fall back on turtle-soup and corporation dinners, and a sphere of action where a respectable hippopotamus with any sense of caste could not be expected to shine. But as a promiscuous gobbler his career was ended. Mr. BARNUM's hippopotamus is young. This, indeed, is his first season. He is bashful, like many another young swell, and retires into obscure corners, until he is wanted in the refreshment room. Offer him something to eat and he is seen to advantage. He will open his mouth for you to an extent that is truly appalling in these hard times. You can drop in a cob of corn, as if you were posting a letter, and see him chew it somewhere deep down in his throat, where his masticators appear to be located. A word from the keeper will send him diving in the water, where he seems well content to remain, until compelled to come to the surface for a breath of fresh air. On these occasions, his amiable face presents the appearance of a block of gutta percha on which some 'prentice hand had vainly endeavored to depict the countenance of a calf. In point of size, Mr. BARNUM's hippopotamus does not compare with the specimen in London, but its huge proportions will not fail to strike the visitor even now. In a few years he will get over the disadvantage of comparison with his European brethren. Every one has an idea of what a hippopotamus is like. Look at a cow, or a mammoth hog, through a very knotty pane of glass, where the best features are sure to be exaggerated, and you get a notion of our friend. He has a tail without a kink in it, but otherwise porcine, and by its symmetry perfectly distracting to the mind of a well-regulated dog. Take him for all in all, we doubt if we shall ever look upon his like again. Decidedly, Mr. BARNUM has the greatest novelty, and most valuable curiosity in the country. No one should miss the opportunity of seeing the hippopotamus.

abstract: The Baltimore Exchange publishes intelligence form Washington, on the strength of a dispatch said to have been received form Nova Scotia, that "England and France have taken decided grounds upon a speedy recognition of the Southern Confederacy." The wish with the Exchange is father to the thought. Nothing can be more absurd than to suppose that either England or France will depart in this case form their usual practice
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore Exchange publishes intelligence form Washington, on the strength of a dispatch said to have been received form Nova Scotia, that "England and France have taken decided grounds upon a speedy recognition of the Southern Confederacy." The wish with the Exchange is father to the thought. Nothing can be more absurd than to suppose that either England or France will depart in this case form their usual practice in regard to the recognition of new States. Their rule of action is clear and fixed: -- they recognize as independent every State which has actually proved its ability to maintain its independence. They do not enter upon the question of right, nor can they permit their sympathies to govern their action. The question is simply one of fact.

abstract: There is a great deal of Constitutional hairsplitting going on, both in and out of Congress, with the hope of stirring up a spirit of opposition to the Government in its efforts to suppress the rebellion. Judge STORY says that "a Constitution of Goverment is addressed
lead_paragraph: There is a great deal of Constitutional hairsplitting going on, both in and out of Congress, with the hope of stirring up a spirit of opposition to the Government in its efforts to suppress the rebellion. Judge STORY says that "a Constitution of Goverment is addressed to the common sense of the people, and never was designed for trials of logical skill or visionary speculation;" and the great body of the people can only look upon the proceedings of the Government to crush out the great conspiracy as a common sense movement, special pleading to the contrary notwithstanding. As the Constitution provides no means for the destruction of the Government, it is but common sense to suppose that it is constitutional to use every effort to preserve it. These Constitutional sticklers have thrown up their hands and rolled their eyes in perfect horror at the impudence of President LINCOLN in asking Congress to sanction such of his acts as he deemed necessary for the preservation of the Government, forgetting that he but followed the example set by JEFFERSON, who deemed it for the common interest of the nation to purchase Louisiana, in face of the fact that there were no provisions in the Constitution for the acquisition of foreign territory; but, unlike JEFFERSON, he was not afraid to have his acts fully discussed. JEFFERSON said, to his friends, "that it will be desirable for Congress to do what is necessary in silence. Whatever Congress shall think necessary to do should be done with as little debate as possible, and particularly so far as respects the Constitutional difficulty." They have laid great stress upon the point that the Supreme Court is the rightful interpreter of the Constitution. How stands the case according to their own logic.

abstract: At a quarter before one, yesterday, an alarm of fire was given, and the engines passed up State-street. The office was completety gutted, and the stands, cases, and newespapers afterward burned in the Square.

abstract: The United States chartered storeship National Guard sailed from the Brooklyn Navy-yard yesterday, for the Florida division of the blockade fleet, to stay ultimately at Fort Pickens. She took a very large cargo of all sorts of necessaries, including coal, rigging-materials, ordnance-stores, &c. No soldiers or sailors, except her own crew, were on board. The National Guard is fully armed, and well able to protect herself, having no less than six formidable guns on deck.

abstract: The Traveller says that Messrs. ALGER & CO., on Foundry-street, South Boston, are at present very busy in manufacturing ordnance for the Government. They are making Navy Dahlgren guns of 9-inch calibre; boat-howitzers, similar to those recently supplied to the cutters Morris and Caleb Cushing by Messrs. ALGER & CO.; sea-coast mortars; 6 and 12-pounder guns and 5-inch bore; brass pieces for merchant ships; JAMES' rifled cannon 6-pound field guns; 12-pound mountain howitzers, and 12-pound field howitzers, on carriages with an elevating screw. They are also making grape and canister: 8, 10, 12 and 13 inch shells, and balls of all the sizes used in the Government service.

abstract: A copy of the New-Orleans Price Current, of Aug. 3, has been received in this city, from which we gather additional proof of the utter stagnation of business in that city. The total number of vessels in the port was 28, of which 12 were ships, 4 barks, 2 brigs, and 10 schooners. Ten of the ships, one bark, and one schooner were under seizure. Number of bales of cotton in port, 9,804. By the first of August new cotton is usually received at New-Orleans, but up to the third none had come to hand. The Price Current reports that the cotton and corn crops are heavy, and that the cane was promising. Also that the Confederate Loan was "unusually popular."
lead_paragraph: A copy of the New-Orleans Price Current, of Aug. 3, has been received in this city, from which we gather additional proof of the utter stagnation of business in that city. abstract: Mr. and Mrs. W.J. FLORENCE leave in the Persia on the 28th inst., for an extended European tour. They open at the Haymarket, London, early in September. During their absence they visit Australia and California. In view of their early departure, a Farewell Ovation will be given them at the Winter Garden, on Friday evening, under, the auspices of the New-York Florence Association and the "Charity Fund Committee" of the Sixty-ninth Regiment. The latter body interest themselves with enthusiasm, the benefit given to the Fund by the FLORENCES last week netting $1,012 25.

abstract: Whereas, A Joint Committee of both Houses of Congress has waited on the President of the United States, and requested him to recommend a day of public humiliation, prayer and fasting, to be observed by the people of the United States with religious solemnities, and the offering of fervent supplications to Almighty God for the safety and welfare of these States, his blessings on their arms, and, a speedy restoration to peace; and, whereas, it is fit and becoming in all people, at all times, to acknowledge and revere the supreme government of God, to bow in humble submission to His chastisements, to confess and deplore their sins and transgressions, in the full conviction that the fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom, and to pray with all fervency and contrition for the pardon of their past offences, and for a blessing upon their present and prospective actions; and, whereas, when our beloved country, once, by the blessing of God, united, prosperous and happy, is now afflicted with factious and civil war, it is peculiarly fit for us to recognize the hand of God in this visitation; and, in sorrowful remembrance of our own faults and crimes, as a nation and as individuals, to humble ourselves before Him, and to pray for His mercy -- to pray that we may be spared further punishment, though most justly deserved; that our arms may be blessed and made effectual for the reestablishment of law, order and peace throughout our country, and that the inestimable boon of civil and religions liberty, earned under His guidance and blessing by the labors and sufferings of our fathers, may be restored in all its original excellency; Therefore, I, ABRAHAM LINCOLN, President of the United States, do appoint the last Thursday in September next as a day of humiliation, prayer and fasting for all the people of the nation; and I do earnestly recommend to the people, and especially to all ministers and teachers of religion, of all denominations, to all heads of families, to observe and keep that day, according to their several creeds and modes of worship, in all humility, and with all religious solemnity, to the end that the united prayers of the nation may ascend to the Throne of Grace, and bring down plentiful blessings upon our own country.

Therefore, I, ABRAHAM LINCOLN, President of the United States, do appoint the last Thursday in September next as a day of humiliation, prayer and fasting for all the people of the nation; and I do earnestly recommend to the people, and especially to all ministers and teachers of religion, of all denominations, to all heads of families, to observe and keep that day, according to their several creeds and modes of worship, in all humility, and with all religious solemnity, to the end that the united prayers of the nation may ascend to the Throne of Grace, and bring down plentiful blessings upon our own country.

abstract: This gentleman, so well known as an officer in the New-York Volunteers in the late war with Mexico, and for his gallantry at the recent battle at Bull Run as Lieutenant Colonel of the Thirty-eighth Regiment New-York Volunteers, (Second Scott Life Guard,) arrived in this City this morning from Virginia. He comes hereby order of the War Department for the purpose of establishing recruiting depots, in order to recruit his regiment to the standard number. The Scott Life Guard was greatly reduced at Bull Run by killed, wounded and missing, and now parades not more than half of its original number. It is officered principally by men of experience, who have "faced the cannon's mouth" on the battle-fields of Mexico. Lieut.-Col. FARNSWORTH was originally a Second Lieutenant in the First Regiment New-York Volunteers, and was twice promoted for his gallantry on the field, receiving the command of his company after the death of the gallant. Capt. VAN O'LINDA at Chepultepec. At the battle of Bull Run, Col. FARNSWORTH conducted himself so gallantly as to receive the especial notice of his immediate commanders. The commandant of the brigade to which he was attached thus refers to him in his official report:
lead_paragraph: This gentleman, so well known as an officer in the New-York Volunteers in the late war with Mexico, and for his gallantry at the recent battle at Bull Run as Lieutenant Colonel of the Thirty-eighth Regiment New-York Volunteers, (Second Scott Life Guard,) arrived in this City this morning from Virginia. He comes hereby order of the War Department for the purpose of establishing recruiting depots, in order to recruit his regiment to the standard number. The Scott Life Guard was greatly reduced at Bull Run by killed, wounded and missing, and now parades not more than half of its original number. It is officered principally by men of experience, who have "faced the cannon's mouth" on the battle-fields of Mexico. Lieut.-Col. FARNSWORTH was originally a Second Lieutenant in the First Regiment New-York Volunteers, and was twice promoted for his gallantry on the field, receiving the command of his company after the death of the gallant. Capt. VAN O'LINDA at Chepultepec. At the battle of Bull Run, Col. FARNSWORTH conducted himself so gallantly as to receive the especial notice of his immediate commanders. The commandant of the brigade to which he was attached thus refers to him in his official report:

The Sheriff was told that about fourteen hundred men could be raised, but that the county was not in possession of artillery sufficiently powerful to make an impression on the fort, and that it would require between five and ten thousand men to take it

abstract: Our financial column this morning records the final and complete success of the great movement of the Government for securing means to carry on the war. The Banks of Boston, New-York and Philadelphia have agreed to loan the Government one hundred and fifty millions of dollars, This we believe to be the largest loan ever negotiated in any country at any time: and the promptness with which it has been taken speaks louder than cannon could possibly do in demonstration of the loyal courage and determination of our people. Half a dozen such defeats as that at Bull Run would be more than offset by this single act. It will breathe confidence and courage into the hearts of the people, and will satisfy foreign nations that we are not yet ready to surrender the Government into the hands of traitors. The London Times can now suspend for a season its solemn warnings to English capitalists against taking the American Loan. They haven't been asked to do so yet.

abstract: DLG held an inquest yesterday on the body of the lad, FREDERICK FINCATENICHT, who was so fearfully assaulted and beaten by a soldier, on the 8th inst., near the corner of Mott and Park streets. He died Wednesday night of the injuries inflicted. The only provocation given by the boy to the soldier, was the remark made by him to another lad.? "How good they do it," called out by seeing this soldier and a companion engaged in the exercise of boxing in the street. The Jury rendered a verdict that deceased died from compression of the brain, superinduced by blows received on the head at the hands of some person unknown. The offender has not yet been caught, but the Police believe they are on his track.

abstract: -Mr. JOHN MORGAN, of Ilion, in this State, has invented a gun for which he claims the efficiency of a whole battery. It is a repeating cannon -- loaded from chambers worked by very simple machinery, and kept cool by a novel application of air and water. It fires a shell which is calculated to explode at three different times. It is well worth examining, and will be on exhibition for a few days at No. 266 Broadway.

abstract: reason to believe that there is a good deal more than meets the eye in the proceedings now going on in Brooklyn, having for their object the release of the Baltimore Police Commissioners now confined in Fort Lafayette. Justice GARRISON, it will be remembered, has issued the writ and made some significant suggestions about serving it by aid of the military power. His antecedents are not such as to encourage the hope of any very high-toned devotion to the interests of the country in the management of the affair. And we have information from a source entitled to credit, that a Southern gentleman is now in the city for the express purpose of pushing the matter forward, with a view to bring about a collision between the civil and military authorities of Brooklyn. He is said to be well supplied with money, and to be acting with great zeal and caution in the steps he is taking. The Secessionists would be very glad to create some disturbance of this kind in this vicinity and can afford to devote a good deal of labor and of money to its accomplishment.

abstract: A correspondent of the Augusta Dispatch writes from Richmond: "ELY, the Republican Congressman, who is in durance vile, was visited a few days ago, by Messrs. KEITT, BOCOCK and PRYOR, who informed him that they called on an errand of mercy, and were desirous of doing something to better his condition, provided it did not conflict with the military regulations. It is related that the earnestness of these gentlemen in their proposal, and their generous forgetfulness of old party lines, which always distinguishes the true Southern gentlemen, affected the prisoner powerfully, and that, shedding tears, he flung his arms around them and said that 'he had often heard of Southern chivalry, but he was now able to appreciate it fully.'"
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the Augusta Dispatch writes from Richmond: "ELY, the Republican Congressman, who is in durance vile, was visited a few days ago, by Messrs. abstract: -- No event of the present rebellion has been more marked or noticeable than the disappearance of the inevitable GEO. N. SANDERS from the political horizon Go where you would before, you were certain to stumble upon him. He regulated the affairs of the Democracy, North and South, for a long time; and, when he was removed from the office of Navy Agent in this City, by Old Buck, not for treason or any such trifling offence, but for having sent him some good advice by telegraph without prepayment, he devoted himself with fresh assiduity to repairing, the breaches in the Democratic bulwarks. He was busy at Charleston, Baltimore and Montgomery; and, when all his efforts at all these points failed, he retired, discomfited and disgusted, to private life in Kentucky. It now turns out that he is a defaulter to the Government to the amount of $21,000. The chances of his coming back to pay it are not flattering. When he does come, we shall take pleasure in announcing his arrival.

abstract: Our citizens may as well now take into serious consideration the social burdens they will be obliged to earry during the approaching Winter. The unemployed poor are increasing upon our hands at an alarming rate. Already we are informed that thousands of able-bodied women are under charge of the Commissioners of Charity and supported at
lead_paragraph: Our citizens may as well now take into serious consideration the social burdens they will be obliged to earry during the approaching Winter. The unemployed poor are increasing upon our hands at an alarming rate. Already we are informed that thousands of able-bodied women are under charge of the Commissioners of Charity and supported at public expense -- women who ask for no charity, but only work. Many families of volunteers have not been relieved by the liberal sums expended, and will be forced soon to become burdens on the City. The swarm of unfortunate children -- the offspring of people impoverished by the business prostration, or of fathers who have abandoned everything for the war -- increases in the streets. The agents of such Societies as the Children's Aid Society, report that numbers of destitute and orphan little ones beset their office or their schools and seek shelter and employment. All signs forebode a severe and gloomy Autumn and Winter for the poor.

abstract: In yesterday's issue we announced the death of NOAH L. FARNHAM, Colonel of the Fire Zouaves. Col. FARNHAM was born in New-Haven, Conn., on the 6th of June, 1829. He enjoyed excellent educational advantages, which he faithfully improved, and at the age of sixteen, received a situation in the mercantile house of Messrs. S.M. BECKLEY & CO., recently the firm of CLAPP, BENT & BECKLEY. He found the confinement of the counter exceedingly irksome, as he possessed a remarkably vigorous constitution, and his tastes impelled him to seek the activity which his occupation did not afford in the ranks of the City Guard, at that time the crack corps of the City. For two years he remained a member of this organization, and in it he received the appellation -- which his stature, five feet and four inches, rendered peculiarly appropriate -- of "Pony" FARNHAM. At the age of twenty he joined Engine Company No. 42, and as a fireman his daring, impetuous nature found full play. Joining Hook and Ladder Company No. 1 soon afterwards, he was chosen Assistant Foreman, and subsequently Foreman; and in 1856, when twenty-four years of age, he was elected Assistant Engineer of the Department. This position he held for three years. In 1857 he connected himself with Company B of the Seventh Regiment, and rapidly ascended from the office of Second Sergeant to that of First Lieutenant of the Company, which position he held when the regiment was summoned to Washington. He pursued the study of the theoretical and practical branches of military science with an enthusiasm which could not be checked, practicing fencing, boxing, &c., with an assiduity which rendered him an expert, although it would be unjust to claim for him the superiority in these arts which some have asserted for him. Col. FARNHAM formed an attachment with Col. ELLSWORTH when the latter visited this City with the famous Chicago Zouaves, and it was in consequence of his urgency that he consented to accept the Lieutenant-Colonelcy of the Fire Zouaves, succeeding to the place occupied by his lamented friend when he was assassinated in Alexandria.
lead_paragraph: In yesterday's issue we announced the death of NOAH L. FARNHAM, Colonel of the Fire Zouaves. Col. FARNHAM was born in New-Haven, Conn., on the 6th of June, 1829. He enjoyed excellent educational advantages, which he faithfully improved, and at the age of sixteen, received a situation in the mercantile house of Messrs. S.M. BECKLEY & CO., recently the firm of CLAPP, BENT & BECKLEY. He found the confinement of the counter exceedingly irksome, as he possessed a remarkably vigorous constitution, and his tastes impelled him to seek the activity which his occupation did not afford in the ranks of the City Guard, at that time the crack corps of the City. For two years he remained a member of this organization, and in it he received the appellation -- which his stature, five feet and four inches, rendered peculiarly appropriate -- of "Pony" FARNHAM. At the age of twenty he joined Engine Company No. 42, and as a fireman his daring, impetuous nature found full play. Joining Hook and Ladder Company No. 1 soon afterwards, he was chosen Assistant Foreman, and subsequently Foreman; and in 1856, when twenty-four years of age, he was elected Assistant Engineer of the Department. This position he held for three years. In 1857 he connected himself with Company B of the Seventh Regiment, and rapidly ascended from the office of Second Sergeant to that of First Lieutenant of the Company, which position he held when the regiment was summoned to Washington. He pursued the study of the theoretical and practical branches of military science with an enthusiasm which could not be checked, practicing fencing, boxing, &c., with an assiduity which rendered him an expert, although it would be unjust to claim for him the superiority in these arts which some have asserted for him. Col. FARNHAM formed an attachment with Col. ELLSWORTH when the latter visited this City with the famous Chicago Zouaves, and it was in consequence of his urgency that he consented to accept the Lieutenant-Colonelcy of the Fire Zouaves, succeeding to the place occupied by his lamented friend when he was assassinated in Alexandria.

abstract: The Apalachicola (Fla.) Times of the 3d inst., in its marine column, under the head of vessels in port, announces the ship Finland, Capt. JONES, 450 tons, from Liverpool, just arrived, and commenced discharging. The propeller tug-boat Enoch Train, formerly belonging to Boston, has been plated with iron in New-Orleans for the purpose of running down the blockading vessels. She is now called the Ram, and the New-Orleans papers say she can run 20 miles an hour. Before she left Boston harbor her rate of speed was less than 10 miles an hour.

abstract: MOVEMENTS OF PRINCE NAPOLEON. -- Prince NAPOLEON occupied his time yesterday in receiving visitors at his hotel, taking a look at the City incog., dining with the Union Club, and making arrangements for his Western trip. In accordance with the Prince's desire, the contemplated operatic serenade has been postponed until his return from his Western tour. His Royal Highness has also requested that the serenade shall be given on board the yacht instead of at the New-York Hotel. In this way the royal party will enjoy the music more than they could in the old-fashioned style, while the musicians themselves will be better accommodated. The Prince, Princess CLOTILDE and the Duchess D'ABRANTES yesterday paid a visit to FREDERICK & Co.'s Photograph Gallery, and gave their first sitting in this country for their visiting cards and other photographs. The Prince and his suite expressed great satisfaction and some surprise at the perfection which the art has attained in this country. The likenesses of these distinguished personages have been added to the already large collection of this gallery, and form quite an attraction to visitors.

abstract: FIRES -- A WOMAN FATALLY INJURED. -- About 1 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire broke out at No. 69 1/2 Division-street, occupied by Mr. J. WOOLFF as an artificial-flower store and dwelling. The entire contents of the store, valued at about $500, were destroyed. They were insured for $1,400. Mr. WOOLFF and his family, who resided in the upper part of the building, succeeded in making their escape by way of a second-story window in the rear; but a servant girl named MARY LEONEY, living with the family, was not so fortunate. She waited until she saw all the family safe out of the building, and then attempted to escape in the same way, but the smoke and flame came rushing up the stairway, and through the rooms to such an extent that she was compelled to run to the front part of the house, and appearing for a moment at a front window on the third floor, she called wildly for aid; but no help appearing, she made a frantic leap and struck upon the pavement below. She was soon taken up by the firemen, assisted by the Police, and taken first to the Tenth Precinct Station-house, and subsequently to the Hospital. It was found upon examination that her spine was fractured, and that she had sustained other serious injuries, which must necessarily prove fatal.

abstract: C.J. JACK, Esq., applied to the County Court and obtained a writ of habeas corpus, upon application of United States soldiers at Fort Hamilton for their release, on the ground that they are illegally detained. abstract: -- There are passages in the report of Col. PORTER which do injustice, unintentionally of course, to Col. BURNSIDE. The "slow and intermittent movements of the Second Brigade," were under the direction of an engineer officer who led the column; and all the halts were ordered by the Colonel of the Division who rode in front, and were for the purpose of clearing the road of fallen [???] and other obstructions to the passage, of artillery. Col. BURNSIDE was not in command of the Division, nor was he responsible for its movements, which do not, however, merit the censure implied by the terms of Col. PORTER's report. The report speaks of the Second Brigade (BURNSIDE's) as having "attacked the enemy's right with perhaps too hasty vigor." The division had been ordered forward by Col. HUNTER, and at the time referred to, one of the Rhode Island regiments, put under fire by his orders, was so sorely pressed by the enemy, that Col. BURNSIDE had no choice but to attack as promptly and with as much vigor as possible. This is evident from the reports of the officers engaged. As to the points referred to in the closing paragraph, it is not easy to see either the occasion or, the motive for Col. PORTER's remarks. Col. BURNSIDE, in his report, merely repeats a remark, made to him by Col. HUNTER, and does not claim that he had command of the division: he is perfectly clear and specific as to the time during which his brigade was in action; and the retreat was covered solely by the battalion of regular infantry, -- Col. PORTER's cavalry and artillery having passed Col BURNSIDE's brigade some three miles from the field of battle -- the cavalry crossing Cub Run nearly a mile above the bridge. These errors are perhaps of trifling importance; but if Col. PORTER enters upon personal criticisms of this kind in an official report, it is only just to himself as well, as to others that he should take pains to be entirely accurate.

abstract: A STATEN ISLAND MYSTERY. -- Yesterday morning, a man, apparently about 27 years old, was found hanging from the limb of a tree in a thicket in the rear of Mr. DAYTON's residence, near the Finger-Board road leading from New-York avenue to Camp Scott, Staten Island. He was dead when found, and, to all appearance,, had been hanging there for two or three days. He was an entire stranger in the place, and nothing was found upon his body to indicate his name or residence. On Tuesday night last, a servant-girl living in the neighborhood says she heard some soldiers running along the road, near where the body was found, crying, "Hang him! hang him!" and from the peculiar manner in which the body was found suspended to the tree, it is believed that the deceased could not have hung himself. Instead of being suspended by a rope, a twig of the tree was found twisted around his -neck, from which the body depended. No marks of violence were discovered upon the person of the deceased, and it is certain that he must have been strangled in this manner, whether by his own act or that of others. There are rumors that a stranger made his appearance at Camp Scott on Tuesday, and was boisterous in proclaiming himself a Secessionist and denouncing the Government soldiers, and it is thought that a party of the volunteers were finally induced to apply to him the argument so generally applied to Union men in the section of the country where his sentiments prevail.

abstract: A telegraphic dispatch has been received from Gen. FREMONT announcing that, in the battle at Wilson's Creek, Gen. SWEENEY received a flesh wound in the leg, but was able to ride back on his horse to Springfield. Gen. SWEENEY's friends in New-York will be glad to learn that his injuries are so slight.

abstract: Mr. Walter R. Danforth, fourth Mayor of Providence, died in that city on Aug. 11. He was born in Providence in 1787, graduated at Brown University in 1805. Until 1818 he was clerk of the Court of Common Pleas of the County, and in 1820 became Editor and joint proprietor of the Providence Gazette, which warmly advocated the interests of the Federalists. Subsequently he became connected with the Microcosm, the Express, and later still with the Republican Herald. Gen. Jackson, whom he ardently supported, appointed him Collector of Customs at Providence in 1829. He held this post until 1841, when he retired to private life, leaving that in 1853 to assume the duties of the Mayoralty. In 1855 he was elected to the General Assembly, holding his seat for a single term.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Walter R. Danforth, fourth Mayor of Providence, died in that city on Aug. 11. He was born in Providence in 1787, graduated at Brown University in 1805. He held this post until 1841, when he retired to private life, leaving that in 1853 to assume the duties of the Mayoralty. In 1855 he was elected to the General Assembly, holding his seat for a single term.

abstract: thing as perfection in counterfeiting, it is reached in an imitation of the $5 and $10 notes of the Prescott Bank of Lowell, something over $4,000 of which have been received by the Suffolk Bank and Bank of Mutual Redemption of this city, from New-York City, and from Rochester, N.Y. We do not see how or where the most accomplished expert can detect the slightest shade of difference between the true and the false notes, except in one trifling particular, in which the false note is the most perfect of the two. By the suggestion of a bank officer who had been informed of the fact, we discover that the dot of the "i," in the name of WRIGHT, (of the engravers,) placed at the bottom of the note in exceedingly fine letters, is to be found in the counterfeit, but is omitted in the real note. -- Boston Herald.

abstract: Another important proclamation has been issued by the President, and will be found in the TIMES this morning. In consequence of the fail ure of the insurgents in the rebellious States to disperse, in accordance with the requirements of his proclamation issued on the 15th of April last, the President now declares the inhabitants of Georgia, South Carolina, Virginia, North Carolina, Tennessee, Alabama, Louisiana, Texas, Arkansas,
lead_paragraph: Another important proclamation has been issued by the President, and will be found in the TIMES this morning. In consequence of the fail ure of the insurgents in the rebellious States to disperse, in accordance with the requirements of his proclamation issued on the 15th of April last, the President now declares the inhabitants of Georgia, South Carolina, Virginia, North Carolina, Tennessee, Alabama, Louisiana, Texas, Arkansas, Mississippi and Florida, to be in a state of insurrection against the United States, and that all commercial intercourse between the rebellious States and the inhabitants thereof, and the citizens of other States and other parts of the United States is unlawful, and will remain unlawful until such insurrection shall cease, or shall have been suppressed. Everything, therefore, coming from those States into other parts of the United States, without the special permission of the President, through the Secretary of the Treasury, or proceeding to any if these States by land or water, will be forfeited to the United States, together with the vessel or vehicle conveying the same. The proclamation also declares the forfeiture of all ships and vessels belonging, in whole or in part, to any citizen or inhabitant of the rebellious States, whether found at sea or in any part of the United States. All grievances occurring under the operation of this law are to be referred to the Secretary of the Treasury. Of course, Western Virginia, East Tennessee, and such other portions of the rebellious States as are true to the Union, are exempted.

abstract: Among the passengers by the steamer Persia, which arrived at this port on Tuesday last, was a man named THOMAS S. SERRELL, a resident of New-Orleans, who, as the statements of his fellow-passengers go to show, avowed the most violent secession sentiments on the passage over, asserting that he was returning to the South with a large sum of money the proceeds of a loan which he had negotiated in Europe for the Southern Confederacy. His opinions were expressed in language so offensive to the friends of the United States Government, (being often coupled with the coarsest epithets,) that he was frequently involved in violent disputes, resulting in a determination on the part of some of the passengers to report his case to the Government officials upon the arrival of the steamer at this port. Accordingly, when United States Deputy-Surveyors ISAACS and BUNN boarded the Persia at Quarantine on Tuesday afternoon, these facts were related to them, and upon their arrival at Jersey City, where the baggage of all passengers is inspected, particular attention was given to that portion of it claimed by Mr. SERRELL. His person was also carefully searched, and resulted in finding L40,000 in Bank of England notes, together with a large number of letters and important papers, the contents of which (whatever may be their legal value as evidence) leave no doubt that the accused party is a violent partisan of JEFF. DAVIS, and an agent of the Southern Confederacy. Surveyor ANDREWS communicated the facts to Secretary CHASE, at that time stopping in the City, who approved of the proceedings, and advised the arrest of SERREL.

abstract: Wm.R. Foster, who is the proprietor of a livery stable in Brooklyn, was yesterday arrested by Officer Hogan, of the lower Police Court, upon a charge of fraud and false representations, on the complaint of Mr. Waldo Phillips, of No. 348 Third-avenue, who alleges that he has been swindled by Foster to the extent of $152.78. lead_paragraph: Wm.R. Foster, who is the proprietor of a livery stable in Brooklyn, was yesterday arrested by Officer Hogan, of the lower Police Court, upon a charge of fraud and false representations, on the complaint of Mr. Waldo Phillips, of No. 348 Third-avenue, who alleges that he has been swindled by Foster to the extent of $152.78. It seems that in the fore part of June last, Foster called upon the complainant, and desired to purchase hay and other horse-feed of him, on credit, at the same time alleging that he was the owner of a pair of fine bay horses then on livery in Harlem-lane. On the strength of these representations, a credit to the above amount was obtained. When the bill was presented for payment, Foster said he was unable to pay it, and at the same time told Phillips that the horses had been sold to a man in Brooklyn for $1,600. Upon inquiry, however, the complainant ascertained that the horses in question did not, and never had belonged to Foster, but that they are owned by a man named David Wood, of No. 43 Fulton-street, Brooklyn. The accused was taken before Justice OSBORN and held in $500 bail to answer the charge.

abstract: ING OF HAMPTON -- It will be seen by extracts from Southern papers, which we publish in another column, that the Confederates avow the burning of Hampton as their own act. One who accompanied the expedition charged with the duty of setting this Virginia village on fire, states in these letters that it was done in pursuance of orders from Gen. MAGRUDER himself -- who had thought it best to destroy the town, though his reasons for such a judgment are not assigned. The writer gives details of the whole proceeding, and says that as they approached they were fired upon by the sentinels of the Union Army, who were unable, however, to make any effective resistance. He says the expedition was one of great danger, as they might have been shelled from Fortress Monroe. We are glad that Gen. BUTLER did not fire upon them. By this forbearance he has left to them the entire responsibilty of this act of wanton barbarism.

abstract: Mr. Secretary CHASE and the Banks have perfected their negotiations, and he has returned to Washington with a credit in his favor of $50,000,000 to begin with. Although the transaction is unprecedented in amount, it is a small affair, considering the ability of the parties furnishing the money. These are really the capitalists and property holders of the loyal States; the Banks acting as their
lead_paragraph: Mr. Secretary CHASE and the Banks have perfected their negotiations, and he has returned to Washington with a credit in his favor of $50,000,000 to begin with. Although the transaction is unprecedented in amount, it is a small affair, considering the ability of the parties furnishing the money. These are really the capitalists and property holders of the loyal States; the Banks acting as their agents. If the latter chose, however, they could readily take and hold, on their own account, the first $50,000,000; at least till a renewal of business should again create the ordinary demand for their money. The capital of the Banks in the loyal States amounts to $329,831,896. They hold very nearly, if not quite, $100,000,-000 in specle, which is twice the ordinary average. Their deposits, not drawing interest, according to the latest reports to the Secretary of the Treasury, are $207,388,618. These are liabilities to be sure, but they are so much capital available for the war. The deposits in the Savings Banks of the State of New-York are $67,450,397; of Massachusetts, $45,654,584; of Rhode Island, $7,765,771; of Connecticut, $20,161,942 - the aggregate for the four States being $141,378,110. This vast sum is solid capital, a great portion of it being invested in securities immediately convertible into coin. It is probable that the deposits in all the Savings Banks in the loyal States will reach very nearly $200,000,006, making the total deposits in banks and savings and discounts fully $400,000,000. It is this immense reserve that is first to be drawn upon, to be replaced, in part, by the gradual absorption of the loan by the public.

abstract: bath committee, whose "Plea" we publish in another column, have always secured a respectful public hearing. The high character and position of the Committee; their dis interested and successful efforts; the uniform moderation of their public documents, and the virulent abuse to which they have been subjected from certain quarters, alike commend their utterances to the great body of good citizens they address. Their present "Plea" is rather a dissuasive from future invasions of the Sabbath by unnecessary Army movements, than a discussion of the somewhat anomalous facts of the campaign thus far; and the claim for increased caution in this behalf is based on grounds which will command generalassent. Aside from the relations of Sunday to the physical and moral well-being ofthe Army, the argument drawn from the strength and unanimity of the Sabbath sentiment of the country, and the respect due to that sentiment, as a matter of policy and principle, is entitled to great weight. Whether right or wrong, none can doubt its existence or prevalence. Civil and military authorities need rather to propitiate than repel it, for it represents a leading element in the resources on which both must rely in the struggle with rebellion. We cannot conceive that any injury could accrue to our armies were Gen. SCOTT to send forth such a general order as that cited in the "Plea" from the Orderly Book of WASHINGTON. We can conceive that millions of our best citizens would have their apprehensions allayed, and that our moral position before the world would be more befitting a Christian nation.

abstract: We cannot help thinking that many of our cotemporaries use very extravagant and unwarranted language in their denunciations of the blockade of our Southern ports. Very many speak of it as utterly inefficient, as a blockade merely in name, neither effective in preventing commerce with the blockaded ports, nor entitled to the respect of foreign Powers.
lead_paragraph: We cannot help thinking that many of our cotemporaries use very extravagant and unwarranted language in their denunciations of the blockade of our Southern ports. Very many speak of it as utterly inefficient, -- as a blockade merely in name, neither effective in preventing commerce with the blockaded ports, nor entitled to the respect of foreign Powers. Much of this censure is doubtless intended to stimulate the Navy Department to a still more vigorous and thorough enforcement of the blockade, and something of it is doubtless designed to aid in displacing the present Secretary. But this is carried too far when it misstates the facts of the case, and may mislead foreigners into a course of action highly injurious ourselves.

abstract: A STATEN ISLAND MYSTERY. -- Yesterday morning, man, apparently about 27 years old, was found hanging from the limb of a tree in a thicket in the rear of Mr. PAYTON's residence, near the Finger-Board road leading from New-York- avenue to Camp Scott, Staten Island, He was dead when found, and, to all appearance had been hanging there for two or three days. He was an entire stranger in the place, and nothing was found upon his body to indicate his name or residence. On Tuesday night last, a servant-girl living in the neighborhood says she heard some soldiers running along the road, near where the body was found, crying, "Hang him! hang him!" and from the peculiar manner in which the body was found suspended to the tree, it is believed that the deceased could not have hung himself. Instead of being suspended by a rope, a twig of the tree was found twisted around his neck, from which the body depended. No marks of violence were discovered upon the person of the deceased, and it is certain that he must have been strangled in this manner, whether by his own act or that of others. There are rumors that a stranger made his appearance at Camp Scott on Tuesday, and was boisterous in proclaiming himself a Secessionist and denouncing: the Government soldiers, and it is thought that a party of the volunteers were finally induced to apply to him the argument so generally applied to Union men in the section of the country where his sentiments prevail.

abstract: leave to congratulate the capitalists of Great Britain on the splendid success of their first investment in the war loans of the Confederate States. Their first remittance, amounting to 40,000, fell yesterday into the hands of Uncle Sam, who will take good care that it is put to a good use. It will a good deal more than offset the cash value of the muskets, baggage-wagons, cannon and canteens that fell into the hands of the Secessionists at Bull Run, -- and will thus contribute essentially to the most desirable result of keeping accounts closely settled between the two belligerents, as they go along. British capitalists may console themselves with the reflection that they have lost nothing, for their chance of getting their money back now is quite as good as it would have been if it had reached its original destination. Perhaps they might find it wise hereafter to intrust their little remittances to some one who can keep the important fact to himself a little longer than Mr. SERRILL seems to have done. We trust the London Times will repeat its exhortations to the British capitalists about the danger of making loans to Americans.

abstract: formerly an editor of this paper, and well Known as one of our most accomplished and forcible writers, has received the appointment of Consul to Paris. Mr. BIGELO's qualifications for the place are of the first order. He speaks French fluently, has resided for some time in Paris, is well acquainted with the history as well as the trade of France, and enjoys the confidence of many persons of high distinction in the French capital. A gentleman in his manners, and a scholar by his attainments, he is also a man of excellent business capacities. -- Evening Post.

abstract: The Albany Atlas and Argus, in replying to our comments upon its political position, evades the main point we had in view which was to ascertain what "concessions" it was disposed to favor, in older to end the Southern rebellion, and restore the Union to its integrity. It said at the outset, such as HOLT, CRITTENDEN and other Southern Union men might think necessary.
lead_paragraph: The Albany Atlas and Argus, in replying to our comments upon its political position, evades the main point we had in view -- which was to ascertain what "concessions" it was disposed to favor, in older to end the Southern rebellion, and restore the Union to its integrity. It said at the outset, such as HOLT, CRITTENDEN and other Southern Union men might think necessary. But this is entirely too vague a pledge for a political platform. The Democratic State Convention will scarcely embody it in their resolutions, or pledge their constituents to its support. Let the Atlas be more specific. Let it define the concessions either to the rights or prejudices of the South, by which it is disposed to seek the preservation of the Union.

abstract: This colony is fully realizing the evil which I predicted in one of my previous letters to arise from the civil war in America. Jamaica is almost entirely dependent upon the United States for the breadstuffs and provisions which she consumes, and it is quite evident that anything which leads to a stoppage of supplies must occasion us very great suffering.

abstract: It has been repeatedly stated that Lieut. J.W. DEMPSEY, of the Second Regiment New-York State Militia, was killed at the battle of Bull Run. This, however, proves not to have been the case. He was badly wounded in the forehead by a fragment of bomb, and was subsequently taken prisoner, and is now in Richmond, rapidly recovering. These facts we gather from a letter written by him to his wife in this City.
lead_paragraph: It has been repeatedly stated that Lieut. J.W. DEMPSEY, of the Second Regiment New-York State Militia, was killed at the battle of Bull Run. These facts we gather from a letter written by him to his wife in this City.

abstract: The body of Col. FARNHAM, of the Fire Zouaves, arrived in this City from Washington at 6 1/2 o'clock last evening, and was conveyed directly to the residence of his father, No. 123 West Thirty-eighth-street. The funeral will take place from Christ Church, corner of Fifth-avenue and Thirty-fifth-street, at 10 o'clock this morning, remains will be taken thence to New-Haven by the 12:15 train, and will be accompanied thither by the second company National Guard, of which deceased was formerly lieutenant. The body was embalmed before leaving Washington, and presents a very life-like and natural appearance.

abstract: If there is any rule of warfare which is of instinctive and universal acceptance among men, whether civilized or savage, it is to strike an enemy where he is weakest. The reason is manifest: you strike thus with least danger to yourself, and with most damage to the foe. But it seems to us that the United States Government has wholly failed to profit by the wisdom of ages.
lead_paragraph: If there is any rule of warfare which is of instinctive and universal acceptance among men, whether civilized or savage, it is to strike an enemy where he is weakest. The reason is manifest: you strike thus with least danger to yourself, and with most damage to the foe. But it seems to us that the United States Government has wholly failed to profit by the wisdom of ages. We have permitted the enemies of the Union to pitch their battles precisely where they wanted them; and we have neglected to strike a single blow where a blow would have fallen with deadly effect, and where none could be given in return.

abstract: Tribune, of yesterday, a very extraordinary story which professes to come from a correspondent at Gatesville, N. C. The writer says that a man named Ross, believing him to had a British subject, told him that he had himself been a sailor on board a British vessel, which had been attacked, captured and burned by a Confederate privateer, the Captain of which had taken her for a Yankee vessel, and regarded the British flag which she hoisted as a false signal. Finding his mistake, he had destroyed the vessel and crew, as the only means of insuring his own safety. The writer says that Ross was at that time on his way North, and that he would undoubtedly lay full particulars of the transaction before the proper authorities.
lead_paragraph: Tribune, of yesterday, a very extraordinary story which professes to come from a correspondent at Gatesville, N. C. The writer says that Ross was at that time on his way North, and that he would undoubtedly lay full particulars of the transaction before the proper authorities.

abstract: Mr. BRADY, the Photographer, has just returned from Washington with the magnificent series of views of scenes, groups and incidents of the war which he has been making for the last two months. Mr. BRADY, after visiting all the camps in the vicinity of Washington, and taking views of all the most striking scenes, accompanied the Army in its advance into Virginia. He had a full corps of artists and workmen, and embraced every opportunity to add to his collection of illustrative views. He went upon the field of battle at Bull Run, -- accompanied HEINTZELMAN's column into the action, and was caught in the whirl and panic which accompanied the retreat of our Army. We saw him constantly, at every point, before and after the fight, neglecting no opportunity and sparing no labor in the pursuit of his professional object. As the result of his arduous and perilous toil, he has brought back a very large collection of pictures which will do more than the most elaborate description to perpetuate the scenes of that brief campaign. Mr. BRADY was the only photographer on the field, and is entitled to the highest credit for the energy and enterprise which he displayed. This series of pictures has been added to the magnificent collection at his Photographic Gallery, corner of Tenth-street and Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Mr. BRADY, the Photographer, has just returned from Washington with the magnificent series of views of scenes, groups and incidents of the war which he has been making for the last two months. abstract: The United States Marshals now in the City held another meeting in the United States District Court-room yesterday morning. They discussed the various methods adopted for obtaining clearances, manifests and other papers, and the different grounds for suspecting vessels and the proper steps for making seizure. Mr. MURRAY communicated much valuable information concerning the operation of the slavetraders in this City. The Marshals visited the slave prisoners at the Tombs, and left the City last evening for their respective homes.

abstract: By this time, about every person in the city is aware that martial law has been declared and established therein by Maj-Gen. FREMONT, commanding the Military Department of the West. The legal status also embraces the entire county of St. Louis.
lead_paragraph: By this time, about every person in the city is aware that martial law has been declared and established therein by Maj-Gen. FREMONT, commanding the Military Department of the West. The legal status also embraces the entire county of St. Louis. Many people had entertained vague and fearful apprehensions respecting the nature and results of the step thus taken, but it has as yet been followed by no unhappy consequences.

abstract: A span of horses, drawing a somewhat dilapidated looking wagon covered with cotton cloth, made its appearance in the streets yesterday. The singular appearance of the vehicle attracted the attention of the passers and when the driver drew rein and halted on Jefferson-avenue, a crowd quickly gathered around.
lead_paragraph: A span of horses, drawing a somewhat dilapidated looking wagon covered with cotton cloth, made its appearance in the streets yesterday. The singular appearance of the vehicle attracted the attention of the passers and when the driver drew rein and halted on Jefferson-avenue, a crowd quickly gathered around. On inquiry they learned that the name of the owner of the establishment was FRANK NAPIER, a former resident of Shreveport. La. On the culmination of the National difficulties, NAPIER, being a strong Union man, perceived that his residence was too far South to permit him to live on peaceable and quiet terms with his neighbors, and, packing up what portion of his goods he could carry, and taking his wife and three daughters, he left for a more congenial clime. He set out the 25th day of April last, and during the journey himself and family have slept every night in the wagon. He has made his way to this State after the long and tedious journey, in hopes of finding a home among our people, where, by tilling the soil, he can earn an honest livelihood and maintain, unmolested, his loyalty to the Stars and Stripes.

abstract: facts in relation to a young man recently enlisted in the Navy at the recruiting-office in this city. Some three years since, and just previous to his sailing on a whaling voyage, he became acquainted with a young girl in Fall River, of unspotted reputation, who was an operative in one of the mills of that city. Returning from his voyage, not long since, he was surprised to learn that this girl, whom he left so pure, was an inmate of one of the foulest dens in our city. He at once found her out, listened to the sad story of her wrongs, and at length induced her to abandon her vicious course of life. She is now an inmate of the Home for the Fallen; and like a good Samaritan, the young sailor, before he went to join his ship, left a half-pay ticket for the benefit of the poor girl. We state but the simple facts (not all of them) to show the touching kindness of heart and unselfish generosity of the young sailor, and the benefit of an institution which furnishes to the penitent girl an asylum.

abstract: The steamers George Peabody, Capt. PRITCHARD, and the Adelaide, Capt. EDGAR, of the Bay line, have been chartered by the United States Government for the purpose of assisting in the blockade of the Southern ports, and they will leave this port for sea as soon as they can be got ready for the expedition. The Adelaide is a staunch side-wheel steamer, capable of making sixteen miles per hour, and a first-rate sea boat. The Peabody is about one thousand tons burden, and is in excellent order. Both steamers are being fitted with masts, so that in case their machinery should become deranged whilst at sea, sails can be hoisted and the boats managed, independent of their steam power. Each steamer is to be supplied with four thirty-two pound guns, located fore and aft, and will leave the port with an armed guard. Nearly all day yesterday gangs of workmen were engaged on them, and they will have a sufficient quantity of coal stowed away in bags, ample for a week's steaming.
lead_paragraph: The steamers George Peabody, Capt. PRITCHARD, and the Adelaide, Capt. abstract: The rebels and destroyers of the Union are at work in the Middle States. During the last fortnight agents of the Southern Confederacy have been visiting various sections of New-Jersey, inaugurating movements for systematic peace meetings throughout the State.
lead_paragraph: The rebels and destroyers of the Union are at work in the Middle States. During the last fortnight agents of the Southern Confederacy have been visiting various sections of New-Jersey, inaugurating movements for systematic peace meetings throughout the State. Individuals have been guaranteed against all expense, and these treason movements have been organized with diabolicel shrewdness through dupes or willing tools in the late Breckinridge Party, who, to gratify their hate, would help to crumble our free institutions for the sake of establishing a Southern monarchy.

abstract: "It is understood, in official circles," says the Richmond Dispatch, "that the Secretary of War, Hon. L. POPE WALKER, has recommended to Congress an addition to the Southern Army of about thee hundred and fifty regiments, or such a number as, added to the force already organized, will make an aggregate of five hundred and sixty regiments. Estimating each regiment at a thousand men, this would give a force of five hundred and sixty thousand men, rank and file. The white population of the Confederate States being, in round numbers, five millions six hundred thousand souls, the proposed Army would amount to just ten percent, of the whole, or one solider to every ten white people."

abstract: The State Executive Committee of the National Union Party of the State of New-York, convened on the 17th, (yesterday,) in the City of New-York, and unanimously adopted a preamble and resolutions, setting forth, their views on the present crisis. They take credit to their party for having foreseen and labored against the evils that now distract the country, but declare, that, as formerly, so now, their motto is, "The Union, the Constitution and the Enforcement of the Laws." They say, "We still proclaim our adherence to those principles, and our unyielding determination to sustain them. The Committee deprecate the indulgence of party strife at the present time, and think the revival of party contests would bode little good to the Confederacy. They close with a sentiment which is honorable to them as patriots, and entirely in accordance with the already expressed sentiments of the Republican party. They say: "May we not, then, hope that party or political distinctions may be obliterated in this State, and that we may all unite in one common determination to sustain and perpetuate 'Our Union and our Constitution?'"
lead_paragraph: The State Executive Committee of the National Union Party of the State of New-York, convened on the 17th, (yesterday,) in the City of New-York, and unanimously adopted a preamble and resolutions, setting forth, their views on the present crisis. abstract: The markets have been very active most of the time since our last review, but also quite irregu1ar and fluctuating. By Saturday a large advance had been established in Flour and Grain, and some improvement in Provisions, Wool and Hides; but since Monday, the Flour and Grain markets have been feverish and fluctuating, prices falling back, with a
lead_paragraph: The markets have been very active most of the time since our last review, but also quite irregu1ar and fluctuating. By Saturday a large advance had been established in Flour and Grain, and some improvement in Provisions, Wool and Hides; but since Monday, the Flour and Grain markets have been feverish and fluctuating, prices falling back, with a variation of 1c.@2c. on Spring Wheat, 1/2c.@1c. on Corn, and 5c.@10c. on Spring Wheat Flour. Notwithstanding the unsettled state of the markets in the last few days, prices are higher on the week for leading articles, and a portion at least of the recent advance seems certain to be maintained. Winter Wheat has experienced the greatest improvement, No. 1 Red having advanced 10c.@12c., and No. 2 do. 4c.@5c., and closing firm. Spring Wheat Flour may safety be quoted 10c.@15c. on the good medium grades, which are scarce, and White Wheat Flour is firm and steady. The advance on Spring Wheat from last Wednesday to Saturday was fully 5c., and the subsequent falling back still leaves an improvement on the week of 2c.@3c. Corn advanced in the same time 1 1/2c.@2c., but closes only 1c. higher than a week ago. Rye advanced 2c.@3c, which is nearly all lost. Barley is 2c.@3c. better, but not active at the improvement. The market for Seeds has not yet opened. Fresh Fruits and Vegetables have been scarce and active at higher prices, but the supply is now increasing again, and prices falling back. Poultry and Game active, but Eggs very dull. Hides are more active, with some improvement in prices. High Wines firm. Alcohol steady. Provisions selling only in a small way. Wool rather better on the medium grades.

abstract: While Hon. JEFFERSON DAVIS was Secretary of War under President PIERCE it will be remembered that the Territory of Kansas was the theatre of grave political controversies, finally degenerating into civil feud. The contest arose among the adherents of two Legislatures respectively assuming to represent the people of that Territory.
lead_paragraph: While Hon. JEFFERSON DAVIS was Secretary of War under President PIERCE it will be remembered that the Territory of Kansas was the theatre of grave political controversies, finally degenerating into civil feud. The contest arose among the adherents of two Legislatures respectively assuming to represent the people of that Territory. The body sitting at Lecompton was recognized by the Administration of Mr. PIERCE as the only legitimate depostaries of the legislative powers capable of being exercised under the organic act constituting the Territory. The body sitting at Topeka was regarded as revolutionary, and, as such, deserving to be dispersed by the National authority. Under these circumstances it was that on the 3d of September, 1856, Mr. Secretary DAVIS wrote as follows to Gen. PERSIFER F. SMITH:

abstract: An important seizure has already been made under the proclamation of the President, which we published yesterday morning. Goods to the value of about $5,000, purchased by parties in Baltimore for Richmond dealers, were yesterday inintercepted at Annapolis Junction and taken possession of, together with the teams and wagons by which they were being conveyed, and a number of letters to officers in the rebel army. It is
lead_paragraph: An important seizure has already been made under the proclamation of the President, which we published yesterday morning. Goods to the value of about $5,000, purchased by parties in Baltimore for Richmond dealers, were yesterday inintercepted at Annapolis Junction and taken possession of, together with the teams and wagons by which they were being conveyed, and a number of letters to officers in the rebel army. It is understood that the man having charge of the goods has also furnished much valuable information in reference to the manner in which communication has been kept up between Baltimore and the rebel States. Thus one prolific source of supply for the rebels is undoubtedly at last cut off.
