abstract: A FIRST WARD POLICEMAN ARRESTED. JOHN SCANLON, a policeman of the First Ward, was arrested on Friday night by Capt. SILVEY of that Ward on a complaint of LEWIS HORAM, who resides in Brooklyn. It seems that on the night of the 8th inst., this policeman went into a coffee and cake saloon on the corner
lead_paragraph: A FIRST WARD POLICEMAN ARRESTED. -- JOHN SCANLON, a policeman of the First Ward, was arrested on Friday night by Capt. SILVEY of that Ward on a complaint of LEWIS HORAM, who resides in Brooklyn. It seems that on the night of the 8th inst., this policeman went into a coffee and cake saloon on the corner of Morris and Greenwich streets and where there got into a quarrel with HORAN, whom he knocked down with his fist. HORAN got up and soon left the place, the policeman following him, and when on the sidewalk knocked him down the second time. In the [???]. HORAN lost his gold watch and a pocket-book, containing $23. SCANLON was dressed in citizen's clothes at the time, and HORAN did not learn until yesterday who it was that assaulted him. The accused was taken before Justice OSHORN and locked up for examination. He says HORAN and others were behaving very disorderly at the time, and that he was trying to restore order, as it was his duty to do.

abstract: The prize-ship Gen. Parkhill, which was brought to this port on the 1st of May, was sold at public sale by the clerk of Marshal MILWARD, and brought $7,400. She was bid off to Messrs. WORKMAN & Co., of this city, but it is understood was bought for HOLMBOE & Co., of New-York. The vessel was sold just as she was, with her tackle, furniture, &c. Several merchants and shipowners were present, but the bidding was confined to two persons. As the vessel has seen considerable service, and is less than 500 tons register, it was thought that she sold for as much as she is worth. The Parkhill was captured about the middle of May, off the harbor of Charleston, by the United States steamship Niagara. She was owned by PATTERSON & STARK, of Charleston, S.C., and at the time of her capture was attempting to run the blockade. Her cargo, consisting solely of salt, is yet on board. It cannot be sold until a decision of the Court is obtained in reference to it.

abstract: The captain of the steamer Boston, of the outside Philadelphia and New-York line, was surprised on Friday by a sudden and unusual accession of passengers for this City. They were mostly dressed in citizen's clothes, and those who had uniforms wore only such portions as would not identify them with any regiment. They represented that they belonged
lead_paragraph: The captain of the steamer Boston, of the outside Philadelphia and New-York line, was surprised on Friday by a sudden and unusual accession of passengers for this City. They were mostly dressed in citizen's clothes, and those who had uniforms wore only such portions as would not identify them with any regiment. They represented that they belonged to three months' regiments, whose terms of enlistment had expired. They numbered about two hundred, and arrived here yesterday (Saturday) morning. It now appears that these were nearly all deserters from the Seventy-ninth Regiment, concerning which the Government have recently had some difficulty in Washington, and 37 of whose number are under arrest for mutiny. They contrived to escape from the lines under cover of night, and taking the cars for Baltimore at a way station, came to Philadelphia, and thence by steamer to New-York. These persons are all liable to arrest and punishment as deserters, having been sworn in for the war. Squads of regulars, with United States officers, were in sharp pursuit of them yesterday, and it is said that several were arrested and conveyed to Governor's Island. They were followed to Staten Island, Hoboken, and other places, where they took to the woods to elude pursuit. Others were supposed to be concealed by their friends in this City. The authorities express the intention to arrest every one of them as fast as they can be found

abstract: If the report which reached this city on yesterday heralded another brilliant victory of the National arms in the southwest, it brought no joy to our hearts. Whelly devoted to the cause of our country, we earnestly desire and anxiously labor and pray for it success in the pending war. Nevertheless, we can only mourn over the slaughter of
lead_paragraph: If the report which reached this city on yesterday heralded another brilliant victory of the National arms in the southwest, it brought no joy to our hearts. Whelly devoted to the cause of our country, we earnestly desire and anxiously labor and pray for it success in the pending war. Nevertheless, we can only mourn over the slaughter of our countrymen. The loss of life, which is reported as immense on both sides, is cause for deep and poignant grief to hundreds and thousands of our people. For one alone of those who fell in battle, St. Louis will mourn, Missouri will mourn, and the nation will mourn. Of course, we allude to Brig.-Gen. LYON. He was a man of commanding intellect, of distinguished scientific, and literary attainments, and a polished soldier. To no one man in this war does Missouri and the National Union owe a larger debt of gratitude than to Gen. LYON. It was our good fortune that he was ordered to service at the St. Louis Arsenal in these difficulties. He came to St. Louis when the whole force at this post did not exceed, if we emember rightly, 380 men. Reinforcements were sought, but were not procured. It was with this small garrison that he was to defend the Arsenal and protect the public property here from an overwhelming body of the enemy, then organized and armed in this city, known as the "Constitutional Guards," Minute Men," and a large portion of another body denominated "Frost's Brigade." And well did he perform his delicate and painful task. How bravely did he enter upon the work with his little body of men -- who does not remember, that could gain admission to the Arsenal in those days, how his cannon and his earthworks were made to coyer the assailable, points -- how his sand bags were distributed to protect his sentries on the rally, and with what desperate resolution he had mined the very buildings over his head determined in the dernier resort to blow them into atoms, and perhaps to perish amid their ruins. It was well understood that an assault upon the St. Louis Arsenal, with the forlorn hope that then constituted its little garrison, would be no idle business. The assault was not made. The known soldierly skill and valor of Capt. LYON deterred the enemy. It was while he was defending the Arsenal in this way, and dealing with the "Minute Men" and the "Police Commissioners of St. Louis, who once ordered his patrols inside the arsenal walls, and placed their sentries over the arsenal gates, that Capt. LYON became satisfied that the Secessionists of Missouri were fatally bent upon war, and would never yield their purpose until they were utterly prostrated by the power of war. Sooner than others, he saw and understood the object of Camp Jackson, and seeing and understanding, did not hesitate to crush in embryo that incipient secession Army.

abstract: E.TULLIS, Esq., who last year shipped one of the first bales of cotton, had picked on his plantation, on Tuesday, the 30th of July, over five thousand pounds of clean cotton. In about another week, picking throughout the parish will be general.
lead_paragraph: E.TULLIS, Esq., who last year shipped one of the first bales of cotton, had picked on his plantation, on Tuesday, the 30th of July, over five thousand pounds of clean cotton. In about another week, picking throughout the parish will be general. The corn-crop is now secured, and very abundant it is; and the cotton-crop, with hardly an exception, gives general satisfaction. We have not heard of a single planter, however who will ship his cotton before the entire removal of the blockade.

abstract: The undersigned, having been requested to act as a Committee upon a Prize National Hymn, acceptcd the office doubtfully, and with some reluctance. They doubted the efficacy of the means proposed to the end which was sought: they were reluctant to assume the function of deciding for their fellow-citizens a question which it seemed to them could really be settled only by general consent and the lapse of time.
lead_paragraph: The undersigned, having been requested to act as a Committee upon a Prize National Hymn, acceptcd the office doubtfully, and with some reluctance. They doubted the efficacy of the means proposed to the end which was sought: they were reluctant to assume the function of deciding for their fellow-citizens a question which it seemed to them could really be settled only by general consent and the lapse of time. And deeply as the events of the present momentous period of our country's history stir the heart of every true American, and strong as the tendency appeared among persons in all parts of the land, and of all grades of culture, to give a lyric expression to patriotic feeling, they still felt that the chances were very slight of obtaining at the call of a Committee and by the offer of a prize, a National Hymn which would live in the hearts and upon the lips of the American people. Therefore, although they did not feel at liberty to decline the service asked of them, they expressly reserved to themselves, in their published conditions of competition, "the right of rejecting all contributions, whatever their merit, should none of them be deemed suitable."*

abstract: week, an aged citizen of wealth and respectability mysteriously disappeared, and for several days nothing was heard of him by his family. His absence gave rise to the most serious apprehensions, and strenuous efforts were made to ascertain his where-abouts, without success. Finally a note was received by one of his daughters, informing her that her immediate presence was desired at a house in the lower part of the city. She repaired there, in company with a servant, and was informed that her father was there, and was very sick. She desired to see him, but was told that she could not. The servant who accompanied her insisted upon the daughter's right to see her father, which led to a quarrel between her and the occupant of the promises, a widow, and she was driven from the door. Taking refuge behind a carriage, a stone was thrown at her, which smashed one of the carriage Windows. The daughter soon after left, her request to see her father being refused to the last. Proceedings were then commenced before Recorder ENUE against the widow, in which she was charged with assault and battery and malicious mischief. After the hearing, the accused was informed by the Recorder that the daughter had a right to see her father, and that she must be permitted to visit him, or legal steps would be taken to compel his production in court. The widow finally consented, and the family physician and one of the Recorder's officers accompanied the daughter. The father was found in a chamber, almost unable to speak from paralysis, one side being entirely paralyzed. The widow said that, soon after his reaching the house, he complained of diarrhoea, and she had given him a glass of lavender brandy; that as he drank it he was deprived of speech, and she called in her family physician, who had attended him. She objected to his removal, but he gave his daughter to understand that he desired it, and he was conveyed to his residence. Yesterday he was better, and hopes were entertained of his recovery. The object of the widow in refusing permission to his daughter to see him, and desiring to keep him at her house, is left to conjecture. He lost his wife recently, and that fact may help to solve the mystery. -- Phil. Ledger, Aug. 16.

abstract: The Mobile Advertiser says that, on Saturday night, the 3d-inst., one of the harbor police boats Was chased by five ship's launches of the enemy, who, it is thought, came from the dry-dock, now anchored midway between Santa Rosa Island and the Navyyard. The steamer Niagara or Wabash, which arrived at the anchorage a day or two previous, sailed Monday evening to the southwest, probably for the Mississippi station.

abstract: We learn that Mr. POMBO, Charge de Affaires ad interim of the Granadian Confederation to the United States of America, has recently had an interview with Secretary SEWARD in reference to the intervention of the United States naval forces stationed at this port and Aspinwall, in case of the invasion of this Isthmus by a rebel force from Carthagena; and that it resulted in Mr. SEWARD's acknowledging the obligation of the United States, under the existing treaty of peace, amity, &c., to protect the neutrality of the Isthmus and insure the safety of the transit against the threatened invasion, and that vessels-of-war would be kept at both ports for that purpose.

abstract: A dispatch from Washington to the Tribune, yesterday, states that an order has gone forward to Gen. SUMNER, military commandant in California, to raise 5,000 or 10,000 troops in that State, and march them into Arkansas and Texas. Unless past experience is utterly
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from Washington to the Tribune, yesterday, states that an order has gone forward to Gen. SUMNER, military commandant in California, to raise 5,000 or 10,000 troops in that State, and march them into Arkansas and Texas. Unless past experience is utterly lost on our Government, we presume this statement is not true. Two or three years since it became necessary to send an Army, not larger than the one that Gen. SUMNER is asked to raise, into Utah. This is about half across the country which Gen. SUMNER is required to traverse entirely.

abstract: There used to be a class of Historians who were fond of tracing the mightiest results to the most trivial causes - finding the origin of a war in a fit of kingly indigestion, and the like. The method latterly has fallen into disrepute; but a recent fracas between Monsignor DE MERODE, the Pope's War Minister, and Gen. DE GUYON, commander of the French garrison at Home, looks very much like an illustration of the old doctrine, for it promises a solution of that knotty Roman question which has baffled all the skill of diplomacy. The story, as told by the French papers, is a piece of genuine Hudibrastic mock-heroic. The main features of the squabble seem to have been as follows: A French and a Papal soldier, having had a misunderstanding about some woman, settled their differences in a combat, in which the former was wounded. According to existing arrangements, the offender ought to have been handed over to a French Court-martial, and he was accordingly claimed by GUYON. M. DE MERODE, however, would not hear of his being given up. The General then appealed to Cardinal ANTONELLI and the Holy Father himself, who imposed their united injunctions on DE MERODE to comply with the demand. The impracticable War Secretary continued, however, to
lead_paragraph: There used to be a class of Historians who were fond of tracing the mightiest results to the most trivial causes - finding the origin of a war in a fit of kingly indigestion, and the like. The method latterly has fallen into disrepute; but a recent fracas between Monsignor DE MERODE, the Pope's War Minister, and Gen. DE GUYON, commander of the French garrison at Home, looks very much like an illustration of the old doctrine, for it promises a solution of that knotty Roman question which has baffled all the skill of diplomacy. The story, as told by the French papers, is a piece of genuine Hudibrastic mock-heroic. The main features of the squabble seem to have been as follows: A French and a Papal soldier, having had a misunderstanding about some woman, settled their differences in a combat, in which the former was wounded. According to existing arrangements, the offender ought to have been handed over to a French Court-martial, and he was accordingly claimed by GUYON. M. DE MERODE, however, would not hear of his being given up. The General then appealed to Cardinal ANTONELLI and the Holy Father himself, who imposed their united injunctions on DE MERODE to comply with the demand. The impracticable War Secretary continued, however, to

abstract: Night before last a little Army of fifty-two hundred men moved in two columns on a march of twelve or fifteed miles to attack a body of rebels twenty-two thousand strong. In a military point of view the move was one of doubtful propriety, not to say absolute rashness. The larger force were, with the exception of three thousand men, well armed and equipped, and they had a very large body of cavalry.

abstract: Receiving information last night, a posse of the Eastern District Police visited the house of Mrs. STEGMAIN, No. 81 Eastern-avenue, and seized a beautiful Minie musket, with a cavalry sword, which were removed to the station-house. The musket is somewhat
lead_paragraph: Receiving information last night, a posse of the Eastern District Police visited the house of Mrs. STEGMAIN, No. 81 Eastern-avenue, and seized a beautiful Minie musket, with a cavalry sword, which were removed to the station-house. The musket is somewhat similar to those used by the Sixth Massachusetts Regiment, and was taken to the house of Mrs. S. a short time subsequent to the attack on that regiment on the 19th of April. It was loaded with a Minie ball cartridge when seized.

abstract: Southern office-hunters and seekers are not likely to receive justice from the present generation: history alone will do honor to their forbearance and long-suffering patience. The moment it became apparent that they were likely to be crowded from their stools in the Departments at Washington, they seceded and tried to get up a Government of their own,withdrawing to regions where they supposed the Yankees would cease from troubling; but the result does not speak well for the shrewdness of the rebels. Had they tarried at Montgomery they might have been safe. But in an evil hour they tempted their fate by removing to Richmond, and the result is before us in a letter from the Confederate Capital to the Charleston Courier, of as late a date as August 4. "The heads of departments," we are told, "dispense their patronage in a reckless and partial manner." They act "with an utter contempt of public opinion; not as the servants of the people, and trustees of their interests, but as their masters, and the proprietors of "the governmental estate." "The offices," it is stated, "were already too full of the old Washington office-beggars and sycophants," (shades of Cobb and Floyd defend us!) "and many of them Yankees." Then we learn that "even within the last week or so, large numbers of eleventh-hour patriots have become refugees (for the sake of the spoils,) from the Abolition Capital, and have taken up their quarters in Richmond. Many have been appointed immediately upon their arrival and few have to wait long." Thus it would appear that the act outlawing those who still clung to their old haunts in Washington has brought an unexpected and undesired avalanche upon Richmond.
lead_paragraph: Southern office-hunters and seekers are not likely to receive justice from the present generation: history alone will do honor to their forbearance and long-suffering patience. abstract: Reliable information is received in our city that the Secessionists in the vicinity of Cynthiana have begun their nefarious work at that point. For some days past they have been sorely troubled by the shipment of arms, ammunition and military clothing from this city for the use of the Union men, who, it is well known, are forming themselves into companies throughout the State for the protection of the interest of the Union. This fact, it seems, has become fully known to the people near Cythiana, and as they are of strong Disunion character, they determined to put a stop to it so far as railway facilities are concerned. Last night, in pursuance of their intentions, they set fire to and completely destroyed about fifteen hundred feet of the trestle work on the road beyond Cynthiana, thereby preventing the shipment of all goods, stores, &c., beyond that point. As a consequence, supplies cannot be sent any further in that direction for the present, but we may congratulate ourselves that previous to the outrage a large amount of arms and ammunition had gone forward, and we hope safely reached its destination.

abstract: In the First Congressional District, Mr. NELSON has been reelected to Congress by a majority of five or six thousand votes. In the Second District, Mr. MAYNARD has been elected by a majority of about six thousand votes. And in the Third District, Mr. BRIDGES has been elected by a majority of from one to two thousand votes. Messrs. BRIDGES and MAYNARD,
lead_paragraph: In the First Congressional District, Mr. NELSON has been reelected to Congress by a majority of five or six thousand votes. In the Second District, Mr. MAYNARD has been elected by a majority of about six thousand votes. And in the Third District, Mr. BRIDGES has been elected by a majority of from one to two thousand votes. Messrs. BRIDGES and MAYNARD, it is said, have both crossed the mountains into Kentucky, and have gone to Washington. No matter what may be said as to the propriety of these gentlemen going to Washington to take their seats, it is due them to say they became candidates for the Congress of the United States, and were elected to go there, their constituents desiring to be represented in the Federal Congress, and not in the Congress of the Southern Confederacy. They were so announced in this paper, as candidates before the people. Their competitors so stated to the people, and no one was deceived in their running the race for Congress.

abstract: The two Government gun-boats, which were ordered to be built by two prominent ship builders of Kensington, are now rapidly approaching completion. It is not two months since the work upon them was begun, and at the present time the one at the yard of JACOB BIRELY has all the frame work, all the iron braces in, and the planking commenced. The one at the yard of HILLMAN & STREAKER, is still further advanced, it having had the wales placed on, and the deck is about being framed. This boat will be launched in about five weeks, whilst the former will be about a week later. The frame-work is of the best Delaware white oak, and over one hundred and fifty hands are engaged upon the two vessels.
lead_paragraph: The two Government gun-boats, which were ordered to be built by two prominent ship builders of Kensington, are now rapidly approaching completion. The frame-work is of the best Delaware white oak, and over one hundred and fifty hands are engaged upon the two vessels.

abstract: Yesterday, at 3 o'clock, the thirty-six men captured by the frigate St. Lawrence, from on board the pirate ship Petrel, were brought again before United States Commissioner HEAZLETT. The accused were brought from prison in two vans, and every two were handcuffed together. The moment the vans drove up to the Court-room a large crowd immediately gathered, but the best of order prevailed. When the
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, at 3 o'clock, the thirty-six men captured by the frigate St. Lawrence, from on board the pirate ship Petrel, were brought again before United States Commissioner HEAZLETT. The accused were brought from prison in two vans, and every two were handcuffed together. The moment the vans drove up to the Court-room a large crowd immediately gathered, but the best of order prevailed. When the doors of Court-room were opened, the crowd made a rush, and soon filled every inch of space. Three ladies were present, the relatives of EDWARDS, one of the prisoners. Counsel appeared for all the prisoners. Mr. N. HARRISON and Mr. JOHN P. O'NEAL represented thirty-three of the party. CHARLES W. BROOKE, Esq., appeared for THOMAS BROOKBANKS, and GEORGE W. ARUNDELL, Esq., appeared for RICHARD LEWIS. The boy, SHARKIE, who is still ill, was not present. GEO. EARLE, Esq., assisted United States District-Attorney COFFEE. It was proposed to proceed with the examination, when Mr. HARRISON stated that the prisoners would waive a hearing.

abstract: Hitherto there has been little difficulty in dealing with the rebels taken on land. To consent to an exchange of prisoners would be de facto to recognize the the Confederates as a belligerent power; so that the National Government has preferred to discharge them, upon swearing allegiance to the United States.
lead_paragraph: Hitherto there has been little difficulty in dealing with the rebels taken on land. To consent to an exchange of prisoners would be de facto to recognize the the Confederates as a belligerent power; so that the National Government has preferred to discharge them, upon swearing allegiance to the United States. Those who would not so swear have been sent to jail. What their ultimate disposition will be remains to be settled. They cannot all be hung, that is clear. It is against the rebels captured on the high seas, however, that the wrath of the people is principally directed. The traitors taken on land have risked their lives in battle. The privateers have done nothing more than plunder United States vessels, and surrender when a man-of-war came in sight. Not to hang them will be proclamation of immunity to all who like to rob Northern merchants upon the ocean. They risk comparatively nothing. They do not fight, because they have no vessels capable of engaging a National man-of-war with any chance of success. Yet to hang them will insure -- so JEFFERSON DAVIS has declared -- the hanging of an equal number of prisoners taken from the National troops. And we believe he will carry out his threat. What, then, is to be done?

abstract: The usual quiet of the city has been somewhat disturbed to-day by the mutinous conduct of the Seventy-ninth Regiment. It appears that an order was sent to them last night to strike their tents early this morning, and march to some other locality to join SICKLES' Brigade, as was generally understood.
lead_paragraph: Correspondence of the New-York Times.

abstract: Col. Geo. Lyons, Commanding Eighth Regiment, N. Y.S.M.: SIR: I beg leave to submit the following report: When our forces retreated after the action of 21st July, several Surgeons, myself among the number, deemed it our duty to remain with the wounded, of whom there were about 300, in and about Sudley Church, the place assigned us for a hospital.

abstract: This steamer sailed from Liverpool July 31, and touched at Queenstown the following day, and sailed at 4 P.M. for this port. The agency of the line are not at all apprehensive of her safety, as she is one of the most substantial ships afloat, having seven watertight compartments. The steamship Persia, which followed the Etna, had clear and pleasant weather, making the passage in eleven days. Some disarrangement of her machinery is supposed to have taken place, and the next arrival from Europe will probably announce her putting back. We published on Friday a list of her cabin passengers, among whom is the agent of the line, Mr. JOHN G. DALE.

abstract: Death yesterday cut off in Lord HERBERT one whom nature had intended for a Prime Minister. It is quite certain, that had he lived, he would before long have attained that honor, if not by virtue of extraordinary intellectual qualities, yet by force of character, by charm of manner, and by aptitude for business. He was one of the most winning statesmen of his time, and, by aid of a great social faculty, rose above men who were on other grounds superior to him. What was most remarkable in him was his anxiety to do everything well. His labors were unceasing; he never spared himself; he gave up life and luxury for toil and trouble; and if he did not die in harness, it was in harness that he earned his death. It was not merely in the fulfillment of duty that he was thus self-sacricing; he was equally unsparing of himself in the discharge of those social observances which men usually bend to the convenience or humor of the moment. With great manliness of character there was curiously intermingled an extraordinary desire to please. He studied and strove to please, and heightened by all the arts of style the natural attractiveness of his character. He had in his favor every social advantage -- high birth, a great estate, a happy home, a handsome person, irresistible manners, many accomplishments, a ready address. He made the most of all this, so that his good nature seemed to be always overflowing, his frankness to be always unbounded, and his power of pleasing to be always undivided. So he won upon all comers, and won most upon those who knew him best. Men would give up to SIDNEY HERBERT what they would grant to no one else. He inspired no jealousy; for his superiority was less the result of brilliant parts than of that indefinable charm from which there is no appeal. Add his power of work and of public speaking to his rare power of making friends, and you have the possible Prime Minister. That power, and love of work, we grieve to say, has killed him, as it has killed many another statesman, before his time. He gave up the enjoyments of wealth and a brilliant home for the great game of politics, and has been known to pass a whole summer and autumn in London with only perhaps a day and a night at Wilton. He drove a good constitution too hard, and at Christmas last began to feel that sentence of death had been passed upon him. There is some reason to think that even then, had he given up all work, he might have recovered. All that he did was to leave the House of Commons and to try the comparative repose of the Peerage, still retaining his office, as Minister for War. The consequence has been fatal. He dies of overwork at the age of 51 -- a great loss to society, a still greater loss to his party.

abstract: A heavy seizure of goods destined for the rebels was made near Annapolis Junction to-day. The goods were bought by parties in Baltimore for Richmond dealers. A draft for $4,975 was sent to pay for them. With the goods were also seized the teams and wagons by which they were being conveyed, and a number of letters to officers in the rebel Army.

abstract: The next sixty days must effect a very great change in the military plans and movements of the rebels, even if we confine ourselves strictly to the work of organization and preparation, and act, as we are doing, with the exception, perhaps, of our forces in Western Virginia, only on the defensive. It is now
lead_paragraph: The next sixty days must effect a very great change in the military plans and movements of the rebels, even if we confine ourselves strictly to the work of organization and preparation, and act, as we are doing, with the exception, perhaps, of our forces in Western Virginia, only on the defensive. It is now easy to see the manner in which the rebels have, from the onset, been led on from one step to another, and the necessities that forced them to make the border States the seat of the war. Secession would never have been ventured upon, but for the belief that the North would be incapable of any aggressive movement, from internal divisions, and that, in case of War, it could be easily overrun by the South. This idea was entertained by many of the most prominent leaders of the Democratic Party, who constantly proclaimed that they would never tolerate any coercive movement, no matter the lengths to which the South might go. Mr. CUSHING publicly proclaimed, both in letters and speeches, that if there was to be any war, it was to be between the factions of the North. Mr. DAVIS, immediately upon his election to the Presidency of the Confederates, echoed the same statement. Secession was to incur no penalty, and be followed by no danger; when danger threatened, the battle was instantly transferred to the strongest ground of the rebels -- the border States. If these could be held, all would be well. To lose them would be a fatal blow. Consequently, the South has poured its whole strength into Virginia and Missouri. The moment a soldier could be made ready for marching orders, he was instantly dispatched North. In these States, the rebels have put forth their whole power. Notwithstanding almost incredible exertions, they have been driven very nearly out of one State, and out of one-half of the other. In Eastern Virginia, with all their immense force they seem incapable of anything but resistance; so that although they have recently achieved a victory, they have not attempted to follow it up by any attack upon our lines.

abstract: The entire regular recruiting service at this station has been thrown into convulsions by an order of the War Department, abolishing the $2 per man always paid to persons procuring recruits. This will complete the destruction of business at all the regular offices in the country, for men will take no pains or trouble to obtain soldiers if they have not some inducement to do so beyond their regular pay. A wise curtailment of recruiting expenses might be made in other respects, but this one is suicidal.

abstract: There still remain twenty-two counties of what is known as Western Virginia the extreme southwestern portion that are supposed to be yet a hot bed of Secessionists. Of no importance in themselves, these counties only deserve attention as they command the road to Cumberland Gap, and the entrance to loyal East Tennessee.

lead_paragraph: The activity at our Navy-yard is now immense. The new war steamer Tuscarora literally presents the appearance of achive of bees -- 300 men now swarming about her, presenting a scene of energy and activity rarely witnessed. This vessel is intended for a serew propeller; she will be launched on Wednesday next, and be ready for sea by the 10th of October. Her length is 212 feet; breadtn of beam, 23 feet; depth of hold, 16 feet. She is flat-bottomed and draws 71/2 feet. Her armament will be eight 32-pound guns and two 11-inch pivot guns.

abstract: The obsequies of Col. NOAH L. FARNHAM, of the First Regiment New-York Fire Zouaves, who died in consequence of injuries at the battle of Bull Run, took place yesterday morning. The body arrived in this City on Friday evening and was removed to the residence of the father of the deceased, No. 123 West Thirty-eighth-street, by a detachment of the Second Company National Guard. The body had been embalmed at Washington, and, dressed in the uniform of Zouaves, was encased in a metallic coffin. The lid of this was removed, and many hundreds of relatives and friends were enabled to take a last look at his well-known features. The National colors, the cap of Col. FARNHAM, and wreaths of flowers were placed upon the lid, and the plate bore the inscription:

abstract: EUGENE MESSICK, who has been for ten years in the regular service, arrived in Pittsburgh on Friday last, on a visit to his friends. MESSICK was chief bugler to SHERMAN's Battery, and was in the Battle at Bull Run, where he was wounded in the arm by a musket ball. In the height of the action he was ordered to sound the call for advance, and, in the act of so doing, he felt a sudden tingling and a numbness in his arm, which fell by his side helpless. His bugle also dropped to the ground, but dismounting and regaining if, he again got upon his horse, and, allowing the latter to go as he would, held his bugle to his lips with the uninjured arm and blew the charge. He has in his possession the ball which struck him, which was afterwards extracted.

abstract: premature, with the materials yet obtained, to attempt an accurate estimate of the products of the pending harvest. Enough, however, has come to hand to justify the following statement of probabilities: The amount of land sown to wheat is at least one-fourth more than last year, while the average yield per acre will have been reduced by the unfavorable weather and insect ravages about thirty per cent. The wheat product will, therefore, be nearly as follows: Number of acres sown 280,000; average yield per acre, 17 bushels; total wheat product, 4,776,000 -- which is not quite a million less than last year. Of corn there is less planted than last year, but, if the weather continues favorable, the yield will average higher by at least sixteen per cent. The total product will be about 2,500,00 bushels. Oats, though much less has been sown, will yield a full average. -- St. Paul Times, Aug.9.

abstract: Senator TRUMBULL, of Illinois, who is making a brief visit to a sister in Belleville, N.J., was complimented, on Thursday evening, with a serenade from the citizens of the village. In response to a call, he appeared and gave a short and spirited address, reviewing the origin of the rebellion, and commending the most vigorous prosecution of the war until the authority of the Government shall be reestablished from the Potomac to the Rio Grande. He stated that Illinois was putting 50,000 men in the field; that the greatest unanimity prevailed throughout the State, and that we would hear no more of 5,000 Union troops contending with 20,000 rebels, and soon they would be driven from the border States to fight the battle on their own soil. He alluded to the patriotism of our capitalists, particularly to the action of the banks in proposing to take a loan of $150,000,000 as calculated in an eminent degree to strengthen the Government.
lead_paragraph: Senator TRUMBULL, of Illinois, who is making a brief visit to a sister in Belleville, N.J., was complimented, on Thursday evening, with a serenade from the citizens of the village. He alluded to the patriotism of our capitalists, particularly to the action of the banks in proposing to take a loan of $150,000,000 as calculated in an eminent degree to strengthen the Government.

abstract: An order has emanated from the War Department, and will be found in the TIMES this morning, which urges all commanders of regiments of volunteers accepted by the Department, in the States of Pennsylvania, New-Jersey, New-York, Connecticut, Massachusetts, Vermont, Rhode Island, New-Hampshire, Maine and Michigan, to hurry forward their commands as early as possible to the Capital, in accordance with an order directed to the Governors of their respective States.
lead_paragraph: An order has emanated from the War Department, and will be found in the TIMES this morning, which urges all commanders of regiments of volunteers accepted by the Department, in the States of Pennsylvania, New-Jersey, New-York, Connecticut, Massachusetts, Vermont, Rhode Island, New-Hampshire, Maine and Michigan, to hurry forward their commands as early as possible to the Capital, in accordance with an order directed to the Governors of their respective States. This order directs that all regiments or parts of regiments, shall be pushed on to Washington immediately, whether armed, equipped or uniformed, or not -- recruiting officers to be left for such organizations as are not full. On arriving in Washington, the commanding officers of the troops will report to the Commanding General, when they will be furnished with all equipments and other necessaries. This hurried order is understood to be in consequence of authentic intelligence received by the War Department that the rebels are gradually pushing their forces nearer the Potomac, with a view to operations in Maryland land, and ultimately against the Capital itself.

abstract: Some time last year THOMAS C. BATES, of Brighton, made a contract for furnishing the rails for the Memphis, El Paso and Pacific Railroads, to the amount of several hundred thousand dollars. Mr. BATES made an arrangement with Eastern parties for the iron; and he had shipped a large quantity prior to the breaking out of the rebellion.
lead_paragraph: Some time last year THOMAS C. BATES, of Brighton, made a contract for furnishing the rails for the Memphis, El Paso and Pacific Railroads, to the amount of several hundred thousand dollars. Mr. BATES made an arrangement with Eastern parties for the iron; and he had shipped a large quantity prior to the breaking out of the rebellion. But [???] to low water in the Southern rivers, none of it had reached its destination. The iron, as appearsby the "Act of the Confederate Congress," quoted below, was scattered at various points, and on the meeting of the rebel Congress, the railroad company procured the passage of a law authorizing them to take the iron and use it without paying or consulting the wishes of Mr. BATES, subject to the conditions specified in the act. A copy of the Act of Confiscation is subjoined:

abstract: DESERTERS FROM THE ARMY. -- The recent offer of $30 for every returned deserter, made by the Government, is already beginning to show its fruits, and the Police returns are beginning to show evidence of the industry, of the police in hunting up the fugitives JOHN WITTON, and WM. WALLACE, two absconding members of the Fourteenth Regiment, were arrested in the Second Precinct yesterday, by Capt. KING, and were sent over to the Police Head-quarters to be returned to their regiment. ETHAN BLANK and STEPHEN GERAN were arrested by Officers DAVIS and MORRIS, of the Seventh Precinct, on a similar charge; and PATRICK WELSH was arrested by Officer J.C. SMITH, of the Fourth Precinct, for the same offence.

abstract: INCREASED RAILROAD FACILITIES. -- The [???] of constructing the Hoboken and Newark Railroad is going forward rapidly, and those who should be well informed on the subject, assert that it will be in operation in two or three months. The passenger and freight depots, engine houses, &c, for this road, are to be built on the grounds of the Atlantic Garden. The ground for the purpose has already been broken, and the work is to be pushed rapidly forward. The new road when completed, will be of great advantage to the residents of Newark, Bloomfield, Orange, Milburn, Morristown, and other places on the line of the road. It is also intended, at an early day, to build a branch of the Hoboken and Newark Railroad which will still better accommodate those residing in the central and southern sections of Newark. These increased railroad facilities are of the utmost importance to the people living on the lines of the proposed routes, and should certainly receive, as we learn they do, the warmest encouragement of all persons interested. To the City of Hoboken the concentration of the several railroad lines is an advantage that the people seem fully to appreciate by extending to the enterprise every possible encouragement. And for so doing they will doubtless be well repaid in the future prosperity of the city.

abstract: Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, under the authority of Confederate legislation, of course, has issued a proclamation ordering all residents in the seceded States, who do not recognize the Confederacy, to depart within forty days, under pain of being "condemned as aliens and enemies."
lead_paragraph: Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, under the authority of Confederate legislation, of course, has issued a proclamation ordering all residents in the seceded States, who do not recognize the Confederacy, to depart within forty days, under pain of being "condemned as aliens and enemies." The purpose of this order must be to operate on the Union population of East Tennessee; for, as we are advised, all opposition to the despotism of the Confederate rebels has been thoroughly crushed out, long since, in every other part of the South. But in East Tennessee the opposition to the rebel rule was too formidable to be suppressed by the usual means of mob violence. Not only large communities, but entire counties and districts, were almost unanimously faithful to the old Union and resolved to know no other allegiance. To deal lightly with such an element was more than the wary traitors of the Confederate States were willing to risk. They have therefore temporized, coaxed, expostulated and flattered by turns, down to the present time. But no amount of persuasion, or cajolery, or intimidation, has been able to swerve the Union patriots of East Tennessee from their duty. And they have recently, by a vote of over thirty thousand, proclaimed anew their detestation of the Southern rebellion, and their purpose to resist it. They have so far defied JEFF. DAVIS and his Government as to elect members to the National Congress, at the very time when the rebel Congress was in session at Richmond, and claiming legislative authority over the State of Tennessee.

abstract: The Americans have different tastes in literature and composition from those which prevail in England. They do not admire, and certainly do not imitate, that mixture of polished language with straightforward common sense which is now our accepted type of good writing on political subjects.
lead_paragraph: The Americans have different tastes in literature and composition from those which prevail in England. They do not admire, and certainly do not imitate, that mixture of polished language with straightforward common sense which is now our accepted type of good writing on political subjects. It may be said that this only shows that they are not very cultivated, and that they have not skill enough to recognize what is best. But the thing which they do admire is one which in its kind is singularly good. They wait to see the salient points of a subject put in a consecutive, unmistakable, unanswerable way. Their writing is in fact modeled upon their speaking. What tells with the best kind of American mob is a speech with very little art in it, but with a continuance of plain and homely logic. Fond as they are of bombast and rhodomontade, they still award the palm to the speaker who puts into intelligible English arguments which are within the compass of ordinary minds. The present President had a reputation as a speaker long before he was thought of as a successor to Mr. BUCHANAN. No one thought him a very clever man, and still less an eloquent one; but it was generally recognized that he meant what he said, and had a happy facility in putting his case so that every sentence led the hearer a step further on towards the desired end. It was, as his admirers described it, as if every sentence drove a fresh nail in. His Message appears to us to have the characteristics that used to mark his speeches. It is badly worded, and in many parts is not English at all. But it puts in a plain and forcible way the case of the Government. It forces on our attention exactly what the North, as represented by the Executive, is doing, and has been doing, and purposes to do. It raises the real question at issue, and instructs the world what are the hopes and fears with which the Government enters on the dreadful struggle. We may be glad that so important a document should force us once for all to consider fairly the whole case of the Union party. We may not agree with the view set before us; but until we know what it is, we cannot gain anything by determining to disagree with it.

abstract: CONCERT IN CENTRAL PARK. Notwithstanding the exceedingly threatening state of the weather, and the cold cheer that car drivers gave to inquiries concerning the musical prospects in Central Park, there was a concert there on Saturday. If the sun had been a little brighter the attendance would unquestionably have been much greater, and the comfort of those who were present perhaps relatively less.
lead_paragraph: CONCERT IN CENTRAL PARK. -- Notwithstanding the exceedingly threatening state of the weather, and the cold cheer that car drivers gave to inquiries concerning the musical prospects in Central Park, there was a concert there on Saturday. If the sun had been a little brighter the attendance would unquestionably have been much greater, and the comfort of those who were present perhaps relatively less. As it was, a select audience enjoyed the admirable strains of Dodworth's Band, and according to the old way, made up in enthusiasm what was lacking in numbers. The programme contained some of the most popular military pieces of the day, and was interpreted with that precision and elegance for which the Band is justly famous. It is to be hoped that the liberal patrens, who furnish us with this agreeable weekly treat, will find it desirable to continue them during the coming days of Autumn. When the weather is reasonably fine nothing can be conceived more charming than listening to soft music, surrounded by youth and beauty, in the Central Park. We would suggest that in that other kind of weather, which is either equivocal or bad, the conductors of the cars be instructed to say positively whether there will be a concert or not. It might even be desirable to exhibit a placard or card, as is done during the skating season.

abstract: We need hardly point out to our intelligent readers that the chance of war breaking out between Great Britain and the United States is of the most distant kind. The dispatch of troops to Canada affords no proof that Lord PALMERSTON expects a collision with the Republic.
lead_paragraph: We need hardly point out to our intelligent readers that the chance of war breaking out between Great Britain and the United States is of the most distant kind. The dispatch of troops to Canada affords no proof that Lord PALMERSTON expects a collision with the Republic. Whenever there is the most remote possibility of danger appearing, then it is the policy of the English authorities to send troops. Their very presence is a security against danger. The troops must lie somewhere; the army is maintained in full force and efficiency, and a few regiments may as well be stationed in Canada as elsewhere. We are by no means sure that the military authorities in England new enough to be aware that the collision in the United States would necessarily take place far from our frontier. A foolish story was started that the St. Lawrence Canal locks were in danger, and troops are now actually employed in watching them. In all probability the War Office imagines Jeff. Davis to be in full force just across the border. It is an ill wind that blows nobody good.

abstract: DRESSER returned from Buffalo last evening, having in custody young WYKOFF, who has figured in the papers here for a short time past. Policeman EMERIC, of Buffalo, assisted DRESSER in hunting him up. WYKOFF was lodged in jail here, and from thence will be brought on Monday before the Police Court for an examination on a charge of bigamy. Mrs. WYKOFF No. 3, Mrs. FIELD, of Detroit, makes the complaint. She alleges that he married her in Detroit, and from there went to Canada, where he left her, and came to this city, she gaving him about $40 worth of silverware to sell, and thereby raise some money. A gold watch and diamond ring of hers he also pawned in this city for a small sum, and they are now awaiting redemption in the hands of the pawnbrokers. Mrs. WYEOFF No. 3 alleges that there is a Mrs. WYKOFF NO. 1 now living in Detroit, but she has not learned her maiden name.

abstract: The futile attempt of the Committee on Federal Relations to manufacture sympathy in behalf of the Commissioners of Police, imparts renewed interest to the scenes of the 19th of April last, in which these gentlemen bore a conspicuous part.
lead_paragraph: The futile attempt of the Committee on Federal Relations to manufacture sympathy in behalf of the Commissioners of Police, imparts renewed interest to the scenes of the 19th of April last, in which these gentlemen bore a conspicuous part. A very brief review of the events of that period will show conclusively that the complaints of the Commissioners themselves are hollow and groundless, that the pretended love of their secession sympathizers for civil liberty is hypocritical and dishonest, and that what has since been styled a riot, if not preconcerted and predetermined, had no sooner occurred than it was publicly indorsed by them, and hailed as a fortunate opportunity to precipitate Maryland into this infamous and bloody revolution. What are the facts? On the evening of the 18th April, the day preceding the riot, a large meeting of the Southern Rights, now the Peace Party, is held at the Taylor Building, some six or seven hundred persons being present, with their passions lashed into fury by the secession Press of Baltimore, and T. PARKIN SCOTT is chosen President. Very inflammatory speeches were made at this meeting, and some by men who are at this moment in arms against the National Government; and not the least significant among them was that of the President himself, who "advised the States Rights Party to go to work, organize ward companies, elect officers, and believed that as there was plenty of money to provide them with arms, so they might soon expect to receive them." This was certainly a most important announcement from "head-quarters," and was an appropriate introduction, at least, to the riot, as it was called, which occurred accordingly on the following day. On the afternoon of the 19th, another public meeting is called at Monument-square. What was the character of its proceedings? The military are placed there under the order of Gen. Geo. H. STEUART now of the Secession forces, and Dr. A.C. ROBINSON, appears upon the stand with the Maryland flag, and "informs the people that the time for sentimental abstraction was passed; he took pleasure in displaying the Maryland flag, and throwing all doubts aside, we would with our strong arms defend ourselves, or be aided in that defense by the stout hearts and vigorous arms of the South." Mr. PRESTON, who came there with no intention of making a speech, told the people now was the time above all times for the sons of glorious old Maryland to stand firmly together in defense of her honor and of her independence. He had seen our citizens butchered in the streets of their own city. Mr. WALLIS "had not come to speak, for if the blood of our brethren shed on the streets of Baltimore to-day, does not speak to the heart of every man in Maryland, then the human voice may well be dumb." For himself, he was devoted to the cause of the South, and was ready to march forward under the flag of Maryland in the common cause of Southern freedom. Secession speeches of like sentiment were delivered by Messrs. MARSHALL, McLANE and others. It thus appears that just before and subsequent to the riot, the men who rose most conspicuous on the stream of popular passion, and directed its course, raised their voices then as loud for war as they do now for peace. Their speeches then were open and unmistakable indorsements of the assault on the troops "who had invaded our soil," and show that these present peace-makers were satisfied that the revolution was complete, and that the time, "yea, the set time" of our redemption was nigh. The Police Board immediately after this appear upon the field of action. Information is given then that fresh troops are approaching, and it was immediately resolved to destroy the bridges, and the order was effectually carried out, the police law fortunately presenting no obstacle in the way. On the following day, large amounts of military stores of every description, belonging to the United States, some of it as much as nine miles from the city, are seized by the police by order of the Police Board -- the secession flag being now very liberally displayed over secession recruiting-offices in the city, while the provisions of the Police law, fortunately for our defence, again threw no obstacle in the way. During these events, it will be remembered, the military forces of the whole State were arming and flocking to Baltimore under the orders of this same Police Board and Police law, and most especially in response to the telegraphic dispatch of Marshal KANE to Bradley T. JOHNSON, now in the Southern Army, requesting the assistance of riflemen from Virginia, "that fresh hordes would be down upon us tomorrow," &c. This dispatch, entirely ignored by the Commissioners in their "memorial," by the Mayor in his message, and in fact by all their sympathizers and apologists, is nevertheless a fact as significant and full of meaning as any event of that period, and in relation to it we would simply inquire what provisions of our special police law direct the riflemen of Virginia or of any other State to be used to suppress a riot, especially after the riot is over. It was also early in the progress of these events that the Mayor and Board of Police invest J.R. TRIMBLE, now we are informed in the Southern Army, with military authority, and his military orders No. 1, 2, &c., now figure conspicuously in the public Press. A brief reference to the orders issued by him under the authority of the Police Board, will unmistakably define the relation of these Commissioners to the National Government. For instance, Order No. 1, April 21, 1861, two days after the riot: "Wm. H. Norris, Robert M. McLane, Benjamin C. Prestman, Charles Wethered, E. Louis Lowe, Frederick Harrison, and Grafton D. Spurrier, are appointed aids to the commander of the Volunteer Uniformed Association, any order given by them will be duly respected. J.R. TRIMBLE, Commanding." Order No. 2: "Captains of the Volunteers Uniformed Association will report their names and the number of men under their command at the office of the Commissioners of Police." By Order No. 9, "Col. F.J. THOMAS, (since killed at Manassas, 'fighting in defence of our beloved city,') from his military experience is well calculated to supply the present deficiency of officers of the staff, and he is appointed Adjutant-General of the forces under my command. J.R. TRIMBLE, commanding." On April the 26th, it is ordered by the Mayor and Board of Police that no provisions of any kind be transferred to any place until further orders, and the execution of this order is intrusted to J.R. TRIMBLE. The ERRICSSON steamers for Philadelphia, and that, too, with mails and passengers, on application to the Board of Police, was refused permission to leave for prudential reasons. The Bremen ship Admiral, with an assorted cargo of tobacco, &c, which cleared on the 22d, was prohibited from leaving the wharf, the police having taken charge of the ship. Then we have the following announcement: "I hereby, by authority of the Mayor and Board of Police, direct that no steamboat shall leave the harbor without my permission. J.R. TRIMBLE." What comment could add force or meaning to these indisputable facts of record? During the rapid progress of such wholly unconstitutional proceedings of the Mayor and Board of Police, we are informed by the Press "that two suspicious characters made their appearance, and are taken up as spies, and detained at the Marshal's office; they are supposed to belong to the Massachusetts Regiment." "Capt. SCOTT, of the Maryland Guards, arrested last night, at Barnum's Hotel, one Sergeant SCHWARTZER, 'recruiting officer at Port McHenry, on suspicion of being a spy; he was committed." This very brief statement of events brings us to Wednesday, the 24th of April, the day of election. No sooner are the election returns made public, than a sudden change comes over the whole aspect of affairs. A panic is visible in the ranks of the party, and at once Major TRIMBLE, his Aids and his military orders, violating every principle of civil law under the authority of the Board, now rapidly disappear from public view. His unlawful restriction on the trade of Baltimore is removed, "the supply of provisions being found to be ample." The police law is now restored to life, and again becomes the sole guide of official action. Every provision must now be sacredly observed, especially from any, the least infraction by the General Government. It now becomes necessary for the Commissioners, by a public declaration of April 28, to inform the people "that the sole object of the Board, in all they had done, was to protect the lives and property of the people of Baltimore. This was the special purpose for which the Board was created," &c. Viewing this declaration in connection with the events of the week, it is somewhat surprising to see the number of secession soldiers and officers who cooperated with them in their patriotic efforts. We know of no men, in the least suspected of attachment to the National Government, who shared their confidence; on the contrary, some such were regarded and detained as spies, others had warning to flee the city; and this fact was boldly published in their own Press. It was in view of these facts, too, that they say in the same declaration that "the Board have been governed by no political views." It is in the face of this record that our Committee on Federal Relations have become so nervously alarmed for the fate of civil liberty, and are desperately struggling to save it by awakening sympathy for the very men who were the first to violate it, and to place the citizens of Baltimore under the military orders of Maj. TRIMBLE and his aids. It will take more, than a few short weeks to erase these facts from our recollection; but, appreciating as we do the efforts of our Committee, covering, as we are informed, seventy-five pages of foolscap, we are happy to recall to their recollection that part of the declaration of the 28th of April, which is so full of comfort to the Commissioners themselves in their confinement, and ought to be no less so to their friends, and which is so forcibly expressed in their own words, viz.: "That the Board are entirely satisfied that their position is understood and appreciated by the General Government, by the authorities of the State, and by a great majority of the thinking and order-loving people of Baltimore."

abstract: We are now entering the third week from the great battle, and we have no official report. We know the difficulties thht have delayed such a report, in the constant movements of many who were engaged in it, but we hope there will be no needless delay. We need no suppression; our people desire the truth, and can face the truth under any circumstances. Can we not at least request immediately an official statement of the amount and variety of ordnance and military stores captured, as an offset to Northern lies? -- Charleston Courier, Aug. 6.

abstract: It is not often that we find an English writer discussing American affairs with sufficient accuracy of facts and liberality of sentiment to command respect on this side of the Atlantic.
lead_paragraph: It is not often that we find an English writer discussing American affairs with sufficient accuracy of facts and liberality of sentiment to command respect on this side of the Atlantic. But in Slavery and Secession in America, by THOS ELLISON, F. S. S., a book published in England, and by an English author, we find a marked exception. It proposes to give a historical sketch of the introduction and growth of Slavery in the States, its development as a political element in the Union, and the successive steps by which it gained control of the National Government, and dictated its policy from the acquisition of the Louisiana territory in 1803, down to the repeal of the Missouri Compromise in 1854.

abstract: The Richmond Dispatch, in narrating the achievements of the Eighth Georgia Regiment at Bull Run, closes a graphic account of their valorous conduct under the fire of the National troops as follows: "At length they withdrew from the fight. Their final rally was with some 60 men of the 600 they took in. Balaklava tells no more heroic tale than this: 'Into the valley of death marched the six hundred.' As they retired, they passed Gen. BEAUREGARD. He drew aside, fronted, raised his hat, and said: I salute the Eighth Georgia with my hat off.'" After the retirement of this remnant of the Eighth Regiment, the Dispatch goes on to tell how the Georgia Seventh was brought up to sustain the position they had occupied, and how bravely they fought; but it appears that they were slaughtered very much in the same manner, the Colonel (BARTOW) being killed immediately upon taking position. These detailed accounts of the losses sustained by each regiment show a much greater loss of the rebels than the papers which publish them have ever been willing to admit in the aggregate. Here are over 500 Georgians admitted have been killed, while the Louisianians claim to have lost over 300, and the South Carolina Legion, whose Colonel was wounded and their Lieutenant-Colonel killed, are officially reported to have been completely "cut up," and to have had more than 200 killed and wounded. The North Carolina Regiment lost 110 men, and every other regiment suffered more or less; and yet the rebel authorities claim that their loss was less than that of the Union Army!

abstract: course at their head, -- are overwhelmed with grief and astonishment at the rigorous confinement of their Police Commissioners in this City. The prisoners, themselves, write long letters of complaint, bewailing their inability to visit the City or to receive their friends, and representing the National Government as the embodiment of tyranny and cruelty. The Exchange is shocked at the danger to civil liberty and constitutional freedom when such things can take place.

abstract: A dispatch from Washington states that "since the affair at Mathias Point, the steamer Freeborn went down and shelled the woods from whence the rebels fired, clearing them up and rendering them untenable for the time being at least."
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from Washington states that "since the affair at Mathias Point, the steamer Freeborn went down and shelled the woods from whence the rebels fired, clearing them up and rendering them untenable for the time being at least." Why not render them permaneatly "untenable" for the enemy, and thus put an end to the murders which are constantly perpetrated at that point? Three or four times now has this trap been set for our men, -- for no other object, apparently, than to indulge the luxury of killing a few individuals: but every time, as soon as the trap has been sprung, the rebels are allowed to set it again and prepare for another slaughter. If the place can be "cleared" it can be held. Why, then is not a force sent down sufficient to occupy it?

abstract: In the Matter of Euphenius Devoe. -- This was an application for the discharge of Devoe on the ground that he was a minor when he enlisted, and that he had enlisted for a less term than his minority. It was claimed, on the part of the Government, that he had voluntarily entered into the service, and with the consent of his mother, who, it was alleged, had signed a paper agreeing to his enlistment. It was sworn to on the part of the young man's mother, however, that she had signed a paper, but that when she did so she was not informed of the actual contents thereof; that the person who. read the paper to her misinformed her of the true nature of the contents. There being no evidence to contradict this the Court discharged the boy from any further service to his uncle.
lead_paragraph: In the Matter of Euphenius Devoe. -- This was an application for the discharge of Devoe on the ground that he was a minor when he enlisted, and that he had enlisted for a less term than his minority. There being no evidence to contradict this the Court discharged the boy from any further service to his uncle.

abstract: Some weeks since, the brig Herald was captured by the United States frigate St. Lawrence and sent to this port. Lord LYONS hearing of the capture at Washington, visited the Secretary of the Navy, and represented that the Herald belonged to British subjects in Nova Scotia, and demanded her release. A release was made out and sent to this city, but previous to its arrival the Herald was brought in, and the prize master had delivered her up to the United States authorities. The order of discharge was not, therefore, obeyed. Lord LYONS then made representations to the Secretary of State, Mr. SEWARD, and and another order was given directing that the vessel should be surrendered to her owners; but between the reception of the two orders, the papers of the brig were examined here, and it was found that the brig, though apparently belonging to British owners, was owned by Americans, and also that her intentions and orders were to force the blockade at Charleston, These facts were made known to Secretary SEWARD, and he immediately withdrew the order for her release, and directed that she should be subject to the decision of the Prize Court in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Some weeks since, the brig Herald was captured by the United States frigate St. Lawrence and sent to this port. abstract: New-Orleans Delta complains that it is becoming quite common to bring charges of being Abolitionists, and of uttering "incendiary" language, against persons on whom the complainants desire to wreak some private revenge. It mentions several instances in which men were thus arraigned for expressing sentiments "more suited to the latitude of Washington than New-Orleans." No man anywhere at the South is allowed to utter any sentiments but those of hatred to the Union, and devotion to the secession cause. Any hint of Unionism is treated and punished as a crime. This is in striking contrast with the course of things here at the North. Scores of persons haunt our hotels who are open in proclaiming their sympathy with rebellion. Many of them do it in the most offensive and insulting manner. Yet they are never molested. This indulgence, beyond all doubt, is often carried too far, -- but it is certainly better to err on this extreme than on the other.

abstract: The Sixteenth Regiment of Massachusetts enlisted for the war, arrived in this City yesterday vid the Fall River roule. The regiment has been for some time encampted at North Cambridge, near Boston, and during its march through the latter city on Saturday morning, was most enthusiastically greeted.
lead_paragraph: The Sixteenth Regiment of Massachusetts enlisted for the war, arrived in this City yesterday vid the Fall River roule. The regiment has been for some time encampted at North Cambridge, near Boston, and during its march through the latter city on Saturday morning, was most enthusiastically greeted. They number 1,040 men, and have 117 horses, 32 wagons, and several ambulances. They are armed with Enfield rifles, and have 60,000 rounds of ball-cartridges. Their canteens, haversacks, knapsacks, and in fact, all their arms and equipments are of excellent quality, and the regiment, as a whole, is equal to any yet sent forth by the old Bay State to do battle for the Union. They are provided with an excellent band, also enlisted for the war. They carry five prisoners with them -- deserters from other regiments. The following are the officers:

abstract: We learn from Hon. HORACE MAYNARD, of Tennessee, who has been in this city for some days, that his colleague, Hon. T.A.R. NELSON, was arrested in attempting to make his way North, and that he is to be tried on a charge of treason. Mr. NELSON's route led him through a corner of Virginia, where he was discovered and taken by a party of Secessionists. Messrs. NELSON and MAYNARD have just been elected to the United States Congress, by their old constituents, who are still true to the Union.

abstract: The rigors of military law are now being brought to bear upon mutinous and malcon tent soldiers. Gen. BUTLER has promptly quelled the revolts in the Second, Ninth and Tenth Regiments at Fortress Monroe, by bringing his loaded batteries to bear upon the mutineers, while he secured the ringleaders and transported them to the Rip Raps to be speedily tried by Court-martial.
lead_paragraph: The rigors of military law are now being brought to bear upon mutinous and malcon tent soldiers. Gen. BUTLER has promptly quelled the revolts in the Second, Ninth and Tenth Regiments at Fortress Monroe, by bringing his loaded batteries to bear upon the mutineers, while he secured the ringleaders and transported them to the Rip Raps to be speedily tried by Court-martial. This he wisely followed up by removing the causes of the regimental discontent -- taking upon himself the responsibility of paying the men their arrearages, and, in generous and manly words, promised them a redress of all their real grievances. The mutineers of the Seventy-ninth, also, have been promptly and sternly dealt with by Gen. MCCLELLAN. He surrounded the regiment with an overpowering force of artillery, cavalry, and infantry, ordered it to return to duty, and threatened to shoot on the spot every man who was disobedient. He then administered to it a terrible and somewhat passionate reprimand -- disgraced it by taking away its colors, and by other martial severities; while over fifty men from its battle-decimated ranks were by his order imprisoned and put in irons, and will be tried by Court-martial to-day. Gen. MCCLELLAN has also severely punished the insubordinates of the Thirteenth New-York and Second Maine regiments, by banishing over a hundred of their number to the Dry Tortugas, where they will be employed as laborers upon the fortifications until the expiration of their term of enlistment. The disaffected members of the Sixteenth and other regiments have been taken in hand with equal promptitude and rigor. In fact, the whole Army is now for the first time beginning to understand that a cheerful obedience to orders, and a manly submission to the necessary hardships of camp-life, are the first virtues of the soldier. These measures of just severity have already done much for the efficiency of the National Army; and will doubtless also do much to repress the frivolous complaints, of which the public and the better portion of the soldiers are now utterly tired. No one will uphold such measures more heartily than the true soldier, as none know so well the fatal results of loose discipline and disaffection.

abstract: Already the new order of the War Department, directing regular soldiers to be enlisted like volunteers, for three years, has exercised a marked influence on recruiting here.
lead_paragraph: Already the new order of the War Department, directing regular soldiers to be enlisted like volunteers, for three years, has exercised a marked influence on recruiting here. Last week more than double the number of men of the week previous were accepted, and sent over to Governor's Island. The Cavalry rendezvous still keeps ahead, so that detachments go to Carlisle now twice as often as they did formerly. Thirty-two men joined the old regiments in the City last week, about twenty of whom were sent to Fort Columbus for drill and regimental muster. The new Twelfth Regiment is fast assuming strength.

abstract: There never has been so much quiet and order in Washington, and so much industry and energy on the part of the young Commander-in-Chief of the American forces. Glad to hear what all men have to say - ready to receive statesmen, editors, and politicians, he is careful to avoid committing himself to a revelation of a single one of his plans. You will observe that nothing has been printed, either as to his purposes or his opinions. His head-quarters, at the residence of Commodore WILKS, corner of Sixteenth and H streets, is thronged with visitors, and, although always busy, he is always ready to receive information - no matter by whom presented.

abstract: We have already alluded to the mischievous exaggerations in which a portion of our newspaper Press indulges, concerning the imperfections of our blockade. They are calculated to do an immense deal of harm, by furnishing plausible pretexts for neutral vessels who may wish to break it, and for foreign nations whose interests, incline them to disregard it.
lead_paragraph: -- We have already alluded to the mischievous exaggerations in which a portion of our newspaper Press indulges, concerning the imperfections of our blockade. They are calculated to do an immense deal of harm, by furnishing plausible pretexts for neutral vessels who may wish to break it, and for foreign nations whose interests, incline them to disregard it. Unquestionably instances have occurred, and will still occur, in which vessels will leave and enter Southern ports in spite of the blockade. A thousand accidents, the darkness of night, a familiarity with channels and coasts not possessed by the blockading force, the temporary absence of a vessel, &c., &c., may facilitate such instances of evasion. But as a general thing, we believe that the blockade is quite as effective and rigorous as could possibly be expected, when all the circumstances of the case are taken into consideration.

abstract: Mr. J.S. CLARKE, whose success in this City on the occasion of his first appearance was of the most flattering kind, returns to us to-night for a short campaign at this house. The play selected for the event is one in which Mr. CLARKE cannot fail to challenge comparison with Mr. BURTON. The "Toodles" was always considered as incomparable in the latter gentleman's hands, but we are assured that Mr. CLARKE's interpretation, although totally different in conception, is not less admirable. A good company has been secured to render efficient assistance to Mr. CLARKE. Amongst many new names we find that of a lady -- Mrs. ALEXINA FISHER BAKER -- who is already known to our public. If the crowded state of promiscuous places of amusement on Broadway is any criterion of the willingness of the public to be amused, we may safely predict that Mr. CLARKE will have a good and prosperous season.

abstract: It is mortifying to discover that, while the Emperor of the French has been profuse in expressions of good wishes towards the Government of the United States, he has at the same time been secretly carrying on an unfriendly and uncalled-for plot against that Government.
lead_paragraph: It is mortifying to discover that, while the Emperor of the French has been profuse in expressions of good wishes towards the Government of the United States, he has at the same time been secretly carrying on an unfriendly and uncalled-for plot against that Government. Our Washington telegrams this morning, revealing the fact of a correspondence between M. THOUVENEL, French Minister of Foreign Affairs, and the English Cabinet, are accompanied with such vouchers, as put the tidings beyond all doubt. It is certain that the French Cabinet has invited the English to enter into an arrangement, for forcibly procuring, this Autumn, a supply of cotton and tobacco from the United States, and that the English Government has declined participating in the scheme.
