abstract: I make no apology for criticising Democrats, since I am myself a Democrat. Nay, almost can I say, "If any other man thinketh that he hath whereof he might trust in" Democracy, "I more." For I have spent much of my life in inculcating it. ...
lead_paragraph: I make no apology for criticising Democrats, since I am myself a Democrat. Nay, almost can I say, "If any other man thinketh that he hath whereof he might trust in" Democracy, "I more." For I have spent much of my life in inculcating it. Moreover, my Democracy is not a half-way but an extreme one -- a Democracy as broad as mankind; and so jealous of Government as to allow its presence not only not in the church but not in the school -- nowhere, indeed, save in the one legitimate Governmental office of protecting persons and property. That mine is the genuine Democracy is manifested by the little patience which the current and spurious Democracy has with it. Nor need I make an apology for praising Republicans, since I have never been one of them. And I need not fear that anything that I shall say of Democrats or Republicans will expose me to the charge of office-seeking, since I am one of the few who, at the expense of being called very eccentric and very foolish, sternly refuse to go in the ways which lead to office.

abstract: Yesterday was emphatically a blue Monday in the City. The sudden demand of the Secretary of War for the immediate dispatch to Washington of all the men who had been accepted for the public service, whether organized or not, was held to indicate apprehensions of an immediate attack, either upon Washington, or upon Baltimore, in its rear.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was emphatically a blue Monday in the City. The sudden demand of the Secretary of War for the immediate dispatch to Washington of all the men who had been accepted for the public service, whether organized or not, was held to indicate apprehensions of an immediate attack, either upon Washington, or upon Baltimore, in its rear. It cannot be denied that the document justified such an interpretation, especially in view of the rumors which have been for some days current concerning the movements of the rebel troops. There is certainly reason to believe that they intend to cross the Potomac some twenty or twenty-five miles above Washington, whenever they consider themselves in sufficient force to do it safely. Their troops are flushed with victory; they are known to have been rapidly preparing and accumulating large means of transportation during the past three weeks; they are believed to have not less than 100,000 men at their command; a bold and brilliant stroke, even if accompanied by corresponding hazards, is what is required by their situation, and an immediate advance upon Washington has been clamorously demanded by their troops, and confidently predicted by their journals for some time past. Under these circumstances the sudden requisition of the Secretary of War was admirably calculated to force the belief that the long-meditated attack was on the eve of being made.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- A sort of prefatory season to the regular campaign was inaugurated at this handsome establishment last evening, by Mr. J.S. CLARKE, a comedian whose great success last season has justified an experiment which, under other circumstances, would be dangerous. Three pieces were provided, and a number of artists comparatively new to our stage, introduced. In the first -- the "Rough Diamond" -- Mrs. ALEKINA FISHER BAKER, an experienced actress of a past school, made her rentree, and was warmly received by a very appreciative audience. The lady's performance of the character of Margery was marked by much vivacity, but was marred by certain nasal extravagances of style, which savored more of the stage Yankee "gal" than the English peasant. The word "sass" does not occur in any British vocabulary, nor do the village girls of Britain cultivate a healthyleisure by whittling on a pine board with a a jack-knife. Mrs. BAKER will probably be astonished when we tell her that her performance would be much improved by omitting these extravagances. Mr. CLARKE was the Cousin Joe, and made the most of the part, which, we may here add, has been reduced to a mere sketch. It was in the second piece -- theimmortal "Toodles" -- that the comedian was seen to the greatest advantage. His performance, although totally unlike Mr. BURTON's, deserves to rank with it in breadth of style. In other respects it is much more finished, and even in the drunken scene was free from grossness. The house was kept in a perfect roar of merriment, and during the progress of the play Mr. CLARKE was twice called out. The part of Mrs. Toodles was played admirably by Mrs. E.N. THAYER.

abstract: Public feeling in Kentucky is tending rapidly to a crisis. Any day the fire of civil war may light up "the dark and bloody ground." The attitude of the State of Tennessee is extremely menacing. That State has three important military camps close on the border of Kentucky; and numerous smaller bodies of troops, established at other points along the State line, apparently watching the Unionists of Kentucky. ...
lead_paragraph: Public feeling in Kentucky is tending rapidly to a crisis. Any day the fire of civil war may light up "the dark and bloody ground." The attitude of the State of Tennessee is extremely menacing. That State has three important military camps close on the border of Kentucky; and numerous smaller bodies of troops, established at other points along the State line, apparently watching the Unionists of Kentucky. These secession troops are all armed and ready for invasion; and they declare it to be their purpose to invade Kentucky, disarm the Home Guards, and put their arms into the hands of the Kentucky Secessionists, the moment that Kentucky shall violate her assumed position of neutrality -- and that neutrality, the Tennesseeans declare, will be violated whenever Kentucky shall attempt to afford aid to the East Tennessee Unionists, or whenever the United States Government shall be permitted to march its troops through Kentucky to the aid of the Union men of East Tennessee.

abstract: Bohemian brought us a factious item in its budget of European news, which was duly telegraphed to us yesterday from Father Point, to the effect that an anonymous advertisement had appeared in a Liverpool paper, after the news of the late battle reached England, inviting a shilling subscription for a testimonial to Gen. BEAUREGARD, in admiration of his skillful generalship. The American public will anxiously wait the details of this horribly mysterious affair, and still more anxiously wait the result of the subscription -- it will furnish such a nice guage by which to measure that intangible but variable element called English sympathy. Curiously enough, a communication appeared in a Charleston paper about the same date, proposing a dollar subscription for a testimonial to the same individual from the women oi the Palmetto State. The Charleston scheme looks marvelousiy like another attempt of the Honorable COBB to raise the wind in behalf of the rebel treasury -- as the money raised there for the testimonial is to be invented in Confederate bonds, and the bonds are to be presented to the little Creole. The paternity of the Liverpool advertisement, too, is somewhat suspicious: it looks so like one of the queer dodges resorted to by the three plenipotentiaries to attract attention, sympathy and cash in England.

abstract: In calling to Washington the incomplete regiments of the Eastern and Middle States, the Government either confesses its fears as to the safety of the Capital, or proposes to introduce a new system into the muster and organization of its Armies. If we are to receive the latter interpretation of the measure, we may accept it as one of the very highest promise: ...
lead_paragraph: In calling to Washington the incomplete regiments of the Eastern and Middle States, the Government either confesses its fears as to the safety of the Capital, or proposes to introduce a new system into the muster and organization of its Armies. If we are to receive the latter interpretation of the measure, we may accept it as one of the very highest promise: The earliest rally for the protection of the seat of Government necessarily originated in the spontaneous patriotism of the masses, which rendered anything like selection or discrimination entirely impossible. All who offered were, unless physically incapacitated, mustered into service. That among these raw and quite inexperienced bodies of men, numbers should find a place whose motives were sordidly confined to pay and plunder, and who, incapable of understanding, or regarding with indifference, the great questions at issue, cared nothing for their eventual solution, was to be anticipated; and we might naturally expect to find insubordination in camp and cowardice in action among this class of the National defenders.

abstract: Gen. WOOL is assigned to the command of  Fortress Monroe. So far, so good. The nation was deeply dissatisfied, not to say indignant, at the fact that one of the bravest, as well as one of the most skillful and experienced of American Generals, was persistently kept in quiet retreat at Troy, N.Y., while political Brigadiers were fretting away the spirit of the Army by awkward blunderings upon masked batteries.

abstract: To the Editor of the New-York Times: I have been a reader of your paper for the last  six months, during which time I have noticed that it is filled with nothing but venom and animosity against the South and everything Southern. Its perusal has given me ample food for reflection, and suggested a few questions to my mind which I hope you will answer with freedom and candor.

abstract: The work of testing the Dahlgren gun, recentlycast at the Fort Pitt Works, Pittsburgh, was brought to a close on Friday. One thousand rounds were fired, yet the bore at the close exhibited an enlargement only of 0.26, or but little more than one-fiftieth of an inch. The result was most satisfactory, and shows the superior quality of the metal from which the gun was cast. The gun weighs considerably over eight thousand pounds, and during the firing was suspendedfrom a heavy frame-work erected for the purpose. Ten thousand pounds of powder and eighteen tons of iron were used in the test, but much of the latter may be recovered. The Fort Pitt Works had a heavy contract for the construction of guns of this character, the fulfillment of which was contingent on the success of that just tried.

abstract: papers announce the appointment of GEORGE B. CRITTENDEN, late Major in the United States Army, to be Brigadier-General in the army of the Confederate States. This Major CRITTENDEN obtained his appointment in the United States Army about twenty years ago, not from any merits of his own, but through the influence of family and friends. He was a man they had all grown tired of supporting, and it was a happy idea, and successfully pushed, to quarter him on the United States Treasury, as an Army officer.

abstract: Strange things happen in these latter days, but longest which has come within out ken  for some time, is the presence in Canada of an active sympathizer with Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, a gentleman who did service to the Southern cause as a newspaper writer in Washington, seeking through the Ministerial press of this country to stir up strife between the Northern States and Great Britain. ...
lead_paragraph: Strange things happen in these latter days, but [???] longest which has come within out ken for some time, is the presence in Canada of an active sympathizer with Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS, a gentleman who did service to the Southern cause as a newspaper writer in Washington, -- seeking through the Ministerial press of this country to stir up strife between the Northern States and Great Britain. If gentry of this stamp could have their will, we should speedily see the deadliest feelings of animosity aroused between the two countries, and this great lake region, at present the scene of busy commerce and prosperous husbandry, become the theatre of a frightful [???] We do not, of course, anticipate that any such result can be produced by the puny means at their command, but it is abundantly evident that the dread of hostilities which some of the Ministerial journalists, perhaps unthinkingly, are endeavoring to raise, is likely to be exceedingly injurious to the Province Upper Canada is just emerging from a protracted period of depression; and we are all engaged in observing with gratified eyes the indications of returning prosperity. Can any one imagine a more fatal means of destroying our fairest prospects than this constant talk of war, this persistent call for troops and arms? We are looking anxiously across the ocean for new settlers to swell our population and our means; will they come if they think that they will be required on their arrival to take up the rifle and the sword, and relinquish the plow and the scythe. We need foreign capital for a hundred important objects; does any one think we will get it, if war, as these journalists aver, is at our gates? We are aware of one large monetary institution connected with Britain, which was asked by its correspondents there as to the prospects of war between the United States and England, and which sought to calm the fears of its clients by a statement of the actual position of affairs. If these gentlemen were to consult the organs of the Canadian Government, they would find a very distinct contradiction of their correspondents' views, but one entirely unsupported by facts. We hear of one large monetary institution making arrangements in London for carrying on its business with greater facility. Can that arrangement be made if the Ministerial journals are all crying out that the war is imminent? The Grand Trunk itself asks money for more rolling stock, yet its organ, under the inspiration of the confidant of JEFF. DAVIS, is proclaiming that at any moment its through traffic may be cut off by war. The people of Toronto are about to hold a meeting to discuss the propriety of proceeding with a much talked-of and very extensive public work, designed to carry the produce of the West through our waters; yet a city journal is industriously spreading the idea that that produce is about to be withdrawn from our canals and rivers by the influence of war. There is no department of business which this foolish suicidal talk does not affect. Who will buy wheat if there is danger that the American market will be closed to the flour into which it is to be ground? Who will buy logs and cut lumber if he thinks there is a chance of its being stopped by force of arms on its way to market? Surely Canada has passed through enough of real trouble during the past four years, without being made the prey of an imaginary danger, the sufferer by an evil which, in all probability, will never arise.

abstract: T. S. SERRILL, the agent of the Southern Confederacy, whose arrival in the Persia with L40,000, the proceeds of a supposed loan negotiated in England for the C. S. A., was previously reported, has been tranferred from the civil to the military authorities. He was to have had an examination before a United States Commissioner yesterday morning, but a dispatch was received from Washington on Saturday evening directing his transfer to the military authorities in command mandat Fort Lafayette. Accordingly, on Sunday afternoon Marshal MURRAY, accompanied by Deputy SAMPSON and Officer DEVOE, proceeded to the Tombs and escorted the prisoner from thence to Fort Hamilton, where he was handed over to the officer in command and at once removed to Fort Lafayette. SERRILL was not very communicative, but expressed the utmost confidence in being discharged if he could only get a hearing. He says that the money brought by him from England is his own private property, and that he was intending to start an exchange brokerage business with it in Philadelphia.

abstract: DISASTROUS FIRE IN BANK-STREET -- Loss $35,000. -- About 5 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the extensive manufactory Nos. 143, 145 and 147 Bank-street, and so rapidly did the flames spread that, although the firemen were early on the ground, they found it impossible to check them, and in a very short space of time after the discovery of the fire the building, which was of brick, three stories in height, 60 feet front and 100 feet-deep, was a mass of ruins. The building was owned by Mr. VAN HOOK, whose loss is estimated at $20,000, mostly covered by insurance. The first floor was occupied by Messrs. STEWART & INNES, machinists, whose loss on stock was about $800. No insurance. Messrs STILLMAN & ILSLEY also occupied a part of the first, floor as a receiving mill. Their loss was about $3,000; insured for $1.000. The second floor was occupied by Messrs. SHEARMAN & RICH, packing-box makers. They lost their whole stock and fixtures, which cannot, at present, be estimated. HADLEY & POST, carpet cleaners, occupied the third floor. The loss on their machinery is about $2,000, and on carpets belonging to customers about $800 -- no insurance. Mr. HALSEY occupied about 60 feet of the third floor, and he lost all his stock and fixtures. It is believed that the fire originated in the sand-pit, which contained shavings and dust, and although discovered early by the night watchman, he was unable to extinguish it. The total loss will be over $35,000.

lead_paragraph: In an article which we copy this morning from the New-York Ledger, Hon. EDWARD EVERETT sets forth, in clear and strong terms, the duty of suppressing all attempts, through the Press or by speech, to aid the cause of the rebellion. He remarks upon the extraordinary spectacle of toleration exhibited by our Government in this respect. News-papers throughout the loyal States are permitted to denounce the endeavors of the Government to protect and defend its own existence. Members of Congress were allowed openly and defiantly to defend the action of those who were waging war upon the Constitution and the Union. The Government, from its regard for freedom of speech, has tolerated the open advocacy of measures which, if successful, inevitably involve its own destruction.

abstract: Mr. J.R. KOOKEN, Ex-United States Consul at Cienfuegos, who came passenger in the steamship Santiago de Cuba, arrived last evening, informs us that the bark Joseph Maxwell, of and from Philadelphia, for Laguyra, was captured by the steam-privateer Sumter, on the 27th of July, off Porto Cabello. Lieut. HANKS, and a prize-crew of five men, were put on board, taking the Captain of the bark and part of her crew on board the steamer. The Joseph Maxwell was taken into Cienfuegos, but was ordered to leave within twenty-four hours. In the meantime, arrangements had been made to run her ashore fifteen miles eastward of Cienfuegos, which was done, and the cargo, consisting of flour, rice, tobacco, and butter, was taken to Cienfuegos and sold, and a part of it had been paid for. The prize-master and his five men had been sent to Havana, by the Governor of Cienfuegos, as ship-wrecked seamen.
lead_paragraph: Mr. J.R. KOOKEN, Ex-United States Consul at Cienfuegos, who came passenger in the steamship Santiago de Cuba, arrived last evening, informs us that the bark Joseph Maxwell, of and from Philadelphia, for Laguyra, was captured by the steam-privateer Sumter, on the 27th of July, off Porto Cabello. Lieut. HANKS, and a prize-crew of five men, were put on board, taking the Captain of the bark and part of her crew on board the steamer. The Joseph Maxwell was taken into Cienfuegos, but was ordered to leave within twenty-four hours. In the meantime, arrangements had been made to run her ashore fifteen miles eastward of Cienfuegos, which was done, and the cargo, consisting of flour, rice, tobacco, and butter, was taken to Cienfuegos and sold, and a part of it had been paid for. The prize-master and his five men had been sent to Havana, by the Governor of Cienfuegos, as ship-wrecked seamen.

abstract: Of all the regiments now forming, under the [???] levy, none has prospered more thoroughly than Col. SERRELL's. Although scarcely two weeks in existence it boasts of a bona fide muster roll of nearly [???] hundred and fifty men. The regiment is stationed at Camp Washington, Staten Island, and occupies the barracks erected by Col. BILLY WILSON, [???] a thorough drill is daily gone through. The men are nearly all artisans, engineers, rail-layers and others, who have been engaged in the construction of railways and public works. They need tools, toolchests, engineering instruments, &c., to render them thoroughly efficient, and it is hoped that when this [???] is known to our manufacturers of these articles it will be generously supplied. As an indication of one of the many uses of this regiment, we may mention that Col. SERRELL on Saturday last reported to his Excellency, the Commander-in-Chief, that plans and specifications were now being made by officers of the regiment, under his direction, [???] pontoon train, which can be built by the men now in camp, if the State will but furnish the material. The officers are all practical engineers; none others, in fact, are accepted -- and hence it happens that men come in quicker than officers. A splendid battery of six guns, constructed on the Parrott principle, and called the Parrott Battery, has been presented to the regiment. Several friends in New-Jersey have offered to mount it if there is any difficulty experienced on the subject here. The head-quarters of the regiment are at the corner of Chambers and Chatham streets.

abstract: Department that there is already an undue proportion of Commissioners, Quartermasters and Paymasters for the Army, and that, therefore, Mr. SANDERSON's appointment to superintend the cooking cannot be made! Why was he not appointed before these places were filled? He has been trying for months to get permission to teach the soldiers gratuitously how to cook their nations so as to make them palatable and nutritious. The soldiers themselves complain that they are not cooks, and cannot prepare their food so as to be either wholesome or agreeable, and the officers are too busy in taking care of themselves to give attention to the culinary wants of their men. So it has been for a long time, and so it is likely to be for a long time to come. Mr. SANDERSON's appointment to some position which shall enable him to instruct the troops in the matter, is of more importance to the well-being of the Army than that of the whole battalion of Commissioners who have been thrust in before him.

abstract: The rumor which became prevalent yesterday that the steamer Marion had been seized, under the President's proclamation, on account of her part ownership by Charleston merchants, is untrue. She was briefly detained for the purpose of receiving dispatches from the President for Fort Pickens.

abstract: Under the apprehension that the general order emanating from the War Department, published yesterday, indicated a belief on the part of the authorities at Washington that the Capital was insufficiently secured against threatened attack, the responses from the various Governors of States to whom the order was addressed have been of the most prompt, enthusiastic and patriotic character. ...
lead_paragraph: Under the apprehension that the general order emanating from the War Department, published yesterday, indicated a belief on the part of the authorities at Washington that the Capital was insufficiently secured against threatened attack, the responses from the various Governors of States to whom the order was addressed have been of the most prompt, enthusiastic and patriotic character. It appears, however, that the order was issued for no such cause. It had its origin in a desire to avoid the delays and routine to which recruits have been subjected, and to save those forming companies the expense of subsisting their men while waiting to be organized into regiments. The promulgation of the order caused considerable excitement in Washington yesterday, under the misapprehension before alluded to, and the most absurd stories were put afloat relative to the movements of the rebels, who were represented to be crossing the Potomac, both above and below the city. When the rebels do undertake to cross the Potomac, they will probably and that such a contingency has been amply provided for. A large number of boats, heavily armed, are watching all accessible points on the Potomac, and will be quite likely to give some trouble to any force attempting to cross.

abstract: We understand that the visit of Quartermaster-General MEIGS to the North has resulted in the establishment of certain important rules and regulations concerning the purchase of supplies for the extraordinary necessities of the Army. We hear, furthermore, that it has been decided by the Government at Washington to appoint a Commissary-General, who will have charge of purchases, supplies and contracts of every kind connected with military operations: -- and that his duties will be performed under a system of rules calculated to insure the most rigid accountability, and to, give the public assurance of thorough efficiency and economy in this most important branch of the public service. Everything will unquestionably be thrown open to free and honorable competition, so that there will be no longer any suspicion that the public welfare will be overlooked out of regard for private interests. We have reason to believe that the appointment in question will be made during the present week.

abstract: THE HOMICIDE ON BOARD THE CITY OF MOBILE. -- Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest on the body of CHARLES LOWE, a sailor on board the ship City of Mobile, who died, as previously reported in the TIMES, from injuries received on board that vessel. The testimony showed that deceased was a fresh sailor, and was ordered by the second mate to go aloft for some purpose. The deceased replied that he was afraid to do so, as he had never been aloft in his life. The mate then seized abroom-handle, and beat LOWE severely, knocking him down three times, and breaking his stick. During this assault the first mate stood by and cried, "Make him go, make him go aloft." The deceased then ascended a little way up the rigging, when he fell back nearly to the deck, and being unable to help himself was brought down by another sailor to the deck, where he shortly expired. The body was conveyed to the Bellevue Hospital, where a post-mortem examination by Dr. BEACH showed external marks of violence upon the sides, thighs, abdomen, back, head, and face, -- the cartilage of the nose being crushed, and the aorta also ruptured. The jury found that the fall was the cause of deceased's death, and that the fall was caused by the violent beating inflicted by the second mate, F. THOMPSON, and that the first mate was an aider and abetter of the violence. The first mate, F. PENNEFEATHER, was committed to the Tombs, but the second mate escaped when he saw his victim was dying, and has not yet been arrested.

abstract: The American bark Joseph Maxwell, which was brought to Cienfuegos by the prize crew of the Sumter, was ordered by the Governor of the town to leave the port within 24 hours, which they did, and were wrecked on the coast soon after having left Cienfuegos. The crew were all saved and brought into our port by one of our coasting steamers.

abstract: The Fire Zouaves were ordered to assemble at the City Assembly Rooms yesterday morning at 9 o'clock. It had been announced by Major LEOSER that the Paymaster and Surgeon would be present to pay those who were entitled to it, and discharge those unfit for duty. The men were late in coining. Neither the Paymaster or Surgeon were on hand, nor could the men obtain any satisfactory answer to their numerous inquiries as to what was to be done. Pay-masterWESTERVELT was busily engage in paying the wounded, and those absent on leave, the residue of pay due from the State. The Government Paymaster was non est. It appears that the legal formalities cannot be complied with, owing to the remissness of the company officers in furnishing properly authenticated rolls. The process of discovering who are and who are not deserters, bids fair to be a long and tedious job, and likely to create even more than existing discontent. Many of the men absolutely refuse to take up arms again unless they are paid, while, it is believed, the very act of such refusal will prevent their being paid, however well they may have previously performed their duty. The statement made by a private of Company G gives a fair sample of the discontented men. This man says the whole thing has been a "dead beat," or swindle on the men; that they never got the arms or uniforms promised; that they never elected their officers; that they never got the present of provisions sent them by the Seventh Regiment; that they never got a penny of the $700 subscribed for their work at the fire at Willard's; that the officers have, the majority of them, deceived and neglected the men, advised them to go home, run away from the field of battle, and done everything to disorganize the regiment; that the Captain of his company (MICHAEL TAGEN) personally advised about fifty men, a few days after the battle of Bull Run, to make the best of their way home; that other officers also advised the men to leave the best way they could; that many men did thus leave, and accompany other volunteer regiments to variousparts of the country; that every man thus told to leave by his officers feels that he did not forfeit his right to pay, and that the great body of the men will never go back unless they are paid. On the other hand, it is stated that the backwardness in paying the men is entirely the fault of the Government, that the rolls have been properly made out, and that the regiment has not received fair treatment at the hands of the War Department.

abstract: Advices from New-Mexico indicate that the rebels are making desperate efforts to gain possession of the Territory. Two or three bodies of National troops had been surrendered by their leaders evidently through treachery and a fight of some consequence had taken place without decisive results.

abstract: sociated Press yesterday took the trouble to telegraph from Washington extracts from private letters said to have been found in an intercepted mail-bag. This could not have been done without the consent of the Post-office Department, and in allowing such a publication it seems to us that a singular breach of propriety has been committed, to use no stronger term. So long as the express companies are allowed to keep open postal communication with the rebels, the letters which they carry should be held sacred. If the recent proclamation of the President is intended to make this transportation of mail matter illegal, then letters are contraband as well as munitions of war, and their proper destination is the dead-letter office.

abstract: All is military parade and bustle here at present. Two Illinois regiments the Fourteenth, under, Col. PALMER, and the Fifteenth, under Col. TURNER, arrived yesterday afternoon. They marched to-day for their camp, about four and a half miles west, to Pantsell's Spring, at the junction of the Little Piney and Big Beaver, where excellent water is found.

abstract: The arrest of BUTLER, READ and others, in Philadelphia, is only the first manifestation of a purpose which the Government has long entertained, but which has been delayed with a view of obtaining accumulative evidence. abstract: Rock River Bank vs. Hoffman  Gelpcke.  The defendants were Bankers at Chicago. It is alleged they collected large sums of money in behalf of the plaintiff, which they refused to deliver. A suit was commenced in this Court against the firm, and an attachment issued, by which the Sheriff attached $8,500 for the Bank and $3,300 for the plaintiff, Naylor.
lead_paragraph: Rock River Bank vs. Hoffman & Gelpcke. -- The defendants were Bankers at Chicago. It is alleged they collected large sums of money in behalf of the plaintiff, which they refused to deliver. A suit was commenced in this Court against the firm, and an attachment issued, by which the Sheriff attached $8,500 for the Bank and $3,300 for the plaintiff, Naylor.

abstract: -- The Judge who hung the stealer of horses, not to punish the theft, but that horses should not be stolen, taught a lesson which we shall do well to master. The Administration, we are told, is disposed to leave the fate of pirates and privateers undetermined until the close of the war; and that then the question of punishment or absolution will be settled, as individual cases may warrant. The motive of this postponement may probably be found in that mistaken idea of humanity which has thus far tempered our entire policy toward the rebels. They have threatened to retaliateupon their prisoners, life for life, the doom to which we consign ours, so that for every maritime thief we may adjudge to the gallows, they propose to measure out an equal length of hemp to the captives in their hands. To avoid such merciless retaliation may be the object which has led to this most impolitic declaration.

abstract: JEROME BARBER was arrested in Marcellus on Friday last, by United States Deputy Marshal LOWELL, of Syracuse, charged with being "violent and turbulent in his denunciations of the Government of the United States, and ardent and fierce in the expression of his sympathy with the rebel cause." The Syracuse Journal says: "BARBER is about 26 or 28 years old. He is a native of the town of Onondaga, where he has relatives now residing.
lead_paragraph: JEROME BARBER was arrested in Marcellus on Friday last, by United States Deputy Marshal LOWELL, of Syracuse, charged with being "violent and turbulent in his denunciations of the Government of the United States, and ardent and fierce in the expression of his sympathy with the rebel cause." The Syracuse Journal says: "BARBER is about 26 or 28 years old. He is a native of the town of Onondaga, where he has relatives now residing. He is an engineer and surveyor by proffession. About three years ago he went to Mississippi to live, and two or three weeks since came back to Onondaga on a visit. It is alleged that he has been affording aid and comfort to the enemies of the country, and that he is an officer (an engineer) in the army of the so-called Confederate States. We are informed that he has freely stated that he was appointed to such office by the Confederate Congress, at a salary of $3,000 a year, and that being stationed at Vicksburgh, Miss., the fortificationand batteries at that place were erected under his direction.

abstract: ing cotemporary has made a remarkable discovery, and bas given the world the benefit of it. Inasmuch as the Army of the United States is to be chiefly benefited by the revelation, and as the cotemporary in question has assumed the position of tutelary guardian of the Administration, the wonder is that the promulgation has been so long delayed. But here it is, done up in italics, in the impressive manner befitting its importance: "The Army is practically without a Commissary-General." Our cotemporary is equal to the emergency, and he proposes that -- a Commissary-General be appointed. Sagacious idea. But who is to be the useful man? "If such men as Judge DAVIS, of Illinois, or Gov. MORGAN, of this States, or Gen. MOREHEAD, of Pennsylvania, or (if he is not too young for so important a post) the gallant, energetic and capable Gov. SPRAGUE, of Rhode Island, were put at head," &c, &c. In these words the gordian knot is cut, and the country put in the highway to relief.

abstract: The Democrats of Maine met in Convention at Augusta a few days ago to organize for the Fall campaign. Resolutions of a decidedly lukewarm character, so far as the Government is concerned, were offered and discussed with much spirit. Propositions were made to qualify them by a resolution supporting the war so far as it is waged to suppress rebellion and sustain the Constitution and the laws, which were promptly voted down.
lead_paragraph: The Democrats of Maine met in Convention at Augusta a few days ago to organize for the Fall campaign. Resolutions of a decidedly lukewarm character, so far as the Government is concerned, were offered and discussed with much spirit. Propositions were made to qualify them by a resolution supporting the war so far as it is waged to suppress rebellion and sustain the Constitution and the laws, which were promptly voted down. The Convention thus putting itself on the record against the Government, the minority retired from the Convention to the number of one hundred and eighty-five. Hon. A.G. JEWETT, of Belfast, one of the Vice-Presidents, administered a scorching rebuke to the traitors, and resigned his place. Hon. JAMES W. BRADBURY, of Augusta, denounced the Convention as having substantially voted opposition to war, even to sustain the Government. Hon. A.W. JOHNSON, of Belfast, told them, they had declared to the heroic JAMESON and BERRY and KNOWLES, and other Democratic officers and their Democratic soldiers that they had made fools of themselves, and in such a declaration he would not join while a spark of manhood was left in him. Hon. S.H. BLAKE, B.A.G. FULLER and others followed up the denunciation, and the faithful abandoned the recreants to their fate. The retiring minority assembled in Concert Hall, with Hon. ARNO WISWELL for President, and adopted the following among other resolutions:

abstract: Mr. BARTLETT JONES, first officer of brig Sa. Clara, of Eastport, arrived in this City, this morning, from Holmes' Hole. Mr. JONES was one of the party that was put on board the schooner Windward, from Turks Island, with a cargo of salt. He states that the Santa Clara, of Eastport, Capt. ELLINGWOOD, was from Fajardo, P.R., with a cargo of sugar, bound to New-York, and consigned to RIVERA & HALL, and was captured Aug. 6, lat. 29Â°, long. 67', by the privateer Jeff. Davis, the pirate just previous to the capture flying the British, flag, but upon approaching within gunshot hauled down that flag, and placed in its stead that of the Confederate States. Upon taking the Santa Clara, Capt. ELLINGWOOD, Mr. JONES and the entire crew, with the exception of the cook and three Spanish passengers, were transferred to the Jeff. Davis, and from thence to the schooner Windward, which vessel was captured the day previous. Mr. JONES says it was the intention of the commander of the privateer to burn or sink the Windward, but, having so great a number of prisoners, and not knowing what to do with them he concluded to put them on board the Windward and set them free, which was accordingly done, only allowing them for subsistence one barrel of bread, two barrels of beef and one barrel of flour, and a small allowance of water, which gave each man one pint per day. Mr. JONES speaks of Capt. COXETER, of the Jeff. Davis, in the highest terms; his gentlemanly conduct and humane feeling were in great contrast with that of his first officer, (POSTELL,) whose language and treatment of the prisoners was very bad. He also says that they had but one prize-master more on board and only about thirty men, and would be compelled to go home soon for a crew. The Jeff. Davis carries two 12-pound medium guns in a battery, two 18-pound medium guns in a battery, and one long 18-pounder on a pivot amidships, and enough small arms of the best quality for one hundred men, with plenty of ammunition. Her officers are: Commander, L.M. COXETER; First officer, POSTELL; Second officer, STEWART; Surgeon, BABCOCK; Assistant Surgeon and acting Purser SEABROOK.

abstract: BOARD OF SUPERVISORS -- THE LATE JEREMIAH LOTT. -- The Supervisors met at the County Jail yesterday afternoon. Before the roll was called, the Chairman, Supervisor CROOK, announced the death of JEREMIAH LOTT at Flatbush, aged 85 years. He stated that Mr. LOTT was for thirty years Clerk of the Board of Supervisors, and had grown up with the County. He could say of him what, it was regretted could not be said of many now-a-days, that he was never suspected of taking one cent not belonging to him. The occasion was one which demanded some special notice, and he should at the proper time offer a resolution. The Board was called to order, when Mr. CROOK presented the following, which was adopted:

abstract: The Central, cars yesterday brought down from the camps near Manassas 350 of our sick soldiers, most of whom are suffering with the measles, while some few are sick with bilious and other affections. Such a large addition to our sick list urgently requires another good hospital, which we hope will be selected and fitted up without the least delay.
lead_paragraph: The Central, cars yesterday brought down from the camps near Manassas 350 of our sick soldiers, most of whom are suffering with the measles, while some few are sick with bilious and other affections. Such a large addition to our sick list urgently requires another good hospital, which we hope will be selected and fitted up without the least delay.

abstract: morning show that the rebels are not inclined to part with the advantage their overwhelming numbers in the Southern counties have gained them. As Gen. SIEGEL has retreated they have advanced. Six weeks ago the National forces had pushed forward to the southwesternmost angle of the State, and the insurgents had withdrawn the main body of their troops into Arkansas. By this position of affairs the lead mines at Granby, indispensable to the rebels, who had no other means of providing an important munition of war, were taken out of their hands, and the capital of the State was effectually barred against the usurpations of Gov. JACKSON. Now, however, the entire South and Southwest are in the possession of the rebels. The imperfect and insufficient resistance of the Home Guard is the only obstacle to their reoccupation of Jefferson City. Add to these reverses the loss of so gallant and sagacious a leader as Gen. LYON, and we discover how, seriously we have suffered in this one department of the war.

abstract: There are many honest people who honestly believe that the North is responsible for the Slavery agitation; and that to Mr. SEWARD the country is indebted for the irrepressible conflict idea; and that the destruction of our Southern trade, and the perilous state of the country, is all owing to Northern fanatics; but our political history does not sustain these honest people in their views.
lead_paragraph: There are many honest people who honestly believe that the North is responsible for the Slavery agitation; and that to Mr. SEWARD the country is indebted for the irrepressible conflict idea; and that the destruction of our Southern trade, and the perilous state of the country, is all owing to Northern fanatics; but our political history does not sustain these honest people in their views. The cunning men in the South, who have for years labored to dissolve the Union, seized upon the Slavery question as one on which the Southern people were most sensitive, and as best calculated to arouse them to action. DAVIS, of Massachusetts, remarked in 1833, "that the root of South Carolina's discontent lay deeper than the tariff." Her political economists reasoned that as Charleston had a larger commerce than New-York before the adoption of the Constitution, and since that time the commerce of New-York had grown to be considerably larger than that of Charleston, hence Charleston had suffered for the benefit of New-York, and the remedy for this was dissolution of the Union -- and when they found the tariff would not unite the Southern people, they took hold of the Slavery question.

abstract: The Philadelphia Press has seen a letter from Turin, dated July 31, which states that GARIBALDI has no intention of coming hither, take part in the battles for Freedom and the Union. But he wishes to organize a National subscription in Italy, has a tribute from one free nation to another -- return, in effect for the liberality displayed by our citizens in the Italian war of 1859.

abstract: The peculiarities of the people of the United States were never more strikingly illustrated than in the progress of the present war. We are always on the highest pinnacle of hope or in the lowest depths of despair. For the first three months of our campaigning, nothing could exceed the confidence, not to say arrogance, of the supporters of the Union. We had confidence not only in our own strength, but an equal degree of confidence in the rebels' weakness. The loyal North was brave,enthusiastic, irresistible. The disloyal South was fearful, lukewarn and demoralized. The latter had only to be met promptly in the field and they would dissolve as a rebel mob -- for were they not without arms, without money and without food?
lead_paragraph: The peculiarities of the people of the United States were never more strikingly illustrated than in the progress of the present war. abstract: PIERCE BUTLER, Esq., of Philadelphia, who was arrested on Monday upon a charge of treason, arrived here on Monday evening by the late train, in charge of two United States officers. The party stopped at the Astor House for a few hours, where the prisoner, as well as his custodians, obtained a few hours of repose, and Mr. BUTLER was then conveyed to Fort Lafayette, where he will share the confinement of other illustrious State prisoners. It appears that the Government had seized a parcel of letters on their way across the Potomac, written by Mr. BUTLER, and addressed to JEFFERSON DAVIS, Gens. BEAUREGARD and JOHNSTON, and other prominent men among the Confederates. A short time after, the matter was placed in the hands of the United States Marshal in Philadelphia, who arrested Mr. BUTLER as he was walking down Chestnut-street, and brought him to New York.
lead_paragraph: PIERCE BUTLER, Esq., of Philadelphia, who was arrested on Monday upon a charge of treason, arrived here on Monday evening by the late train, in charge of two United States officers. BEAUREGARD and JOHNSTON, and other prominent men among the Confederates. A short time after, the matter was placed in the hands of the United States Marshal in Philadelphia, who arrested Mr. BUTLER as he was walking down Chestnut-street, and brought him to New York.

abstract: The late action of the Banks of Boston, in taking so large a portion of the Government loan, at par, says the Boston Journal, is due in a great degree to the exertions of the Chairman of the Committee of the Banks, William Gray. This gentleman is a grandson of that William Gray, the merchant prince of 1812, who did so much to sustain the credit of the Government in the last war with England. The descendant inherits the energy, the patriotism and the influence of the grandfather.

abstract: We have Mr. RUSSELL's letter at last, together with the comments of the London Times. Both have been expected with a feeling which our cousins across the water might consider complimentary, if they were not too anxious about their neutrality to dare to be complimented by either party. We scarcely exaggerate the fact, when we say that the first and foremost thought in the minds of a very large portion of our people after the repulse at Bull Run was, "What will RUSSELL say?" "How will this affect us abroad?" "What will the London Times think of us?" and "in what light win it present this untoward affair to the European world?" Speculation soon succeeded wonder, and enterprising journalists began to hint that they happened to know what Mr. RUSSELL had said; that he had written to the Times that he never saw such fighting in all his life; that there was nothing at Alma or Inkerman to equal it, in spite of the disgraceful panic by which it was followed. The phrase, if not apocryphal was at least equivocal, and might very well have been used by the shrewd and humorous Special, without any wide departure from the literal truth.

abstract: This regiment, which has been quartered, drilled and equipped on Riker's Island, has received the general order to march, and they will leave to-day for Washington. Four thousand rations have been ordered for their subsistence en route. Steam-lugs will receive them on board at the Island, and convey them direct to Elizabethport, where they will take the Central Railroad of New-Jersey for Baltimoreand Washington. They are provided with the Springfield musket, but are promised a more effective arm when they reach their destination. Yesterday a large number of their friends went down to take leave of the regiment.

abstract: Monday afternoon, Officer Mason of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, arrested Conrad A. Ten Eyck, a professed passenger or shipping agent, living in Brooklyn. It appears that on Saturday last accused accosted Mr. John Maher, a German, as he was passing along South-street, and asked him if he wanted to take a voyage to Liverpool. Maher at once replied in the affirmative, whereupon Ten Eyck told him that the ship Great Western would sail for that port in about two hours, and that he would sell him a second cabin ticket for $14. The ticket was accordinglybought, but the holder thereof subsequently learned that the Great Western had sailed for Liverpool early that morning. It also appeared that the ticket was not in accordance with the law, in that it failed to state the names of the owners or consignees. Ten Eyck Was taken before Justice OSBORN and held to bail in the sum of $500.

abstract: The August Term of the United States District Court commenced yesterday, SAMUEL R. FISHER was appointed foreman of the Grand Jury. Judge CADWALLADER, in addressing the jury, referred to his charge to the former Grand Jury, as embodying all that was required to guide them in their deliberations. It was explained to them that business pertaining to the Circuit Court, as well as the United States, would come before them during the term.

abstract: All apprehensions of a forward movement of the rebels towards Washington, or an attempt to cross the Potomac for operations in Maryland seem to be now at an end. That rebel leaders have intended to make some such movement is, no doubt, true. Information has been received at...
lead_paragraph: All apprehensions of a forward movement of the rebels towards Washington, or an attempt to cross the Potomac for operations in Maryland seem to be now at an end. That rebel leaders have intended to make some such movement is, no doubt, true. Information has been received at head-quarters in Washington which renders this certain, but it appears that the recent heavy rains have interfered with the plans, by swelling the waters of the Potomac, so as to render it unfordable. There is now no point between Georgetown and Harper's Ferry where the river can be crossed. It is possible now that when the rebels do "advance," it will be in the other direction. Indeed, our dispatches state that they have already gone as far as Fairfax Court-house, under the apprehension that the National Army was again in motion.

ROBERTS, arrived at this port last evening from Monrovia via St. Thomas 8th instant, and reports, August 10, lat. 22 12' N. lon. 67 10' W., at 7 A.M., discovered a schooner, pilotboat build, to windward, running down for the bark, and apparently full of men. lead_paragraph: The bark Cordelia, Capt. ROBERTS, arrived at this port last evening from Monrovia via St. Thomas 8th instant, and reports, August 10, lat. 22 12' N. lon. 67 10' W., at 7 A.M., discovered a schooner, pilotboat build, to windward, running down for the bark, and apparently full of men. Capt. R. then kept off, when the schooner made chase, and after pursuing her for an hour, and not being able to gain on her, she hauled her wind and gave up the chase, and stood to the southwest. She was painted entirely black, and showed no colors.

abstract: The steamer Joseph Whitney, side-wheel, formerly employed between Baltimore and Boston, has been purchased by the Government, and she is fitting up as a transport, to convey fresh provisions to Forts Pickens, Jefferson and other United States stations in the Gulf. She is provided with two heavy rifled guns, capable of bring a 14-pound Hotchkiss shell, and has a crew of seventy men. Capt. A.G. GRAY has superintended the work on the ship, and will have command. The Whitney is a fast steamer, as well as a very substantial one, and is admirably adapted to the work for which she has been detailed.

abstract: The privateer Jeff. Davis was at St. Johns, P.R., July 26. She took in wood and water, and proceeded to sea the next day, where she lay on and off the Island, supposed to be waiting for a bark expected from the United States, with a cargo of provisions. The authorities of the Island sent to her, and ordered her off. Capt. DAY, of the British brig J.W. Johnson, arrived yesterday, from Arroyo, P.R., reports seeing a vessel in Crooked Island Passage, which he is pretty certain was the Jeff. Davis.

abstract: the regiment of Fire Zouaves seems to be a matter of a good deal of difficulty. The fact is, the officers of the regiment appear to be utterly incompetent and not to possess, in the slightest degree, the respect or confidence of the men. The latter have steadily ascribed their misfortunes to the lack of leaders, and they seem likely to suffer still further from this cause. If the men of this regiment have any regard for their own reputation as soldiers, they can scarcely afford to leave matters as they are. We should be glad to see them reorganized and purged of the elements which have done them so much damage already: -- but they must have proper officers if this is to be accomplished. It would be far better to disband them at once than suffer them again to take the field without competent leaders and in their present demoralized condition. They have unquestionably good fighting material among them, but it will be worse than wasted without proper discipline.

If the men of this regiment have any regard for their own reputation as soldiers, they can scarcely afford to leave matters as they are. We should be glad to see them reorganized and purged of the elements which have done them so much damage already: -- but they must have proper officers if this is to be accomplished. It would be far better to disband them at once than suffer them again to take the field without competent leaders and in their present demoralized condition. They have unquestionably good fighting material among them, but it will be worse than wasted without proper discipline.

abstract: There are now very few ships under contract for the merchant service, most of those building being for Government use. They are 220 feet long, 30 feet breadth
lead_paragraph: There are now very few ships under contract for the merchant service, most of those building being for Government use. Among those under way are two side-wheel steamers for the house of OLIPHANT, SONS CO. These vessels are building at the shipyard Of ROSEVELT JOICE, foot of Houston-street, East River. They are 220 feet long, 30 feet breadth of beam, and 12 feet deep. They are to be employed on the Yang-tee-Kyang River, in China. The first of these boats has been built even to the planking, and is now being taken down to be shipped in sections on board the ship Sea Lark. The engine was built by the Morgan Iron Works, which has had a large share of these engines to build. It is now on board the same ship. She was built exclusively for river navigation, and is unsuited for a long ocean voyage. The second vessel is nearly completed, and will be launched early next week. Her engine is built by the Allaire Works. It is 50 inches diameter of cylinder, and 12 feet stroke.

abstract: Capt. BREWER, from Sierra Leone, July 12, arrived here this morning, and reports that the brig Flight, formerly of Boston, had been captured by the British vessel-of-war Falcon, and taken to Sierra Leone June 30. The Flight had 550 slaves on board. A Spanish schooner was also captured by a British steamer, and was taken in July 2, just as she was about to take a cargo of slaves on board. We learn from Capt. BREWER that the Flight was captured near Ascension, and was first taken in there. The slaves were taken on board on the southwest coast. They were brought to Sierra Leone, and were to be sent to the West India Islands as apprentices. The Flight was hauled upon the beach, and was to be broken up, that being the custom of the British Government, as formerly vessels that had been captured were purchased by parties who again used them in the same trade. It is not known where the brig, which is an old one, came from. The words "Flight, of Boston," were painted on the stern The crew of the slaver, some eight or ten in number, were liberated at Sierra Leone and set ashore. Most of them had been shipped on a vessel about to clear for England. When the vessel wasboard refused to take it down, declaring that it must be done by force. The Spanish vessel mentioned above was seized in the River Pongas, by the British man-of-war Torch. Her crew were all Spaniards. -- Boston Traveller, Aug. 29.

abstract: Col. John E. Gowen, of Boston, who went to Sebastopol several years since, to raise the sunken fleet of the Russians, having bestowed great care in preserving and restoring the graves of the English who fell during the siege of that place, a subscription has been raised by British officers and relatives of those who died during the Crimean war, in order that a testimonial might be presented to him, to mark the grateful sense of his generous care. Lord Frederick Paulet and Col. Hudson were the chief movers in the matter. They procured the manufacture of a silvergilt shield, of the weight of three hundred and fifty ounces. The border is richly chased with equestrian and other figures, subjects taken from the Elgin marbles. The centre bears an appropriate inscription. The plate has been presented to the English Consul at Theodosio, for presentation to Mr. Gowen.

abstract: The completed returns show that the population found in the United Kingdom at the recent census, not reckoning Army, Navy, or merchant seamen who were abroad, amounted to 29,031,298, an increase of 61 percent, in 50 years, notwithstanding that we have been planting nations by a vast emigration. The census found here 14,077,189 males, and 14,954,109 females -- an excess of females over males of 876,920. The overplus of women and girls in England would fill all Liverpool and Leeds; in Scotland, all Edinburgh; in Ireland, all Belfast, Waterford, and Wexford. There are 16 towns in the United Kingdom with a population exceeding 100,000, and 6 parishes in the outskirts of London with such a population -- of them (St. Paneras) with very nearly 200,000, (198,882.) The number of inhabited houses in the United Kingdom is 5,151,985, which allows a house to every 5.6 persons.

abstract: A dispatch received in Boston, on Monday, from Plymouth, Mass., announces the death of Rev. J.S. CLARK. abstract: ago we published a proclamation issued by Brig.-Gen. POPE, telling the people of the portion of Missouri in which he is located what they might expect if they interfered in any way with the Union citizens residing there, or if they molested the National forces who might be ordered thither on duty.
lead_paragraph: ago we published a proclamation issued by Brig.-Gen. POPE, telling the people of the portion of Missouri in which he is located what they might expect if they interfered in any way with the Union citizens residing there, or if they molested the National forces who might be ordered thither on duty. The people of Marion County apparently regarded this document as worth no more than the paper on which it was printed, and proceeded to ascertain whether the General meant what he said, by firing into a railroad train filled with National troops. It is to be hoped they are satisfied with the result of their first experiment. No sooner did intelligence of the outrage reach Gen. POPE's head-quarters than he dispatched Brig-Gen. HURLBUT to Palmyra, the county seat, with a force sufficient to overawe any hostile demonstration which might be made, and that officer in his turn issued a proclamation to the people of the county, calling on them to deliver a miscellaneous assortment of groceries at his headquarters daily, before 9 o'clock in the morning. For instance, they must furnish 687 pounds of fresh beef, a like quantity of corn meal, and beans, rice, coffee and sugar to match. Besides all this, they are informed that they must haul enough water for the use of the command. If any of the articles named are not forthcoming, they will be taken from the most convenient place, and this operation will be repeated "until the marauders who fired upon the train" are surrended to the military authorities.

abstract: The fourth annual report of the Board of Commissioners of the Central Park has been issued. The Treasurer's report states that the receipts of the last year amounted to $1,110,620.05; disbursements, $978,354.95; balance in the Treasury, $51,161.72. The total receipts of the Board, since its organization in 1857, amount to $2,694,132.41; expenditures, $2,642970.69.
lead_paragraph: The fourth annual report of the Board of Commissioners of the Central Park has been issued. The Treasurer's report states that the receipts of the last year amounted to $1,110,620.05; disbursements, $978,354.95; balance in the Treasury, $51,161.72. The total receipts of the Board, since its organization in 1857, amount to $2,694,132.41; expenditures, $2,642970.69. The amount received for the maintenance of the Park for the last year was $80,000; expenditures $60,195 37; total remainder in the Treasury, $70,966 35. The indebtedness Jan. 1, 1861, was $240,000. The amount of expenditures, $2,763,166 06, added to the total cost of the land, $3,744,708 74, makes the total cost of the Park, up to the present year, to be $6,447,-964 80. The interest on this sum is $386,877 88. The appendix to the report contains the several acts of the Legislature relating to the Central Park, and the Board of Commissioners, and also the orders granted by the Supreme Court. The report of the Senate Committee, appointed to examine into the condition, affairs and progress of the Central Park, is likewise included. The appendix to the report also gives the ordinances for the government of the Park, and an explanation of the purposes of the work already done on the Park, and of that in immediate contemplation. In relation to unaccomplished plans, the report affords the following information:

abstract: Gov. MAGOFFIN, of Kentucky, once more appears on the scene of National politics. His present demonstration being simultaneous with the return of Senator JOHN C. lead_paragraph: Gov. MAGOFFIN, of Kentucky, once more appears on the scene of National politics. His present demonstration being simultaneous with the return of Senator JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE from Washington, there can be no doubt by whom he is inspired. The Frankfort(Ky.) Yeoman, the secession State organ, announces that Gov. MAGOFFIN has deputed WM.A. DUDLEY and FRANK HUNT as Commissioners to President LINCOLN, to request the withdrawal of troops from Kentucky, and GEO. JOHNSON to JEFF. DAVIS, to request him to respect Kentucky's neutrality.

abstract: We give elsewhere copious extracts from late English journals, upon affairs in this country. The Bull Run battle, with its influence upon the great contest, and upon the tempter and spirit of the North, is an abundant theme for them as well as ourselves.
lead_paragraph: We give elsewhere copious extracts from late English journals, upon affairs in this country. The Bull Run battle, with its influence upon the great contest, and upon the tempter and spirit of the North, is an abundant theme for them as well as ourselves. On the whole, we have no reason to be dissatisfied with the comments made upon us, or of the position of England toward this country, assuming that to be defined and expressed in the late speech of the Queen. We accept the unfriendliness of Lord PALMERSTON, and, in fact, of the English aristocracy, toward us; but it does not follow that this feeling is to disturb the peaceful relations between the two countries. We are confident it will not, notwithstanding the hostile tone of the Post, Palmerston organ, and the Times, which also reflect his temper as well as his policy. We think we may accept it as a fixed fact that the relations between the two countries are not to be changed, at present at least. On the other hand, the News, and other influential journals, which express the feelings of the masses of the people, are outspoken in our favor, and in favor of a cause which is identical with that which has given England all its worth and glory. Because we have suffered reverse they see that our cause is no less just or deserving of their sympathy. It is even foreseen that our disaster may not, in the end, prove to have been a disadvantage. The patriotism of the North and West is confidently counted upon as being equal to any emergency. The matter of our finances seems to give some anxiety to the friendly journals, and our supposed inability to negotiate the loan voted by Congress is dwelt upon with ardent satisfaction by those hostile to us. They confidently count upon having spoiled for us the English market. The people of that country well know that this, like all similar contests, is simply a question of money. Their surprise will besomewhat excited, and their respect very greatly increased for us, when they see upon the very heels of defeat, that all the money wanted by Government is readily proffered by our own people. This fact will tell with more effect upon the public mind of England than a dozen such actions as that of Bull Run. They will see that it was nothing but a skirmish of outposts, and is no more conclusive of the contest, than the repulse first sustained by them in the late contest with China was of that war. As our war progresses, Englishmen will gradually learn that the people of the Northern States are very like the old stock; addicted to peace; slow to acquire new habits; prone to commit blunders and mistakes on being forced into a war; but are not to be upset or discouraged by one, two or three severe reverses. Each one suffered only serves to stimulate us to renewed and greater efforts. Such will be the case here as there. Already, in our conduct under defeat, have we given them food for reflection, while the more they see henceforth, will only tend to confirm the feeling which, in that country, has already set in in our favor.

abstract: About 6 o'clock yesterday morning a very destructive fire broke out in the blind and sash manufactory owned and occupied by LEONARD BALDWIN, at No. 89 Delancey-street. The fire was first discovered in the engine-room situated in the rear, and, notwithstanding the fact that the alarm was quickly given, the flames spread to the main building with such rapidity that before the arrival of the firemen it was completely enveloped in flame, and soon afterwards was a mass of ruins. From this building thefire spread with great rapidity, and soon reached the large tenement-house of JOHN W. FARMER, located in the rear of No. 95 Ludlow-street, and being surrounded on all sides by other buildings, it was very soon a mass of fire from basement to attic. In this building there were over twenty families, and when the flames reached it, the frightened women and children were seen running in all directions, shrieking with the wildest terror, andcrying piteously to the firemen and citizens to save their furniture. Some, with three or four small children, who clung to them for safety, were trying to get out their little stock of goods with one hand, while the other held their infants. All the younger portion of the families were almost in a state of nakedness, having doubtless been aroused from their beds by the alarm. It is believed they all escaped with their lives, but how, under the circumstances, is truly wonderful. From this tenement-house the fire extended rapidly to the adjoining buildings, notwithstanding the steam and other engines by this time were well at work. On Orchard-street the fire did great damage. The first one on the street was No. 108 -- a lager-beer saloon -- which almost joined the building where the fire broke out. This was a two-story brick building, and was a total loss. The damage here was about $3,000. Insured for $1,000. No. 110 Orchard-street was the next building which took fire. This was occupied as a dwelling by Mr. HUNT and family. The most of their personal effects were saved. The damage to the building was very serious, though the firemen succeeded in staying the flames before it was entirely destroyed. No. 116 Delancey street, a three-story frame building, occupied by Mr. BALDWIN, was damaged to the extent of about $600. It was fully insured. No. 104 Delancey-street was a three-story brick building, occupied by Mr. TOOLEY, and was damaged about $500. No. 102 same street also took fire and was damaged to the extent of $300 or $400. They succeeded in saving the most of the furniture. Several other buildings in the vicinity, with the goods they contained, were more or less damaged by fire and water, but those mentioned above are the principal losses.

abstract: The Anderson Zouaves, Col. RIKER, embarked at a late hour last evening for Washington, via the Central New-Jersey Railroad. At last accounts they were on their way to Elizabethport.

abstract: We learn from a reliable source the following particulars of the troubles in the Seventy-ninth Regiment, which we lay before our readers. The causes of the mutiny in the Seventy-ninth Regiment are given as follows: After the battle of Bull Run the disorganization of the regiment was complete.
lead_paragraph: We learn from a reliable source the following particulars of the troubles in the Seventy-ninth Regiment, which we lay before our readers. The causes of the mutiny in the Seventy-ninth Regiment are given as follows: After the battle of Bull Run the disorganization of the regiment was complete. Owing to a number of officers resigning, and others being wounded or taken prisoners, the men had no one to command them. Major MCCLELLAND, owing to the death of Col. CAMERON, and Lieut.-Col. ELLIOTT being confined to bed by his bruises, was in command mand of the regiment; and the men state, that owing to the neglect of the Commissariat, they did not have a sufficiency of food, and were actually starving. Finally, the Lieutenant-Colonel was obliged to rise from a sick-bed, and attend in person to the subsistence of the men. One of the reasons for discontent was on account of the regiment being dissatisfied with their treatment in SHERMAN's Brigade.

abstract: If the estimate commonly placed upon the number and appointments of the rebels now in the field against the Government be correct, history cannot furnish a parallel to the power put forth by so small a population as that which composes the seceding States. All told, their whites number only about 5,000,000, scattered over an area of nearly 800,000 square miles.
lead_paragraph: If the estimate commonly placed upon the number and appointments of the rebels now in the field against the Government be correct, history cannot furnish a parallel to the power put forth by so small a population as that which composes the seceding States. All told, their whites number only about 5,000,000, scattered over an area of nearly 800,000 square miles. As a rule, a people are weak for active operations in proportion to the extent of the area they occupy. Neither Texas nor Arkansas can be represented to any considerable extent in the Army in Virginia. The same difficulty exists throughout the South. The more dense the population, the more readily, and in greater numbers, can large bodies of men be concentrated. The City of New-York can furnish twice the number of men for the war than can an equal population in the farming districts. In large towns the male population have fewer local ties than in the country, and can with much less inconvenience turn themselves into soldiers, and be moved to distant quarters.

abstract: We publish this morning a very important letter from our correspondent in the City of Mexico. It announces that England, France and Spain have simultaneously closed their relations with the Mexican Government, and withdrawn their Ministers, on the ground which may or may not be more than a pretext that the Government has, in its financial extremity, suspended for two years payment of its public debt.
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning a very important letter from our correspondent in the City of Mexico. It announces that England, France and Spain have simultaneously closed their relations with the Mexican Government, and withdrawn their Ministers, on the ground -- which may or may not be more than a pretext -- that the Government has, in its financial extremity, suspended for two years payment of its public debt.

abstract: The schooner Fair Wind, of and from Baltimore,for Fall River, with grain, has been detained several days under Sandy Hook, by head winds. She reports, Aug. 14, in lat. 39° 16', lon. 73° "We saw a brig to windward, running towards us, with her color half-masted, and union down. They asked us to lay by them, but we, laboring very heavy in the sea, could not do so. The brig drifted very fast to leeward, and at 4 P.M. we saw her go down. She was bound to New-York, but we were unable to learn her name. Could not see whether they had got their boats out or not. Her sails were blown for pieces. The captain said his crew were all sick. We saw molasses hogsheads on deck, from which we supposed her to be from the West Indies."
lead_paragraph: The schooner Fair Wind, of and from Baltimore,for Fall River, with grain, has been detained several days under Sandy Hook, by head winds. She reports, Aug. 14, in lat. 39 16', lon. 73 "We saw a brig to windward, running towards us, with her color half-masted, and union down. She was bound to New-York, but we were unable to learn her name. Could not see whether they had got their boats out or not. Her sails were blown for pieces. The captain said his crew were all sick. We saw molasses hogsheads on deck, from which we supposed her to be from the West Indies."

abstract: of Commerce enumerates eleven newspapers in the Northern States which have been obliged to cease the publication of seditious sentiments by the pressure of mob law. The subject is one in regard to which the Journal is profoundly interested.
lead_paragraph: of Commerce enumerates eleven newspapers in the Northern States which have been obliged to cease the publication of seditious sentiments by the pressure of mob law. The subject is one in regard to which the Journal is profoundly interested. At what moment some new disaster may goad the popular feeling of this City to repeat, in a serious form, the playful demonstration of April, whereby the National flag was made to float over several reluctant newspaper offices, the Journal has no assurance; and may therefore properly regard with concern demonstrations that may be mischievously useful as examples.

abstract: ate who writes from Norfolk, Va., says that the hulk of the Merrimac, steam-frigate, sunk it Gosport Navy-yard, has been successfully raised, and is now undergoing repairs and modifications that will fit her for a gunboat. She is to be cased over with iron, (railroad bars, perhaps,) so as to be wholly impenetrable to shot; and with her splendid machinery, she will be able to outsail any ship in the united States Navy. The writer adds, grouping all the powers of the Merrimac in one graphic whole, that she will be able to shell Fortress Monroe without danger to herself from all the guns there mounted, and then passing out of those waters, steam down the coast and successfully shell and sink every blockading ship now infesting Southern waters, aud open all the ports to the commerce of the world.

abstract: We learn that the President has authorized Hon. JOHN S. PHELPS, of Springfield, in Southwest Missouri, to embody the citizens and form five regiments of infantry and one of cavalry, to serve under the laws of Missouri for six months. As he raised about 2,000 Home Guards two months ago, at the request, of Gen. LYON,...
lead_paragraph: We learn that the President has authorized Hon. JOHN S. PHELPS, of Springfield, in Southwest Missouri, to embody the citizens and form five regiments of infantry and one of cavalry, to serve under the laws of Missouri for six months. As he raised about 2,000 Home Guards two months ago, at the request, of Gen. LYON, and had them in Springfield in less than a week, it is believed that Gen. PHELPS will find little difficulty in persuading his neighbors to rise and drive out their Arkansas invaders. He is a man of energy and eminently practical.

abstract: The steamer Yankee arrived last evening. She comes for repairs, and will leave to-morrow. Her officers report eleven steamers and four cutters at Aquia Creek. Everything there is quiet. The report that the rebels had erected batteries on the Maryland side, below Aquia Creek, is untrue.

abstract: Every page of the morning edition of the New-York TIMES is stereotyped, and worked in duplicate. We have resorted to this expedient as the only means of delivering our very large and constantly increasing edition to our subscribers at a reasonably early hour in the morning. We trust that any defects in the typography and general appearance of the paper will be pardoned until they can be remedied, -- which shall be at the earliest possible moment.

abstract: According to instructions, the men forming this regiment began to assemble at the Armory of the Seventh Regiment, yesterday morning at 10 o'clock. After some little delay, during which our reporter, who had not seen Col. FAIRMAN, and thinking it strange that he should be absent on such an occasion, inquired for him, but nobody knew where he was. Maj. MORIARTY was unable to inform our reporter where Col. FAIRMAN could be found, and thought it a strange question when asked if the Colonel ought not to be present.
