abstract: Whatever may be the result of the present war between the principle of Freedom and the principle of Slavery in the American States, it can always be said that Slavery had a fair fight; and, if it falls, it will "fall like Lucifer, never to hope again." It has been urged, by those who have doubted the ability of the South to maintain an independent existence, that its main supplies of food have been drawn from the Northwest, and that the corn and bacon from that region being cut off, the mules and the negroes of the Southern plantations would become almost valueless. In reply to this, it has been as zealously claimed by the Southerners that they occupied the most prolific and completely self-sustaining region in the world; that corn, wheat, beef and hogs could be produced in limitless supply whenever Southern labor and Southern fields should be applied to their production. Cotton and sugar were grown, they said, simply because it was more remunerative to employ all the labor on them, and purchase the plantation supplies from the Northwest with a part of the product.
lead_paragraph: Whatever may be the result of the present war between the principle of Freedom and the principle of Slavery in the American States, it can always be said that Slavery had a fair fight; and, if it falls, it will "fall like Lucifer, never to hope again." It has been urged, by those who have doubted the ability of the South to maintain an independent existence, that its main supplies of food have been drawn from the Northwest, and that the corn and bacon from that region being cut off, the mules and the negroes of the Southern plantations would become almost valueless. In reply to this, it has been as zealously claimed by the Southerners that they occupied the most prolific and completely self-sustaining region in the world; that corn, wheat, beef and hogs could be produced in limitless supply whenever Southern labor and Southern fields should be applied to their production. Cotton and sugar were grown, they said, simply because it was more remunerative to employ all the labor on them, and purchase the plantation supplies from the Northwest with a part of the product.

abstract: To the Editor of New-York Times:  I notice that a correspondent in your issue of Saturday is disposed to be severe upon my short communication in regard to "Foreign Officers." I have no desire to enter into an unnecessary or impolitic discussion of the position I there assumed. I thought I had sufficiently guarded my expressions, not to be misunderstood as attacking men of the Kosciusko or Lafayette stripe.
lead_paragraph: NEW-YORK, Monday, Aug. 19,1861.

abstract: Lord PALMERSTON, in the course of a recent speech in the House of Lords, went out of his way to assimilate the present threatening relations of Austria and Hungary to those between the Government of the United States and the Pro-Slavery insurgents. In the "unfortunate dissensions" between Austria and Hungary, he would not enter into the question of which side is in the right and which is in the wrong, just as he did not presume to determine as to the right or wrong of the "unhappy dissensions" between the North and South of the American States!
lead_paragraph: Lord PALMERSTON, in the course of a recent speech in the House of Lords, went out of his way to assimilate the present threatening relations of Austria and Hungary to those between the Government of the United States and the Pro-Slavery insurgents. abstract: tude has been shown that the weapons of the soldiers should be good and their food nutritious and healthy. This is right. It should be so. But there is a deadly poison infusing itself into the ranks, which must be met by Christian men. The idleness of the camp is dreadful. It is destructive of the moral, sense and integrity of the soldier, and it must be met by the efforts of Christians to supply healthy occupation. Books are better than liquor or cards, and the Soldier's Pocket and Camp Libraries, published at the low price of $2 and $3 by the Tract Society, in Nassau-street, seem to meet just the wants of the camp and forecastle. Why will not interested friends carry their brothers and husbands works of this sort, rather than liquor? Why not do something to elevate and improve their hearts, rather than to make them vicious and disorderly? Just before a regiment left Fort Hamilton the other day, there was an immense amount of wrangling and profanity. Many of the soldiers were drunk, and their officers found the utmost difficulty in securing obedience and getting their men ready to embark. One of the Captains said to a bystander that the "mistaken kindness of friends, in bringing liquor to the soldiers, was the source of all the trouble." The same money expended in judicious works to read in the monotonous hours of camp life, would neither exasperate the passions nor render soldiers unfit for duty

abstract: A meeting of the Kings County Board of Supervisors was held yesterday afternoon, at the County Jail. The annual report of the Superintendents of the Poor was presented, and referred to a Committee for examination. The report shows that there were in the Almshouse, at the beginning of the year, 1,150 persons; 5,876 were admitted during the year; 33 foundlings were boarded out; 21,023 persons were temporarily relieved -- making a total of 28,082 persons relieved or supported, wholly or in part, during the year.

abstract: Monday the counsel for the Rebel Police Commissioners, now confined in Fort Lafayette, applied to the County Court for an order to compel the Sheriff to show cause why an attachment should not be issued against him, as for a contempt, on the ground that his returns to the attachment and precept were improper, counsel contending that he should have called out all the force in the county to enforce a compliance with the order of the Court. Yesterday Judge GARRISON responded as follows: "I decline to make an order requiring the Sheriff to show cause why, &c, because I believe the Sheriff to have acted in good faith in his attempt to execute the two processes, and consider, therefore, his return as sufficient."

abstract: of Wednesday afternoon states that durine the seven hours succeeding 11 o'clock of the preceding night no less than seven thousand troops passed through the city, on their way to Washington, over the Philadelphia road alone. Numbers were also transported over the Northern Central Railway. This is but the vanguard of the vast Army moving forward in response to the last call of the Secretary of War. Not the least encouraging characteristic of this great demonstration is the comparative secrecy and silence with which it is made. Before the battle at Bull Run the Baltimore papers would have given us not only the names of the officers of each regiment, but the number of men under their command. Now, if the rebels want this interesting information, they must rely largely upon their own enterprise for procuring it. Meanwhile, they may make all they can of the bare fact that now and then the tide of volunteers flowing Southward averages one thousand an hour.

abstract: AN INCORRIGIBLE SPORT. -- An Englishman, known as HARRY JENNINGS, has been exercising a baleful influence for a year or two past upon the youth of the lower part of the City by inducing their attendance at rat-baits, dog-fights and other demoralizing sports, of which he was the presiding genius at Kerrigan Hall, in White-street. Not more than two months ago the conduct of JENNINGS and the frequenters of his establishment became so disorderly and offensive that Capt. PETTY, of the Fifth Ward Police, found it necessary to pay the place a visit, and having quietly carried out his plans, the proprietor and more than thirty of his audience found themselves in custody. Most of the prisoners were discharged afterreceiving a magisterial reprimand, but JENNINGS' case was sent before the Recorder at the Court of General Sessions, where he was found guilty of keeping a disorderly house, and sentenced to pay a fine of $200, as well as to be imprisoned for thirty days in the City Prison. The Recorder afterwards remitted the fine, but JENNINGS underwent the incarceration, obtaining his discharge about four weeks since. This punishment, however, has proved powerless to deter him from pursuing his former vocation, as immediately upon regaining his liberty he fitted up another sporting place, directly adjoining that which he had occupied, and a week's operation has shown himself and his patrons to be guilty of excesses similar to those which formerly brought them to trouble. Under these circumstances, JENNINGS was arrested again, yesterday, and Justice OSBORN held him to answer in bail of $500.
lead_paragraph: AN INCORRIGIBLE SPORT. -- An Englishman, known as HARRY JENNINGS, has been exercising a baleful influence for a year or two past upon the youth of the lower part of the City by inducing their attendance at rat-baits, dog-fights and other demoralizing sports, of which he was the presiding genius at Kerrigan Hall, in White-street. Not more than two months ago the conduct of JENNINGS and the frequenters of his establishment became so disorderly and offensive that Capt. PETTY, of the Fifth Ward Police, found it necessary to pay the place a visit, and having quietly carried out his plans, the proprietor and more than thirty of his audience found themselves in custody. Most of the prisoners were discharged afterreceiving a magisterial reprimand, but JENNINGS' case was sent before the Recorder at the Court of General Sessions, where he was found guilty of keeping a disorderly house, and sentenced to pay a fine of $200, as well as to be imprisoned for thirty days in the City Prison. The Recorder afterwards remitted the fine, but JENNINGS underwent the incarceration, obtaining his discharge about four weeks since. This punishment, however, has proved powerless to deter him from pursuing his former vocation, as immediately upon regaining his liberty he fitted up another sporting place, directly adjoining that which he had occupied, and a week's operation has shown himself and his patrons to be guilty of excesses similar to those which formerly brought them to trouble. Under these circumstances, JENNINGS was arrested again, yesterday, and Justice OSBORN held him to answer in bail of $500.

abstract: The arrest, at Cincinnati, of THOMAS B. LINCOLN, of Texas, but well known in this City as a full-blooded Secessionist, has furnished undoubted evidence, of the complicity of Hon. JESSE D. BRIGHT, Senator from Indiana, in the rebellion. Mr. BRIGHT has always been in the closest sympathy with the extreme Southern wing of the Democratic Party, and for his subserviency, was for many years elected President of the Senate pro tempore, and was by the Constitution eligible, in a certain contingency, to the Presidency of the United States. He was an ardent supporter of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE against Mr. DOUGLAS, and was found side by side with the former gentleman at the late session of Congress in opposition to the action and policy of the Government. While Senator, sworn to support and defend the Constitution, he salutes Mr. DAVIS as President of that portion of the country in rebellion against this Constitution, and sends a man to his Capital as the bearer of an improved weapon of destruction, to be used against his own constituents. The case of Mr. BRIGHT is only an illustration of the universal ramification of the great conspiracy, and of the shameless manner in which the oath of allegiance to the Constitution is habitually violated. Men set in Congress whose whole efforts are directed toward breaking up the Government. Only a few months ago a Cabinet, while holding office, was so employed. The population of Washington only a few mouths ago was composed of such conspirators, and is still swarming with them. Their name everywhere is legion, and up to this time, they have been the cause of nearly all our reverses. They still crowd, as officeholders, the several departments. A mistaken leniency yet allows them pretty free range. We are gradually working ourselves up to a proper treatment of such villains, and we trust and believe Mr. BRIGHT will be unceremoniously ejected from his seat in the Senate. Upon a prisoner lately captured in Missouri, a letter was found from Senator POLK, showing him to be one of the fellow-conspirators with JACKSON. The impudence of these creatures is astounding, and should be effectually cured by stringing a few of them up with a halter.

While Senator, sworn to support and defend the Constitution, he salutes Mr. DAVIS as President of that portion of the country in rebellion against this Constitution, and sends a man to his Capital as the bearer of an improved weapon of destruction, to be used against his own constituents. abstract: If any one feels disposed to lament that much of the passionate exaltation which possessed the public mind some weeks ago, has now passed away, it may be consoling to reflect how little, after all, is accomplished by mere enthusiasm. Things planted like to last come out of deeper roots, are of slow growth and are nourished by struggle, antagonism and defeat. However sublime as a purely
lead_paragraph: If any one feels disposed to lament that much of the passionate exaltation which possessed the public mind some weeks ago, has now passed away, it may be consoling to reflect how little, after all, is accomplished by mere enthusiasm. Things planted like to last come out of deeper roots, are of slow growth and are nourished by struggle, antagonism and defeat. However sublime as a purely moral phenomenon may have been that spontaneous upsurging from the deeps of the popular heart, -- that season when there was flood-tide in the spiritual energies of the nation, filling all the inlets of our life, -- yet it is very sure that the needs of the hour now demand a deeper range of purpose and conviction. Reason and duty must come in aid of what feeling and impulse prompted. It is one thing to be borne along on the tide of popular enthusiasm and share the magnetism of the mass, and quite another to cherish a cause with resolute devotion amid delays and disasters, to hold to it by day and by night and never give up.

abstract: The community was startled pesterday by a rumor, based upon a dispatch published in a Philadelphia paper, that Gen. BANKS had withdrawn his army from its position contiguous to Harper's Ferry, and that this withdrawal had been immediately followed by the reoccupation of Harper's Ferry by the rebels under Gen. JOHNSTON, and the crossing of the Potomac by a portion of his command.
lead_paragraph: The community was startled pesterday by a rumor, based upon a dispatch published in a Philadelphia paper, that Gen. BANKS had withdrawn his army from its position contiguous to Harper's Ferry, and that this withdrawal had been immediately followed by the reoccupation of Harper's Ferry by the rebels under Gen. JOHNSTON, and the crossing of the Potomac by a portion of his command. It is almost needless to say, that there is no truth whatever in the report. At least, it is positively denied at head-quarters in Washington, where the news of such a movement would be likely to be received quite as promptly as at any other point. Even should Gen. BANKS' command be removed, as reported, there is little likelihood that JOHNSTON would pursue any such reckless course as that indicated. His forces would thus be divided, with a wide river between to prevent a rapid junction, and he might by this means lose his entire army. Besides, we have no positive knowledge that JOHNSTON was in the immediate vicinity of the Potomac with any considerable body of men. There have been rumors to that effect, but they have never been verified. It seems to be understood in Washington that all the approaches towards the river, and towards the Capital, have been merely feints, intended as much to deceive the rebel army as our own, and to inculcate on both sides the false belief that an immediate demonstration against Washington was the main feature in the programme of the rebel leaders.

abstract: The very worst counselors for Generals in the field are an impatient populace. If we are to believe Gen. SCOTT, the calamity that has recently overwhelmed the grand Yankee army was caused by surrendering his own opinions of policy, and obeying the orders of the Yankee mob, headed by GREELEY,  BLAIR, and WILSON. The mob, under these commanders, drove him into a battle which was little better than slaughter and ruin.

abstract: It is well known that hundreds, and sometimes thousands, of pounds of projectiles are thrown away before one ball hits the mark, on account of the rapid, nervous and careless manner in which all men, except professional riflemen, fire. It is probable that the great majority of the rank and file could not hit a man at the modern rifle-musket range, under the most favorable auspices; add to this want of skill the hurry and excitement of battle, and the harmlessness of the musket may be accounted for. In fact, it is really formidable only because it has a bayonet at its end, except at close quarters, if it happens to have a charge in it. Therefore, the military authorities condemn a breech-loading arm, since its increased rapidity of action will only throw away a still greater quantity of innocuous lead.

abstract: defect in the actual system of raising volunteers, is the fact that an enlisted soldier has no encouragement to expect pay until same indefinite period in the future. We are assured by officers, engaged in recruiting, that this is a cardinal and threatens to be a fatal difficulty. Throngs of men present themselves ready to serve, if any method of providing for their families, in the interval referred to, can be shown, them, but who turn awaybecause the exigencies of food for wives and' children are too urgent. Those engaged in procuring the men are in the practice of exhausting their private means, and of appealing to public patriotism for aid in meeting such cases. When these sources are exhausted, they witness and immediate cessation of their work. An appeal, presenting precisely such a case in the instance of a highly meritorious corps, the German Rangers, appears in another column of this paper. An immediate amendment of the system is clearly needed. If those controlling the business will establish depots for recruits, on the several islands of the Bay -Governor's Island, now almost deserted, will accommodate twenty thousand -- to which the men maybe sent as they are enrolled, assured that advances of their pay will be at once made to their families, there will be no difficulty of obtaining three good men where we now get a single bad one. Let us uncoil our red tape, and bring to this the common sense principles which prevail in the conduct of an successful business, and there will be no deficiency of soldiers.

abstract: The correspondent of a New-York cotemporary, writing from Fort Pickens, undertakes, on the strength of a communication received from Havana, to give the substance of Admiral MILNE'S rumored dispatch to the Government, the contents of which, as well as the instructions in reply, are looked for with so much interest, both here and in America.
lead_paragraph: The correspondent of a New-York cotemporary, writing from Fort Pickens, undertakes, on the strength of a communication received from Havana, to give the substance of Admiral MILNE'S rumored dispatch to the Government, the contents of which, as well as the instructions in reply, are looked for with so much interest, both here and in America. The writer of the letter from Fort Pickens may be rightly informed, or he may be hazarding what he imagines a shrewd guess at the contents of the British Admiral's dispatch; but we do not require the information he professes to place before us, or the dispatch itself, to enable us to appreciate the conduct of the National Government with reference to the blockade, and of those officers instructed to establish it. The blockade of the Southern ports was formally proclaimed on the 29th of April, fifteen days of grace being allowed for vessels to clear out after the date of the proclamation. Some weeks subsequently another proclamation was issued, declaring all the ports south of Baltimore, Key West excepted, to be under blockade. We need not repeat what we have so often stated, upon the authority of the most eminent jurists, and especially those of the United States, that no blockade can be maintained without the continued presence of a competent armed force, except where that force may be removed by a gale of wind, or some temporary necessity. The ports at which, since the publication of the blockade, this requirement of the law of nations has been complied with are, Hampton Roads, Savannah, Charleston, Pensacola, Mobile, New-Orleans, and since the 7th of July, the port of Galveston. These are the ports at which blockading ships have been stationed, and, consequently, the only ports under such a blockade as can be recognized by a neutral State. At the ports of Wilmington, (in North Carolina,) St. Mark's and Apalachicola, (in Florida,) Beaufort and other places, no such steps have been taken to render the blockade effectual. No men-of-war have been stationed, or have even arrived, so far as we can ascertain, with that object. It is by no means improbable, moreover, that the blockade even of those ports where it has been regularly established has been irregularly and inefficiently maintained. We can hardly conceive how it could be otherwise, considering the vast extent of coast line the National Government have undertaken to close against commerce, and the limited resources at their disposal, to effect so extensive a blockade. The inability of the Cabinet at Washington to give effect to their war policy in this regard is manifest from the fact that they have been compelled, after the publication of the blockade, to leave the date and manner of effecting it entirely to the discretion of the commanders of the blockading squadron. This, in itself, must have created confusion and misunderstandings innumerable. The National Government may say that they are at liberty to take their own time in the matter of blockading the Southern coast, seeing that in doing so they are only closing their own ports. This is not an explanation which would for a moment be listened to by any European. Government, more especially by the Government of this country, which has expressly conceded to the South the rights of belligerents, and has acted from the first on the understanding that the National Government, in proclaiming a blockade of the Southern ports, was also exercising those rights which, in a spirit of rigid neutrality, we extended to North and South alike. Moreover, the National Government has within the past year refused to recognize the right of a Sovereign to blockade his own ports, and on these grounds actually obtained compensation from the ex-Government of Naples for losses incurred by an American ship during the blockade of the Neapolitan ports. The National Government must blockade as belligerents, or they cannot blockade at all; and what we have from the first contended for on behalf of neutral commerce is, that the blockade shall be established and maintained according to the strict usages of maritime warfare -- that it shall be effectual in form and impartial in its operation. This, we have no doubt, the British Government will insist upon, and they will be supported in their demand by all the maritime States of Europe; and if it shall appear that the National Government is unequal to blockade the whole of the Southern seaboard, then it will be the duty of the neutral fleets in those waters to see that neutral vessels entering or leaving unblockaded ports are not subjected to interference or molestation on the part of the National cruisers.

abstract: SPONSE OF NEW-YORK. -- Gov. MORGAN has appealed in a manner befitting the occasion, to the people of this State, to put forth renewed exertions in the great cause. Of money there is now an abundance. The greater want, at present, is men; but we are confident that these will come forward as fast as they can be received and properly organized. New-York has a population lacking only a million of being equal to the whole number of rebel whites, and could, should it be necessary, put an equal force into the field. Having a larger population and wealth than any State, she has a greater stake in the contest. Whatever she has is involved in it, to say nothing of her historical devotion to the cause of human freedom. As New-York leads all follow. The action of our merchants and capitalists has filled the Government Treasury. Let her hardy sons do as much for its Army, and we need not have an anxiety for the result.

abstract: The United States Marshal, at Philadelphia, has seized the packages of New-York Daily News sent to that city for sale, and also numerous other packages of the same paper destined for Baltimore, Washington, Louisville, and other points in the South and West.
lead_paragraph: The United States Marshal, at Philadelphia, has seized the packages of New-York Daily News sent to that city for sale, and also numerous other packages of the same paper destined for Baltimore, Washington, Louisville, and other points in the South and West. The Marshal could not have known of anything peculiarly obnoxious to censure in that particular issue of the paper, for the packages were seized when the contents were yet unknown. Neither could the action of the Marshal have been without authority of the Government, for the peril of such an invasion of private rights would not have been willingly incurred. We are brought to the conclusion, therefore, that the Daily News is condemned, by reason of its general political tone, and that the Administration has resolved to prohibit its circulation in certain districts.

abstract: A day or two ago, information was received at Police Head-quarters, that a wealthy merchant  and tobacco manufacturer, residing at Petersburgh, Va., was in the City, engaged in making collections for himself and other Southern merchants, from their creditors in this City. Sergeant YOUNG, of the De
lead_paragraph: A day or two ago, information was received at Police Head-quarters, that a wealthy merchant and tobacco manufacturer, residing at Petersburgh, Va., was in the City, engaged in making collections for himself and other Southern merchants, from their creditors in this City. Sergeant YOUNG, of the Detective force, and Detective King, were accordingly deputed to make search for him, with a view to his arrest. After much time spent in fruitless search, they at last became satisfied that the offender they sought was stopping at the Fifth-avenue Hotel. Thither they went, and found him just on the point of taking his departure for the South, he having concluded his business an hour or two previously. He was taken to the Police Head-quarters, and there searched. Upon his person was found about $200,000 in Virginia, Tennessee and Georgia six per cent. bonds, about $1,000 in gold, over $100 in Virginia bank-notes, and a large number of drafts, acceptance, certificates of deposit, &c., the amount of which is at present unknown. Also, a large number of letters from men in this City and Boston, to merchants in the rebel States. The Southerner's name is JOHN GARNETT GUTHERIE, an extensive tobacco-planter, manufacturer and merchant, and is reputed very wealthy, owning three large tobacco plantations in Virginia, and carrying on a large manufactory in Petersburgh.

abstract: organ of Lord PALMERSTON, whereas the London Times is his larger and more blatant mouth-piece, is of opinion that our blockade of the Southern ports does not answer the requirements of the Paris dogma, and therefore deserves no respect. According to the Parisian criterion, blockades must be such in fact, not merely in form. The ports must be actually impervious to the neutral vessel. And yet the truth is, shipping is constantly running our cordon, cotton ships put to sea, privateers go with impunity upon their naughty business, and evidence daily accumulates that maritime communication between the rebels and foreign countries is kept up with vexatious frequency. So this impartial spokesman of the hostile Minister of a friendly and sympathetic Government, proposes to disallow our blockade, and get whatever our recusant brothers have in store for it.

abstract: The rebels are busy in repeating an experiment, which has a hundred times been tried and as often failed, of making the shadow perform the office of substance by assuming that a mere promise can have all the attributes of property.
lead_paragraph: The rebels are busy in repeating an experiment, which has a hundred times been tried and as often failed, of making the shadow perform the office of substance by assuming that a mere promise can have all the attributes of property. Symbols may be taken for a time, but then only under a belief that what they represented will be forthcoming when called for. All currencies are repudiated the moment it is suspected that they cannot be instantly paid in gold and silver. It even matters not how well they may be secured by property which, in turn, may be converted into coin. The world is full of such illustrations, and upon a much grander scale than are furnished in commercial or Banking operations. The two most celebrated are the Continental money, or currency issued by Congress during the war of the Revolution, and the assignats issued by the French Government during the Revolution in that country. In neither case had the people the means for the purchase of the securities of the Governments issuing them; and, of course, had not the means for providing either the principal or interest of the debts or obligations contracted. As this fact forced itself upon the public mind, they gradually sank in value, so that in this country a dollar in coin could not be purchased by one hundred dollars in Government paper. So utterly baseless and discredited was this, that it was funded in the financial scheme of Mr. HAMILTON, at one hundred dollars for one, and hardly any complaint was made that the new Government was not liberal in recognizing it at all. It had a common history of all such issues. At first it was taken at par. As it sank in public estimation, the amount was increased till ten, twenty and thirty dollars, and so on, was paid out in discharge of debts and in making purchases, when only a dollar in actual value was due or to be received. The French assignats fared still worse, not sharing even the dignity of a recognition by the Government succeeding that which issued them.

abstract: AVOIDED -- The Government have lately determined that no person shall be allowed to leave this country for Europe without a passport, on account of the constant use made of our lines of steamers and sailing vessels by rebels going abroad for the purchase of arms, or to raise means, or to operate in the character of diplomats against the Government. Mr. SEWARD, however, has issued an explanatory circular, which we publish this morning, stating that it is not intended to apply to travelers going to the Canadas. This qualification completely defeats the whole object of the original order, as Canada has lines of steamers running to Liverpool and other English ports, as well as a vast number of sailing vessels, which can be and are being taken with entire impunity. So long as this route is left open, Mr. SEWARD may as well allow free egress from our own ports. Only a short time since BEVERLY TUCKER, one of the leading Secessionists, returned home through Canada. At present no person, in crossing the line, is ever inquired of or objected to. Mr. SEWARD'S order consequentlyis only an embarrassment to loyal citizens, and no check whatever to traitors. Will he not speedily modify it, so as to cover thewhole ground?

abstract: We have important news from Bogota, the Capital. Gen. abstract: A willful murder occurred early on the morning of Wednesday last, in this city. abstract: Our dispatches from Washington this morning disclose a bad condition of affairs among the rebels. According to information received by the Government, the leaders have commenced quarreling among themselves already, not content to wait until they have overcome the Yankees, and quartered themselves in the marble palaces in Broadway.
lead_paragraph: Our dispatches from Washington this morning disclose a bad condition of affairs among the rebels. According to information received by the Government, the leaders have commenced quarreling among themselves already, not content to wait until they have overcome the Yankees, and quartered themselves in the marble palaces in Broadway. It will be recollected that Gov. BROWN, of Georgia, some time ago protested against some of the acts of DAVIS, and it is now understood that in doing so he acted in concert with other more formidable malcontents at Richmond, prominent among whom are TOOMBS, the Virginians and the North Carolinians. In opposition to these are arrayed DAVIS, WIGFALL, and the Extremists of South Carolina. The complaint is that DAVIS and his coadjutors are drifting a little too fast towards despotism, and the quarrel has already reached to such an extent that he is openly denounced in the streets and public places of Richmond.

abstract: Prof. ROBERT GRANT, who has rendered such valuable service to Gen. BUTLER's division at Fortress Monroe, by the use of his Calcium Light for reconnoitering purposes, has been authorized by the War Department to organize a regiment, to be called the Cacium Light Infantry Sharp-shooters. He has already collected several hundred men, and is about to have a series of experimental drills by the aid of the Calcium light, commencing on Monday evening, at Palisade Gardens, Weehawken -- ferry at foot of Forty-second-street. Mr. EDGE, the celebrated fireworks man, has joined Mr. GRANT's regiment with 250 men.

abstract: The correspondence of Mr. RUSSELL, the writer of the London Times, improves as the effect of the panic which carried him away from the verge of battle subsides. The letter we give this morning does much to rectify the precipitate errors of that which contained his earliest description of the disaster.
lead_paragraph: -- The correspondence of Mr. RUSSELL, the writer of the London Times, improves as the effect of the panic which carried him away from the verge of battle subsides. The letter we give this morning does much to rectify the precipitate errors of that which contained his earliest description of the disaster. Our men are not all cowards, success is not altogether hopeless, the Army not entirely disbanded. He has become conscious that had the handling of the troops been intrusted to leaders of skill, there was the material to insure victory. He has also learned, and taught his employers, who confess the knowledge editorially, that the spirit of the loyal North, so far from being impaired by the event, is strengthened by deeper resolutions, and a readiness for even exhaustive sacrifices rather than permit this apparent demonstration of the weakness of our Government to pass without emphatic contradiction. These indications of the docility of the Special Correspondent we may regard with satisfaction. We have never doubted the candor or impartiality of Mr. RUSSELL; and, certainly, repudiate all share in that truculent jealousy, which assumes that the view he is to give of our affairs was foreordained in London. We may, therefore, expect confidently, to find errors, clearly the result of misinformation, or of imperfect observation, corrected, as his correspondence proceeds; and a just estimate of the country and its cause, the aggregate result of his labors.

abstract: FUL. -- Our advices from the Isthmus indicate the final triumph of Gen. MOSQUERA, who has occupied Bogota. If it were possible to anticipate anything permanent or beneficial from a Spanish-American revolution, this change would be fruitful with hope for New-Granada. Long a resident in the United States, Gen. MOSQUERA is thoroughly penetrated with the wants and deficiencies of our political system, and is prepared to apply it to his native country with a discriminating intelligence rare among South Americans. In any event, and with whatever eventual popular prosperity his ideas may secure, we may regard the triumph of this chief as the renewal of satisfactory guarantees to the safety of our great interoceanic route.
lead_paragraph: FUL. -- Our advices from the Isthmus indicate the final triumph of Gen. MOSQUERA, who has occupied Bogota. abstract: Every, page of the morning edition of the New-York TIMES is stereotyped, and worked in duplicate. We have resorted to this expedient as the only means of delivering our very large and constantly increasing edition to our subscribers at a reasonably early hour in the morning. We trust that any defects in the typography and general appearance of the paper will be pardoned until they can be remedied, -- which shall be at the earliest possible moment.

abstract: The most shocking tragedy which has occurred on shipboard for a long time, is thus reported by an arrival yesterday at this port. The ship B.D. Metcalf, STETSON, of Damariscotta, from Liverpool, reports that on the 2d inst., in lat. 45.25', lon. 43.39', she fell
lead_paragraph: The most shocking tragedy which has occurred on shipboard for a long time, is thus reported by an arrival yesterday at this port. The ship B.D. Metcalf, STETSON, of Damariscotta, from Liverpool, reports that on the 2d inst., in lat. 45 25, lon. 43 39, she fell in with the bark Czarina, DYWER, of Boston, from Cronstadt for Boston, forty odd days out, with ensign Union down. We kept off and spoke her, when she reported that they were without a navigator; and that, on July 31, at 3 1/2 A.M., Mr. COTTER, first officer, took an axe and proceeded to the Captain's room and killed the Captain while asleep in his berth,, and on the same day he killed the second mate and one of the seamen; that he then tried to kill the steward,but the steward killed him. One of the seamen stated to Capt. STETSON that the carpenter struck the mate with a top-maul, and he died in consequence and was buried. The crew were apparently all foreigners, and were much excited. Put on board of her Mr. LEVITT, first officer of the B.D. Metcalf, to take her into port. Remained in company with her three days, when Mr. LEVITT, reporting all right on board, we parted in lat. 45, lon. 45.

abstract: As no one can say what a day or a night may bring forth, particularly in time of war, I avail myself of a change of probable quiet, such as it is, amid the rolling of drums, the braying of trumpets and bands, the noise of marching men, rolling of wagons, and general life and activity in the streets, to write some remarks on tha action at Manassas or Bull Run.

abstract: not be alarmed. We do not initiate a new military movement on the pattern of the one attempted last month. We do not initiate one at all; but merely give the intelligence to the country that Richmond is yet considered, at Washington, a good place to go to -- perhaps to "reconnoitre in force." A correspondent of a Philadelphia paper, in a favorable position to know, writes that "the War Department has decided to send seventy-five or eighty of the first regiments that are organized at Washington, to Fortress Monroe, to reinforce Gen-WOOL, with the ultimate design of marching on Richmond from that point."

abstract: Capt. WALLACE, of the British schooner Prince Leopold, seized on Thursday by order of the Surveyor of the Port for running the blockade, was up before the Prize Commissioners yesterday, and partially examined relative to the facts about his vessel. The captain's statements, as well as those of the crew, to say nothing of the evidence found on board the schooner itself, abundantly prove that she ran the blockade with a cargo of turpentine from Newbern, N.C.; but there will doubtless be an attempt to prove that the cargo changed hands at Bermuda when the schooner touched, before coming to this port. The captain claims that his destination after leaving Bermuda was Halifax, but that he put into this port in distress. The schooner has been libeled by the District-Attorney as a North Carolina vessel, and there is abundant evidence to justify her confiscation as a prize to the United States Government, and not a little tending to implicate the British Consul at Bermuda, in the attempt to violate the blockade established by this Government.

abstract: While Gen. DIX was  Secretary of the Treasury, under Mr. BuCHANAN, he gave an order in the revenue service that electrified the country. It was about the first defiance that treason had received. The order was substantially this: "If any man attempts to haul down the American flag, shoot him on the Spot."
lead_paragraph: -- While Gen. DIX was Secretary of the Treasury, under Mr. BuCHANAN, he gave an order in the revenue service that electrified the country. abstract: tention has been called to the fact that, in soliciting recruits, promises have been held out in certain quarters that the soldiers will receive bounty land at the close of his term of service. While this may possibly be the case, since it corresponds with the custom of the Government, if is proper to say that Congress has made no provision for such grants; and that a pledge of them is a highly discreditable false pretence, which should east suspicion upon the motives and honesty of those who make them. All the Government contracts to give the soldier is his food, clothing, and more liberal pay than is offered to any soldiery in the world. Such inducements do not need to be eked out with lies.

abstract: The Twenty-first Regiment of Massachusetts Volunteers, enlisted for the war, arrived at Jersey City yesterday morning at 6 o'clock. They struck tents at the Agricultural Grounds, Worcester, on Friday morning, and were presented by the ladies with a splendid regimental banner. They arrived here on the steamer Connecticut, in fine health, and ready for action. They are generally hearty and robust young men, well calculated to sustain the hardships of a soldier's life. They are dressed like the other regiments from the Old Bay State, and are armed with the smooth-bore Springfield musket of 1849, -- a very inferior arm. They have twenty-five camp wagons, besides ambulances and hospital wagons, and 150 horses. They are accompanied by an excellent Band, enlisted for the war. One of the companies -- mainly from Worcester -- has the French Zouave uniform. Thetotal number of men is 1,045. The following is the list of officers:

abstract: The Washington Star hears that an effort is being made by gentlemen connected with the Masonic fraternity in Virginia to obtain the body of Col. CAMERON, of the New-York Seventy-ninth Regiment, for his widow. For this purpose four gentlemen of Alexandria went to the Confederate lines, and made their request to be allowed to have the body, and returned encouraged to believe that they will be successful. With this effort the Government has nothing to do.

abstract: Looking back over the course of the Produce market since our last review, great changes and fluctuations are to be noticed, and at the close a very large decline on leading articles. Flour has been  active and prices better, but the previous improvement has all been lost in the last few days, and it is lower than a week ago.
lead_paragraph: Looking back over the course of the Produce market since our last review, great changes and fluctuations are to be noticed, and at the close a very large decline on leading articles. Flour has been active and prices better, but the previous improvement has all been lost in the last few days, and it is lower than a week ago. In Wheat, very great fluctuation have been experienced, depression and buoyancy succeeding each other until Monday, since which the decline has been large and rapid, amounting to 7c.@8c. on Spring and 8c.@10c. on Winter, and closing very much unsettled. Corn has been dull, and declining most of the time, and is fully 1c. lower at the close than a week ago, and still tending downward. Oats have varied more or less, but close steady at 1c. decline. Rye has been firm and closes active. Barley unsettled and nearly nominal on account of scarcity. Grass Seed yet unsettled; not enough offering to establish the market. Vegetables more plenty, and Potatoes especially are dull at a large decline. Highwines are moderately active but steady. Alcohol quiet. Naval Stores have experienced a remarkable advance, and are still buoyant. Live Stock markets have ruled active, and prices rather better for both Cattle and Hogs, but at the close Hogs are in less demand and prices hardly sustained, while Cattle are in moderate supply and very firm. Hides active and firmer. Tallow active, but steady.

abstract: COLLISION TWO MEN DROWNED. About 7  o'clock on Friday evening, the Fulton Ferry-boat Peconic ran down a boat in which three men were rowing down the East River. Two men named JOHN SULLIVAN and EUGENE SULLIVAN, both residents of Water-street, in this City, were drowned.
lead_paragraph: COLLISION -- TWO MEN DROWNED. -- About 7 o'clock on Friday evening, the Fulton Ferry-boat Peconic ran down a boat in which three men were rowing down the East River. Two men named JOHN SULLIVAN and EUGENE SULLIVAN, both residents of Water-street, in this City, were drowned. The third, who, by a curious coincidence, bears the name of JOHN SULLIVAN, was rescued and taken to the City Hospital, where he lies in great pain, having been struck by the paddle and badly bruised. His injuries, however, are thought to be mainly external and not serious. The survivor states that he was employed on board the sloop Lucy Edwards, lying at Pier No. 19, East River, and that the drowned men -- whose bodies have not been recovered -- requested him to take thom in the sloop's boat down to Peck-slip, with some wood and clothing which they had. Mr. SULLIVAN's brother being mate of the sloop, he felt at liberty to use the boat. Accordingly, the three embarked, and were run down as above stated. The surviving JOHN SULLIVAN, who is a sailor of 40 years, has a wife and nine children, who reside at South Boston, Mass.

abstract: After the review of Gen. McCALL's Brigade, on Wednesday, by Gen. McCLELLAN, the Commissioned Officers were called forward, They marched up to Gen. McCLELLAN, who, with uncovered head, saluted them and made a brief address part of which was lost to us by the unfavorable position we occupied. He said that he was proud of the display there witnessed, and that the President and Secretary of war had expressed much gratification at their fine appearance and perfection in drill. We have here the material for as fine an army as the world ever saw, and it is to you that the world look to do honor to Pennsylvania. A Pennsylvanian myself, I feel that upon your action will depend my own reputation. He asked them to continue to drill their men, morning, noon and evening, until every man knew the meaning of all the orders that were ever given. With a quiet salutation they withdrew, and the troops marched off to their camps. Gen. McCLELLAN then, surrounded by two companies of cavalry, moved off towards Gen. COUCH's brigade. The scene as the different regiments deployed off the field, around the hilltops, on a circuit of a mile or two, on the way to their camps, was one seldom witnessed, and for military grandeur rarely equaled. But fifty or sixty civilians were present, among whom were the following Philadelphians: John M. Coleman, Jacob Dock, A.S. Bright, Martin Thomas, George Bead, and Richard Moore.
lead_paragraph: After the review of Gen. McCALL's Brigade, on Wednesday, by Gen. McCLELLAN, the Commissioned Officers were called forward, They marched up to Gen. abstract: "An important commercial regulation," says the Richmond Enquirer, "has been adopted by the Confederate Congress in its enactment of the extension of the prohibition of the exportation of cotton, except through the Confederate ports. The extension covers rice, sugar, molasses and syrups. The prohibition is to be continued during the existence of the blockade, and is fortified by severe penalties, amounting to fine or imprisonment of the person violating the same, and the forfeiture to the Government of any steamboat or railroad car engaged in the transportation of these staples to an illegal port."

abstract: This morning Gen. ROBERT ANDERSON, accompanied by Hon. HORACE MAYNARD, of Tenn., and others, visited the Navy-yard and witnessed the artillery practice of the gunners under the supervision of Commandant DAHLGREN. The firing, with a 12-pound boat howitzer, was performed with great rapidity, making four shots in thirteen seconds. So rapid, in fact, were the shots made that, before the report of the exploded shell had died away, the piece would be run up to its position, sponged, loaded, and another shell sent screaming over the river, dashing the spray far and near by the shower of falling missiles.

abstract: The disaster which has befallen the Army of the United States is undoubtedly a great one, though we cannot say that it was wholly unexpected, and still less that it is irretrievable. Vast bodies of men new to arms, unversed in the ordinary evolutions of warfare, and almost as much so. In regimental discipline, are brought face to face with one of the most difficult, tasks that soldiers can be called upon to perform, and they prove unequal to it. In this there is nothing wonderful.

abstract: The act of the Convention of the people of Western Virginia in proposing to erect that district into a new State, to be called the State of Kanawha, is calling down much harsher censure, from a portion of the public Press, than the proceeding deserves.
lead_paragraph: The act of the Convention of the people of Western Virginia in proposing to erect that district into a new State, to be called the State of Kanawha, is calling down much harsher censure, from a portion of the public Press, than the proceeding deserves. Without intending to commit ourselves, at present, on the expediency or wisdom of the movement we think it due to the loyal citizens of that portion of the Union, who have braved everything for the Government they love, to present their action in the most favorable light that justice will allow.

abstract: The natives of the old Granite State, residing in California, have prepared a magnificent flag for the First Regiment New-Hampshire Volunteers,which was the first regiment to embark for the war, and is now stationed on the banks of the Potomac. It is composed of companies from various parts of the State, and is equipped in excellent style. The flag is of exact regimental size, about six feet long, made of the finest silk that could be found in the market. It is trimmed with a heavy fringe of gold bullion, and the starsare embroidered upon she blue with the same material. The staff is to be obtained in the [???] because it could not be conveniently attached here; but all the trimmings of the staff are made here, and are of silver. These trimmings are -- a battle-ax, weighingseveral pounds, for the head of the staff; a point for the bottom, a catch for the belt, a plate for the inscription, and rings for fastening the flag to the staff. The plate bears the following legend: "Presented to the First Regiment of New-Hampshire Volunteers, by natives of the State, now residents of California. San Francisco, July 4, 1861." In the centre of the blue there is a painting on each side. On one side is a National shield lying flat, with an American eagle standing upon it, flapping his wings and screaming. Upon the other side are the State shields of California and New-Hampshire united. Minerva, the grizzly bear, the pan and pick represent the State of Gold, while the sun rising over the sea, a beach with a ship house, and a ship on the stocks, are from the escutcheon of the Granite State. The Paintings are fine works of art in their style, and were done by NAHL. The embroidery was done under the superintendence of T. ROGERS, and the sewing by Mrs. ROGERS, of GROVER & BAKER's establishment. The silverwork cost about $200, and the silk trimmings, &c., $300 more. The flag will be sent Eastward on the steamer of the 1st. The subscribers are to meet next Monday at noon, at No. 14 Montgomery Block, to receive the flag from the Committee.

abstract: At the outbreak of the rebellion, we took occasion to show that, if successful, it must lead to a consolidated despotism, in which State lines would be necessarily effaced. Southern society rests upon force, in violation of natural right, and must be sustained in the same way. It would be speedily dissolved,...
lead_paragraph: At the outbreak of the rebellion, we took occasion to show that, if successful, it must lead to a consolidated despotism, in which State lines would be necessarily effaced. Southern society rests upon force, in violation of natural right, and must be sustained in the same way. It would be speedily dissolved, could investigation and inquiry be left free to test its institutions by the ordinary process of induction. For the same reason that the slave must not assert his right to freedom, the white man must not argue against the social or political economy of the system. The most inexorable of all despotisms, that which silences the tongue, must prevail. Whoever transgresses is forthwith ostracised. The habits and necessities of the people gradually enact themselves into laws and political institutions, and rapidly, when a great crisis supervenes. Such a one is now present in the South. The old ties and relations are dissolved, and new ones are to be formed, and it is only natural that a rebellion commenced for the perpetuation of Slavery, should adapt the Government it seeks to form to its great object, which can only be accomplished by a military despotism, unchecked and untrammeled by political or State boundaries, or local habits or peculiarities. Homogenousness is the prime necessity, and must be had and maintained, no matter how.
headline: {'main': 'Conflict at the South Between Consolidated and Local Despotisms.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Conflict at the South Between Consolidated and Local Despotisms.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Tribune the other day gave a neat and comprehensive programme for the war, the authorship of which it attributed to some "astute youth" of its imagination, but which is marvelously like the plan lately advocated by itself with such vehement iteration: "Just, march down there" these are the words  "crush out the rebellion, and return quietly to your homes." Brief, beautiful and dra-...
lead_paragraph: -- The Tribune the other day gave a neat and comprehensive programme for the war, the authorship of which it attributed to some "astute youth" of its imagination, but which is marvelously like the plan lately advocated by itself with such vehement iteration: "Just, march down there" -- these are the words -- "crush out the rebellion, and return quietly to your homes." Brief, beautiful and dramatic; three brief acts, and then -- music by the band! It is not, however, in connection with fields of blood, nor the great march to Richmond, that our cotemporary now puts forth this remarkable bit of strategy. He has already broken his sword and thrown away the scabbard, and so can only display his tactical talent surreptiously in articles on other, and, as EMERSON would say, the otherest subjects. This time it is brought in in a very odd place. A few days ago the TIMES suggested a feasible and simple plan for the relief of the most helpless and suffering class in the community, the unemployed industrial women of the City -- just as months ago it had suggested feasible plans for the capture of Richmond. It was shown that many of the trades and industries which ordinarily furnish employment to tens of thousands of young women in New-York, were now utterly collapsed, and that consequently many thousands of these women were now idle and penniless; and it was suggested that now would be an opportune moment to put in operation some of the schemes discussed in bygone years for introducing them to appropriate employments, from which they are now virtually excluded, as shopwomen, accountants, clerks, waitresses, and-so-forth. This suggestion, simple, practical and practicable, the Tribune of course does not like. It says it is "profound and of a serene fixedness;" then it slyly introduces the military programme we have quoted, attributing it to an "astute youth;" then recommends the hapless girls to charity and the needle, and winds up by saying: "May we not confide in the sex to sustain and comfort itself?" It is hard to make out whether the article is military, benevolent or comic. But, nevertheless, we still think that employment such as we proposed is better than charity, and that the needle can furnish but a poor refuge, in these days of sewingmachines, to the tens of thousands of young women now idle and destitute; and, moreover, we are glad to inform the Tribune that our suggestion has been adopted by more than one business house, with the best results. It is practicable, however, on a widely-extended scale; and we, still believe that it would result in great and permanent advantage to both sexes.

abstract: -- A most fiendish murder was commuted near Wheelersburgh, Scioto County, on Sunday night of last week. A Mr. POWELL, a widower, was sleeping with his only two small children in a bed in the lower story of his house, and during the night a teriffic explosion took place in the room, instantly killing the two children, and injuring Mr. POWELL so that he died next morning. A hired woman and her child who were sleeping in a trundle bed in the same room, were also badly injured but will probably recover.

lead_paragraph: A great many lists of gunboats, purchased vessels, and chartered vessels have recently been published. It is needless to say that there is not one of them perfect, as the Navy Department will not, and we believe cannot, furnish a complete and accurate statement of the craft now in its employ. The list printed by us some weeks since was by far the fullest given out. Every craft known to be hired or bought since is added to it, as below. Vessels having a + attached are gunboats; those owned by the Government are marked *.

abstract: The Richmond Enquirer says; "It has been decided to change the formation of the Hampton Legion. The infantry battalion is to be increased to a regiment of ten companies, the cavalry will comprise five companies, and there will be an increase of field pieces in their company of flying artillery. With these numbers Col. HAMPTON will be doubtless raised to the rank of Brigadier, and the infantry regiment will have a Colonel, Lieutenant-Colonel, and Major. The officers of cavalry and artillery will be the same as formerly."

abstract: AMERICANS vs. ENGLISH. -- The second annual match between the English and American cricketers of Long Island was played at Bedford, yesterday, in the presence of an unusually large crowd of spectators, there being considerable interest manifested in the result. The game was well played throughout, but on the part of the Americans the fielding was not up to their usual high standard, and to their deficiency in this respect many attribute the loss of the match. It was one of the shortest games on record, considering the scores that were made -- the whole match only occupying six hours, the actual time of playing the four innings being four hours and thirty minutes. The score is as follows:
lead_paragraph: AMERICANS vs. ENGLISH. -- The second annual match between the English and American cricketers of Long Island was played at Bedford, yesterday, in the presence of an unusually large crowd of spectators, there being considerable interest manifested in the result. abstract: "We feel that we have a Commander-in-chief -the selection of President DAVIS, and,as we are informed, his early companion-in-arms, and loug his intimate companion and friend -- in whose hands our defence against the mighty dangers which threatens us is secure -- whose sagacity, energy and valor will guard our State, against the attacks of the enemy, at whatever points they may be attempted. It is an affecting spectacle to see a distinguished Christian pastor, eminent for talents, learning and piety, returning to his early profession of arms at the call of his country, and assuming the responsible and perilous task of defending our homes and firesides from a ruthless and murderous enemy. It imparts an additional sanctity to the holy cause of Southern freedom and independence, on which has 50 far rested the visible smile of the God of battles."
lead_paragraph: "We feel that we have a Commander-in-chief -the selection of President DAVIS, and,as we are informed, his early companion-in-arms, and loug his intimate companion and friend -- in whose hands our defence against the mighty dangers which threatens us is secure -- whose sagacity, energy and valor will guard our State, against the attacks of the enemy, at whatever points they may be attempted. It is an affecting spectacle to see a distinguished Christian pastor, eminent for talents, learning and piety, returning to his early profession of arms at the call of his country, and assuming the responsible and perilous task of defending our homes and firesides from a ruthless and murderous enemy. It imparts an additional sanctity to the holy cause of Southern freedom and independence, on which has 50 far rested the visible smile of the God of battles."

abstract: If we were to say, without attempting to prove it, that the United States has nearly as many naval sailors afloat to-day as England, there is no doubt that a large number of intelligent persons would be tempted to smile incredulously at us. But that circumstance would not alter the facts of the case, nevertheless. There is hardly any subject, in connection with British naval resources, so thoroughly misunderstood with us, as the available manual material of the Royal Navy. The recent efforts to establish a naval reserve, and their total failure, do not seem to have opened any one's eyes on the matter. The general impression which prevails in America, and indeed in Eng and, is that Her Majesty has 70,000 sailors, or there abouts, afloat. This is frequently confirmed by editorials in the London Press, backed up often by statistics as to the number of persons for whose support and remuneration the Navy estimates provide.

There is hardly any subject, in connection with British naval resources, so thoroughly misunderstood with us, as the available manual material of the Royal Navy. abstract: By order of the Surveyor of the Port, the schooner Alabama which has been for several days past loading at Pier No. 8, North River, was seized and towed to the Atlantic Dock, where she will be overhauled and her papers examined. Various circumstances combined to warrant the suspicion that this schooner was laying in a cargo for a Southern port, intending to run the blockade, and yesterday it was ascertained that she had changed hands, the new owner purporting to be one JOHN E. BILLUPS who, on being questioned by the Surveyor, said the craft was bound for Washington, but could not give the name of any responsible person in that city to whom he was known, nor did he have the appearance of a bona fide owner of a cargo worth at least $15,000. The shipper of the cargo, one J. STARKEY, was sent for, who made his appearance in a condition far from sober, and whose equivocations and contradictory statements confirmed the suspicions at first entertained. The cargo of the schooner consists of salt, leather, whisky, brandy, mackerel, tanners-oil, butter and other stores of this kind, whose possession at the present time would be very acceptable almost anywhere in the boundaries of the C.S.A., but which are not likely to be wafted thither by the schooner Alabama for several days to come.

abstract: Through the especial kindness of. Col. BURKE, Commanding Officer at Fort Hamilton, we were last week permitted to reconnoitre these premises, which are at present the seat of so much interest. Everything
lead_paragraph: Through the especial kindness of. Col. BURKE, Commanding Officer at Fort Hamilton, we were last week permitted to reconnoitre these premises, which are at present the seat of so much interest. Everything has a business look, from the domestic every-day proceedings within the battlements, to the ugly sixty-four pounders peeping over the seaward ramparts, on the alert for any audacious crafts that would fain give the slip to such awful bores. The redout remains unfurnished with artillery as yet.

abstract: learn from the New-Orleans Picayune of the 15th inst., that the steam frigate Mississippi and the St. Louis have joined the Brooklyn in the blockade of the mouth of the Mississippi River. abstract: The inhabitants of the Twentieth Ward were aroused on Saturday morning by the startling intelligence of a murder in their midst.
lead_paragraph: The inhabitants of the Twentieth Ward were aroused on Saturday morning by the startling intelligence of a murder in their midst. It was rumored man, on Friday evening, a person whose habits had not been exemplary had been caught in a theft, had fatally stabbed the person who had caught him, had been taken into custody by the Police of the Twentieth Ward, and was under arrest at the Twentieth Ward Station-house, where an inquest would be held. Thousands flocked to the Station-house at an early hour, and blockaded the street. Intense excitement prevailed. Of course the doors of the Station-house were closed to all but the representatives of the Press, the Coroners and their assistants, the jury and the witnesses.

abstract: An interesting question with Virginia farmers is, what to do with their wheat. The Confederate Government is also interested in the same question. The probability is that we shall have at least 400,000 men in the field for the next twelve months. These will require, at a moderate calculation, 1,600,000 barrels of flour, or 8,000,000 bushels of wheat. We suppose the crop of the State will not exceed 12,000,000 bushels. Of this amount, about half will be needed for seed and family use, as distinguished from the military. At this calculation, there would remain 6,000,000 bushels for sale -- not enough to supply the demand of the Government by 2,000,000. We do not know, but suppose North Carolina, Tennessee and Georgia make fully 2,000,000 more than requisite for their own consumption.

abstract: We learn that Col. VINTON, Deputy Quartermaster-General of the United States Army for the City of New-York, has, by the advice of Gen. MEIGS, appointed Hon. GEORGE A. SHAW, of Boston, Inspector-General of all the Army goods being manufactured for Government under the bids recently accepted in New-York, and that his special duties for the present are to visit the factories where the work is being done and goods manufactured, with the standard sealed samples of all the Government goods, and see that contractors produce goods equally as good and made from best of materials.
lead_paragraph: We learn that Col. VINTON, Deputy Quartermaster-General of the United States Army for the City of New-York, has, by the advice of Gen. MEIGS, appointed Hon. GEORGE A. SHAW, of Boston, Inspector-General of all the Army goods being manufactured for Government under the bids recently accepted in New-York, and that his special duties for the present are to visit the factories where the work is being done and goods manufactured, with the standard sealed samples of all the Government goods, and see that contractors produce goods equally as good and made from best of materials.

abstract: A Southern Journal says: "The Confederate States Supreme Court will hold no session until it shall be organized under the provisions of the permanent Constitution. Under the Constitution of the Provisional Government it was provided that the Supreme Court shall be constituted of all the District Judges, and shall sit at such times and places as Congress shall appoint. Under the permanent Constitution, however, the Supreme Court has not been established; during theexisting hiatus in our judiciary system, the Clerks of District Courts are empowered to issue writs of error with the same force and as if issued out of the Supreme Court, and returnable on the second Monday of its first term after its establishment.
lead_paragraph: A Southern Journal says: "The Confederate States Supreme Court will hold no session until it shall be organized under the provisions of the permanent Constitution. Under the Constitution of the Provisional Government it was provided that the Supreme Court shall be constituted of all the District Judges, and shall sit at such times and places as Congress shall appoint. Under the permanent Constitution, however, the Supreme Court has not been established; during theexisting hiatus in our judiciary system, the Clerks of District Courts are empowered to issue writs of error with the same force and as if issued out of the Supreme Court, and returnable on the second Monday of its first term after its establishment.

abstract: The Monroe Coun  ty Bank of this City has a claim against the Brockport Exchange Bank, lately suspended, for collections, to the amount of $1,200. When the Brockport institution suspended, an assignment was made in favor of three classes of creditors. First, the State of New-York for Canal deposits, of which $19,000 were held. Second, sundry parties for whom collections had been made with instructions to remit immediately; and third, all other creditors.

abstract: This regiment, which has been encamped at Augusta, Me., for some time past, broke camp on Friday, and proceeded to Boston en route for Washington. On Friday evening the regiment embarked on the steamer Bay State for this City. Shortly after 10 o'clock, yesterday morning, the Bay State arrived off Pier No. 4 North River. The men did not land, but were at once transferred to the steamer Red Jacket and taken to Elizabethport, whence they took the cars for Washington.

abstract: The War Department, on Aug. 21, received a telegraphic dispatch from Gen. ROSECRANS, giving the gratifying intelligence that he and his command are all right, and if they should happen to meet with LEE or LORING he will enact RichMountain and Carricksford over again, and with like results. The command is in fine condition, and eager to drive the rebels out of Western Virginia once more.

abstract: Gens. WOOL and BUTLER have spent a part of to-day at the Rip Raps, experimenting with SAWYER'S gun. The second shell thrown burst in the Confederate camp at Sewall's Point, which broke down the flag-staff and scattered the rebels-like chaff. A propeller which was landing troops at the Point, put back towards Norfolk. The whole affair was witnessed from the Newport's News steamer.

abstract: TAYLOR, of this City, has received orders not to mail any copies of the Journal of Commerce, Daily News, Freeman's Journal, and perhaps of some other less important secession journals of this latitude. We can but repeat the opinion on this subject heretofore expressed. If the journals in question are treasonable, and subversive of the authority and integrity of the Government, so much so that their circulation is unsafe, it is absolute trifling with a grave subject to allow of their publication. Each step so far taken is only an advertisement of the papers -- a recommendation of them to the traitors of Maryland, Kentucky and Missouri; a guarantee of enthusiastic sympathy and support, not only from the traitors in those States, but from the traitors of New-York, Pennsylvania, Connecticut, and every part of the Union. And the mail failing to disseminate the journals, a hundred avenues will speedily be found, whereby they will be disseminated wherever rebel malevolence shall choose to send them. The present policy of the Government is merely an annoyance to the secession prints -- it is not a corrective of the evil complained of.

abstract: This question has already taken strong possession of the minds of the people of the United States -- we might say of every mind -- and cannot be put aside until; answered. It could not be otherwise. The stern logic and rousing eloquence of passing events are forcing everybody to entertain this question, and to look for the solution of it with the deepest interest. Few, perhaps, are prepared as yet to answer it in the affirmative, but it is well that the subject be carefully and patiently examined, that we may be prepared to give it a satisfactory and united answer in due time.

abstract: The writer attended the concert at the Central Park last Saturday, and was delighted to find assembled at the end of the Mall a crowded audience o many thousands of well dressed and orderly, though heated and fatigued persons. With the simple fact that the announcement of out-of-door music is enough to draw at least twenty thousand people out of the City, of whom two-thirds are willing to walk a mile of a hot afternoon, and that such an audience will be quiet and orderly, his delight ends.. The concert arrangements were entirely inadequate to such an audience. The canvas canopies under which a small part of the crowd obtained shelter from the sun, together with the crowd itself, absorbed and deadened the music so that in no direction could it be heard with satisfaction. Within a hundred feet there was a carriage road, whereon the passage of vehicles and the attempt to set down passengers, constantly, created a noisy turmoil. It is not too much to say that of all the host who were really attracted to the Park by the promise of such music as the announcement gave all reason to expect, every, one must have been, disappointed.

abstract: We wish to call the attention of all our Generals on the Potomac, and in Western Virginia, to what we regard as probably the real danger now menacing the Capital. The care of our military authorities has been for some weeks past so earnestly addressed to the strengthening of their lines on the heights of Arlington, in Virginia, and ...
lead_paragraph: We wish to call the attention of all our Generals on the Potomac, and in Western Virginia, to what we regard as probably the real danger now menacing the Capital. The care of our military authorities has been for some weeks past so earnestly addressed to the strengthening of their lines on the heights of Arlington, in Virginia, and more recently of those on the Northern approaches to Washington, that we have very little apprehension of any direct attack upon the position of our Army there. But there is a point and a danger to which we fear attention has not yet been directed, and we therefore submit our views on that point publicly, that they may the sooner reach every officer who shares the responsibility of a proper defence.

abstract: There appears to be little doubt that the rebel Army at Manassas and in that vicinity is now made more numerous than it has ever been before, whatever its appointments may be. Immediately after the Bull Run battle, the rebel leaders imade extraordinary exertions to concentrate troops in Virginia, in anticipation of another and more formidable demonstration by the National Army, and the result, it is understood, has been the transfer of large forces from Tennessee, which had been held there for the defence of the Mississippi, together with all that could be spared from the Cotton States, including a portion of BRAGG's command at PensacolaIn addition to all this the work of improvement -- for it can be callednothing else -- has been steadily going on in Virginia. The Maryland side of the Potomac is now filled with refugees fron Loudon and other counties, who have fled to avoid this impressment, in some instances driving over their stock to save it from the marauders, and in others leaving everything behind, glad even to escape with their lives. With the immense Army thus raised, it is absolutely necessary that some hostile movement should soon he made by the rebel leaders, but what direction it will take can hardly yet be decided. That it will be directly towards Washington, however, seems now to be doubted by the military authorities.
lead_paragraph: There appears to be little doubt that the rebel Army at Manassas and in that vicinity is now made more numerous than it has ever been before, whatever its appointments may be. The Maryland side of the Potomac is now filled with refugees fron Loudon and other counties, who have fled to avoid this impressment, in some instances driving over their stock to save it from the marauders, and in others leaving everything behind, glad even to escape with their lives. With the immense Army thus raised, it is absolutely necessary that some hostile movement should soon he made by the rebel leaders, but what direction it will take can hardly yet be decided. That it will be directly towards Washington, however, seems now to be doubted by the military authorities.

abstract: The camp where this is dated is the advance post of our Army on the direct road to Alexandria. Our pickets of course are thrown out much further, covering perhaps more ground than we occupied before the advance of the "Grand Army." abstract: MORTALITY.--Health Officer J.B. JONES, M.D., reports 171 deaths in the city of Brooklyn, during the week ending Aug. 24: Men, 22; women, 20; boys, 73; girls, 56; adults, 42; children, 129; under two years of age, 113. Some of the diseases were: Cholera infantum, 52; convulsions, infantile, 18; consumption, 8; marasmus, infantile, 13; teething, 4; scarlet fever, 6; small-pox, 2; diphtheria, 1.

abstract: There is still something wanting to the Northern side in this struggle with the rebels. These men fight with desperation, for they believe they strike for the chastity of wives, the safety of children and homes. Their war-cry is "Death, rather than subjection!" To the masses who do not think, this watch-word is the most exciting appeal.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Tuesday, July 30,1661.
