abstract: Having mixed somewhat extensively with the merchants and tradespeople of England during the past four or five weeks, and discussed in many circles our American troubles, I am able to form a correct opinion as to the feeling of sympathy amongst that particular class. It is almost universally with the North, but at the same time there is an almost universal doubt as to the ability of the North to accomplish what that they undertaken.
lead_paragraph: Having mixed somewhat extensively with the merchants and tradespeople of England during the past four or five weeks, and discussed in many circles our American troubles, I am able to form a correct opinion as to the feeling of sympathy amongst that particular class. It is almost universally with the North, but at the same time there is an almost universal doubt as to the ability of the North to accomplish what that they undertaken. That doubt has been greatly strengthened by the inglorious defeat at Manassas. The strategy of BEAUREGARD, it is thought, in retreating from the minor points of occupation to the strong intrenchments he had for months been erecting, should have been sufficient warning to the least competent official that his object was to entrap them; and I venture to say that when he is dislodged from that stronghold, and our troops enter it, that mines will be exploded which will annihilate half their number, unless a greater precaution is exercised than has been thus far exhibited by our Northern Generals.

abstract: DROWNED. -- Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest yesterday, at No. 20 Greenwich-street, upon the body of JOHN RYAN, a laborer, who was recently drowned at Pier No. 8, East River, where he fell into the dock while engaged in loading a vessel belonging to the New-York and Erie Railroad Company. Deceased was a native of Ireland, 35 years of age.... The body of an unknown person was found, yesterday, in the dock at Pier No. 40, East River, but it was so far advanced in decomposition, that it was impossible to determine either the age or sex of the deceased. Coroner JACKMAN will hold an Inquest on the body to-day.
lead_paragraph: DROWNED. -- Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest yesterday, at No. 20 Greenwich-street, upon the body of JOHN RYAN, a laborer, who was recently drowned at Pier No. 8, East River, where he fell into the dock while engaged in loading a vessel belonging to the New-York and Erie Railroad Company. Deceased was a native of Ireland, 35 years of age.... abstract: According to the Annuaire Encyclopedique, the average number of suicides in each year in France is 3,899, of whom only 842 are females. It is in April, May, June, and July, that they are most frequent, and the age of the greatest number of persons committing them is from 40 to 60. Of the total, 2,833 are accomplished by strangulation or drowning, 271 by suffocation with the fumes of charcoal, 395 by fire-arms, 153 by sharp instruments, 110 by leaping from high places, 93 by poison, and the rest by different means.

lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE, Thursday, Aug. 22, 1861.

abstract: On yesterday, at noon, 214 East Tennesseeans, refugees from Southern tyranny, passed through Danville. Their progress was not that of loud huzzas and acclamations, for spectator and refugee were filled with emotions too deep for utterance. Escorted by a large number of citizens, they marched in silence through the streets to the Seminary yard, where a bountiful dinner was prepared by the generous hospitality of the citizens for their benefit.

abstract: One of the most remarkable events connected with our present war arrangements, is the uniform health of the troops, both at the recruiting stations and also at the various camps about Washington and the Mississippi River. Even when the soldiers have slept for weeks in the open air, unsheltered by tent or roof, lying on the bare, often wet ground, there has been no disease engendered. The change of food, varieties ...
lead_paragraph: One of the most remarkable events connected with our present war arrangements, is the uniform health of the troops, both at the recruiting stations and also at the various camps about Washington and the Mississippi River. Even when the soldiers have slept for weeks in the open air, unsheltered by tent or roof, lying on the bare, often wet ground, there has been no disease engendered. The change of food, varieties of crude diet, beans, alternating with salt pork, green fruit, and even the poisoned gifts of Southern foes, have had no results of a deleterious character worthy the notice. In fact, the health of our troops in Washington, Cairo, Fortresses Monroe and Pickens has averaged better than in the City of New-York in its present, no more than ordinary, hygienic condition. Why this is so, it is not easy to say. For, notwithstanding the publication of little manuals of health, (Dr. Ordronaux's Hints on the Preservation of Health in Armies -- APPLETON's,) the numerous squibs of hygienic value in our various newspapers, the supply of Havelocks and flannels made by the patriotic industry of our ladies, the presence of the ordinary proportion of medical men, or the exertions of the Sanitary Commission, the question is not answered. Any one who has taken the trouble to run his eye over the features of the various corps who have embarked from this City for the South, whether starting from here or in transitu, will have made up his mind that instructive pamphlets or newspaper articles are rarely seen and less noted by the majority of them. The Havelocks worn with such ostentation by the recruit, like the gay ribbons of the French conscript, have, after going through a service as a handkerchief, been discarded as valueless by the veteran of a month's service in camp. The flannel body-bandages which volunteer regimental, surgeons have, with an apparent desire for notoriety, been calling for by the thousand, perhaps may have occasionally been put on by some, mindful of their mother's last directions upon leaving their home, "to take care of their health." But if the dweller in the sweltering casemates of Fort Monroe may have taken an occasional cool day to invest himself in this itching protective, with the first Southern puff flapping the lazy fold of his flag, he has more speedily doffed them.

abstract: The Hamilton Artillery, of Queens County, is one of the oldest light artillery corps on Long Island, its organization dating back over twenty years. The officers now in command, viz.: Capt. ROBINSON and First-Lieut. ROEMER, and others, are artillerists of established reputations, and their battery, on all public reviews, has attracted the favorable notice of military men.
lead_paragraph: The Hamilton Artillery, of Queens County, is one of the oldest light artillery corps on Long Island, its organization dating back over twenty years. The officers now in command, viz.: Capt. ROBINSON and First-Lieut. ROEMER, and others, are artillerists of established reputations, and their battery, on all public reviews, has attracted the favorable notice of military men. Failing to get to the seat of war with the Fifteenth Regiment -- which did not go -- they have since offered their services to the Government, and through the exertions of Mr. SMITH, their Member of Congress, they have been accepted, and ordered to report themselves at Washington. On Saturday evening a public meeting was called of the citizens of Flushing for the purpose of procuring the necessary means to sustain the families of a portion of the company while they are absent. By some misunderstanding, or what is worse, indifference to the object, very few of the wealthy citizens attended. Hon. LUTHER C. CARTER, late member of Congress, presided, and Mr. BAKER was appointed Secretary. Mr. CARTES, commented with some severity upon the lack of patriotic spirit manifested by the well-to-do citizens. Gen. HAMILTON, Capt. ROBINSON, Lieut. ROEMER and others, addressed the meeting in a similar strain, expressing the readiness of their corps to move, provided the citizens would pledge support to the Families. A series of patriotic resolutions was adopted, and the meeting was adjourned to this (Monday) evening, at the Pavilion Hotel, when a final decision will be come to.

abstract: Hugh Lynch and his wife Jane were arrested yesterday, charged with brutally beating Edward Toucy. The injured man was found by the Police early yesterday morning, at No. 433 Hudson-street, bleeding profusely from several wounds upon the head, which he charged Lynch and his wife with having inflicted. They were locked up by Justice QUACKENBUSH, and Toucy was taken to the Hospital.... Charles Mount, ...
lead_paragraph: Hugh Lynch and his wife Jane were arrested yesterday, charged with brutally beating Edward Toucy. The injured man was found by the Police early yesterday morning, at No. 433 Hudson-street, bleeding profusely from several wounds upon the head, which he charged Lynch and his wife with having inflicted. They were locked up by Justice QUACKENBUSH, and Toucy was taken to the Hospital.... Charles Mount, book-keeper for Messrs. Bouton & Bruce, merchants, at No. 87 Walker-street, was arrested on Saturday evening, charged with having embezzled about $180 from his employers. He was brought before Justice OSBORN and committed for trial. The accused resides at No. 47 Henry-street. His father, who is very wealthy, declined to interfere in his behalf..... A man named John Moran was arrested on Saturday night charged with passing a counterfeit $10 bill to Israel Kohn, of No. 218 East Houston-street. He was held by Justice STEERS for examination....Joseph Stevens, a Frenchman, was arrested on a charge of stealing $17 from the pocket of Thomas Reilly, of No. 328 Pearl-street, whilst the latter was asleep upon a bench in the house. He was locked up by Justice OSBORN for trials.... Edward Falconer the street preacher, was arrested again, yesterday for lecturing on temperance to a noisy crowd in the Park. He was taken before Justice OSBORN, who released him on his promise to appear this morning and answer the charge. .... Wm. W. Fowler and Joseph Johnson were arrested, charged with attempting to pick the pocket of a gentleman who was witnessing the march of the Fire Zouaves. The prisoners were taken to court... .. P.H. Moran, and Hepburn alias Madden, a sporting character, got into a fight together at the corner of the Bowery and Bond-street, during which which Madden put his teeth through Moran's ear, inflicting a severe wound.

abstract: The English papers, which lend themselves to the interests of the Slaveholding rebellion, are the victims of disquieting apprehensions lest the British Court or British capital shall be enlisted on the side of the Union. The London Times, surrendering its City Article to fatiguing arguments against the solvency of our Government, offers a thousand reasons, ...
lead_paragraph: The English papers, which lend themselves to the interests of the Slaveholding rebellion, are the victims of disquieting apprehensions lest the British Court or British capital shall be enlisted on the side of the Union. The London Times, surrendering its City Article to fatiguing arguments against the solvency of our Government, offers a thousand reasons, beside the supposed prohibition contained in the Queen's proclamation of neutrality, why British gold should not be exchanged for National bonds. The Saturday Review, the organ of literary snobbery, labors earnestly in the same direction. The vision of a possible advertisement inviting sealed proposals for twenty million pounds sterling, to replenish the empty coffers of Treasurer CHASE, is to these ProSlavery zealots a nightmare, pregnant with unspeakable evils for their Southern protgs, and it will go hard but political economy shall be made to furnish logic enough to defeat the miserable attempt. Why, indeed, should England lend her spare millions to promote a war with which she has no possible concern? That England is not concerned, is one of those convenient assumptions which so much facilitate an otherwise lagging argument.

abstract: The Confederate Junto at Richmond has authorized JEFF. DAVIS to raise for his service an Army four hundred thousand strong, to be composed of cavalry, mounted riflemen, artillery and infantry, in due proportion, and to serve for a period of not less than one nor more than three years.
lead_paragraph: The Confederate Junto at Richmond has authorized JEFF. DAVIS to raise for his service an Army four hundred thousand strong, to be composed of cavalry, mounted riflemen, artillery and infantry, in due proportion, and to serve for a period of not less than one nor more than three years. This, if meant for anything more than mere show and brag, involves a levy en masse of all the white men in the seceded States capable of bearing arms. The whole fighting population of DAVIS' widespread dominions -- all those who "would rather fight than not," as well as those who would rather not fight -- must be put in soldier's clothes in order to make up this number; and even then, it -- is to be feared, there will be fewer soldiers than figures.

abstract: The third concert of the season took place at Central Park on Saturday afternoon, and attracted a very fine attendance of our most respectable classes. The weather was all that could be desired, tempting alike to those who could boast of horseflesh and those who could not. Hence there were more people present than we have witnessed on any previous occasion The vicinity of the music-stand was densely crowded, and in the adjoining drives there were vehicles of all kinds, and in the greatest profusion. A scene ofgreater animation has seldom been witnessed in this City, and, as the best of order prevailed, we may safety refer to it as one of the most pleasurable days of the year. At the appointed hour Mr. DODWORTH assumed the baton, and, under its influence, a varied programme was admirably interpreted. A couple of hours were passed amid healthful and charming influences, and when the throng separated it was with good wishes toward the patrons of music who had furnished them with so excellent an entertainment. The numbers present can hardly be estimated, but those who are dexterous in such matters say that there were not less than twenty thousand persons.

abstract: There seems to have been quite an eruption of white flags, last week, over in the State of Connecticut. The simultaneousnees of the attack is evidence of concert of action. It is an artful attempt to convert sporadic treason into a peace epidemic. The scheme does not seem to prosper; for before the white flag goes up, the starry ensign of the Republic must come down. So Mr. WIGFALL stated to Major ANDERSON when Fort Sumter was bombarded and on fire.

abstract: Recruiting for the Army here is still exceedingly dull. There were about eighteen men enlisted for all the old regular regiments last week at the offices in this neighborhood, and two or three detachments arrived from Buffalo and Rochester. The new Twelfth Regiment has from 150 to 175 soldiers, all told, at its head-quarters in Fort Hamilton. The difficulty of augmenting their number was found to be so great, that an additional office had to be opened for recruiting in this City on Thursday last. Indeed, it is said that the Broadway establishment did not get four men during the past six days.

abstract: A war is not necessarily incompatible with a prosperous condition of a country engaged in it,--in fact, it may give an extraordinary impulse to its industries by the demand created for its products, and by the universal energy and activity which it excites. The commercial and manufacturing interests of England made vast progress during the whole period of her colossal wars with France.
lead_paragraph: A war is not necessarily incompatible with a prosperous condition of a country engaged in it, -- in fact, it may give an extraordinary impulse to its industries by the demand created for its products, and by the universal energy and activity which it excites. The commercial and manufacturing interests of England made vast progress during the whole period of her colossal wars with France. Her command of the ocean ensured security at home, and kept open for her the markets of the world. With the exception of Ireland, no hostile foot trod her soil, so that industry and enterprise had at all times full scope. The Low Countries were never more powerful, nor hardly more prosperous than during the terrible wars so long waged for their independence against Philip the Second. Their territories were for generations the battle-ground of Europe, and their political existence threatened by powerful foes on every side. Yet, in the midst of these long wars, theirs was the richest country on the Continent, in ratio to its area and population. The Dutch and Flemings are by nature a laborious, pains-taking and thrifty people, and so adapted their habits to their conditions that they were equally expert with implements of destruction or industry, and were always ready to assume either, as the occasion called.

abstract: Considerable excitement was created in Evansville, Ind., on Monday morning, by the arrest of a man charged with being a recruiting-officer for the Confederate Army. The circumstances of the arrest, as stated by the Journal, are as follows: Last Sunday, during the examination of the steamer Samuel Orr by Capt. WOOD, a trunk was
lead_paragraph: Considerable excitement was created in Evansville, Ind., on Monday morning, by the arrest of a man charged with being a recruiting-officer for the Confederate Army. The circumstances of the arrest, as stated by the Journal, are as follows: Last Sunday, during the examination of the steamer Samuel Orr by Capt. WOOD, a trunk was discovered for which no owner could be found. The Captain at once took the trunk to the warehouse,when it was opened and several treasonable letters were brought to light. On Monday a stranger appeared at the warehouse and demanded the trunk taken from the Orr. Capt. WOOD at once arrested him and took him before Surveyor ROBINSON, who sent him to Camp Vanderburg. The name of the prisoner is JOHN CARTWELL, of the firm of CARTWELL BROTHERS, Caseyville, Ky. One of the letters is from CARTWELL to Lieut. CHARLES SEMPLE, Louisville, an officer in the rebel Army. It states that he (CARTWELL) had a talk with Mr. ANDERSON, a bar-keeper at HAMILTON & BROS., Second, between Main and Market streets, Louisville, and that ANDERSON told him that he had 40 men for the Southern Army, but had no means of sending them to Tennessee. CARTWELL also tells SEMPLE that he would try and fill up the latter's company at Caseyville, whither he was bound at the time of his arrest. Copies of letteas, introducing Lieut. SEMPAMLE to JOHN M. BLAIR, of Clarksville, Tenn, as all right on the secesh question, were also found. CARTWELL also expresses the hope of meeting Lieut. SEMPLE very soon at Camp Boone, the head-quarters of the Kentucky traitors. CARTWELL will be held until orders are received from Gov. MORTON as to his disposal. He is apparently an intelligent man, writes well, and should have been sharp enough to have confined his operations to lower latitudes.

abstract: We stated a short time ago, says the Louisville Journal, that two young men, named BUSBEY and HARP, arrived in this city, from Hickman County, Kentucky, having been driven from their homes by the Secessionists of Southern Kentucky and Tennessee. Three large families, numbering fully twenty-five souls, arrived from the same vicinity, yesterday, and stopped at the Oyler House, on Market street. The heads of the families were JOHN BOSWELL, JOHN BUSBEY, and WM. HARP. Their condition is really deplorable. They were forced to leave their farms at a few hours' notice, leaving their crops and household goods at the mercy of the heartless rebels. They traveled with the aged and infirm, and youthful and tender members of their families from Hickman County, in wagons, and encountered many hardships. They inform us that fully fitty families in Hickman and Ballard Counties have been forced to leave their homes, and to abandon their crops and nearly all they possessed in the world, their offence being that they entertained Union sentiments.

abstract: The ship Universe, Capt. MORRISON, from Liverpool, 46 days, with merchandise to WILLIAMS & GUYON, reports: "Had heavy westerly winds for 30 days. On the eastern edge of the Banks signalised a British bark, from London for St. Johns, N.B., 49 days out and short of provisions. Aug. 16, in lat. 43° 20', lon. 55° 30', was chased by a low, rakish, fullrigged brig, during the middle watch. She came bearing down from the northeast, under whole topsails and courses, it blowing hard from northwest, with a heavy cross sea, the wind having shifted about an hour previous from southwest. The Universe was under double-reefed topsails and courses at the time. At 4 A.M. the brig passed to windward, and when about a quarter of a mile ahead crossed the weather bow, and ran off southeast. She was evidently a brig-of-war, for her ports were plainly in sight, and lights could be seen through them about her deck.

abstract: United States Marshal MURRAY seized at the office of the American Express Company, yesterday, several packages of the Daily News, amounting altogether to about 5,000 copies, destined for St. Louis and St. Joseph, Mo., and Louisville, Ky. One large package was directed to GRAY & CRAWFORD, St. Louis; two large packages to S.H. HUMMELL and A. GUNTHER, Louisville, and several small packages to various parties at the above-named places. The seizure was made on the Marshal's own responsibility, without special orders from Washington.

abstract: There is nothing like a definite object as a stimulant to energetic action, and nothing like assigning each man to the duty for which he is fitted, if we would reap the best result at the lowest cost. Up to this time the grand idea has been the defence of Washington.
lead_paragraph: There is nothing like a definite object as a stimulant to energetic action, and nothing like assigning each man to the duty for which he is fitted, if we would reap the best result at the lowest cost. Up to this time the grand idea has been the defence of Washington. For this purpose we have been collecting at and about it an, army of nearly 100,000 men. But we shall soon be in a position to assume something better than a defensive attitude. To crush the rebellion we must move forward into the territory where it exists, and derives its chief support. In what manner shall the advance be made?

abstract: The Government feeling the necessity for more extended and more thorough operations with the Artillery arm of the service, and with a view to attaining  this object in the quickest possible time, has commis  sioned Commander BRICKEL to raise four battalions, each battalion forming one full battery, with power to select his officers from among the best throughout the country. Commander BRICKEL is well known as one of
lead_paragraph: The Government feeling the necessity for more extended and more thorough operations with the Artillery arm of the service, and with a view to attaining this object in the quickest possible time, has commis sioned Commander BRICKEL to raise four battalions, each battalion forming one full battery, with power to select his officers from among the best throughout the country. Commander BRICKEL is well known as one of the best artillerists now in America, he having served under Gen. SIEGEL throughout the Baden revolution as Chief of Artillery. Among the officers already selected by him is Capt. ARNDT, who constructed the celebrated Dueppler Schanzen, in Holstein. The head-quarters of the corps is at No. 52 Franklin-street, where already some 250 or 300 good men have enrolled their names. The location of the corps is at present at Conrad's Park, Yorkville. Rations, pay, and uniforms are guaranteed from the day of enlistment. Patriotic citizens, who feel disposed to further an enterprise in which the Government feels an especial interest, may send in subscriptions to Capt. ARNDT, Capt. VOEGELEE, or Quartermaster LOEWENTHAL, who have been selected as a Finance Committee.

abstract: miles, and came to Danville, Ky., in a body -- some with only shreds of shirts, many with no coats and no shoes; and with trowsers tattered and threadbare. After the hungry exiles had been fed by the hospitable people of Danville, one of their number, an old man, made a brief speech, and said that they had left their property, their wives and children, their homes, everything, and fled through the mountains, to old Kentucky, to escape the Secession patrols, who were exacting obedience to the authorities of the Confederate States. They might have all remained at home, lived well, and been unmolested by merely raising a "white flag;" but, said the old man, pointing to the flag that waved hard by -- For sixty years I have looked up to those 'Stars and Stripes,' and, if the Lord lets me, I intend to look up to them sixty years longer." It is stated that every man of the exiled band proceeded, next day, to the Union camp, in Garrard County, adjoining the County that received them, and enlisted in the National service. There is a moral in this movement for Northern traitors to profit by. If Southern patriots brave poverty, exile and death, rather than raise a "white flag" to JEFF. DAVIS, can we not hold out a little longer?

abstract: DANIEL C. LOWBER., who was arrested at Crestline, Ohio, by Detective KING, of this City, charged with being a bearer of dispatches from England to JEFF. DAVIS, was yesterday removed from the quarters he has occupied for a few days at the Central Police Office, and placed with the other State prisoners in Fort Lafayette. The change was in accordance with directions from the Department of State to the Police Superintendent. LOWBER is said to be a native of this City, but for many years past he has lived at New-Orleans.

abstract: A correspondent, writing from Conklingville, Saratoga County, under date of August 3, gives us some particulars of the murder of Mr. WHEELER, who was killed in Grand Glaize, Arkansas, some weeks ago. He writes: "Mrs. W., who is an amiable and excellent lady, left her home last Fall in company with (I was about to say a gentleman and his wife,) a slave-dealer who married a lady of this County, for their home in Grand Glaize, Arkansas, where she married Mr. WHEELER. She lived a very happy lift up to July the 4th, the day of the death of her husband. Some person in conversation with her husband, asked him whether he was a Union man. His reply was that he might as well be that as anything else. Just at that moment Mrs. W. stepped out to call her husband in to dinner, and as she opened the store-door she heard the report of a gun. Her first impression was that she was herself wounded, but as soon as she recovered from her fright, she saw her husband lying on the floor, extending his arms and looking towards her without the power of utterance. This scene was too much for Mrs. W., and for four days she was entirely unconscious.
lead_paragraph: A correspondent, writing from Conklingville, Saratoga County, under date of August 3, gives us some particulars of the murder of Mr. WHEELER, who was killed in Grand Glaize, Arkansas, some weeks ago. She lived a very happy lift up to July the 4th, the day of the death of her husband. Some person in conversation with her husband, asked him whether he was a Union man. His reply was that he might as well be that as anything else. Just at that moment Mrs. W. stepped out to call her husband in to dinner, and as she opened the store-door she heard the report of a gun. Her first impression was that she was herself wounded, but as soon as she recovered from her fright, she saw her husband lying on the floor, extending his arms and looking towards her without the power of utterance. This scene was too much for Mrs. W., and for four days she was entirely unconscious.

abstract: RIOT. -- On Sunday evening a drunken party attempted to enter a liquor store in Greene-street, Jersey City, kept by MICHAEL CART, but were refused admittance on account of its being Sunday. The party then broke open the door, and destroyed considerable furniture and fixtures. Officers HARNEY, GOFF, and KIPP came up and arrested JOHN MADDOX, the ringleader, when his friends rallied, and in rescuing him, a desperate fight occurred, and the officers were badly beaten. Officer HARNEY received a severe cut on the head with a stone. Chief of Police MARINUS, with a posse of men, soon arrived, and with the aid of citizens, quelled the riot, and 15 of the men were subsequently arrested. Yesterday, Recorder MARTINDALE held them for examination.

abstract: A leading dry goods house in Philadelphia, according to the North American, recently received a letter from a customer in Tennessee inclosing a check for $600, and an order for goods to that amount. The firm responded that as Tennessee had seceded, and was arrayed against the Union, they could not send the goods. On receipt of this letter the Tennessee house wrote again, directing the goods to be sent to a certain direction at Louisville, Ky., by which means, of course, they would have received them. Upon this the Philadelphia firm sent back the check, and declined filling the order at all.

abstract: SUTHERLAND, J. -- In the Matter of Stephen A. Spencer. -- Stephen A. Spencer, a youth of good looks and modest mien, was returned into court on a writ of habeas corpus, directing his Colonel, John W. Latson, to show cause why he should not be discharged. Spencer's father alleges that he was an infant when he enlisted, and that he enlisted without his consent, and claims him as a right. The Colonel on the contrary maintains that he was of the full age of eighteen when he came into his command, and has received the United States rations. There were some questions connected with this case which the Judge required time to consider. He said Judge Hoffman, of the Superior Court, had recently written a learned and elaborate opinion in a similar case before him, which he would wish to consult before arriving at a decision. The boy was accordingly remanded until Wednesday, when the Judge will decide his case.

abstract: Misrepresentations as to the sanitary state of our Army are among the numerous expedients adopted by the busy malcontents whose treasonable efforts to check the ardor for enlistment have been frequently noticed of late in our columns.
lead_paragraph: Misrepresentations as to the sanitary state of our Army are among the numerous expedients adopted by the busy malcontents whose treasonable efforts to check the ardor for enlistment have been frequently noticed of late in our columns. These unfavorable reports are supported by the statements of a few discontented, obscure members of disbanded regiments, and are, for the most part, so absurd and self-contradictory as to impose on no one of ordinary intelligence and information. It is gratifying to find that the sweeping charges thus boldly made can, many of them, be easily shown to be at variance with undoubted facts. Instances of incompetency, neglect, waste, peculation, or official mismanagement may no doubt be pointed out, the authors of which, we trust, will be severely dealt with. Still we are assured that in spite of these exceptional cases, and although some of the most trying and sickly months of the year have passed, our unacclimated troops have, on the whole, been so well cared for that they have emerged satisfactorily from the ordeal; and the various camps, with scarcely an exception, have, as yet, been more free from disease than might reasonably have been expected. Authentic statistical tables have, in a few instances, been published, and we further learn from the concurrent testimony of the representatives of the Press, of the Sanitary Commission, and of other unprejudiced observers at the seat of war, that although in camp as in civil life, some of the most simple and imperative sanitary precautions are often in abeyance, still the sick list has very rarely been immoderate, and the efficiency of our troops is less impaired by the virulence of dysentery, fever, diarrhea, and other camp diseases, than the public had anticipated under the peculiar circumstances of the case.
headline: {'main': 'Recruiting and Army Hygiene.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Recruiting and Army Hygiene.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A COLONEL OF VOLUNTEERS IN AN UNPLEASANT PREDICAMENT. JOHN W. LATSON, a lawyer of this City, who has recently received newspaper notices as Colonel of the "New-York Horse Artillery," was yesterday brought before Justice OSBORN, at the Tombs, on the complaint of Messrs. BONNELL  WILSON, clothiers in Cortlandt-street, charged with having defrauded them of property valued at over $200, by means of false statements.
lead_paragraph: A COLONEL OF VOLUNTEERS IN AN UNPLEASANT PREDICAMENT. -- JOHN W. LATSON, a lawyer of this City, who has recently received newspaper notices as Colonel of the "New-York Horse Artillery," was yesterday brought before Justice OSBORN, at the Tombs, on the complaint of Messrs. BONNELL WILSON, clothiers in Cortlandt-street, charged with having defrauded them of property valued at over $200, by means of false statements. Mr. BONNELL, a member of the firm, testified that on the 13th inst., the accused had rooms at the Western Hotel, and requested him to call and converse with reference to furnishing clothing for his regiment. He talked largely, saying that he should be obliged to purchase an immense quantity of goods, but he wanted no commissions and was only desirous of buying at fair prices. He also said that he had full authority to draw upon the Government for all the goods he wanted, and no other Colonel had been similarly favored. Unfortunately, however, he had left his documents at home, but in proof of his assertion, he referred Mr. BONNELL to the Washington telegraphic correspondence of one of the City papers, wherein he was spoken of flatteringly in connection with his regiment and the War Department. He closed his conversation by expressing a desire to "take a few pants and shirts immediately for his suffering men," which the merchant gladly furnished to the amount of $212 50, and LATSON offered to give next day a Government draft [???]. These goods were duly sent to Camp Low. Staten Island, and at a subsequent interview LATSON renewed his conversation about purchasiug goods, but never alluded to the Government dran in payment for the first lot. On the 19th inst. LATSON again saw Mr. BONNELL, and spoke of the clothing he wanted. Mr. BONNELL, who had gradually been growing suspicious of the Colonel's honesty, declined to negotiate further until he was shown the authority to draw upon the Government. This LATSON did not satisfactorily exhibit, and as he omitted to pay for the goods he did receive, a warrant was issued for his arrest. Officer CUMMINGS, of the Police Court, took him into custody, and he was required to furnish bonds in $500 for trial.

abstract: Everything was extremely quiet at Washington yesterday. Almost the only incident worthy of note was the departure of the mutineers of the Maine Second, and the New-York Thirteenth and Seventy-ninth, for Fortress Monroe, on the way to the Dry Tortugas, where, in the language of the order of the War Department, they will remain until they learn how to behave like soldiers.
lead_paragraph: Everything was extremely quiet at Washington yesterday. Almost the only incident worthy of note was the departure of the mutineers of the Maine Second, and the New-York Thirteenth and Seventy-ninth, for Fortress Monroe, on the way to the Dry Tortugas, where, in the language of the order of the War Department, they will remain until they learn how to behave like soldiers. The order for the seizure of small craft on the Potomac, mentioned yesterday, resulted in the capture of some four hundred of all sizes, which are now at the Washington Navy-yard.

abstract: REORGANIZATION OF THE THIRTEENTH REGIMENT. -- The Thirteenth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., which has already served a three months' term, is being reorganized for the war, under the following field officers: Colonel, ABEL SMITH; Lieutenant-Colonel, STEPHEN A. DODGE; Major, ABRAM ALLEN. Company F will meet to-day at the City Armory, and Company E will meet at the same place on Wednesday, to reorganize and make arrangements for filling up the companies. Several companies have already been filled up for this regiment.

abstract: The London Times Has become the great Pro-Slavery journal of the world. So remarkable are the changes wrought by the rebellion in the United States. Not many months since, the Times was no exception to the English Press.
lead_paragraph: The London Times Has become the great Pro-Slavery journal of the world. So remarkable are the changes wrought by the rebellion in the United States. Not many months since, the Times was no exception to the English Press. If any journal among them, feeling in a bad humor, wished to give the United States an unfriendly cut, the opportunity was ever ready, and the "dark spot of Slavery" received the thrust of the spear. The most reluctant tributes to American progress and power never failed to be accompanied by conspicuous grief over the baleful institution of Slavery. It was the plague-spot of the Republic -- it was our weakness and our shame. So the Times thought, and so it wrote; and the American People were forced to feel that the judgment of the civilized world, as represented so largely by the English Press, was decidedly and painfully against them, because of the toleration of human bondage in one-half of the area of the American Union.

abstract: The Lincoln Cavalry, Col. ANDREW T. McREYNOLDS, took their departure yesterday for Washington, going by the Camden and Amboy route. The rumor, an unauthorized one, that the regiment was to have a presentation of regimental colors by Mrs. President LINCOLN, raised the hopes of the men somewhat, but they finally concluded to wait for the realization of their hopes until they reach Washington
lead_paragraph: The Lincoln Cavalry, Col. ANDREW T. McREYNOLDS, took their departure yesterday for Washington, going by the Camden and Amboy route. The rumor, an unauthorized one, that the regiment was to have a presentation of regimental colors by Mrs. President LINCOLN, raised the hopes of the men somewhat, but they finally concluded to wait for the realization of their hopes until they reach Washington. The Lincoln Cavalry have been recruited mainly in this City, with one company from Syracuse, and one from Michigan, and three in Pennsylvania. They are as fine a body of men as have left this City since recruiting began. Their appearance as they marched through Broadway to the Battery was very fine, the men in their neat uniforms, but without sabres, marching on foot, the staff officers only being mounted. Col. McREYNOLDS rode his handsome bay charger at the head of his regiment, and was frequently recognized and cheered as he passed along, the Colonel giving his friends the parting salute. A large crowd followed them to the place of embarkation, among whom were many of the wives and other female friends of the members, to take a farewell. As the regiment marched on to the pier, DODWORTH's Band, which had escorted them played "Dixie's Land," while some of the more jolly in the ranks struck out into a kind of double shuffle, and went forward in the liveliest manner. The band then changed to "Old Lang Syne," when the scene became really affecting. Wives and husbands, brothers and sisters, were for a time locked in each others arms, and the last good-by and parting kiss was given. Great credit is due to Lieut. LEAVITT, who has labored industriously from the beginning in recruiting this regiment, overcoming many difficulties which have opposed their progress. One of the companies belonging to the regiment is now doing service in Virginia. They will receive their horses and equipments in Washington.

abstract: The telegraph from Fortress Monroe announces, with an affectation of reserve and secrecy, the fitting out at that place of a flotilla designed possibly to act upon points on the Southern Coast. Demonstrations of this character are intended to operate immediately, by scattering the rebel force congregated in Virginia.
lead_paragraph: The telegraph from Fortress Monroe announces, with an affectation of reserve and secrecy, the fitting out at that place of a flotilla designed possibly to act upon points on the Southern Coast. Demonstrations of this character are intended to operate immediately, by scattering the rebel force congregated in Virginia. And so long as the particular points to be assailed are not designated, there is no occasion for reserve respecting the general plan. Secresy, indeed, might defeat it. There is one position close upon the Atlantic coast, which should not be omitted from the general programme, if such a programme exist. Beaufort, in South Carolina, is the chosen seat, the West End, the Versailles, of South Carolina aristocracy. There the PICKENS', the RHETTS, the BARNWELLS, whose town houses are in Charleston, have their country seats, and in all likelihood, are even now solacing themselves with cool sea breezes, after the heat and labor of the greater city. For Beaufort is famous for its perfect salubrity. At all seasons it is free from fever and miasm; and Northerner and Southerner, alike, may reside there the summer long in the enjoyment of the soundest health. So jealous are the South Carolina magnates of this favored spot, that they permit no mechanics, and only a necessary number of merchants, to inhabit the place. In the heart of a dense slave population, and so near as to control direct communication by rail between Savannah and Charleston, the eligibility of Beaufort, as a position to be held as an entrenched camp of instruction, which might be farther protected by a squadron in the harbor, wherein the largest men-of-war may ride at anchor, is too obvious to be questioned. Of course the healthfulness of the neighborhood would admit of earlier movements to seize it than would be practicable at any other desirable point on the coast. And how long would the Georgia and South Carolina troops remain at Manassas after the news of such a descent should reach them?

abstract: MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE. WILLIAM GRA HAM left his home, No. 33 Madison-street, for a visit to Albany, on the 25th of July. A letter, dated there on the 27th, was received from him, since which time ...
lead_paragraph: MYSTERIOUS DISAPPEARANCE. -- WILLIAM GRA HAM left his home, No. 33 Madison-street, for a visit to Albany, on the 25th of July. A letter, dated there on the 27th, was received from him, since which time no trace whatever has been discovered of his whereabouts. He is about 31 years of age; is dark in feature, with an Italian look; has dark eyes, one smaller than the other; a moustache; and he has the walk of a sailor. His dress consisted of a light blue coat, trowsers of a light tan color, white Marseilles vest with a small lilac spot, and a Leghorn hat, bound and trimmed with black; and he wore gold studs enameled in blue. The fact that he came into possession of a large sum of money at Albany leads to the fear that he may have met with foul treatment. Any information that may lead to his discovery will be gladly received by his wife, at No. 33 Madison-street.

abstract: -- In some remarks, a few days since, upon the sumptuous treatment in Baltimore of the rebel prisoners captured at Carrick's Ford, we expressed the conviction that the blame could in no wise be attributed to Maj.-Gen. Dix. A correspondent at Baltimore, who has the means of knowing, assures us that such was the case. The prisoners were sent from the West under a guard detailed, by Gov. DEXSON, of Ohio; and the only duty of Gen. DIX in connection with them was prescribed by the War Department, and consisted in providing transportation from Baltimore to Fortress Monroe. It will always be safe to acquit this early, consistent and able combatant of treason, of any alleged sympathy with the traitors.
lead_paragraph: -- In some remarks, a few days since, upon the sumptuous treatment in Baltimore of the rebel prisoners captured at Carrick's Ford, we expressed the conviction that the blame could in no wise be attributed to Maj.-Gen. abstract: The Herald is doing its best to disorganize society at the North by stirring up mobs and riots, under pretence of serving the Government. Having taken its own first lessons of loyalty at the Lands of a street mob, it regards ...
lead_paragraph: The Herald is doing its best to disorganize society at the North by stirring up mobs and riots, under pretence of serving the Government. Having taken its own first lessons of loyalty at the Lands of a street mob, it regards that process as the only one by which traitors can be tutored into obedience. It invokes popular violence, accordingly, against the Daily News, Journal of Commerce and Day Book, and in order to relieve itself from the slightest suspicion of principle in the matter, it includes the Tribune in its proposed crusade.

abstract: Another of the new steam gun-boats building here for the Government was launched yesterday, at the ship-yard of Mr. J. SIMONSON, Greenpoint. A large crowd of persons assembled to witness the ...
lead_paragraph: Another of the new steam gun-boats building here for the Government was launched yesterday, at the ship-yard of Mr. J. SIMONSON, Greenpoint. A large crowd of persons assembled to witness the vessel floating into the briny element, which she did amid loud cheers. She was christened the Seneca, and is of the same dimensions as the others building here, which have been frequently described. The Seneca will have her machinery put on board as soon as possible, when she is to be reported to the Navy Department. Her contract time will not have expired before she is equipped and manned.

abstract: The exodus of patriots from East Tennessee has fairly commenced. We have already published an account of the arrival of two hundred and fourteen fugitives at Danville, Ky. They, escaped from East Tennssee at ...
lead_paragraph: The exodus of patriots from East Tennessee has fairly commenced. We have already published an account of the arrival of two hundred and fourteen fugitives at Danville, Ky. They, escaped from East Tennssee at night, and with their clothes barely, and, is some few cases, a trusty fire-lock; and in this sad plight took up their weary line of march, as many a poor negro slave has done before them, towards the North Star. The pitiable precession arrived at Danville, travel-stained, ragged and foot-sore; and were received by the hospitable citizens of that loyal Kentucky town, in silence and with profound emotion, but with prompt and earnest sympathy A general contribution of food was made, and a generous dinner was soon prepared and set in the Seminary grounds for the fugitives. It was an acceptable gift, and gladly partaken of, amid the on-looking of hundreds of citizens of the surrounding country, whom the novel scene had gathered together. We can well believe the letters from Danville which say that the population of Kentucky through which the slow-moving caravan of fugitive freemen passed, had been excited to the highest pitch, and that a rage of honest resentment against the horrible despotism of JEFF DAVIS had seized all hearts. Surely, so incendiary a movement was never made in the South as this movement of exiled patriots out of it; and we greatly mistake the signs of the times, if it does not prove the fire-brand that will light the fires of civil war, down to the borders and on the soil of the State of Tennessee.

abstract: -- Drowned,on the afternoon of Friday, Aug. 16, in the Hudson, opposite the residence of his grandmother, at Riverside, Ulster County, New-York, HENRY CLAZ WARING,  only son of CHARLES R. WARING, of this City, in the fourteenth year of his age. He was sailing with another young man from New-York in a small boat, and in attempting to throw a line to a passing sloop. He lost his balance, fell overboard, and sank beforehelp could reach him. His body was recovered on the 21st. and interred in the family burying-ground at Riverside.

abstract: At 11 1/2 o'clock on Monday night a fire broke out in the large stables owned and occupied by the Hoboken and Hudson City Horse-car Railroad Company, located near Newkirk's Hotel at Hudson City. The flames spread throughout the stables with such rapidity that all efforts to rescue the horses were fruitless, and 23 of them were burned to death. There was also considerable hay, grain, harness, &c., destroyed. The building was worth about $2,000, and was insured for $700 in the Hudson County Mutual Insurance Company. The horses were owned by Mr. DE MOTT, the contractor for running the cars, and were valued at about $2,300, upon which there was an insurance of $1,150 in the Jersey City Insurance Company. The flames extended to a two-story dwelling-house adjoining, owned by Mr. BOOKSTADER, and from thence to NEWKIRK's stables adjoining the hotel, both of which were burned down. Mr. BOOKSTADER's loss is about $1,200, and Mr. NEWKIRK's about $500; no insurance. The Fire Departments of Hudson City, Jersey City and Hoboken were present at the earliest possible moment, and did all that was possible to subdue the fire. At one time, NEWKIRK's large hotel, which cost some $20,000, was in great danger, but the firemen succeeded in saving it, with but little damage to the walls.

abstract: This regiment, which has been encamped for the last ten days at Willett's Point, broke camp ...
lead_paragraph: This regiment, which has been encamped for the last ten days at Willett's Point, broke camp yesterday, and proceeded in the steamer Kill von Kull to this City. Landing at the foot of Fourteenth-street, East River, shorty after 5 o'clock P.M., the men were marched to Broadway, down which through-fare they paraded to Pier No. 1 North River where the boat was again taken to convey them to Camder, where the care would be taken for Washington, via Philadelphia.

abstract: United States Marshal MURRAY yesterday caused the arrest of Mr. J.A. MACHADO, a well known resident of this City, charged with having been engaged for several years past in the business of finding out slavers from this port for the Coast of Africa. The last veasel known to have been sent out by him was the bark Mary Francis, which was fitted out at this port about nine months since, ostensibly for Wilmington, N.C., to which port she did in fact go, but soon left there for the Coast of Africa, on pretence of going to one of the West India islands. The voyage was successful, and the Mary Francis landed between 500 and 606 negroes on the Island of Cuba. Besides the Mary Francis, Mr. MACHADO is charged with fitting out for the same trade, the Montank, the Brutus, the Kate; the Triton, the W.R. Kibby, and divers other vessels' not known to the present United States Marshal, and probably not unknown to his predecessor. Indeed Mr. MACHADO has long been regarded by those who knew him, as the king of the slave-traders in this City, and is said to have fitted out more than half of the slavers that have sailed from this port during the last five years. He is a Spaniard by birth, about 50 years of age, and has resided in this City for ten years past, making frequent trips to Cuba to look after the branch of his business located there. He returned from his last trip thither about three weeks ago, and has since shown himself about the streets and at public places as usual, apparently conscious of the rectitude of his calling, and confident that his business at least was safe from the vicissitudes of war. This illusion was suddenly dispelled by the entrance into his parlor, at No. 33 St. Mark's-place, yesterday morning, of Deputy Marshals LAN and SHEHAN, who took him into custody and forthwith marched him off to the Tombs. We will doubtless find bail to-day and regain his liberty, but he will hardly be able, should he stand trial, to resist the accumulated evidence against him in the hands of the Marshal. Mr. MACHADO is reported to be a single man, although he keeps house, and has a female partner to share his woes, and participate to the profits of his trade.

abstract: The Eighteenth Regiment of Massachusetts, enlisted for the war, arrived in this City, yesterday morning, en route for Washington. The regiment was expected at 7.A.M. but owing to the delay in embarkation did not arrive until 1  P.M.
lead_paragraph: The Eighteenth Regiment of Massachusetts, enlisted for the war, arrived in this City, yesterday morning, en route for Washington. The regiment was expected at 7.A.M. but owing to the delay in embarkation did not arrive until 1 1/2 P.M. They came on the steamer Commodore, of the Stonington line. They left their camp at Reedville, near Deadham, Mass., on Monday afternoon, and were welcomed on their arrival at the foot of Cortlandt-street by a large deputation of sons of Massachusetts, leaded by FRANK E. HOWE, Assistant Quartermaster-General of the State of Massachusetts. The corps at present numbers 870 men, but will be recruited to 1,040 within a few weeks. They are uniformed in the Conventional blue and gray of Massachussetts, armed with Springfield muskets of 1842, and fully equipped. They have camp equipage company wagons and ambulance, and 60 horses, a band of 25 pieces enlisted for the war, 25,000 rounds of ball cartridges, and 25,000 rounds of buckshot, and, in fact, all the paraphernalia of war ready to fit them for immediate service in the field.

abstract: We have just received a Blue Book from England, from which we extrtact a singular and interesting story. The look is a report in full of the affidavits and arguments upon ...
lead_paragraph: We have just received a Blue Book from England, from which we extrtact a singular and interesting story. The look is a report in full of the affidavits and arguments upon a motion for a new trial in the telegraphic case of "GLASS and another versus BOSWALL." The trial was in Westminster Hall, Common Pleas, before the eminent Chief Justice ERLE and a full bench. The plaintiffs, GLASS and ELLIOT, are iron-workers, and the principal manufacturers of submarine telegraphic cable in the world. They made that of the Atlantic Company, those which cross the English Channel, the Red Sea, and in fact almost all the submarine telegraphic lines of communication which have been laid down. BOSWALL, the defendant, is the London agent of another great iron-manufacturing house, NEWALL & Co., of immense wealth, the highest both social and commercial respectability, and connected, as such manufacturers not uncommonly are at this day, with the nobility. There was jealousy and ill-feeling between these two manufacturing establishments, which seem to have been felt chiefly on the part of the NEWALLS. They alleged that their rivals had intentionally violated one of their patents; and, what was certain and more aggravating, they were the more successful, at least in the matter of telegraphic cable manufacturing.

abstract: -- Cotton may be never so great a King, but he is dependent on other countries for the garb in which he is presented to the nations. The staple cannot be moved a mile on its way to the markets of the world, until it is picked and ginned, and the bags in which it is pressed are the product of Russia, or of Kentucky and Missouri, no supplies of which are in the South adequate to the baling of one-fiftieth part of of an ordinary crop. The desperate right the Secessionists are going to make for Kentucky and Missouri have a direct reference to the marketing of the Cotton crop. They cannot get along without the hemp-bagging and bale rope, with which their Cotton is bagged and bound, and prepared for shipment. The recent advice of the Cotton-factors of the Southern ports to the planters, not to send their Cotton to the cities, was founded moreon necessity than choice. It was "to make a virtue of necessity," and conceal from the world a weakness that the port returns would have made too manifest.

abstract: We do not believe the people of this country were ever more nearly unanimous on any subject, than they are in demanding that JO  SEPH HOLT, of Kentucky, should be made Secretary of War.
lead_paragraph: We do not believe the people of this country were ever more nearly unanimous on any subject, than they are in demanding that JO SEPH HOLT, of Kentucky, should be made Secretary of War. We mention this simply as a fact, forced upon our notice by what we see and hear every day, in the City and the country, among men of all parties, -- and without the slightest purpose or expectation of seeing any such event achieved. The person most interested in knowing the fact is probably the very last one who will be permitted to believe or understand it. Mr. LINCOLN'S knowledge of what the people want comes to him through those by whom he is immediately surrounded, -- men who have personal purposes to serve by approaching him, and whose facts are shaped by their bearing on those purposes. They tell him what they suppose he desires to hear; and as he is known to have certain favorite ideas about keeping his Cabinet unbroken, making it a unit, &c., he is not likely to be very thoroughly informed of anything which would disturb those ideas.

abstract: On Saturday afternoon, upon the arrival of Hon. JOHN P. HALE at the depot in Dover, N.H. (the place of his residence.) a man, apparently intoxicated to whom an acquaintance had pointed our Mr. HALE as an ...
lead_paragraph: -- On Saturday afternoon, upon the arrival of Hon. JOHN P. HALE at the depot in Dover, N.H. (the place of his residence.) a man, apparently intoxicated to whom an acquaintance had pointed our Mr. HALE as an "Abolitionist." stepped up to Mr. HALE, and with the remark, "You are one of the men who have brought all this trouble upon us," struck him in the face, knocking off his hat. Mr. HALE, seeing the condition of the man, replied, "Get out of my way," when the drunken fellow struck him again. Mr. HALE did not return the blow, but walked quietly away. The depot-master and others interfered to prevent any further assault. The attack did not appear to be premeditated, and the affair was over in a few minutes. Boston Traveller, Aug. 26.

abstract: The grand match between New-York and All Massachusetts was commenced yesterday, the 27th inst., at Hoboken, and will be resumed to-day, at 11 A.M. The attendance of spectators was the most numerous of any match played at Hoboken this season. The New-Yorkers went first to the bat, and scored 130 runs for their first innings. Messrs. HUDSON, WILBY, HORTON and BAILLIERE being the chief contributors, the two former scoring respectively 40 and 29 by a fine display of batting. The Massachusetts Eleven had scored a total of 67 when the stumps were drawn.

abstract: By way of Cincinnati we have received intelligence that a fight has taken place in the Kanawha Valley, which resulted disastrously to our arms. Particulars are wanting, but we gather from the brief dispatch that Col. TYLER'S command, said to ...
lead_paragraph: By way of Cincinnati we have received intelligence that a fight has taken place in the Kanawha Valley, which resulted disastrously to our arms. Particulars are wanting, but we gather from the brief dispatch that Col. TYLER'S command, said to number some 3,000, located at Summersville, was on Monday morning unexpectedly surrounded by the rebels under FLOYD, and badly defeated. Particulars will probably reach us to-day.

abstract: Mr. RUSSELL has been for some time in the  United States discharging for the British public, not to say for the whole world, the same services that he did so well before in the Crimea and in India. He has everywhere had to perform his laborious ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. RUSSELL has been for some time in the United States discharging for the British public, not to say for the whole world, the same services that he did so well before in the Crimea and in India. He has everywhere had to perform his laborious duties under difficulties inconceivable to most Of his readers, and little shared by writers compiling narratives at a library-table, or taking down the words of some customary informant. He has had to write in haste, in exhaustion, in noise, in danger, in the very turmoil of war, with disputation and even menace still in his ears. He has been occasionally contradicted, generally confessed to be right, and sometimes has frankly and courageously avowed himself to be mistaken or misinformed. His letters are now before the world in volumes, and, having passed through the or deal of criticism, are part of the literature of his country. Nowhere has his liberty of speech been so furiously arraigned, and his vocation so denounced, as in the United-States. A correspondence in another column will show how little support, truthful, exact and candid as he is, he is likely to receive, there, even from those who might be supposed above the madness of a mob.

abstract: Unless history is a record of misleading precedents, the American Government will in a month be the stronger for its defeats. That is should be so must be the wish of every Englishman, for the consequences of defeat must be disastrous to human freedom. The South in possession of Washington, and once recognized as a power, would be in the best position to realize itsdream of conquest and spoliation. The army whichhad defeated the North; or even driven it back fromits soil, would overrun Mexico as easily as the firstconquerors of the country. Once masters of the silvermines, and of a great taxable population, theSouthern leaders might in a few years organize anArmy which nothing on the American continent couldwithstand, and which would speedily bring about a new calamity -- the armed interterence of Europe in Central America. Such a power, while unopposed, might reopen the slave trade, and would certainly so extend the area of Slavery as to render its extinction all but impossible. The first barrier against a misfortune so terrible to the world is the strenght of the American Government, and however annoying its failures, or however deep our disgust at its tone, it is with that Government that the sympathies of all free men perforce must lie.

abstract: A DELIBERATE ATTEMPT TO COMMIT MURDER.  Between 12 and 1 o'clock, Monday night, PADDY FOX a well-known politician in the Twelfth Ward, entered KERRIGAN'S saloon, No.65 Hamilton-avenue, and ...
lead_paragraph: A DELIBERATE ATTEMPT TO COMMIT MURDER. -- Between 12 and 1 o'clock, Monday night, PADDY FOX a well-known politician in the Twelfth Ward, entered KERRIGAN'S saloon, No.65 Hamilton-avenue, and taking deliberate aim, discharged a pistol at JAMES McCORMICK -- the ball from which took effect in McCORMICK'S right side, inflicting a serious, but not necessarily mortal wound. During the excitement following the shooting of the pistol, Cox made his escape, and has not since been seen. Fox and McCORMICK had some hard words at the Twelfth Ward Democratic Primary meeting, Monday evening, and the shooting was carrying out a threat he then made.

abstract: next Monday. The returns from the late election have all been received at Frankfort, and the political opinions of every member elect, except one, whom both sides claim, have been ascertained. The result shows a majority of fifty Unionists in the House, numbering only one hundred members. The Senate stands: Union, 27; Secession, 11. Ten of these Secessionists are Senators who hold over, and who, consequently, escaped the popular verdict.

abstract: The two public school buildings recently erected at Hudson City will be thrown open for public inspection on Friday and Saturday afternoons of this week. abstract: Fox vs. Healh. -- The assignment which the plaintiff in this case seeks to set aside, was executed by three partners, one of whom is an infant. The interest of such infant did not pass by the assignment. The assignee took no title, could convey none as to his part, and the execution of the trust is impossible The assignment of property for the benefit of creditors must be absolute and irrevocable in terms, and the instrument itself not subject to any defeasance by the act of any of the parties. The act of the infant in signing the paper is voidable, and may be counteracted by him either before or at maturity. The estate cannot be administered with the doubt of the infant's ratification, which can be solved only when the infant arrives at the age of twenty-one years. The creditors cannot be delayed under such circumstances. I think the assignment void, and that a Receiver should be appointed. I think, also, that the assignee of the judgment debtors, having given the security required by law, and having accepted the performance of the trust, should be appointed the Receiver in this case, and order accordingly. Order to be entered herein to be settled on two days' notice.
lead_paragraph: Fox vs. Healh. -- The assignment which the plaintiff in this case seeks to set aside, was executed by three partners, one of whom is an infant. The act of the infant in signing the paper is voidable, and may be counteracted by him either before or at maturity. abstract: The Brooklyn Navy-yard still continues to be the busiest of all others. The ordnance authorities, the riggers, sail-makers, caulkers, and machinists, have not only to do all the work in their several lines for all the ships brought to this station, but for nearly half those ordered to fit out elsewhere. The amount of overhauling and repairing to be done is so great that the construction of new vessels is only a secondary affair.

abstract: Messers. J.G.  I. EDGE, pyrotechnists, of Jersey City, are to give an exhibition this (Thursday) evening at Weehawken, in connection with Prof. GEANT, of their rockets and incendiary shells, which it is believed can be used with great effect against the enemy.
lead_paragraph: Messers. J.G. & I. EDGE, pyrotechnists, of Jersey City, are to give an exhibition this (Thursday) evening at Weehawken, in connection with Prof. GEANT, of their rockets and incendiary shells, which it is believed can be used with great effect against the enemy. The larger sized shells can be thrown froma mortar or cannon to a great distance. At the discharge from the piece it instantly ignites, causing a ball of fire four feet in circumference, which it is impossible to extinguish except by complete immersion in water. After burning fiercely for two or three minutes, an internal shell charged with powder explodes, and the outer shell is broken into not less than sixteen pieces, which are scattered in all directions with great force. One great advantage claimed for these shells is the facility they would afford in setting fire to the woods, and especially in the locality of masked batteries. They would also be effective against cavalry, not only by throwing the ranks into disorder, but by causing great destruction upon bursting. They have also a smaller missile which can be thrown from a paper mortar to a considerable distance, and presenting a ball of fire two feet in circumference. A mortar and twenty of these missiles can be easily carried by one man, and would be particularly useful at night in setting fire to the woods and driving the enemy from their strong-hold.

abstract: Egbert vs. Watson BY THE COURT BRADY, J. When an attachment issues from a Justices' Court it is the duty of the constable to attach the goods of the defendant, make an inventory of the property seized, and serve a copy of the attachment and inventory on the defendant, personally, if he can be found in the county. If he cannot be found in the county.
lead_paragraph: Egbert vs. Watson -- BY THE COURT -- BRADY, J. -- When an attachment issues from a Justices' Court it is the duty of the constable to attach the goods of the defendant, make an inventory of the property seized, and serve a copy of the attachment and inventory on the defendant, personally, if he can be found in the county. If he cannot be found in the county. If he cannot be found in the county the copy must be left at his last place of residence; or if he have no place of residence in the county, with the person in whose possession the goods are found, and the return of the officer must state specifically whether such copy was or was not personally served upon the defendant. (McDoel vs. Cook, 2 Coms., 110.)

abstract: MCDOWELL makes no display in his report, but it is a plain detail of his movements, and it shows that he arranged and fought the battle as well as any of LINCOLN's Generals, with their troops, could have done, nut excepting General SCOTT. He managed it admirably in every respect, and was very nearly successful. * * * The columns of HUNTER and HEINTZELMAN passed up the Run, crossed at Sudley's Ford, and attempted to turn our left, which was me great feature of the plan. HUNTER did cross, did attack as ordered, and did force our men down the Run, where they Had to receive the cross-time of TAYLER's column; and nothing but the protection of Heaven, the genius of Beauregard, (who detected HUNTER's movement by the clouds of dust,) and the unequaled heroic courage and great endurance of our men, prevented our left being turned, and porhaps the seizure by HUNTER of the Manassas Railroad at Gainesville. -- Augusta (Ga.) Sentinel.

abstract: The Chester County Democrat gives the following curious account of the recent "mob" in Westchester: On Tuesday morning last the quiet inhabitants of Westchester were surprised by a rumor that the type on which the tory newspaper of this borough was printed had been throw into the street or otherwise disposed of, and that some slight damage had been done to the press, making it useless until repairs could be made.
lead_paragraph: The Chester County Democrat gives the following curious account of the recent "mob" in Westchester: On Tuesday morning last the quiet inhabitants of Westchester were surprised by a rumor that the type on which the tory newspaper of this borough was printed had been throw into the street or otherwise disposed of, and that some slight damage had been done to the press, making it useless until repairs could be made. From those who visited the scene, we learn that everything seemed to have been done with care, and as little property destroyed as the nature of the case would admit. Indeed, to a careful observer, there were not wanting indications that the event had been anticipated, and carried out by the friends of the paper and the tory party, in order to create sympathy and make an excuse for violence and bullyism. The whole thing was a surprise, at all events, and the damage not very serious; and the well-known promptness and energy of the publishers will probably be displayed in producing a rampant specimen of toryism by the regular day of publication.All sorts of rumors are afloat in regard to the affair. One statement is that some tory friends from the country visited the office, and not being acquainted with the business of handling type, spilled, it and made it into pi. With the press they were entirely unacquainted, and injured that also in attempting to work off a paper. Some are uncharitable enough to charge the proprietors with instigating the whole affair, in order to gain sympathy and more extended credit, and allege many circumstances which they think tend to prove this to be the case. It is stated by some that the senior proprietor was seen a square or two from the office at 12 o'clock that night, in company with two or three others, and that the accident occurred between 12 and 1 o'clock.

abstract: Last night at 10 o'clock Gen. FRANKLIN'S Brigade the Fifteenth, Eighteenth, Thirty-first and  Thirty-second New-York were ordered to advance without knapsacks.
lead_paragraph: Last night at 10 o'clock Gen. FRANKLIN's Brigade -- the Fifteenth, Eighteenth, Thirty-first and Thirty-second New-York -- were ordered to advance without knapsacks. They marched to within 2 1/2 miles of Bailey's Cross Roads. Early this morning the enemy opened with two rifled cannon on a hill-top a quarter of a mile beyond Cross Roads, drove in our pickets, and followed them about half a mile. Gen. FRANKLIN, with about 3,000 of our troops and five cannon, marched to a point near the crossing, and were sent into a cornfield. A detachment of pickets, under Lieut. Col. WASHBURN, of the Thirty-first, went forward. The enemy were seen about eight hundred yards beyond our advance guard, and fired upon them, but without doing any injury. Three of the enemy were seen to fall.

abstract: Commendable dispatch is evidently being made in the completion of the gun-boats lately put under contract in this City for the use of the United States Government. Yesterday afternoon, the Pembina was.
lead_paragraph: Commendable dispatch is evidently being made in the completion of the gun-boats lately put under contract in this City for the use of the United States Government. Yesterday afternoon, the Pembina was successfully launched from the ship-yard of THOMAS STACK, at the foot of North Sixth-street, Williamsburgh, in the presence of 1,500 persons, among whom were several naval officers and distinguished merchants. The ship was beautifully decorated with the American flag, which waved proudly over the handsomely-modeled craft, and as she glided into her native element, the good wishes of the multitude for her success, as well as that of her builders, were expressed in hearty cheers.

abstract: RACH COURSE. The entente cordials which still exists between our Metropolis and Old Kentucky, is beautifully illustrated by a race cup of silver, just finished and now on exhibition by TIFEANY  Co. For years this house has filled all the orders required by our Southern friends of the turf, and regularly sent its annual trophy, in silver or gold, to New-Orleans or Louisville.
lead_paragraph: RACE COURSE. -- The entente cordiale which still exists between our Metropolis and Old Kentucky, is beautifully illustrated by a race cup of silver, just finished and now on exhibition by TIFFANY & CO. For years this house has filled all the orders required by our Southern friends of the turf, and regularly sent its annual trophy, in silver or gold, to New-Orleans or Louisville. But a few weeks ago it forwarded to Louisville the mammoth vase which is to be the hardbought prize of a three-years' winner of the Woodlawn Course -- the most magificent piece of silver of the kind ever produced in the country; and a month or so previous a splendid Crescent Cup for the Metairie track at New-Orleans. In view of the favor thus dispensed to them Messrs. TIFFANY have produced, on their own account, for the forthcoming races of the celebrated Woodlawn Association, of Kentucky, a cup, which, though surpassed by its predecessors in largeness, does not yield to them in beauty of design. Some time since, the Directors of the Course announced "the Tiffany Stake," an entirely new event in the programme of the Association. This cup is the pleasant return which TIFFANY & Co. render for their courtesy. The piece is a tankard, some seven inches in height -- its design an artistic, variation from the familiar type which art-critics call the Flemish. The foot of the cup is a deep border in spirited engraving, horseshoes in etching, and the lighter lines of a wreath, in which the artistic eye will detect the spur, alternating to form it. The body is quite plain, with the exception of an oblong space, bounded by characteristic engraving on each side. One of these spaces is now occupied by a beautiful view of the Woodlawn Course; and the other will contain at no distant day the proper inscription with the winner's name. The top of the cup and the handle are Grecian in ornament, an exquisite medallion cameo after the antique finishing the latter where it joins the base. The main feature of the cup is a spirited statuette, some three inches in height, of the celebrated racer, Lexington, accompanied by his negro groom. This group is a perfect portraiture, the utmost care having been taken to attain the truth. The top of the cup is chased to represent a paddock, in which the group is placed. The cost of the cup is $250, and the hunters and racers of Kentucky may well be proud of this compliment from a New-York house.

abstract: Dame Rumor, ever ready to whet the public appetite; furnishes us with startling reports of an engagement on the southern side of the Potomac. No reliable particulars are given, but it is supposed that three companies of cavalry, three of in fantry, and two field-pieces, under secession auspices, which have been manoeuvering near Ball's Cross-roads, have drawn out a detachment of Union troops.
lead_paragraph: Dame Rumor, ever ready to whet the public appetite; furnishes us with startling reports of an engagement on the southern side of the Potomac. No reliable particulars are given, but it is supposed that three companies of cavalry, three of in fantry, and two field-pieces, under secession auspices, which have been manoeuvering near Ball's Cross-roads, have drawn out a detachment of Union troops. The whole story is, however, conjectural. The Washington Star has several rumors of engagements near Bailey's Cross-roads, and from other sources general rumors are cur-rent of skirmishes having taken place. There appears, however, to be nothing reliable.

abstract: We have been permitted to read a private letter, written by one of the most prominent Union men of Kentucky, touching the progress of civil strife in that State. The writer resides not far from the centre of the State, on the line of communication between Central Kentucky and East Tennessee.
lead_paragraph: We have been permitted to read a private letter, written by one of the most prominent Union men of Kentucky, touching the progress of civil strife in that State. The writer resides not far from the centre of the State, on the line of communication between Central Kentucky and East Tennessee. It is along here that the fugitive patriots from East Tennessee have lately moved, and in the same vicinity that Camp Dick Robinson has been established by the united States Government, which has so much provoked the ire of BRECKINRIDGE, MAGOFFIN, and the rest of the Kentucky Secessionists. The correspondent, whose letter we have examined, is in the best position to know the temper of parties and the state of feeling in Kentucky; and we think we will subserve the public interest by making publication of his private sentiments, along with the facts he gives, which are as follows:
