abstract: A FOREIGNER IN A FIX -- VERY SINGULAR. --JACOB F. BUTCHART, a German, was arrested yesterday by Officer MCLOUGHLIN, of the First Precinct, on suspicion of having stolen a draft for $402, made in Buffalo, on the 26th inst., by H.A. FRINK & Co., on JAMES STOCKBRIDGE, No. 14 Broadway, and made payable to the order of the assignees of S.F.R. CODDINGTON. On presenting the draft for payment, at the office of the assignees, No. 78 Broad-street, he was unable to satisfactorily account for the manner in which it came into his possession, and was arrested. Having been taken before Justice KELLY, he made me following strange explanation, which, however, was not deemed worthy of credit, and he was locked up pending an examination. He arrived in this country from Germany one day last week, and on the same evening went about town with some of his acquaintances, and became stupidly intoxicated. The next morning, he awoke with a bad headache at a recruiting-office somewhere in Fortieth-street, where he found he had enlisted. He discovered, also, that advantage had been taken of his condition to rob him of a considerable sum of money, together with a draft which had been brought from England, and for which the one in question had been substituted. Thinking it about right that his loss should be reimbursed, he presented the draft, with the result as slated. Mr. CODDINGTON made an affidavit that the document was his property, and the Court surrendered it to him.

abstract: THE SECESSION MEETING IN QUEENS COUNTY INDEFINITELY POSTPONED THE SECESSIONISTS BECOME ALARMED. A call for a so-called "Peace Meeting," to be held at Hicks' Hotel, Newtown, Queens County, this (Thursday) evening, has been very generally circulated throughout Brooklyn during the present week.
lead_paragraph: THE SECESSION MEETING IN QUEENS COUNTY INDEFINITELY POSTPONED -- THE SECESSIONISTS BECOME ALARMED. -- A call for a so-called "Peace Meeting," to be held at Hicks' Hotel, Newtown, Queens County, this (Thursday) evening, has been very generally circulated throughout Brooklyn during the present week. It was signed, as a Committee of Arrangement by C. Covert, lumber merchant, Morpeth; A. Baccus, farmer and gardener, Flushing; William H. Furman, Morpeth Bridge; J.F. Blauvelt, physician, Newtown; J. Henry, William McCoy and William Hulse. As the call said "come one, come all," a large number of people residing in Brooklyn, Jamaica, and other part of Queens and Kings Counties made arrangements to attend the meeting. This, it seems, alarmed the managers, and yesterday the following card was issued, indefinitely psstponing the proposed peace meeting:

abstract: Gov. GREINER, who has just entered upon the discharge of his duties in New-Mexico, writes to the Columbus (Ohio) State Journal, under date of Aug 3:
lead_paragraph: Gov. GREINER, who has just entered upon the discharge of his duties in New-Mexico, writes to the Columbus (Ohio) State Journal, under date of Aug 3: "We Have information that a large body of Texans made an attack upon the United States troops in the Messilla Valley, on Thursday of last week, and after one or two skirmishes, in which Lieuts. MCNALLY and BROOKS were severely wounded, the command retreated to Fort Fillmore, and its commander, Major LYNDE, thinking himself unable to maintain his positions, abandoned the fort, and by a hasty retreat endeavored to reach Fort Stanton, 161 miles distant. The command, numbering 750 men, reached the San Augustine Spring, in the Oregon Mountains, a march of about 20 miles when it was surrounded by the Texan horse, said to be only 300 strong. Major LYNDE, without firing a gun, and without making a show of resistance, surrendered his whole force into the hands of the enemy. Whether cowardice, bribery or treachery prompted the deed, we are at a loss to determine, out the report, scandalous as it is to the fair fame of our troops, is believed to be true by the best informed citizens here. This is not the worst. Two companies from Forts Buchanan and Breckinridge, in the western part of the Territory, intended as reinforcements for Fort Fillmore, with 60 Government wagons, are supposed to be on the road, and most serious fears are apprehended that this detachment will also be cut off. This will give the whole of the Messilia Valley and Ariz [???] into the hands of the Texans.
headline: {'main': 'DISCOURAGING FROM NEW-MEXICO.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'DISCOURAGING FROM NEW-MEXICO.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The general impression of the public is, that the Editor of the Herald is constitutionally incapable of telling the truth. It may be so; but we should feel much better satisfied of the fact, if he had ever made the attempt.
lead_paragraph: The general impression of the public is, that the Editor of the Herald is constitutionally incapable of telling the truth. It may be so; but we should feel much better satisfied of the fact, if he had ever made the attempt. But we defy any man to point to a single incident in his whole life, or a single sentence in the files of the Herald, from the day it was started until now, which indicates the faintest possible preference for truth over falsehood. From the beginning to the end of his career he has been steadily and unwaveringly consistent, in never telling the truth when a lie would answer his purpose half as well. This may be "constitutional," or it may be the result of calculation; but it is systematic. Whenever he has an object to accomplish, he never shows the slightest scruple as to the means of reaching it; and as in nine cases out of ten his objects are purely malignant and devilish, naturally enough falsehood and calumny are the weapons which he wields.
headline: {'main': 'Lying as a Profession.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Lying as a Profession.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: This week, recruiting in the City has been much more active than it has been for some time past. It would be brisker if the officers in command at the various recruiting-offices would get rid of the loafers who hang around them.
lead_paragraph: This week, recruiting in the City has been much more active than it has been for some time past. It would be brisker if the officers in command at the various recruiting-offices would get rid of the loafers who hang around them. The object of these idlersappears to be to deter men from enlisting, by magnifying and expatiating upon the hardships of a soldier's life. Officers complain daily of losing their men by the intervention of some one or somebody. These hangers-on of recruiting-offices may be emissaries of the enemy. Any way, it would be no harm for the authorities to have an eye upon them, and keep the various offices for the enrollment of men cleared of all but actual recruits.

abstract: This match was brought to a close yesterday morning, the result being a victory for the NewYork Club, whose score, in their first innings, exceeded that of their opponents in two, by twenty-five runs. On part of New-York, the batting of HUDSON,...
lead_paragraph: This match was brought to a close yesterday morning, the result being a victory for the New-York Club, whose score, in their first innings, exceeded that of their opponents in two, by twenty-five runs. On part of New-York, the batting of HUDSON, WILBY, HORTON, and BAILLIERE, is worthy of notice, and in bowling, MARSH and CROSSLEY merit praise. WILBY's fine long stopping was the feature of their fielding. On behalf of the Massachusetts Eleven, the good batting of young ROBINSON, a promising American player, from Lowell, deserves special remark; PERKINS and BURGESS, too, batted merely for their double figures, as did the brothers SAMMOND. DRAPER, a good player, was quite unfortunate. The match was played throughout in that hearty spirit of good fellowship that should characterize all such contests. The Massachusetts men were hospitably cared for during their sojourn here, and express themselves as highly pleased with their visit -- albeit, they feel a little sore at the result. The score is as follows:

abstract: About noon, yesterday, two British war steamers were noticed in the offing, and one of them crossed the bar inward, and came up to Quarantine, where she anchored about 2 1/2 o'clock P.M. She proved to be H.B.M. screw-steamer Rinaldo, Commander HEWETT, from Halifax Aug. 23d. She came to relieve the British gun-boat Gladiator, which has been on this station for a short time. The Rinaldo mounts seventeen guns, and has a crew of 190 men, who are all in good health. The name of the ship which remained outside is not mentioned.

abstract: It is somewhat difficult to get at even approximate numbers of the rebel armies in Missouri. A few days ago the Missouri Dem-...
lead_paragraph: It is somewhat difficult to get at even approximate numbers of the rebel armies in Missouri. A few days ago the Missouri Democrat estimated them at between 50,000 and 60,000. This allowed about 20,000 to BEN. McCULLOCH in the southwest; about 20,000 to Gen. PILLOW at New-Madrid, in the southeast, and about 15,000 to Gen. HARDEE, JEFF. THOMPSON, Col. HUNTER and other inferior brigands, near Ironton. This makes a total of 55,000; and at the time the estimate was made, it was not too large.

abstract: Messrs. J.G.  I. EDGE, pyrotechnists, of Jersey City, are to give an exhibition this (Thursday) evening at Weehawken, in connection with Prof. GEANT, of their rockets and incendiary shells, which it is believed can be used with great effect against the enemy. The larger sized shells can be thrown from a mortar or cannon to a great distance.
lead_paragraph: Messrs. J.G. & I. EDGE, pyrotechnists, of Jersey City, are to give an exhibition this (Thursday) evening at Weehawken, in connection with Prof. GEANT, of their rockets and incendiary shells, which it is believed can be used with great effect against the enemy. The larger sized shells can be thrown from a mortar or cannon to a great distance. At the discharge from the piece it instantly ignites, causing a ball of fire four feet in circumference, which it is impossible to extinguish except by complete immersion in water. After burning fiercely for two or three minutes, an internal shell charged with powder explodes, and the outer shell is broken into not less than sixteen pieces, which are scattered in all directions with great force. One great advantage claimed for those shells is the facility they would afford in setting fire to the woods, and especially in the locality of masked batteries. They would also be effective against cavalry, not only by throwing the ranks into disorder, but by causing great destruction upon bursting. They have also a smaller missile which can be thrown from a paper mortar to a considerable distance, and presenting a ball fire two feet in circumference. A mortar and twenty of these missiles can be easily carried by one man, and would be particularly useful at night in setting fire to the woods and driving the enemy from their strong-hold.

abstract: An honest confession is said to be good for the soul. We are glad, therefore, to see the London Times coming forward with a frank avowal of its motives in joining the assault of the rebels on the Constitution and Government of the United States.
lead_paragraph: An honest confession is said to be good for the soul. We are glad, therefore, to see the London Times coming forward with a frank avowal of its motives in joining the assault of the rebels on the Constitution and Government of the United States. It is not any doubt on its part that the Government is doing perfectly right in trying to preserve its own existence. It has "repeatedly admitted" that the nation "could not be expected to view the dismemberment of the Union without an effort to avert the loss." Nor does it attribute to the Americans any "special faults" or any "peculiar incapacity for self-government." Quite the reverse.

abstract: Henry Farrington vs. John W. Latson. -- The plaintiff in this action having enlisted in the regiment now in course of construction by Col. Latson, the defendant, which regiment is at present in camp at Staten Island, and, as alleged, the said plaintiff having been guilty of a breach of discipline, after being sworn and mustered into the service of the United States, he was arrested by order of the Colonel and shut up in the guard-house. After he had obtained his release he proceeds to the City, obtains the services of a lawyer, and commences an action for false imprisonment, with an order of arrest against the Colonel. The Colonel, while on business in the City relative to his command, was arrested by the Sheriff and placed in custody. A motion now comes before the Court for the discharge of the defendant from arrest. The defendant presented an affidavit of the foregoing facts, and claims that he is not liable upon civil process. It is also argued that, if any disorderly member of a regiment at his own option can cause the arrest of his commanding officer upon civil process, such puts an end to all discipline, and will result in the total demoralization of regiments or companies, and defeat the purpose for which such regiment was enlisted. The Court, however, refused to decide the question upon the spot, but allowed the plaintiff's Attorney another day to present further affidavits upon the question. Col. Latson requested the Court to designate some officer in whose custody he was to remain; that he had been treated insultingly and tyrannically by the Under-Sheriff, and, although he had offered ample bail, it had been refused, and he was still in the custody of the Sheriff, while his regiment was being neglected. The Court said he had no power over the matter, and remanded him to the custody of the Sheriff.

After he had obtained his release he proceeds to the City, obtains the services of a lawyer, and commences an action for false imprisonment, with an order of arrest against the Colonel. The Colonel, while on business in the City relative to his command, was arrested by the Sheriff and placed in custody. A motion now comes before the Court for the discharge of the defendant from arrest. The defendant presented an affidavit of the foregoing facts, and claims that he is not liable upon civil process. It is also argued that, if any disorderly member of a regiment at his own option can cause the arrest of his commanding officer upon civil process, such puts an end to all discipline, and will result in the total demoralization of regiments or companies, and defeat the purpose for which such regiment was enlisted. The Court, however, refused to decide the question upon the spot, but allowed the plaintiff's Attorney another day to present further affidavits upon the question. Col. Latson requested the Court to designate some officer in whose custody he was to remain; that he had been treated insultingly and tyrannically by the Under-Sheriff, and, although he had offered ample bail, it had been refused, and he was still in the custody of the Sheriff, while his regiment was being neglected. The Court said he had no power over the matter, and remanded him to the custody of the Sheriff.

abstract: Fairly one-half the already superabundant anxiety with which we have watched the development of this National struggle is attributable to a morbid sensitiveness about British opinion. What would be said by the English...
lead_paragraph: Fairly one-half the already superabundant anxiety with which we have watched the development of this National struggle is attributable to a morbid sensitiveness about British opinion. What would be said by the English Press, or thought by the English people, or done by the English Government, have been the spectres and bugbears we have sucessively called up to frighten us; and as the event has proved satisfactory or otherwise, have we been cheered or despondent.

abstract: Gov. HARRIS, of Tennessee. Not long ago some gentlemen wrote him a letter stating that Yankees were still employed on the Edgefield and Kentucky Railroad, and that large quanti-...
lead_paragraph: -- Gov. HARRIS, of Tennessee, -- King HARRIS, as the Union men in the eastern part of the State style him, -- has been giving new proof of his astuteness as a political economist, and of the jealous care with which he is guarding the Confederate cause. Not long ago some gentlemen wrote him a letter stating that Yankees were still employed on the Edgefield and Kentucky Railroad, and that large quantities of whisky were continually transported over that track With a short-sightedness which would almost subject them to the suspicion of being traitors to the Government presided over by JEFF. DAVIS, they stated that they wanted the Yankees removed and the whisky trade stopped.

abstract: This regiment of Zouaves, formed under the exact principles of the French Imperial Zouaves, is fast filling up, and will be ready for orders within twenty days. The principal officers have all seen much active service in the French Army. The uniform is much richer than that supplied to any regiment recruited in New-York. The recruits receive pay and rations from the time of enrollment. They are quartered at Camp Leslie, Staten Island. The head-quarterr in this City are at No. 86 Cedar-street.

abstract: THE SUPPOSED SUICIDE OF A YOUNG WOMAN.  The inquest on the body of ELLEN BRACKEN, previously mentioned as having been found lying dead under a tree, between Jersey City and Hoboken, on Tuesday morning last, was held at the Jersey City Stationhouse, before Coroner GAFNEY, last night. It appears from the evidence of witnesses that deceased was a...
lead_paragraph: THE SUPPOSED SUICIDE OF A YOUNG WOMAN. -- The inquest on the body of ELLEN BRACKEN, previously mentioned as having been found lying dead under a tree, between Jersey City and Hoboken, on Tuesday morning last, was held at the Jersey City Station-house, before Coroner GAFNEY, last night. It appears from the evidence of witnesses that deceased was a young married woman, of intemperate and dissolute habits, and for several months past resided with OWEN FAGAN, at No. 35 Prospect-street, in the capacity of housekeeper. On Monday evening last, about 81/2 o'clock, she went into Mrs.MCNULTY's store, in the same building where she resided, to borrow a phial. She said to Mrs. MCNULTY, "before this time to-morrow night there will be a bully old time." Deceased handed Mrs. MCNULTY fifty cents on account, and remarked: "There is all I have got for you to-night, and God pay you the rest." A short time after 9 o'clock the same night, two boys saw deceased going down Jersey-avenue, towards Hoboken, in company with a man whom they did not know. This was the last trace of her alive. A sister testified that deceased had attempted to destroy her life eight or ten times within the past seven years, by taking laudanum; and it was also shown that on various occasions she had threatened to destroy her life. Dr. W.J. HADDAN, City Physician, made a post-mortem examination. He found several bruises about the arms and legs. An examination of the internal organs showed that there was not sufficient disease existing to have caused death. The stomach and part of the intestines were removed, and a portion of their contents were analyzed by himself and ROBERT BIRCH. They found arsenic, and the Doctor was satisfied that death was caused by poison. The case was submitted to the Jury shortly before 11 o'clock, and the following verdict was rendered: "That ELLEN BRACKEN came to her death by taking arsenic, but whether administered by herself or by some other person the Jury are unable to say."

abstract: Mr. ELLISON, whose first book relative to cotton culture attracted much attention two years ago, has written a second on the causes of the American War. This the London Times has reviewed at length, and with much less truculence than distinguishes its usual utterances in regard to American affairs.
lead_paragraph: Mr. ELLISON, whose first book relative to cotton culture attracted much attention two years ago, has written a second on the causes of the American War. This the London Times has reviewed at length, and with much less truculence than distinguishes its usual utterances in regard to American affairs. It confesses substantially that Mr. ELLISON's work is a just estimate of the question; concedes its historical chain of facts and causes to be correctly intercalated and trustworthy; but warns its readers that the author is an "Abolitionist," a class whose incontrovertible facts are, it seems, to be received with prudent reserve. For the rest, the Times lets no syllable of criticism express its partiality for either party, whose merits Mr. ELLISON fairly estimates; but leads the reader to the conviction, that its sympathies, if with either side, incline to the South.

abstract: much complaint of bad food among volunteers. A simple knowledge of their rights would remedy it all. The soldier of Uncle Sam. can, perhaps for the first time in his life, afford to eat the best food. If provisions are really bad, the company officers may and should call for a Board of Survey, which their own Colonel will order. The Board forth with condemns the bad supplies, and more must be issued. There is no mistake, about the remedy, if the defect really exists.

abstract: One of the largest gatherings of holiday folk and others, moved by a kindly impulse, it has ever been our good fortune to witness, assembled yesterday at Jones' Wood, to do honor to the brave sons of Erin who fought in the ranks of the gallant Sixtyninth. The Wood, which has long been consecrated to monster gatherings, was crowded to an excess which can scarcely be described without apparent exaggeration.
lead_paragraph: One of the largest gatherings of holiday folk and others, moved by a kindly impulse, it has ever been our good fortune to witness, assembled yesterday at Jones' Wood, to do honor to the brave sons of Erin who fought in the ranks of the gallant Sixtyninth. The Wood, which has long been consecrated to monster gatherings, was crowded to an excess which can scarcely be described without apparent exaggeration. Every avenue leading to them was lined with human beings, and every inch of ground that could bear wheels was beaten by the hoofs of horses. A sight more cheering or hearty has seldom been seen in this City. From the point where the Third-avenue cars deposit their living freight to the portal where a plethoric Celt -- borne down with pockets of silver and other current coin -- demanded a quarter for admission, there was not only a stream of human beings, but a degree of animation which can only be compared with a European fair. He who made the run of that gauntlet passed through the fire of a class of traders who had a joke for every stranger. Everything edible or palatable was proffered with a delicate Hibernian reference to the gallant Sixty-ninth, and a hint that the exigencies of Bull Run demanded its immediate purchase. All the lager-bier was from the brewery of Bull Run; all the water-melons were from the nursery of Bull Run; all the ice-creams, weighing-machines, side shows, and cider barrels were from the same locality. The second word that you heard on each side was Bull Run.

abstract: THE CASE OF MR. MACHADO. Mr. J.A. MACHADO, the alleged slave-trader, who was arrested on Tuesday on a charge of fitting out the Mary Frances and various other slavers from this port, was again brought before Commissioner HENRY yesterday for examination. As on the day previous, the Government failed to produce their witnesses, they, as was alleged, having been telegraphed for to Boston, but failed to arrive.
lead_paragraph: THE CASE OF MR. MACHADO. -- Mr. J.A. MACHADO, the alleged slave-trader, who was arrested on Tuesday on a charge of fitting out the Mary Frances and various other slavers from this port, was again brought before Commissioner HENRY yesterday for examination. As on the day previous, the Government failed to produce their witnesses, they, as was alleged, having been telegraphed for to Boston, but failed to arrive. In accordance with the stipulation of counsel, the day previous, the Commissioner stated that he should admit Mr. MACHADO to bail, with the privilege of an examination when the witnesses for the Government arrived, and that if they did not arrive by this morning he would entertain a motion for his discharge,provided his counsel saw fit to make it. Judge BEEBE, counsel for the prisoner, after consulting with his client, stated that Mr. MACHADO preferred not to give bail, but wished for an examination, and if he did not get it to-day he should demand his discharge. At this point Mr. DONOHUE, associate counsel for the prisoner, asked for the affidavit on which the warrant for the arrest of the prisoner was based, and on examining it, discovered, to his surprise, that It was entirely insufficient to justify the retention of the prisoner. The affidavit was made by a man in Boston, who is himself under indictment fur being engaged in the Slave-trade, and was sworn to before one THOMPSON D. LOTHROP, of Suffolk County, Mass. Upon this state of facts counsel demanded the immediate discharge of Mr. MACHADO on the ground that there was no proof before the Commissioner that Mr. LOTHROP was in reality a Justice of the Peace for Massachusetts, or, indeed, that there was any such man in existence. The Commissioner, after consulting the authorities, decided that the point was well taken, and immediately ordered the discharge of the prisoner.

abstract: A messenger from the Virginia side this morning states that our picket forces advanced to Bailey's Cross-roads yesterday, and drove those of the Secessionists a mile and a half beyond, where, it is said' the latter have taken possession of a commanding eminence, and are throwing up intrenchments. There  was much firing during the day, but without fatal results. The inhabitants generally of that section have removed elsewhere some of them to this city.

abstract: while for the Government to give a little attention to the two privateers, Jeff. Davis and Sumter? We are tired of chronicling their movements and exploits. They have been cruising now for two or three months, -- capturing every few days some prize or other, -- announcingtheir arrival and departure at the various ports they see fit to visit, and giving our commerce more trouble, and our country more concern, than a respectable-sized navy ought to do in time of war. Is there no way of checking their depredations? Is our whole Navy absolutely unable to cope with these Wretched little pirates? Have we no steamers that can sail as fast, -- no commanders as good at seamanship, -- no naval officers energetic enough to hunt up and hunt down these bestilent prowlers of the sea? If not, we had better disband the Navy, and hire out the job of capturing this brace of privateers. Perhaps it would be expecting too much of Mr. WELLES to ask him to give the matter his attention: but Mr. CAMERON, we presume, could easily contract with some Pennsylvania politician to undertake it for a consideration.

abstract: Vincent vs. Buhler. -- By the Court: BRADY, J. -- The lease executed by Mrs. Buhler contained covenants, on her part, to pay the rent, and her estate was dependent upon those covenants. They could not be enforced against her, and the contract was void for want of mutuality of obligation. A married woman cannot make a contract, except in reference to her separate estate, and the intention to charge the separate estate must be expressed in the contract, if in writing. (Yale vs. Dederer, 22 N.Y. Rep., 450.)
lead_paragraph: Vincent vs. Buhler. -- By the Court: BRADY, J. -- The lease executed by Mrs. Buhler contained covenants, on her part, to pay the rent, and her estate was dependent upon those covenants. A married woman cannot make a contract, except in reference to her separate estate, and the intention to charge the separate estate must be expressed in the contract, if in writing. (Yale vs. Dederer, 22 N.Y. Rep., 450.)

abstract: The Nineteenth Regiment of Massachusetts Volunteers, enlisted for the war, arrived in this City by the steamer Bay State, of the Fall River line, at 2 P.M., yesterday. The regiment is under the command of Col. EDWARD W. HINCKS, the acting Colonel of the Eighth Regiment Massachusetts Militia, whose services at the beginning of the war, conjointly with the Seventh New-York Regiment, in opening the route from Annapolis to the Junction, are well remembered.
lead_paragraph: The Nineteenth Regiment of Massachusetts Volunteers, enlisted for the war, arrived in this City by the steamer Bay State, of the Fall River line, at 2 P.M., yesterday. The regiment is under the command of Col. EDWARD W. HINCKS, the acting Colonel of the Eighth Regiment Massachusetts Militia, whose services at the beginning of the war, conjointly with the Seventh New-York Regiment, in opening the route from Annapolis to the Junction, are well remembered. Col. HINCKS returned home with the Eighth, at the expiration of their term of service, about four weeks ago, and was immediately requested by Gov. ANDREWS to raise a regiment of volunteers for the war. The regiment now under his command -- composed of between 800 and 900 as fine troops as are to be found in our volunteer army -- attests the popularity of the Colonel, and the prompt patriotism of the old Bay State. The regiment left their camp-ground, in Lynfield, Essex County, on Wednesday morning, and proceeded to Boston, whence they took the cars for Fall River, and thence by boat to this City. Their progress from Boston to Fall River was a continued ovation of bonfires, cheers, and other manifestations of popular enthusiasm. The regiment is armed with Enfield rifles, and takes along 70 horses, 15 baggage-wagons, 2 hospital-wagons, and a complete [???] of tents and camp equipage. It has a full drum corps, and is also accompanied by a fine brass band, belonging to the Seventeenth Massachusetts Regiment, now in Washington. The band of the Nineteenth is now being organized in Lynn, and will join the regiment in a few days. One company of the regiment -- Company K -- is composed entirely of Boston firemen. The following is a full list of the officers of the regiment:

abstract: By an order of the Secretary of the Treasury, all future clearances for the port of Matamoras, Mexico, are forbidden. Thus far a thriving trade has been carried on with the Brazos, giving to the Texans all the provisions, clothing, and probably powder and munitions which they required. Vessels clearing for Bermuda and Nassau should also be carefully looked after.

abstract: have taken special pains to quash this subject -- none the less thoroughly, however, becauseit authorized a Commission to examine it. This Commission was not appointed, at the latest advices, and no money was appropriated for the battery, should the report prove favorable. Another Commission to report upon modern iron-clad ships was appointed, however, and money was voted to build the vessels. But the Stevens ship was especially excluded from the benefits of this live Commission and this appropriation. In short, the best ship-of-war known, as any competent person can know by familiarizing himself with the subject -- a ship of which the Government has already paid half the cost, while $200,000 of it has been paid by Mr. STEVENS out of his own pocket -- a ship whose total cost will not exceed that of our larger passenger steamers, exclusive of the armor, and for the completion of which only half a million is asked -- this vessel is not only abandoned by the present Government, but, it would seem, so politely abandoned, as to retire the subject from all further notice. If the Government really intends to have an inferior article at a greater cost, the public would be pleased to know some of the reasons. Is it because the Engineering Department of the Navy can't stand high steam? Is it because the space occupied by boilers and engines is too small? Is it because the boilers are below the waterline, and so protected from shot? These are some of the important features in which it differs from the Government's gun-boats, and if they are defects the public would be glad to know it. If the Naval Engineers approved of the Stevens Battery it would probably be finished.

abstract: When Mr. WILLIAM PATRICK was in the Superintendent's office on Wednesday, shortly after his arrest on a charge of treason, preferred by the Secretary of War, and prior to his removal to the Fort, he was informed of a fact which startled him beyond measure. Mr. KENNEDY was asking him questions with a view of finding out the hiding-place of a suspected person, known to be an acquaintance of the prisoner.
lead_paragraph: When Mr. WILLIAM PATRICK was in the Superintendent's office on Wednesday, shortly after his arrest on a charge of treason, preferred by the Secretary of War, and prior to his removal to the Fort, he was informed of a fact which startled him beyond measure. Mr. KENNEDY was asking him questions with a view of finding out the hiding-place of a suspected person, known to be an acquaintance of the prisoner. Finally, the latter became flurried and unwilling to say anything more on the subject, and at the same time, putting himself upon his dignity, he remarked: "I was born in Nova Scotia, and am a British subject, consequently I demand my discharge. You have no authority over me whatever."

abstract: an Eastern journal another speech by WENDELL PHILLIPS, professedly in commemoration of the birth of THEODORE PARKER, but devoted mainly to the pending war. It is in general tone and tenor like all his speeches on this subject, -- bitter in its complaints of lack of earnestness and energy on the part of the Government, and anxious for the day when the Government shall pronounce in favor of the emancipation of the slaves. This, he thinks, would give vigor and energy to the war, and lead tens and hundreds of thousands to take part in it who now feel no interest in its progress or results.

abstract: The police are on the alert for traitors. No man's liberty may be considered safe an instant whose predilections incline towards "secesh," and those especially who would be guilty of affording "aid and comfort" to the enemies of the country, by shipping articles to the South which are "contraband of war," need not hope for mercy if Superintendent KENNEDY gets an inkling of their misdeeds. Yesterday Mr. KENNEDY learned that a gentleman named JOHN SLEIGHT, who has been spending some time in this City, was manoeuvring suspiciously in connection with the purchase of a quantity of just such merchandise as would be highly acceptable to the South at the present juncture. Detective WILSON was sent to conduct him to head-quarters, where he had to undergo a series of sharp questionings. Developments were made proving him to be a member of the firm of WILLIAM HENDLEY & Co., merchants, at Galveston, Texas; and a document was found upon him, addressed to his partners, advising them of the importance of having certain goods reach Galveston by Sept. 1. In explanation, Mr. SLEIGHT stated that the memorandum was made at a time when he supposed that the blockade would be raised before the date indicated, and he assured Mr. KENNEDY that he had made no purchases here for the past 15 years. There being no evidence upon which he could be detained at present, he went away, promising, at the Superintendent's request, to visit him "semi-occasionally" during his sojourn in the City.

abstract: On Tuesday night last, about twenty of the prisoners confined in the Kings County Jail, were seized with vomiting and purging, accompanied by other symptoms, indicating that they had partaken of some deadly poison. Dr. CHARLES A. VAN ZANDT, the Jail Physician, was at once sent for by the keepers and by judicious management succeeded in saving the lives of all attacked,...
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night last, about twenty of the prisoners confined in the Kings County Jail, were seized with vomiting and purging, accompanied by other symptoms, indicating that they had partaken of some deadly poison. Dr. CHARLES A. VAN ZANDT, the Jail Physician, was at once sent for by the keepers and by judicious management succeeded in saving the lives of all attacked, numbering, up to yesterday, about 50 of the inmates of the jail. When Dr. VAN ZANDT examined the first case, he was considerable puzzled to know in what manner the prisoners had been poisoned, but after a while he arrived at the conclusion that it must have been from the Ridgewood water, with which the jail is supplied throughout, in the common lead pipe. For tunately he hit upon the right cause and was able to neutralize the reflects of the poison. He at once ordered the Ridgewood water to be cut off, and directed that well water -- of which there is an abundance on the premises -- should be used.

abstract: A young man named HARRAL, belonging to Galena, Ga., is detained at Police Head-quarters, and will probably be sent to Fort Lafayette to-day. He was arrested on Wednesday evening, at the Erie Railroad depot, Jersey City, when on the point of departing with his two sisters for the South. The young ladies had for some time attended a boarding-school at Glen Cove, and their brother, in view of the National troubles, had come here to escort them home. On his way to the City from Glen Cove he engaged in conversation with some of the passengers, and making use of treasonable expressions, information was given to the Police, who arrested him. Five large trunks, containing the ladies wardrobe, were brought to Head-quarters and overhauled, but nothing was found supporting the allegation made against the young man, who was yesterday discharged from custody. It was afterwards ascertained that the complaint against him was based upon good evidence, and, indeed, it is said that conclusive proof of his secession sentiments has been obtained. Under these circumstances, he was rearrested last evening.

abstract: When Mayor BERRETT, of Washington, was admitted to Fort Lafayette, his hair and whiskers were of raven hue. Since then they have faded gradually, and now are almost white. At first it was believed that grief had produced the change; but Mr. BERRETT makes the assertion that his altered appearance is occasioned by lack of hair-dye.

abstract: The London Times' City Article again warns English capitalists against the probable consequences of lending their money to the Government of Washington. The writer says:
lead_paragraph: "The Morrill Tariff, which commercially assimilates the United States with the most retrograde countries in the world, is not only to be maintained but to be increased in force by the imposition of additional duties. At the same time the Secretary of the Treasury is to be empowered to put forth an apparently unlimited creation of Treasury notes for amounts equivalent to L1 and L2 each "for national circulation." We are consequently to witness in combined action the two influences of a protective and prohibitory Custom-house system, and a paper currency of the most enticing and dangerous description. Coupled with this there is to be an income tax of 3 per cent. on all incomes of L160 per annum, which will leave entirely untouched the great mass of the people who regulate the politics of the nation, and which will depend for its amount upon the voluntary honesty of the returns sent in by the remainder. The measure was to apply in fair proportion to landed property, but the Western farmers would not submit to this, and the House of Representatives, it said, "wisely gave way to their objections." A tax of 2s. on silver watches and of 4s. on gold watches, as well as of 4s. to L1.0 on carriages, according to their quality, an excise on spirits and beer, an increased duty on sugar, and entirely new duties on tea and coffee, are among the other means by which it is hoped to add a few millions sterling to the revenue. The cost of collection in a wide country like America must, of course, be enormous, and 15 per cent. is to be offered to each State that will perform that task for itself, and thus save the necessity of providing a separate and costly machinery on the part of the General Government. The nine seceding States are reckoned among the contributories each in their proportion, and after they shall have been coerced back into the Union, and have ruined themselves as far as possible by their efforts in war, they will, therefore, have to meet heavy arreors while they are voluntarily voting the supplies to provide the dividends on such National loans as may have been raised for bringing them to obedience. The journals hold out that, "of course, they do not anticipate any such state of things as the income tax becoming permanent, as has been the case in Great Britain;" but the substitute that is to be found for it, when the results of borrowing enormous sums at 10 and 12 per cent. interest shall come to be truly felt, is not even hinted at. The National expenditure is now estimated, on good authority, to be going on at the rate of L75,000,000 per annum, exclusive of the distinct and sovereign expenditure of the thirty-four States. The ordinary National revenue, from all sources, is about L16,000,000. Supposing the new duties to yield the L4,000,000 or L6,000,000 anticipated, there remains about L50,000,000 or L60,000,000 to be obtained by loans in the shape of issues, either of stock, Treasury bonds, or notes for national circulation. At present, with an amount of bullion in the New-York banks far exceeding any sum ever before known, and while the money pressure from the new order of things has scarcely yet been practically felt, the lowest rate at which the Government can borrow, even for short periods, is ten per cent. What will be the charge when specie rapidly flows out in consequence of the gigantic expenditure, when a severe money market operates together with political distrust, and when it is found that three months' loans are as bad and deceptive as three months' enlistments? Already we have assertions that the votes in Congress have destroyed the credit of the Government, and that it could not now get L4,000,000 on any terms, in the New-York market, while the most hopeful and strongest friends of the Administration go no further than to allege that the Government credit will still prove good, "if" its financial scheme is broad enough to meet the necessities of the case; if, after the fashion of Mexico and Turkey, specific branches of revenue are pledged as security; and if L10,000,000 or L20,000,000 of paper circulation is put out. Under the circumstances, the most earnest wish of the friends of America must be that the difficulties thus in sight may accumulate with sufficient rapidity to bring both North and South to reason. If they were to be staved off by funds from Europe, the lenders would richly deserve that share of the bitter results which would be certain speedily to fall upon them."

abstract: The Bank of England on the 15th reduced their rate of discount from 5 to 4 cent. The event was not altogether anticipated. It caused a slight improvement in the funds, but this improvement was subsequently lost. After the reduction in the rate there was a full average demand for money at the Bank. The Banks and Discount houses had reduced their allowance in deposits in conformity with the movement at the Bank of England.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of England on the 15th reduced their rate of discount from 5 to 4 1/2 cent. The event was not altogether anticipated. It caused a slight improvement in the funds, but this improvement was subsequently lost. After the reduction in the rate there was a full average demand for money at the Bank. The Banks and Discount houses had reduced their allowance in deposits in conformity with the movement at the Bank of England.

lead_paragraph: The Oath of Allegiance prescribed by Congress at its late session, and administered the other day to those in the civil service at Washington, although designed purely as a prudential measure, is in reality a very interesting and significant historical fact. "I do solemnly swear," thus run the terms, "that I will support, protect and defend the Constitution of the United States against all enemies, whether domestic or foreign, and that I will bear true faith, allegiance and loyalty to the same, any ordinance, law or resolution of any State Convention or Legislature to the contrary notwithstanding; and further, that I do this with a full determination, pledge and purpose, and without any mental reservation or evasion whatsoever," &c.

abstract: states that the horses and other live stock of the Union Army in Western Virginia are fed on hay purchased in Cincinnati at $18 a ton, and shipped and wagoned at heavy charges, to the points where it is used. And this, notwithstanding the Army is in the midst of the finest pastures, and surrounded by the greatest abundance of well-cured hay in Virginia. But the explanation given is that the farmers of Virginia have combined and put up prices to an extortionate figure, and refuse to sell a blade of grass except at their figures.

abstract: We sometimes hear our present contest with the Southern rebels compared with the Revolutionary contest with Great Britain, or with similar struggles in past ages. These comparisons are drawn by two classes of persons, those who are desirous that some particular course of prosecuting the war or some ...
lead_paragraph: We sometimes hear our present contest with the Southern rebels compared with the Revolutionary contest with Great Britain, or with similar struggles in past ages. These comparisons are drawn by two classes of persons, those who are desirous that some particular course of prosecuting the war or some particular measure in that course shall be adopted, and those who desire that the war shall not be prosecuted at all. The first class say "Did not our forefathers successfully resist the mighty power of Great Britain? Did not the Netherlands succeed in establishing their independence of PHILIP II. of Spain? unless this or that thing is done as I advise, the result of the present contest will be the same." And the latter class, catching us by the button, when they think they are unobserved and can do it with impunity, whisper to us "You can never conquer the South. Look at the Revolution. Look at the rise of the Dutch Republic. The South is far more powerful than our forefathers or the Netherlanders were, but Spain had to give up her efforts, and Great Britain had to acknowledge the independence of the colonies, and we shall have to do the same. Better do it at once and save all the valuable lives and the immense expenses of a protracted war."

abstract: Our Washington news is unusually interesting this morning. The vigorous awakening of the Government seems to be continued. No passes are granted to visit the rebel States. The enforcement of the fifty-seventh article of war is to be carried to the sweeping extent of preventing ...
lead_paragraph: Our Washington news is unusually interesting this morning. The vigorous awakening of the Government seems to be continued. No passes are granted to visit the rebel States. The enforcement of the fifty-seventh article of war is to be carried to the sweeping extent of preventing the publication of any information anywhere concerning the movements, process of increase, condition or location of the Army. No less than tree members of the Cabinet will be absent to-day, Messrs. SEWARD, CAMERON and BATES. The rebels made a demonstration yesterday morning at Falls Cross Roads with three pieces of artillery. They were driven back, and are known to be intrenching themselves, about 500 strong, at Munson's Hill. It is estimated that there are at least from four to six rebel regiments between Falls Church and Fairfax. The sentence of the Court-martial in the case of Col. MCCUNN has been promulgated, and is fully indorsed by Gen. MCCLELLAN, who seems to think it is quite too lenient. The General, in his document of approval, takes occasion to give the volunteer officers some wholesome lessons. Col. MCCUNN is to be reprimanded in general orders.

abstract: CITY.--The authorities of Hudson City, N.J., have just completed too fine public school-buildings, and yesterday afternoon they were thrown open for the inspection of the public. No. 1 is a three-story and basement brick building, 40 feet front and 60 feet ...
lead_paragraph: CITY. -- The authorities of Hudson City, N.J., have just completed too fine public school-buildings, and yesterday afternoon they were thrown open for the inspection of the public. No. 1 is a three-story and basement brick building, 40 feet front and 60 feet deep, situated at the corner of St. Paul and Montgomery streets. It has a projection in front, 8 feet deep and 18 feet wide, for staircases. The primary department is on the first floor, and has seats for 212 children, over whom Mrs. KOHLBECK acts as Principal. The second floor is for the female department, with seats for 124 children -- Miss E.P. BROWN, Principal. The male department is on the third floor, and has seats for 124 children -- Principal, WM. H. STORRS, The building and internal arrangements are on the modern plan. Staircases are erected in the rear to insure safety against fire or accident. The cost of building, furniture and ground was about $14,000. Schoolhouse No. 2 is located at the corner of Montgomoryavenue and Warren-street. It is a two-story and basement brick building, erected something in the style of the Grecian cross architecture. The first floor is to be used for the present for the primary department, under Miss MEKKEH as Principal. The second floor is for the higher classes in the male and female department, under D.P. LEE as Principal. The entire cost is about $10,000. including the grounds. There are about 500 children enrolled at No. 1, and 300 at No. 2. Mr. CHARLES E. NEWHAM, President of the Board of Education, was present yesterday afternoon at School No. 1, and conducted the visitors through the building.

abstract: The returned volunteers have all been paid off, and experience will obviate any delay, hereafter, in paying our troops promptly. Volunteers receive $13 per month, and are allowed $3 50 per month for clothing. When discharged, each volunteer will be paid $100 in cash, an important item should the war be of short duration, as there is reason to suppose it will be. It is not improbable that the Government will grant to each soldier, in addition, a quarter section of land. Such pay and prospects should induce the necessary numbers to rally around the standard of their country at once.

lead_paragraph: The United States storeship Release, Commander J. MADISON FRAILE, from Fort Pickens Aug. 2, and Key West Aug. 14, has just arrived at this port. She experienced a very heavy gale from north and east on the evening of the day she sailed from Key West, which blew violcutly for forty hours, compelling her to bear up and run to the westward of Tortugas. Since reaching Hatteras, the wind has been constantly from the north and east, and at times quite fresh, until yesterday, when she was favored with a moderate breeze from the south and west and south and east. She left off Port Pickens the United States steamers Colorado and Niagara, and the American bark W.H. Wall and schooner Joseph M. Lane. She left at Key West the United States ships Macedonian and Preble and steamer Crusader. The American bark Ann Elizabeth, from Philadelphia with coal for squadron; sailed from Key West for Fort Pickens on the 12th, and got on the reef going out with a pilot on board, but succeeded in getting off during the night and proceeded to her destination. On Saturday, Aug. 17, lat. 26 06' long. 79 13' spoke American ship Charles Sprague, of Kennebunk, from Matanzas for Glasgow.

abstract: BOARD OF SUPERVISORS.--At the regular meating of this Board yesterday afternoon, the hill of the Sheriff for $8,881 49, for the quarter, was opposed by Mr. WEISSMAN, who took up many of the longer items and claimed that they were exorbitant, at the  same time, however, stating that his opposition was ...
lead_paragraph: BOARD OF SUPERVISORS. -- At the regular meeting of this Board yesterday afternoon, the hill of the Sheriff for $8,881 49, for the quarter, was opposed by Mr. WEISSMAN, who took up many of the longer items and claimed that they were exorbitant, at the same time, however, stating that his opposition was not grounded on personal grounds towards the Sheriff, but as a matter of principle and economy; in view of the enormous expenses which must necessarily be entailed on the City by reason of the war. Mr. WEISSMAN opposed especially the item of fees for reporting to the Secretary of State the names of the parties convicted in the various Courts of the City. The bill was much discussed by Messrs. PORDY, BLUNT and others, but was finally ordered paid. The report on the tax levy was called up; but on motion of Mr. PURDY, it was laid over till Monday at2 P.M., for the purpose of enabling the Committee to examine more fully into some of the items containedin it; for although the law forbade the Board from in-creasing the sum total it was discretionary with them to make reductions. Mr. PURDY offered a resolution authorizing the Special Committee on Building a new Court-house, to employ an architect to prepare plans and Specifications therefor, and to proceed with the erection of said Court-house with all possible dispatch; to purchase all materials necessary therefor, and to have such parts of the same as they deemed best erected by days' work only, or by contract at their option; all contracts made by the Committee to be binding on the County, after being approved by the Board; and that the Comptroller be directed to pay all bills presented to him out of the $280,000 appropriated for that purpose, on being properly vouched and audited by the Committee, which was adopted unanimously. Adjourned until Monday P.M.

abstract: Every night the rebel forces advance close in upon our lines in front of Arlington and Alexandria; but before day-break they invariably retire, leaving no evidence behind of an intention to hold the ground they had occupied. Such is the tenor of the dispatches we have received daily, for several days, from ...
lead_paragraph: Every night the rebel forces advance close in upon our lines in front of Arlington and Alexandria; but before day-break they invariably retire, leaving no evidence behind of an intention to hold the ground they had occupied. Such is the tenor of the dispatches we have received daily, for several days, from Washington. The correspondents from the vicinity of these rebel movements, seem to be puzzled to account for them. One of them, writing to the Washington Star, says: "What was meant [by these nocturnal advances] further than to murder a few Union pickets, I know not; nothing like an attack, as is evident by their retirement before day-break everywhere." The Star comments on these demonstrations of the rebels, and expresses the opinion that "a considerable affair of outposts" may come off within a very short time; and it "prepares the citizens to know," if they hear the booming of cannon over the river, "just what it amounts to." To settle the matter beyond any possibility of doubt, the same paper observes that "it is utterly impossible that BEAUREGARD contemplates a serious movement against the fortifications on the other side of the river."

abstract: The two considerations upon which John Bull grounds his dislike of the American war, are, that it will cost a painful sacrifice of life, and that it involves no particular benefit to the negro. British philanthropy, therefore, ...
lead_paragraph: The two considerations upon which John Bull grounds his dislike of the American war, are, that it will cost a painful sacrifice of life, and that it involves no particular benefit to the negro. British philanthropy, therefore, withholds all sympathy from a cause so destitute of humanitarian recommendations. It would be simply frivolous to question the sincerity of these sentiments. We are forced to the conviction that if the war could be prosecuted upon strictly millenarian principles, with provisions securing the immunity of persons and property, and pointing to the instantaneous liberation of 4,000,000 blacks, England would have all these tender and most creditable scruples satisfied, and would bid us God-speed with a full heart. This is clearly the Christian programme our transatlantic cousins would charitably prescribe in cases such as ours.

abstract: As rents, provisions, and everything else that enters into the expense of living, are certain to be low in price for the coming season, it is natural that hotel charges should follow the downward tendency. DELMONICO led the way two or three weeks ago, by reducing his rates from ten to twenty-five per cent., and the proprietors of the St. Nicholas have followed suit, and announce a uniform reduction in their price of board from two dollars and a half to two dollars a day. Probably the other hotels will do the same. The prices of everthing, -- labor as well as living, -- in all departments must come down. The supply of everything is abundant, while the ability to pay has been seriously diminished. This can have but one result, and we think, therefore, that the coming Winter will be the cheapest, so far as living is concerned, which we have seen for many years.

abstract: There are a few irate traitors yet to be found lurking in different parts of Long Island, but the loyal citizens have pretty generally determined that their treasonable acts shall not be manifested in a concentrated form. So long as their acts were confined to a ...
lead_paragraph: There are a few irate traitors yet to be found lurking in different parts of Long Island, but the loyal citizens have pretty generally determined that their treasonable acts shall not be manifested in a concentrated form. So long as their acts were confined to a simple expression of treasonable sentiments individually in private, they were permitted to go undisturbed.But when, under the influence of the noted SCHNABEL, who now, happily, is safely quartered at the Government waterlng-place near Fort Hamilton, of which Col. BURKE is the popular host, an attempt is made to con-' centrate this treasonable sentiment, and to give it; some infiuence by holding a public meeting, the loyalcitizens determined to remain passive no longer, but to act promptly as occasion might require. At the instigation of a Southern agent, a "Peace" meeting was announced to be held at Newtown last Thursday night. The announcement created the most intense excitement, and much indignation was expressed that any resident of the Island could be found, so lost to self respect, as to permit his name to be used in connection with so treasonable a purpose. The leaders were promptly given to understand that the people would not permit any such meeting to be beld, and as a consequence the affair was indefinitely postponed, and a Union meeting was held in its stead at the time and placenamed in the call for the "Peace" meeting. Several thousand persons were present, and the greatest enthusiasm prevailed. Hon. JOHN D. TOWNSEND presided, and JOSIAH WHITHEY, Esq., acted as Secretary. Speeches were made by DANIEL L. NORTHRUP, Mr. MCCORMICK and RICHARD BUSTEED, Esqrs., and the following preamble and resolutions were unanimously adopted:

abstract: We have at last the card of Hon. Mr. NELSON, of Tennessee, explaining the manner of his release by the Jeff. Davis Government at Richmond. We regret to say that it is not creditable to him either as a man of personal firmness or of political fidelity. Mr. NELSON was elected to the Congress of the United ...
lead_paragraph: We have at last the card of Hon. Mr. NELSON, of Tennessee, explaining the manner of his release by the Jeff. Davis Government at Richmond. We regret to say that it is not creditable to him either as a man of personal firmness or of political fidelity. Mr. NELSON was elected to the Congress of the United States by avery large majority, as a Union man, and on the express ground of his Union sentiments. He accepted the position, and started for Washington to take his seat in the National Congress, thereby acknowledging. by an unmistakable act, his purpose to maintain his loyalty to the National Constitution, and in that respect to represent faithfully the sentiments of his constituents. His arrest, however, seems to have wrought a marvelous change in his opinions. His first act on reaching Richmond was to write to JEFF. DAVIS -- asking to be released, and promising, as a condition of such release, to do no act, "directly, or indirectly, by counsel, advice or action, which should encourage, aid or assist the United States Government" in its struggle with the rebellion -- nor would he "counsel or advise others to thwart or cripple the Confederate States in the pending contest with the United States -- or do so by his own acts." Upon this pledge, broad enough certainly to answer all possible requirements of the Confederate Government, Mr. NELSON was discharged and has returned to Tennessee.

abstract: This distinguished and eloquent defender of the Union is in our City, stopping at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, where he has been called on by many admiring patriots. We do not know whether Mr. HOLT has been invited to deliver an address in New-York on the extraordinary state of the nation, but we know it would gratify tens of thousands for him to do so. The country grows stronger through the inspirations of his patriotic eloquence, and he would have here an audience such as few men could call out, and that it would be well worth his while to speak to.

abstract: WILLIAM LYON MACKENZIE, whose death at Toronto, on Aug. 28, has been announced by telegraph, occupied a prominent position in Canadian politics. In the revolution of 1837, he led the body ofSieurgents which went to Toronto, and insisted on air FRANCIS HEAD calling a convention to arrange terms of settlement of the difficulty in which the out-break originated. This was of course refused, and the insurgenls prepared to proceed to extremities. Although reinforced at Navy Island, whither they were obliged to retreat, by live hundred men, under Mr. VAN RENSSELAER, an American, the Canadians did not respond to the call of their leader with any alacrity, and Mr. MACKENZIE's demonstration failed most miserably, he managing eventually to escape into the United States. For a time this emeute threatened to involve the United States in difficulties with England, but that result was happily averted. MACKENZIE remained in the United States until the British Government proclaimed an amnesty to political offenders in 1849, when he relurnvd to Canada, where he was warmly received. Soon after he was elected a member of the Provincial Parliament. Mr. MACKENZIE gained some celebrity as a writer for the Press during his residence in the States He died poor, but was saved from actual want by a subscription which his admirers made up for his benefit.
lead_paragraph: WILLIAM LYON MACKENZIE, whose death at Toronto, on Aug. 28, has been announced by telegraph, occupied a prominent position in Canadian politics. In the revolution of 1837, he led the body ofSieurgents which went to Toronto, and insisted on air FRANCIS HEAD calling a convention to arrange terms of settlement of the difficulty in which the out-break originated. This was of course refused, and the insurgenls prepared to proceed to extremities. Although reinforced at Navy Island, whither they were obliged to retreat, by live hundred men, under Mr. VAN RENSSELAER, an American, the Canadians did not respond to the call of their leader with any alacrity, and Mr. MACKENZIE's demonstration failed most miserably, he managing eventually to escape into the United States. For a time this emeute threatened to involve the United States in difficulties with England, but that result was happily averted. MACKENZIE remained in the United States until the British Government proclaimed an amnesty to political offenders in 1849, when he relurnvd to Canada, where he was warmly received. Soon after he was elected a member of the Provincial Parliament. Mr. MACKENZIE gained some celebrity as a writer for the Press during his residence in the States He died poor, but was saved from actual want by a subscription which his admirers made up for his benefit.
